site_title: Malaysia's Farm Fresh aims to raise RM1b in IPO
summary: Malaysia's dairy producer Farm Fresh aims to raise RM1 billion (S$323.3 million) through its initial public offering (IPO), the largest listing in the country since June 2021. The company plans to use the funds to establish a new manufacturing hub, expand its operations in Australia, and increase its presence in Singapore. Farm Fresh expects to have a market capitalization of RM2.5 billion after listing on Bursa Malaysia's main market on March 22.

site_title: Disney pausing film releases in Russia over Ukraine invasion
summary: Disney has paused the release of theatrical films in Russia due to the "unprovoked invasion of Ukraine and the tragic humanitarian crisis". This decision comes after the Ukrainian Film Academy called for an international boycott of Russian cinema. The move affects films like "Turning Red" and "The Batman", which were set for release in Russia. Disney is instead focusing on providing humanitarian aid and assistance. The decision is seen as a response to the economic sanctions imposed by the US and its European allies on Russia.

site_title: ComfortDelGro Australia to operate hydrogen-powered electric buses
summary: ComfortDelGro Australia, a subsidiary of ComfortDelGro Corporation Australia, has partnered with Viva Energy to operate 2 hydrogen-powered fuel cell electric buses in Geelong, Australia. The project, part of the Geelong New Energies Service Station, aims to be Australia's most ambitious green hydrogen mobility project. The partnership has received A$24 million in grants and will establish a hydrogen refuelling station in late 2023, with other partners deploying hydrogen-fuelled heavy vehicles. The buses will be manufactured by Aluminium Revolutionary Chassis Company and are scheduled to service customers from late 2023.

site_title: Electric vehicles to have higher charging limit, more options: LTA-SSC working group
summary: Singapore's Land Transport Authority (LTA) has completed a review of its national electric vehicle standard, Technical Reference 25 (TR 25), and recommended changes to support the safe installation, maintenance, and operation of charging. The new standard introduces two new modes of low-powered charging (2A and 2B), raises the high-powered charging limit to 400 kW for CHAdeMO and 500 kW for Combined Charging Systems, and includes standards for liquid cooled cables and pantograph charging methods. The changes aim to provide more charging options for electric vehicles and motorcyclists, with a 6-month transition period before compliance becomes mandatory.

site_title: Ron Sim's V3, which owns OSIM, files for Hong Kong IPO
summary: V3 Group, the parent company of OSIM and TWG Tea, has filed for an initial public offering (IPO) on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange. The IPO, valued at S$196.6 million, aims to repay existing loans, fund digitalization initiatives, and expand the company's product portfolio. The move comes after the group posted a surge in profit for the 9 months ended September 30, 2021, with revenue increasing 32.8% to S$332.8 million. The IPO is the latest step in V3's expansion plans, following its delisting from the Singapore Exchange in 2016.

site_title: Macau gaming revenue rebounds on Chinese New Year tourist boost
summary: Macau's gaming revenue rebounded 6.1% in February, driven by a surge in tourists during the Lunar New Year holiday. The city saw a 25% increase in visitors, but still trailed pre-pandemic levels. Revenue rose 22% from the previous month, but remains down 69% from 2019 levels. Analysts warn of potential headwinds due to tightened visa approvals and increased crackdowns on cross-border gambling, which may impact the $3.5 billion VIP sector.

site_title: Singtel's redevelopment of Comcentre to unlock value is a well-trodden path
summary: Singtel plans to redevelop its Comcentre headquarters into a mixed-use office development, with a total gross floor area of over 110,000 square meters. The project, valued at over S$2 billion, will feature offices, a retail component, and Singtel's existing Orchard Exchange. The company will divest Comcentre to a joint venture, holding a majority stake and occupying 30% of the space, generating a recurring income stream for the group.

site_title: Dividends in developed Asia-Pacific markets jumped to record high in 2021: report
summary: Dividends in developed Asia-Pacific markets reached a record high in 2021, growing 31.7% to US$163.3 billion from US$124 billion in 2020. Australia and South Korea led gains, with the region's dividend growth outpacing global averages.

site_title: Global banks lose juicy fees as China junk bond drought drags on
summary: Global banks are facing a decline in high-yield bond sales in Asia due to China's restrictions on property firms, resulting in a significant drop in issuance this year. The US$2.41 billion raised in the dollar junk bond market this year is a far cry from the US$21.9 billion in the same period last year. As a result, banks are expected to lose lucrative fees and some of their most prolific borrowers, including Chinese developers, may default on debts. Major international underwriters are diversifying their businesses to other markets, such as investment-grade issuers and the green debt market.

site_title: Coda lands top SAG award on road to Oscars
summary: CODA, a coming-of-age drama about a deaf family, won the top SAG award for ensemble cast, beating contenders including Belfast and King Richard. The film, which also stars deaf actors Marlee Matlin and Troy Kotsur, raised its chances of success at the Oscars. CODA's win was seen as a milestone for deaf representation in film, with Matlin praising progress for deaf actors. The SAG awards are closely watched by the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, with winners often going on to win Oscars.

site_title: CBRE appoints Luke Moffat as new Asia-Pacific head of advisory and transaction services
summary: CBRE appoints Luke Moffat as its new Asia-Pacific head of advisory and transaction services, effective immediately. Moffat, relocating from Shanghai, China, will oversee a team of over 2,000 professionals across 15 markets and various commercial real estate sectors. He succeeds Manish Kashyap, who took on a senior leadership role as global president of A&T. Moffat brings experience from his previous roles at BlackRock and CBRE, and will be based in Singapore.

site_title: Lockdown fears spark panic buying in Hong Kong
summary: Panic buying in Hong Kong has led to empty supermarket shelves as residents stock up due to uncertainty over potential lockdowns. The government's mixed messaging has sparked fears, with residents rushing to buy essential items such as meat, vegetables, and testing kits. Photos show widespread shortages of various products, leaving many without access to basic necessities. The situation highlights the anxiety and insecurity felt by Hong Kongers amidst the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Hong Kong to lock down city for mass testing
summary: Hong Kong is set to enforce a city-wide lockdown to ensure a mandatory Covid-19 testing drive, starting after March 17, with a stay-at-home order in place for 9 days. The city's 7.4 million residents will be tested three times during the period, with core financial services continuing to operate. Residents will be allowed to leave homes for necessities like food. The lockdown aims to combat the highly transmissible Omicron variant, which has caused a surge in new cases and deaths.

site_title: Zoom forecasts annual revenue, profit below estimates
summary: Zoom Video Communications forecasted annual revenue and profit below Wall Street estimates, citing tough competition and lower sign-ups for its core Meetings platform. The company expects full-year revenue of $4.53-4.55 billion and adjusted profit of $3.45-3.51 per share. Despite beating estimates for fourth-quarter sales and profit, Zoom's shares rose 4.4% after the company authorized a $1 billion stock repurchase program. Analysts see a possible rebound in the second half of 2023, with growth rates expected to trough before accelerating.

site_title: Oil settles higher on Russian supply disruption
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday after Western allies imposed sanctions on Russia, potentially disrupting its oil exports. Brent crude settled up 3.1% at $100.99 a barrel, reaching a high of $105.07 in early trade. The sanctions, combined with blocked Russian banks from a global payments system, could cause severe disruption to Russia's oil exports, driving up prices.

site_title: Coinbase jumps as investors search for bottom in crypto prices
summary: Coinbase Global surged 8.7% on Monday, its largest gain in almost 3 months, as investors sought a bottom in crypto prices. The stock has dropped 25% this year due to risk aversion amid the Ukraine war. Coinbase warned of declining trading volumes in the first quarter, but Monday's rally suggests traders may have already priced in risks. The stock is now more than 10% above its 2022 low.

site_title: Australia's Q4 GDP looking even stronger as trade surprises
summary: Australia's Q4 GDP is expected to be stronger than initially thought, thanks to a narrower-than-expected current account surplus and a less significant impact from net exports on GDP growth. The surplus narrowed to A$12.7 billion, from A$22 billion in the third quarter, trimming only 0.2 percentage points from GDP growth. This suggests upside risk for growth, despite imports outstripping exports and dividend payments flowing offshore.

site_title: Twitter, Facebook clamp down on Russia state-linked news
summary: Social media giants Twitter and Facebook parent Meta have restricted access to Russian state-linked news outlets RT and Sputnik in the European Union, citing concerns over misinformation about Moscow's invasion of Ukraine. Western nations have accused these outlets of being Kremlin mouthpieces, and the tech platforms aim to curb their influence. This move follows international condemnation of Russia's actions in Ukraine, marking a significant step in addressing the spread of misinformation.

site_title: EU dampens Ukraine plea for 'immediate' membership
summary: The European Union has dampened Ukraine's plea for "immediate" membership, citing the lengthy adherence procedure that takes years. EU officials stressed that Ukraine's membership would not provide an immediate solution to the Russian invasion and would not speed up military, financial, and political support. This move comes despite strong support from eastern EU states. The EU's European Commission chief, Ursula von der Leyen, later clarified her comments, suggesting that Ukraine's membership is not imminent.

site_title: Russian oil tanker hit by US sanctions heading to Malaysia
summary: A Russian-flagged oil tanker, targeted by US sanctions and suspected of carrying Iranian oil, is heading to Malaysia's Sungai Linggi port. The Linda, a crude oil tanker, was in the Indian Ocean and is expected to arrive on Sunday, according to ship tracking data. Authorities in Malaysia have not commented on whether the ship will be allowed to anchor. The move comes amid growing scrutiny of businesses linked to Moscow following Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

site_title: Tactical asset allocation: the flexibility advantage
summary: Tactical asset allocation (TAA) is a short-term strategy that deviates from the strategic asset allocation (SAA) process to add value to an investor's portfolio. SAA determines long-run exposure to systematic risk factors, while TAA exploits deviations from long-term expectations and perceived disequilibria in the market. This strategy provides flexibility, particularly in a world where ultra-loose monetary policy is ending, and can leverage deviations from expected long-run returns. TAA can be used to track risk with the SAA benchmark, but its benefits must be weighed against the costs of tactical adjustments.

site_title: Indonesia's Feb inflation eases slightly to +2.06% yoy: stats bureau
summary: Indonesia's annual inflation rate rose to 2.06% in February, easing from 2.18% in January, according to the statistics bureau. The easing was attributed to cooling food prices, particularly after the government's move to control cooking oil prices in early February. The annual core inflation rate, excluding government-controlled prices, reached 2.03%, the highest since July 2020.

site_title: JPMorgan's Kolanovic says 'worst might be behind us' on US market sell-off
summary: JPMorgan strategist Marko Kolanovic believes the worst of the US market sell-off may be behind it, citing a diminished impact of the war in Ukraine on corporate earnings and a dovish reassessment of the Federal Reserve. The crisis has forced the market to price in lower odds of aggressive rate hikes, and tech stocks are poised for a rebound despite recent volatility. However, other risks, such as higher commodity prices and inflation, remain substantial.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 10.97 points or 0.68% to 1,619.25 on Tuesday, driven by a higher trading volume of 110.18 million lots worth RM41.676 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 168 to 100, with the market opening higher despite global economic uncertainty.

site_title: EU must deploy financial shock and awe against Putin's aggression
summary: The European Union must adopt a more aggressive financial strategy against Russia's invasion of Ukraine, shifting focus from interdependence to countering Russia's control over oil, gas, and raw materials. This approach is more direct and existential, requiring the EU to counter a land war in Europe and assert its global leadership. The EU's "strategic autonomy" debate was misguided, as the real challenge lies in countering Russia's economic and military power, not in maintaining dependence on other countries. A more assertive financial strategy is necessary to counter Putin's aggression and prevent a larger conflict.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks start higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened with small gains on March 1, 2022, as Ukraine-fueled volatility subsided slightly. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.41% to 22,807.12, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.63% to 3,484.01. Traders remain cautious due to ongoing global market uncertainty.

site_title: Sea's e-commerce arm exits France a few months into Europe foray
summary: Sea's e-commerce arm Shopee is exiting France, just months after launching in Europe. The site will close on March 6, completing all paid orders before then. This marks another setback for Sea, which recently lost $16 billion in value after India banned its popular game Free Fire. Shopee may now focus on Latin America, as regulatory scrutiny in India continues to pose challenges. The move follows asset managers cutting their holdings in Sea due to concerns about the company's expansion beyond South-east Asia.

site_title: China's Feb factory activity returns to growth as new orders improve
summary: China's factory activity returned to growth in February, with the Caixin/Markit Manufacturing PMI rising to 50.4, up from a 2-year low of 49.1 in the previous month. New orders expanded, but employment remained in contraction, and inflationary pressures intensified. The 50.4 mark separates growth from contraction, indicating a return to expansion.

site_title: UK to freeze assets of all Russian banks 'in days'
summary: The UK is set to freeze the assets of all Russian banks "in days" in response to Russia's invasion of Ukraine. This move, part of new legislation, aims to squeeze Russia's economy. The freeze follows Britain's ban on the Russian central bank using its reserves to support the plummeting ruble. The UK joins the US and Western allies in imposing sanctions on Russia.

site_title: Giant floating solar flowers offer hope for coal-addicted South Korea
summary: South Korea's 17 giant floating solar flowers on a 12-mile-long reservoir generate 41 megawatts of power, enough to power 20,000 homes. The plant, built by Hanwha Solutions, is one of the largest floating solar plants in the world and offers a solution to South Korea's climate target of becoming carbon neutral by 2050. Local residents were given the chance to invest and were offered jobs during construction, helping to overcome local resistance to the project. The plant's success shows the potential of floating solar arrays in overcoming land scarcity and opposition in developed nations.

site_title: Isolating Russia: 10 sectors where businesses are reacting
summary: Businesses are increasingly reacting to Russia's invasion of Ukraine, with companies in various sectors pulling out or re-evaluating their ties to the country. This corporate backlash spans 10 sectors, including energy, metals, and crypto. Companies such as Creative Technology and CGSI have downgraded their assessments of Russia, citing concerns over revenue and earnings growth. Meanwhile, Singapore's OCBC Bank has announced a leadership change, with Tan Teck Long succeeding Helen Wong as CEO. The move reflects the growing impact of global events on business operations and strategies.

site_title: Petrochem industry needs a 'just transition' to green economy: Workers' Party
summary: Workers' Party MP Dennis Tan emphasized the need for a "just transition" in Singapore's petrochemical industry to manage its green transition. The industry's abrupt shift could disrupt the talent pipeline, with a 2020 drop in employment from 28,000 to 27,000. Tan noted that petrochemicals are still necessary for modern green technologies, and the government should provide more details on its plans to manage the transition.

site_title: After decades of flat pay, some Japan firms boost salaries to retain skilled staff
summary: Japan's Lasertec Corp and other firms are boosting salaries to retain skilled staff, a shift away from decades of flat pay. Average salaries are rising, with some companies paying up to 14 million yen (S$165,000) per year, more than three times the national average. This move is driven by the labor crunch and the need to attract talented engineers, particularly in research and development. However, performance-linked pay can lead to bonuses being cut in a downturn, which may be unattractive to Japanese workers who prize stability.

site_title: China Everbright FY21 net profit up 17% at HK$1.2b
summary: China Everbright Water reported a 17% increase in FY21 net profit to HK$1.2 billion, driven by higher revenue from construction services. Revenue rose 22% to HK$6.9 billion, with the environmental protection company also seeing an increase in gross profit margin to 41%. The board proposed a final dividend of 6.83 cents per share, up from 6.07 cents in FY2020. The company's construction projects resumed in April 2020 after the lifting of COVID-19 restrictions in China.

site_title: Australia: Banking, tech stocks boost shares ahead of RBA meeting
summary: Australia's shares rose 1.2% to 7,133.9 ahead of the Reserve Bank of Australia's policy meeting, boosted by financial and tech stocks. The "Big Four" banks gained 1.9%, while technology stocks advanced 4.4%. Energy stocks rose 1.5% due to oil price jumps, and shares in IGO and Virtus Health jumped 10.4% and 4% respectively. The RBA is expected to keep rates steady with a possible hike in the July-September quarter.

site_title: PropertyGuru grows FY2021 revenue by 22.7% to S$100.7m
summary: PropertyGuru, a Singapore-based real estate firm, reported a 22.7% increase in FY2021 revenue to S$100.7 million, exceeding its forecast of S$97.5 million. The company attributes the growth to rising confidence in the property market and plans to go public through a merger with Bridgetown 2 Holdings, backed by Peter Thiel and Richard Li, with an expected enterprise value of US$1.35 billion. PropertyGuru expects FY2022 revenue to grow 44% to S$145.1 million, driven by strong business momentum and growth in South-east Asian markets.

site_title: Vast Russian army convoy spotted north of Kyiv
summary: A US satellite imaging company spotted a 64 km-long Russian military convoy north of Kyiv, Ukraine, just days after it began massing in the area. The convoy, seen to be traveling along roads near the Ukrainian capital, has raised concerns of a potential new assault. According to Ukrainian and US sources, Moscow is preparing to launch a new military push imminently, with Russian forces accumulating armoured vehicles and artillery in southern Belarus. The main Russian effort remains an advance on Kyiv, which had slowed down on the fifth day of the invasion.

site_title: Pentagon studying Putin nuclear order
summary: The Pentagon is studying Russian President Vladimir Putin's order to mobilize his nuclear forces, with no clear results. Belarus troops have not yet joined the conflict in Ukraine. The US defence official stated that the situation is being closely monitored, but no specific actions have been taken as a result of Putin's announcement.

site_title: Uber to accelerate sale of Yandex taxi joint venture
summary: Uber is accelerating the sale of its 29% stake in Yandex.Taxi, a joint venture valued at $800 million, due to recent events. Uber will remove its executives from the board and appoint a single non-executive representative to oversee the sale. This decision comes after Yandex bought out Uber's interest in several joint ventures, including Yandex.Eats, in August. The move also reflects Uber's pause in operations in Ukraine and its efforts to divest its remaining holdings.

site_title: China warns of 'huge' pressure on foreign trade as economic challenges mount
summary: China's Commerce Minister Wang Wentao warned of "huge" pressure on foreign trade due to global uncertainty and a high statistical base from 2021. Labour shortages and high raw material costs also affect small and medium-sized companies handling overseas orders. China aims to spur domestic consumption and broaden access to its markets, with foreign direct investment growing in the double-digits in January-February. The government seeks to stabilize society ahead of the Communist Party's once-in-five-year congress in late 2022, where President Xi Jinping is expected to claim his third term as leader.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Tokyo shares opened higher on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index rising 1.20% and the Topix index climbing 0.91%. This followed a relatively calm Wall Street session, as investors awaited further economic news in the US amid the Ukraine crisis.

site_title: US: Stocks mostly fall as sanctions on Russia mount
summary: US stocks fell on Monday as sanctions on Russia exacerbated concerns over the economic impact of the Ukraine crisis. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.5%, while the S&P 500 fell 0.2%. Russia's currency plummeted and investors feared inflation would worsen due to rising oil prices. Individual companies saw varying results, with First Horizon jumping 28.6% after a $13.4 billion acquisition, and Lordstown Motors diving nearly 20% after announcing production plans.

site_title: Europe is re-arming, and its defence firms stand to profit
summary: Germany has pledged 100 billion euros to modernize its army, meeting NATO's 2% GDP defense target by 2024. This move is expected to boost Europe's defense industry, with stocks of defense firms such as Hensoldt, Rheinmetall, and Thales increasing by up to 89%. The investment will help address outdated equipment and shortages of replacement parts, with Chancellor Olaf Scholz also announcing plans for increased international cooperation and the acquisition of new military technology, including the Eurodrone project and Israeli Heron drones.

site_title: Ukraine crisis clouds Singapore's outlook, sanctions on Russia planned
summary: Singapore has imposed sanctions against Russia, including export controls on items that can be used directly as weapons in Ukraine, and blocked certain Russian banks and financial transactions. The move comes as the country joins a growing number of nations condemning Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The sanctions are expected to have a limited impact on Singapore's economy, with Trade and Industry Minister Gan Kim Yong stating that the immediate impact has been "manageable" due to the country's limited presence in Ukraine. However, higher energy costs are likely to raise the cost of living, with higher pump prices for petrol and diesel, and electricity rates for businesses and households.

site_title: Ceasefire talks get underway in Belarus as Ukraine demands Russia withdraw troops
summary: Ukraine's delegation met Russian negotiators in Belarus for the first talks since Moscow's invasion, as the country demands an immediate Russian ceasefire and troop withdrawal. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky urged the European Union to give Ukraine "immediate" membership, while the US and EU imposed sanctions on Russia, cutting off major financial institutions from Western markets. Russia's forces seized two cities in southeastern Ukraine, but faced stiff resistance elsewhere, and at least 102 civilians have been killed in the conflict, with over 360,000 people fleeing to neighboring countries.

site_title: Toshiba CEO resigns amid growing opposition to restructuring plans
summary: Toshiba CEO Satoshi Ttsunakawa has resigned amid growing opposition to the company's restructuring plans. Senior executive Taro Shimada, a former Siemens executive, will take over as the new head of the company, effective immediately. This move comes as Toshiba faces increasing resistance to its plans, which have sparked concerns among investors and stakeholders. The company's restructuring efforts aim to improve its financial performance, but the opposition suggests that the plans may not be well-received.

site_title: China tells UN 'nothing can be gained' from a new Cold War
summary: China's UN ambassador, Zhang Jun, stated that a new Cold War between the US and Russia would yield no benefits and harm everyone involved. He emphasized the need to abandon a Cold War mentality and instead focus on cooperation. This comes as China's economic growth is expected to slow, raising pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Europe: Stocks cut losses after Russia-Ukraine ceasefire talks
summary: European stocks cut losses after Russia and Ukraine held ceasefire talks, with the Stoxx 600 index ending 0.1% lower. Despite this, euro zone banks plummeted 5.7% due to concerns over sanctions on Russia. Officials ended peace talks and will return for further consultations. The conflict's escalation is seen as necessary for further selling, according to analysts.

site_title: Cryptoverse: Bitcoin gains conflict currency credentials
summary: Bitcoin has surged 13% since Russia's invasion of Ukraine, with daily trading volumes in the Russian rouble increasing 259% and in Ukrainian hryvnias tripling. The cryptocurrency is seen as an anonymous and decentralized way to transfer value, with some speculating it could be used by Russian oligarchs to avoid sanctions. Meanwhile, stablecoins have also gained popularity, with USD Tether's market capitalization reaching an all-time high of nearly $80 billion.

site_title: Budget 2022: venturing overseas and supply chain challenges
summary: Singapore aims to support local companies in scaling up and investing overseas with new initiatives such as the Singapore Global Enterprises program and the Singapore Global Executive Programme. However, the country faces supply chain challenges, with 59.7% of local businesses planning to venture overseas in 2021, citing e-commerce platforms as effective in expanding their businesses. Despite Singapore's role as a major transhipment hub, disruptions in the supply chain can have ripple effects on the entire network, and the government has launched the S$18 million Supply Chain 4.0 Initiative to integrate technology and build resilience.

site_title: HK abandoning key Covid Zero measures as cases surge
summary: Hong Kong is abandoning key Covid Zero measures as the city struggles with a surge in new cases, with hospitals and morgues nearly full. Patients with mild cases are now advised to stay home until they test negative, and close contacts are no longer required to quarantine. The city's lab testing has also shifted to rapid antigen tests, and the app that flags locations with confirmed cases has suspended risk alerts. Hong Kong reported a record 34,466 new cases on Monday, and deaths are climbing due to low vaccination rates among the elderly.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Tuesday's open; STI climbs 0.9%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.9% at Tuesday's open, with the Straits Times Index (STI) climbing 30.31 points to 3,272.55. The most actively traded counter was Singtel, which rose 2.4%. Local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB also gained, while US stocks closed lower on Monday due to concerns over the Ukraine crisis. European stocks rebounded, and Asian markets also opened higher, with Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index rising 1.2%.

images.alt_text: Singapore stocks rose in early trade on Tuesday (Mar 1) morning after dropping slightly on Monday. The Straits Times Index climbed 0.9 per cent or 30.31 points to 3,272.55 as at 9.02 am.

site_title: Fintech startup Volopay raises US$29m led by Tinder co-founder's JAM Fund
summary: Singapore-based fintech startup Volopay has raised US$29 million in a Series A round led by JAM Fund, the venture capital firm of Tinder co-founder Justin Mateen. Other investors include Winklevoss Capital Management, Rapyd Ventures, and angel investor Jeffrey Cruttenden. Volopay provides multi-currency wallets to startups and SMEs, addressing high forex charges. The company plans to use the funds to expand in Asia-Pacific, the Middle East, and North Africa, build new tech, and hire aggressively. Founded in 2019, Volopay has clients including Funding Societies and Zipmex.

site_title: War-stoked volatility brings new challenge to IPO plans in Asia
summary: Asia-Pacific initial public offerings (IPOs) faced their worst start to the year, with February raising only US$5.1 billion, the lowest for any month since May 2020. Geopolitical tensions, including Russia's invasion of Ukraine, have added to regional headwinds, causing delays in funding deals. Several major IPOs, including India's LIC and South Korea's LG Energy Solution, have been postponed due to valuation mismatches and investor uncertainty. The outlook for March remains uncertain, with analysts warning of potential IPO cancellations.

site_title: Ten of thousands are evacuated from floods in Australia
summary: Tens of thousands of Australians were evacuated from flooded areas in the country, with 43,000 residents ordered to leave the town of Lismore due to record-breaking floodwaters. Eight people have died, and the country's weather bureau warned of further severe thunderstorms and intense rainfall, causing "life-threatening flash flooding" across a central Pacific coastal region. Emergency services deployed helicopters and rescue boats to pluck stranded residents from rooftops, as the town's levees were breached, with over 16 inches of rain falling in the past 24 hours.

site_title: Australia's home price boom slows, Sydney takes a rare dip
summary: Australian home prices rose 0.6% in February, the slowest growth since August 2021. Despite a national price increase, Sydney saw its first price drop in 17 months, with a 0.1% decline. Regional areas saw a 1.6% gain, driven by pandemic-induced migration. National prices are up 20.6% for the year, with the median home value at A$728,034. Regulators are concerned about rapid growth in housing debt, and interest rates may rise later this year, potentially cooling the market.

site_title: Tech gear maker warns conflict is blocking China-Europe railway
summary: Zyxel Communications, a Taiwan-based networking gear maker, has suspended shipping from China to Europe by rail due to the ongoing conflict in Ukraine, threatening to disrupt a key land route for Beijing's Belt and Road Initiative. The company had relied on rail transport to reduce shipping times, but now fears disruptions and potential delays. The move is part of a broader global shipping crisis affecting electronics supplies, including smartphones and gaming consoles. Zyxel anticipates potential disruptions along the China-Russia-Europe rail network, which is a major conduit for Chinese exports to Europe.

site_title: Carbon scorecard: informing consumers so that they learn to do their bit
summary: Singapore's government has announced a plan to increase the country's carbon price from S$5 to S$50-S$80 per tonne of emissions by 2030, aiming to encourage environmentally friendly choices. The proposal includes a carbon scorecard for individuals, which would track their carbon footprint and provide incentives for reducing emissions. The scorecard would consider factors such as transportation, utilities, and food consumption choices, and could lead to a progressive carbon tax for households. The move aims to address climate inequality and encourage consumers to participate in the transition to a sustainable economy.

site_title: Golden Agri-Resources H2 profit up 71.2% to US$323m
summary: Golden Agri-Resources reported a 71.2% increase in H2 net profit to US$323 million, driven by higher crude palm oil prices, improved margins, and increased production. Revenue for the period reached US$5.73 billion, a 55.3% increase from the same period last year. The company's earnings per share (EPS) rose to 2.54 US cents, and a final dividend of 1.077 Singapore cents per share is proposed, totaling 1.605 cents per share. Golden Agri plans to initiate a share buyback program with US$100 million allocated for 2022.

images.alt_text: Above: A Golden Agri-Resources refinery complex. The group on Tuesday posted a 71.2 per cent growth in net profit to US$323 million for the second half ended Dec 31, 2021, up from US$188.6 million in the corresponding year-ago period.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts bullish on Bumitama Agri, expect continued rally of CPO prices
summary: Analysts at RHB Research, UOB Kay Hian, and Maybank Securities have upgraded their ratings on Bumitama Agri, a palm oil producer, due to its strong FY2021 results and expected continued rally in CPO prices. The brokerages raised their target prices for the stock, with RHB targeting S$0.90, UOBKH at S$0.85, and Maybank at S$0.98. The upgrades are attributed to the company's focus on spot selling, inexpensive valuations, and attractive dividend yields.

site_title: Medtecs full-year profit tumbles 87% to US$17.3m on lower PPE, face mask demand
summary: Medtecs International, a protective gear manufacturer, reported a net profit of US$17.3 million for the full year 2021, 87% lower than the previous year due to decreased demand and margins for personal protective equipment (PPE) and facemasks. Revenue declined 64% to US$144.2 million, mainly due to lower sales and inventory provisions. The company will generate a net profit despite the decline, and has expanded into business-to-consumer services and is exploring renewable energy opportunities.

site_title: Look for a North Star in volatile markets
summary: Investors should be cautious in volatile markets due to rising interest rates, which could lead to asset price bubbles bursting. Historically, interest rates have been the primary driver of asset prices, and when rates rise, asset values tend to fall. As interest rates are expected to increase, investors should focus on reliable income streams, such as dividends, to navigate the uncertainty and potential market volatility.

site_title: HP boosts annual profit outlook amid sustained PC demand
summary: HP boosts annual profit outlook to $4.38 per share, a 11-cent increase, driven by strong PC demand. The company expects the PC market to reach $560 billion by 2024. Despite a 3-cent quarterly hit from global sanctions on Russia, HP's full-year earnings are now expected to be higher. The company's fiscal first-quarter revenue increased 8.8% to $17 billion, with personal systems sales jumping 15% to $12.2 billion.

site_title: BigSeller raises US$100m Series C round led by Tiger Global, Huaxing Growth Capital
summary: BigSeller, the parent company of e-commerce platform BigSeller, has raised US$100 million in a Series C round led by Tiger Global and Huaxing Growth Capital. The funding will support the company's expansion into other parts of South-east Asia. BigSeller allows sellers to manage product listings, order aggregation, and data analytics across marketplaces, and has doubled its user base since its launch in 2019. The company serves over 370,000 sellers in the region and has been integrated with major e-commerce marketplaces, including Shopee and Lazada.

site_title: Putin announces emergency measures to prop up rouble
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin announced emergency measures to prop up the plunging rouble, including banning foreign cash transfers and requiring exporters to hold 80% of their reserves in roubles. The move comes after Western sanctions, which have caused the rouble to fall to a record low and the central bank to double its key interest rate to 20%. Putin believes Russia has the potential to compensate for the damage, and the measures are expected to fuel inflation and hit non-energy-related companies.

images.alt_text: Common concerns about the skin include the 3 Ps of pores, pigmentation and pimples. A basic facial skincare checklist prescribed to a patient with normal skin consists of "C.R.E.A.M.S." - Cleanser and Toner, Retinoid, Exfoliator, Antioxidant, Moisturiser, and Sunscreen.

site_title: TikTok videos get longer in challenge to YouTube
summary: TikTok has begun allowing users to upload videos up to 10 minutes long, a significant increase from its previous 3-minute limit. The move is seen as a challenge to YouTube, with Insider Intelligence analyst Jasmine Enberg stating that longer videos could help TikTok catch up in terms of engagement and advertising revenue. YouTube has also been investing in short-form content, including its "Shorts" feature, which has logged over 5 trillion views. The platform's parent, Meta, also offers a similar feature called Reels.

images.alt_text: TikTok on Monday (Feb 28) began letting users upload videos as long as 10 minutes, ramping up the young platform's challenge to veteran titan YouTube.

site_title: Macron urges Putin to spare Ukrainian civilians
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron urged Russian President Vladimir Putin to spare Ukrainian civilians and stop attacks on civilians and infrastructure. Macron asked Putin to secure major roadways, including the road from the south of Kyiv, and allow aid shipments to reach the population. Putin confirmed his willingness to make commitments on these points, but Macron's office did not provide details on his response. Macron also reiterated the demand for an immediate ceasefire and respect for international humanitarian law. The two leaders agreed to remain in contact to prevent a worsening of the situation.

site_title: Paris concert hall cancels star Russian conductor
summary: The prestigious Philharmonie concert hall in Paris has cancelled two concerts by Russian conductor Valery Gergiev in April due to his close ties to President Vladimir Putin. The decision was made in solidarity with the Ukrainian people following Russia's invasion of the country. Gergiev's ties to the Kremlin have led to his disassociation from various orchestras, including the Munich Philharmonic and Teatro alla Scala in Milan, with his agent stating he could no longer represent him due to his refusal to publicly condemn the war.

site_title: SPH to hold scheme meeting on Mar 22 to vote on Cuscaden takeover offer
summary: SPH will hold a scheme meeting on March 22 to vote on the takeover offer from Cuscaden Peak. The company has obtained court permission to convene the meeting, allowing it to withdraw its application for a separate Keppel scheme. The decision comes after the court granted leave for the Cuscaden scheme meeting, paving the way for shareholders to vote on the proposed takeover.

site_title: Australia financial crime watchdog slaps money laundering lawsuit on Crown Resorts
summary: Australia's financial crime watchdog, AUSTRAC, has filed a civil lawsuit against Crown Resorts, accusing it of failing to assess money laundering and terrorism financing risks at its two operational casinos. The watchdog claims Crown's business and Australia's financial system are vulnerable to criminal exploitation due to the company's failure to meet its obligations. Crown has reviewed the statement of claim and developed a mediation plan, stating it has overhauled its governance since allegations surfaced in 2020.

site_title: Novavax expects to apply for full US approval of Covid vaccine in H2
summary: Novavax plans to apply for full US approval of its Covid-19 vaccine in the second half of 2022, with forecasted total revenue of $4 billion to $5 billion for 2022. The company has completed vaccine deliveries to Indonesia, Australia, and South Korea and expects to supply 69 million doses to Europe in the first half of 2022. An extended study found the vaccine provided 82.7% long-term protection against the coronavirus, and Novavax is working on an Omicron-specific vaccine.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher on tech, banking boost; RBA holds rates
summary: Australian shares ended 0.7% higher on Tuesday, driven by gains in technology and banking stocks, despite the Reserve Bank of Australia keeping interest rates at a record low of 0.1%. The S&P/ASX 200 index extended its third consecutive gain, following firmer Asian markets. Tech stocks jumped 5.7%, with Block's Australian shares rising 12.8%, while Commonwealth Bank of Australia's shares advanced 1.5% after selling a stake in China's Bank of Hangzhou.

site_title: Market Capitalisation
summary: Creative Technology warns it may miss its H2 revenue target, with an operating loss similar to the first half. Singapore stocks see a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while OCBC names Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO, replacing Helen Wong. Meanwhile, London's Heathrow eyes higher fees for a £10b upgrade, and Indonesia detains a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. MAS and PBOC plan to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. CGSI downgrades Grab to 'hold' due to slowing earnings growth.

site_title: Neil Diamond sells entire song catalogue to Universal
summary: US singer-songwriter Neil Diamond has sold his entire song catalogue to Universal Music Group, covering 60 years of work, including 110 unreleased tracks and archival recordings. The deal also includes the rights to future music if Diamond returns to the studio. Financial details were not disclosed.

site_title: Biden to host South-east Asian leaders in Washington in late March
summary: President Joe Biden will host a summit of US and South-east Asian leaders in Washington on March 28-29, commemorating 45 years of US-Asean relations. The event aims to strengthen US engagement with the region amid China's growing power and address issues such as the Myanmar military takeover, pandemic recovery, and climate change. The Biden administration has prioritized the Indo-Pacific region, pledging to defend freedom of the seas and democracy, and plans to launch a regional economic framework. The summit will also discuss pandemic recovery and investment.

site_title: IOC recommends banning Russian, Belarusian athletes from international events
summary: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) has recommended banning Russian and Belarusian athletes and officials from international events, citing the need to protect the integrity of global sports competitions and ensure the safety of participants. The decision comes after Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The IOC also urged sports federations to ensure no athlete or official from Russia or Belarus participates under their national name, with exceptions for neutral athletes or teams. The recommendation does not include a full suspension, but rather leaves it to organizations to address extreme circumstances.

site_title: Baode Building sold for S$27m in collective sale
summary: The Baode Building, an 8-storey freehold residential building in Singapore, has been sold via private treaty for S$27 million after a relaunch of tender on Dec 14, 2021. The buyer, Amitabha Buddhist Society (Singapore), will receive estimated gross sale proceeds of S$1.92 million to S$1.94 million per unit, depending on unit size. The sale price matches the owners' asking price and translates to a land rate of S$1,007 per square foot per plot ratio.

site_title: Luxury home prices to climb 5.7% this year: Knight Frank
summary: Luxury home prices are projected to rise 5.7% in 2022, according to Knight Frank, with cities like Dubai, Miami, and Zurich leading the pack. The Asia Pacific region is expected to trail slightly, with cities like Seoul and Sydney seeing 9% and 7% increases, respectively. The US Federal Reserve's interest rate hike may soften buyer sentiment, but locations like Byron Bay and London's Knightsbridge are expected to see significant price gains in the next five years.

site_title: Toyota halts Japan plants after reported cyber attack
summary: Toyota halted operations at all 14 domestic plants in Japan for a day due to a reported cyber attack on a parts supplier. The company suspended 28 production lines, affecting both first and second shifts, on March 1, 2022. The cause of the cyber attack is not specified.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Golden Agri-Resources, Medtecs, Jardine C&C, UOL, ComfortDelGro
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Several Singaporean companies reported significant financial developments on Tuesday, March 1, 2022. Golden Agri-Resources saw a 71.2% growth in net profit to US$323 million, while Medtecs International reported an 87% drop in net profit. Jardine Cycle & Carriage's earnings increased 22% to US$661 million, and UOL's net profit jumped 127% to S$216.1 million. ComfortDelGro reported a 114% increase in FY2021 earnings, and Ho Bee Land's net profit surged 141% to S$330.5 million. These announcements may affect trading of these companies' securities.

site_title: Gold prices dip as Russia-Ukraine ceasefire talks underway
summary: Gold prices dropped 0.3% to $1,902.15 per ounce as Russian and Ukrainian officials began ceasefire talks, amid Western sanctions against Moscow. The decline follows a 1% gain in the previous session. Russia's central bank doubled its key policy rate and introduced capital controls, but its governor attributed sanctions for limiting foreign currency sales. The move follows Western companies, such as BP and Shell, pulling out of Russia, and is expected to maintain demand for safe-haven assets.

site_title: New Chinese hacking tool found, spurring US warning to allies
summary: US cybersecurity firm Symantec has discovered a "highly sophisticated" Chinese hacking tool, dubbed Daxin, which has evaded public attention for over a decade. The tool has been used in intrusions targeting high-level government agencies in Asia and Africa, and its capabilities suggest advanced communication techniques that can blend in with normal network traffic. The US government has shared the information with foreign partners, and Symantec has joined a joint public-private cybersecurity information sharing partnership, the JCDC.

site_title: Hong Fok Corporation reports profit of S$41.8m for FY2021
summary: Hong Fok Corporation reported a profit of S$41.8 million for FY2021, reversing a loss of S$8.7 million the previous year. Revenue rose 13% to S$90.5 million, driven by sales of residential units and higher property management income. The company attributed its turnaround to the recovery of the pandemic and the opening of vaccinated travel lanes to more countries. However, the property development segment faces headwinds due to travel restrictions and property cooling measures in Singapore, prompting Hong Fok to take a cautious approach to its business.

site_title: Asia: Equities rise, oil rally slows as volatility eases for now
summary: Asian equities rose on Tuesday as volatility eased, with oil prices stabilizing despite concerns over supplies from the region. Russia's invasion of Ukraine continues, with widespread sanctions and a 20% interest rate hike. The US considers releasing oil reserves to temper prices, but analysts warn it may not be enough. Global central banks are expected to recalibrate their plans to tighten monetary policy, but some observers now forecast a more dovish approach from the Federal Reserve. Markets are expected to remain volatile in the short term.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Creative Technology warns that its second-half revenue may be lower than the target, with an operating loss similar to the first half. Meanwhile, Heathrow Airport is considering higher fees for its £10 billion upgrade. In Singapore, OCBC Bank has announced the retirement of CEO Helen Wong, with Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, set to take over as the new CEO. MAS and the PBOC are also deepening cooperation in green and transition finance, while Singapore stocks have experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. Grab's earnings growth is expected to slow in the second half.

site_title: Paris Fashion Week returns to pre-pandemic form
summary: Paris Fashion Week has largely returned to pre-pandemic form, with 95 out of 95 houses holding live shows. Notable brands such as Dior, Chanel, and Hermes are participating, while Saint Laurent has also returned to the official calendar after dropping out during the pandemic. The event marks a significant milestone two years after France's first pandemic lockdown. Despite the passing of Off-White's founder Virgil Abloh, the brand is expected to continue growing under Louis Vuitton's majority stake.

site_title: Virus wave deepens grim conditions for Hong Kong domestic workers
summary: Hong Kong's pandemic restrictions have taken a toll on domestic workers from the Philippines and Indonesia, with hundreds of thousands suffering under the city's severe coronavirus wave. Many are at breaking point, with limited access to support and resources. The situation has worsened, with workers struggling to maintain their livelihoods and connect with loved ones due to restrictions. The city's severe restrictions have exacerbated the already dire conditions for these workers, raising concerns about their well-being and future prospects.

site_title: Responding to Putin's aggression with economic, financial weaponry
summary: US President Joe Biden has announced economic sanctions against Russia, targeting 90 Russian financial institutions and government officials, in response to Vladimir Putin's aggression against Ukraine. The sanctions aim to bolster Western diplomatic leverage without risking military action, but may have economic blowback and impact global economies. The move restricts access to the Swift international payments system for select Russian banks, potentially raising global energy prices and inflation. The sanctions are seen as a necessary step to counter Putin's "deadly gamble" and protect Western interests.

site_title: Around US$23m raised via crypto to fund Ukraine's defence efforts
summary: Cryptocurrency donations to Ukraine's defense efforts have surged since Russia's invasion, with over $22.8 million raised in 5 days through over 24,000 crypto-asset donations. The funds are being used by the government and non-governmental organizations (NGOs) supporting the military. Notably, a single $1.86 million donation was made from the sale of NFTs originally intended to raise funds for Julian Assange. The use of cryptocurrency for cross-border donations has allowed easier access to wealthy overseas donors, but also raises concerns about fraudulent scams.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as West ratchets up sanctions against Russia
summary: US stocks fell at the open on Monday as investors assessed the fallout from Western sanctions on Russia. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.55%, the S&P 500 fell 0.70%, and the Nasdaq Composite declined 0.90%. The sanctions, imposed in response to Russia's invasion of Ukraine, are expected to have a significant impact on the global economy. Investors are also monitoring US-EU trade talks, which may influence market sentiment. The Dow Jones Industrial Average opened at 33,870.62.

site_title: Singapore millionaires surge to 526,000; ultra-wealthy up 8.6% to 4,200
summary: Singapore's number of ultra-high-net-worth individuals (UHNWIs) surged to 526,000 in 2021, a 8.6% increase from the previous year. The global UHNWI population rose 51,000, a 9.3% increase, with those with at least US$30 million expected to jump 43% to almost 6,000 by 2026. This growth is attributed to a surge in asset prices in 2021, despite ongoing COVID disruptions.

site_title: Uncharted stays on top as Spider-Man nears US$800m mark
summary: Tom Holland's Uncharted film stays at the top of the US box office charts, earning US$23.2 million in its second weekend, bringing its domestic total to US$83.3 million. Spider-Man: No Way Home follows closely in third place, with a total of US$779.8 million and a potential US$800 million mark soon to be reached.

site_title: Deutsche Bank delays GIC-sponsored CMBS deal tied to its New York headquarters
summary: Deutsche Bank has delayed a nearly $1.5 billion commercial mortgage bond deal tied to its New York headquarters, citing market weakness. The deal was postponed amid Russia's invasion of Ukraine, which has led to unpredictable borrowing and widening bond yields. The single-loan, single-borrower commercial mortgage bond was sponsored by Singapore's sovereign wealth fund and the Abu Dhabi Investment Authority. The transaction is expected to be completed when market conditions improve, according to people close to the deal. This is the latest in a series of delayed transactions in US capital markets.

site_title: Dream Cruises' World Dream to stop sailing after liquidation; request for refunds must be submitted
summary: Dream Cruises' vessel World Dream will cease operations after its return to Singapore on March 2, due to financial constraints. The company's parent, Genting Hong Kong, filed to be wound up at the Supreme Court of Bermuda, citing mounting creditor pressure and lack of sustainable operational income. Passengers who paid deposits for scheduled sailings after March 2 must submit their claims to the company, with the outcome uncertain. The World Dream, one of two "cruise-to-nowhere" vessels, had carried over 82,000 passengers since its launch in 2020.

site_title: ComfortDelGro still keen on Aussie listing, eyes bigger logistics play
summary: ComfortDelGro Corporation, a Singapore-listed transportation company, remains committed to listing its Australian subsidiary despite not needing cash. The group is exploring further investments in the logistics sector, including acquiring related properties, to expand its presence in the field. This move aims to capitalize on the growing demand for logistics services.

site_title: Most Finns favour Nato membership in 'historic' shift: poll
summary: Most Finns now favor joining NATO, according to a poll, marking a historic shift in attitude. The survey found 53% of Finns support joining the military alliance, while 28% oppose it and 19% are unsure. This change comes amid Russia's invasion of Ukraine and a response to the crisis. Meanwhile, Finland's state-run alcohol distributor removed vodka from shelves in response to the situation. The poll's results indicate a significant shift in public opinion on NATO membership in Finland.

site_title: Euro, rouble trim losses as Russia-Ukraine talks begin
summary: Russia said talks with Ukraine have begun, leading to a recovery in the rouble, which trimmed some of its earlier losses, and a slight decline in the euro against the US dollar. The rouble, which had plummeted 30% to an all-time low, recovered some ground, trading at 102 per US dollar. The euro, initially down 1%, pared some of its losses against the yen, but remained 0.7% lower against the US dollar. Western nations have imposed tough sanctions on Russia, further exacerbating market volatility.

site_title: SC Capital Partners launches data centre platform with first investment in Seoul
summary: SC Capital Partners has launched a pan-Asian data centre platform, SC Zeus Data Centers, with its first investment in Seoul, South Korea. The company has committed US$500 million to a 45-megawatt hyperscale data centre project. The platform will offer design, investment, and technical services across the Asia-Pacific region, with a presence in China, Japan, and South Korea. CEO Joe Gooi expects an "attractive pipeline" of 250 MW of IT load, driven by institutional investors' growing appetite for the data centre sector in Asia-Pacific.

site_title: Investment interest in Vietnam still high
summary: Vietnam remains a popular destination for foreign investment, particularly for Singaporean businesses, with its young population and competitive labor costs. The country's economic growth rate slowed in 2020 due to the pandemic but still outpaced many other nations. Recent trade agreements with the US have made Vietnam more attractive to foreign investors, with its stocks experiencing a surge. Analysts attribute the rebound to the favorable terms of the trade deal. Vietnam's favorable fundamentals continue to make it an attractive investment destination, ranking second only to Singapore among Asean countries.

site_title: OCBC unit sells private market feeder funds for US$5m
summary: BANK of Singapore (BOS), a subsidiary of OCBC, has sold its management shares in two private market feeder funds for US$5 million to fintech platform iCapital. The deal allows iCapital to take over fund management, while BOS retains client servicing responsibilities. The funds, Straits 01 and Straits Private Equity Investment, will cease to be subsidiaries of OCBC after the transaction. OCBC expects no material impact on its financials and will continue to source and advise on private market investments to its clients.

site_title: Russian central bank hikes rates to 20% to manage sanctions fallout
summary: The Russian central bank sharply raised its key policy rate to 20% on February 28, 2022, to counter risks of rouble depreciation and higher inflation amid harsh Western sanctions. The bank also ordered companies to sell 80% of their foreign currency revenues. The move aims to support domestic markets and maintain financial stability, following a day of Western sanctions. The rouble hit a low of 120 to the US dollar, and the central bank has stopped interventions due to the latest sanctions, suggesting the rouble is supported by other market participants.

site_title: Hikes in DC rates mirror recovery in most segments of Singapore property market
summary: Singapore's development charge (DC) rates have been raised for landed and non-landed residential, commercial, and industrial use groups, reflecting the recovery in the country's property market. The hikes range from 0.3% to 10% for non-landed residential and 4.8% for landed residential use groups. The exceptions are the hotel use group, which saw a 0.7% drop, and the place of worship/civic and community institution use group, which saw no changes. The increases are attributed to strong demand and prices in various segments, including the Good Class Bungalow market.

site_title: Airbus claims US$220m from Qatar in legal spat over paint
summary: Airbus is seeking over US$220 million in compensation from Qatar Airways in a legal dispute over paint defects on its A350 aircraft. The dispute began after Qatar rejected proposed repairs, including repainting and inserting fiberglass, and Airbus cancelled delivery of two A350s and a separate contract for A321s. Airbus claims the surface issues do not affect airworthiness, but Qatar alleges the manufacturer has not conducted a full analysis of the cause of the problems. The dispute is ongoing in a London court.

site_title: Growing demand for remote tech talent in Vietnam, Indonesia
summary: Demand for remote tech talent is intensifying in Vietnam and Indonesia, driven by companies seeking specialized talent and lower costs. In Vietnam, base tech salaries have risen 15-20% over the past 3 years, and the demand for developers far outstrips supply. Indonesian tech salaries have also surged, with companies competing for mid-to-senior level talent. Offshoring is becoming a way for companies to expand talent pools, with emerging markets like Vietnam and Indonesia offering access to skilled workers well-versed in open-source technologies. However, retention and integration of remote talent remain challenges.

site_title: EU could survive without Russian gas next winter: study
summary: A new report by Bruegel suggests the European Union can survive without Russian natural gas imports next winter without significant economic damage, by curtailing demand by 10-15%. This would be achieved by reducing consumption by at least that amount should Russia halt imports following its attack on Ukraine.

site_title: UOL H2 profit up 127%; proposes dividend of S$0.15 a share for FY2021
summary: UOL Group reported a 127% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$216.1 million for the second half of 2021, driven by fair value and other gains. Full-year earnings rose 2,239% to S$307.4 million, and the company proposed a dividend of 15 cents per share. Revenue grew 32% to S$2.6 billion, driven by property development and hotel operations. The company expects the residential sector to remain resilient despite cooling measures, but notes rising costs and supply chain disruption.

site_title: Airbnb to house up to 100,000 Ukrainian refugees
summary: Airbnb's non-profit arm, Airbnb.org, plans to offer free temporary housing to up to 100,000 Ukrainian refugees fleeing the country due to Russia's invasion. The company has reached out to Poland, Romania, Germany, and Hungary, which share borders with Ukraine, to provide assistance. At least 300,000 Ukrainian refugees have already entered the European Union, with millions more expected.

site_title: Govt 'will not hesitate' to give more inflation-related help to businesses, workers
summary: Singapore's government is prepared to provide additional inflation-related assistance to businesses and workers if needed, said Trade and Industry Minister Gan Kim Yong during the 2022 Budget debate. He also discussed the ongoing Russia-Ukraine crisis and its impact on the economy. Meanwhile, global economic trends are being closely monitored, with concerns over China's slowing GDP growth and the UK's shrinking economy. The Singapore government remains committed to addressing economic challenges while navigating international uncertainties.

site_title: Asian insurer FWD nears filing for US$1b IPO
summary: Asian insurer FWD Group Holdings Ltd, backed by Hong Kong billionaire Richard Li, is nearing a US$1 billion initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong, following US-China tensions that scuppered plans for an overseas debut. Sponsoring banks include Morgan Stanley, Goldman Sachs, and JPMorgan Chase. FWD's value of new business rose 11% to US$686 million in 2021, and a listing may take place within the first half of the year, depending on market volatility and investor demand. The company had previously filed for an IPO in the US, which was put on hold due to US regulatory concerns.

site_title: Singapore shares fall 1.6% due to further Western sanctions on Russia
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 1.6% on Monday, February 28, 2022, due to further Western sanctions on Russia following its attack on Ukraine. The decline was led by major banks DBS and UOB, with ST Engineering being the only top counter to rise 1.3%. The market's recovery was uneven, with decliners outnumbering advancers 277 to 224.

site_title: Glints rides on remote hiring boom, with eye towards IPO
summary: Glints, a Singapore-based startup, is expanding its hiring services to cater to the growing demand for tech talent in Southeast Asia, particularly in Vietnam and Indonesia. The company, which started as an internship matching service, has secured clients such as the Vietnam Posts and Telecommunications group and Tokopedia. Glints aims to capitalize on the booming remote hiring trend, with a potential initial public offering (IPO) on the horizon.

site_title: CIMB suffers RM280 million 'credit loss' from duplicate payments
summary: CIMB Group Holdings Bhd incurred a credit loss of RM280.9 million (S$91 million) in 2021 due to a processing error with a third-party remittance service, resulting in excess funds being deposited into customer accounts. The Malaysian lender is taking steps to recover the duplicate payments and may take an additional final provision amount in the first quarter of 2022. This technical glitch comes as South-east Asian banks face scrutiny over digital infrastructure issues.

site_title: Breaking the bias on female investors
summary: Women investors outperform their male counterparts by an average of 0.4% per year, according to a Fidelity study of 5 million US customers. A 30-year investment of $100,000 yields a $68,000 difference in favor of the female investor. Despite this data, only 9% of surveyed investors believe women are better at investing than men. Research suggests that women are more aware of risks and take a longer-term approach, focusing on goals-based investing rather than short-term performance. This deliberate approach makes women less emotional and less prone to market volatility, resulting in better investment outcomes.

site_title: BT Explains: What happens on the detachment dates of SGX SPACs?
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) will see its first batch of special purpose acquisition companies (SPACs) detach into shares and warrants in March, starting with Pegasus Asia and Vertex Technology Acquisition Corporation (VTAC) on March 7 and 14, respectively. One SPAC unit will split into one share and a fractional warrant, which can be combined into a whole warrant. Investors must hold an even number of units to ensure whole warrants. Detached units can be traded on and after the detachment date, and whole warrants can be exercised within 30 days after de-SPAC completion.

site_title: Olam posts H2 profit of S$264.9m on reorganisation-led turnaround
summary: Olam International, an agri-food giant, reported a net profit of S$264.9 million for its second half ended Dec 31, 2021, up from a loss of S$87 million a year ago. Revenue rose 29% to S$24.2 billion. The company's reorganisation plan, which includes the spin-off of three units, is on track, with Olam Food Ingredients set to list in the second quarter of 2022. Despite challenges, the group is "cautiously optimistic" about its prospects for 2022, with a strong demand for commodities and tight supply chain disruptions.

site_title: Russia bonds, now junk, set to reel from fresh sanctions on central bank
summary: Russia's bonds, now junk-rated, face fresh sanctions on the central bank, potentially drying up access to sovereign debt funding. S&P Global Ratings downgraded Russia's credit rating, while Moody's put it on review for a downgrade. US and EU sanctions on the Bank of Russia could freeze access to cash buffers and further restrict the country's banking system. Russia's biggest dollar-denominated bonds slumped 26% last week, with investors fleeing the market amid concerns about the nation's ability to service its debt. The rouble is expected to plummet further, with some analysts warning that sanctions could turn Russia's surplus into a deficit.

site_title: 13% of Russian reserves are in yuan assets
summary: China's central bank could provide a financial lifeline to Russia by selling off yuan assets held in Russian foreign exchange reserves, estimated at 13% or $77 billion. This could give Russia much-needed liquidity as Western nations impose sanctions. China is treading cautiously, with two major state-owned banks restricting financing for purchasing Russian commodities. The yuan assets could counter the impact of US and European sanctions, and China is unlikely to follow Western nations in freezing Russia's yuan assets. China's financial system, including its homegrown payments settlement system, could also provide an alternative to the Swift messaging system.

site_title: Raffles Education responds to SGX Regco; directors currently on bail to stay put
summary: RAFFLES Education has responded to SGX Regulation Company's queries, stating that it will not replace its directors currently out on bail. The company's Nomination Committee believes the ongoing investigations do not impact the directors' ability to perform their duties. The NC will redesignate current independent director Lim Siew Mun as lead independent director and appoint another independent director to provide additional oversight. The directors will continue to assist with investigations and maintain their roles.

site_title: Singapore's Feb market cap up 0.3% from Jan
summary: Singapore's total stock market value rose 0.3% in February, with the Straits Times Index (STI) increasing 0.4% to S$536.1 billion. Local banks, including OCBC, DBS, and Prudential, were among the biggest losers, with OCBC suffering the heaviest selloff. Despite geopolitical risks, blue-chip stocks saw gains, driven by safe-haven status. The agriculture and mining sectors led the gains, while electricity, gas, and water saw significant losses.

site_title: EU could survive without Russian gas next winter, says study
summary: A new report by the Belgium-based think tank Bruegel suggests the European Union can survive next winter without Russian natural gas imports, requiring a 10% reduction in demand. If Gazprom continues to meet its contractual obligations, Europe's depleted storage can be replenished before the heating season. The report highlights the EU's dependence on Russian gas and the need for improvisation to survive without it, including revising regulations, spending heavily, and making hard decisions.

site_title: Indonesia may see spike in inflation, faster interest rate hikes due to war: analysts
summary: Indonesia may experience a spike in inflation and faster interest rate hikes due to the ongoing war in Ukraine, according to analysts. The conflict is expected to disrupt global food prices and supply chains, particularly for energy and food, which could lead to inflation and interest rate hikes. Indonesia's total trade with Russia and Ukraine is less than $1 billion annually, but the country is a significant importer of wheat from the two countries. The conflict could exacerbate food insecurity in Indonesia, where 26 million people lack sufficient food consumption.

site_title: DBS, OCBC, UOB said to be cutting financing for Russian energy trades
summary: Singapore's three largest banks, DBS, OCBC, and UOB, are restricting trade financing for Russian energy trades due to uncertainty over sanctions. They have stopped issuing letters of credit in US dollars for Russian oil and liquefied natural gas, which could snarl trade and add pressure to prices. This move follows the US and EU's exclusion of energy from new sanctions, and comes as Singapore's government blocks certain Russian banks and financial transactions. The banks cited risk management obligations and minimal exposure to Russia, but the move highlights the impact of sanctions on global energy markets.

site_title: OUE reverses into black for FY2021, proposes final dividend of 1 Singapore cent per share
summary: OUE Limited reported FY2021 earnings of S$80.9 million, reversing from losses of S$343.4 million in FY2020. Revenue declined 43.3% to S$300.8 million due to lower real estate segment contributions. The company proposes a final tax-exempt dividend of 1 Singapore cent per share, totaling 2 Singapore cents per share. OUE expects an economic recovery in Singapore to be disparate across sectors, with sufficient liquidity to meet near-term debt obligations.

site_title: Singapore inflation set to rise with growth outlook clouded by Ukraine crisis: Gan
summary: Singapore's inflation is expected to rise due to the ongoing Ukraine crisis, which has clouded the country's economic outlook. The crisis may lead to higher global prices of energy and other products, affecting Singapore's energy costs and causing higher pump prices and electricity rates. The government is monitoring the situation closely and will introduce additional measures if necessary, with Trade and Industry Minister Gan Kim Yong warning that Singapore's economy is vulnerable to external shocks.

site_title: Large residential en-bloc sites can work despite cooling measures
summary: Residential en-bloc sites, despite cooling measures, can still be viable due to the potential for developers to create high-quality, leading-edge projects catering to Covid-endemic homeowners. Large sites offer more creative freedom, and projects with few units to sell have lower risk of not selling out. The government may tweak the land ABSD formula to be based on unsold units, benefiting large en-bloc sites. Successful en-bloc sales often involve a majority of strata owners cashing out at a premium, and big sites can offer better amenities and green spaces, making them more competitive in sales and marketing.

site_title: Medvedev replaces Djokovic as world No 1
summary: Daniil Medvedev has become the world's number one tennis player, surpassing Novak Djokovic after the Serb's quarter-final loss in Dubai. Medvedev, the US Open champion, is the third Russian man to hold the top spot, and the 26-year-old's rise marks a significant shift in the ATP rankings. Djokovic, who has spent a record 361 weeks as the world number one, falls to second place.

images.alt_text: Russia's Daniil Medvedev returns the ball to Spain's Rafael Nadal during their Mexico ATP Open 500 men's singles semi-final tennis match at the Arena GNP, in Acapulco, Mexico, on February 25, 2022. (Photo by PEDRO PARDO / AFP)

site_title: India's economic recovery slows amid growing external risks
summary: India's economy is growing at a slower pace than forecast, expanding 8.9% in the year ending March 31, according to the Statistics Ministry. The slowdown is attributed to the latest wave of coronavirus cases and rising external risks, including high commodity prices due to the Russia-Ukraine crisis. This may hurt investment and job creation, testing fiscal and monetary policies. Manufacturing output is expected to increase 10.5%, while mining sector growth is forecast at 12.6%, with agriculture sector growth at 3.3%.

site_title: Budget 2022: Venturing overseas and supply chain challenges
summary: The Singapore Budget 2022 introduced the Singapore Global Enterprises initiative to support local companies venturing overseas, coupled with the Singapore Global Executive Programme for talent development. Despite the pandemic, 59.7% of Singapore Chinese Chamber of Commerce and Industry members planned to venture overseas in 2021, with top markets being China, Malaysia, and Indonesia. The new initiatives aim to help local companies navigate supply chain challenges and mitigate disruptions.

site_title: Jardine C&C FY2021 profit up 22% at US$661m
summary: Jardine Cycle & Carriage (Jardine C&C) reported a 22% increase in earnings to US$661m for FY2021, driven by growth across all business units. Revenue rose 34% to US$17.7b, and underlying profit jumped 83% to US$786m. A proposed final dividend of US$0.80 per share represents an 86% increase from FY2020. The company attributes earnings growth to improved performances in its automotive, financial services, and other business units. Despite the pandemic's ongoing impact, the company remains optimistic about long-term economic prospects in South-east Asia.

site_title: Jardine Cycle & Carriage FY2021 profit rises in tandem with revenue
summary: Jardine Cycle & Carriage (J C&C) reported a 22% increase in FY2021 earnings to US$661 million and a 34% increase in revenue to US$17.7 billion. The company's underlying profit jumped 83% to US$786 million, driven by improved performances in its various business units. A proposed final dividend of US$0.62 per share brings the total dividend to US$0.80, 86% higher than in FY2020. The company remains optimistic about long-term economic prospects in South-east Asia despite the pandemic's ongoing risks.

site_title: Ho Bee Land's FY2022 earnings surge 141 per cent to S$330.5 million, proposes final dividend of 10 cents per share
summary: Ho Bee Land's FY2021 earnings surged 141% to S$330.5 million, driven by contributions from jointly controlled entities and associates, and growth in revenue from development properties and investment properties. The company proposed a final dividend of 10 cents per share. Revenue rose 61.2% to S$347.7 million, while earnings per share increased to 49.77 cents. The company's CEO, Nicholas Chua, attributed the resilience to its robust portfolio of investment properties in Singapore and London.

site_title: Fallout on global finance: ECB warns on Sberbank; Russian issuers dropped
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has warned that Sberbank Europe, a unit of Russia's Sberbank, and two other subsidiaries are at risk of failing due to a deterioration in their liquidity situation. Austria's Financial Market Authority has also imposed a moratorium on Sberbank Europe. Deutsche Boerse has suspended trading of securities from Russian issuers, while European banks are expected to open lower due to sanctions and changes in global payments systems. This move follows Russia's invasion of Ukraine and is part of a broader fallout in global finance.

site_title: Oil shipping costs soar for key routes following invasion and sanctions
summary: The escalating crisis in Ukraine has led to a surge in oil shipping costs, with freight rates doubling for routes carrying crude from Russia to China. Shipowners are offering higher rates to carry ESPO crude from Kozmino to Chinese ports, while rates for US and Persian Gulf grades have also increased. The surge in Brent crude to over $100 a barrel has boosted the incentive to take alternative routes, with US oil becoming a sought-after alternative to Russian crude. This has disrupted global commodity markets, with prices for gold, solar stocks, and other commodities also affected.

site_title: Germany's sanctions-busting pipeline foundation to be wound down
summary: Germany's public foundation to support Russia's Gazprom in evading US sanctions on the Nord Stream 2 pipeline will be wound down, announced by the premier of the German state of Mecklenburg-Vorpommern. The foundation was established last year to help Gazprom circumvent sanctions. The decision was made to pause the foundation's work and, to the extent possible, dissolve it, amid growing tensions between Russia and the US.

site_title: Malaysia's Farm Fresh seeks to raise RM1b in March IPO
summary: Malaysia's dairy producer Farm Fresh aims to raise RM1 billion through its initial public offering (IPO) in March, the largest listing in the country since June 2021. The IPO will involve an offer for sale of existing shares and a public issue of new shares, with cornerstone investors securing up to 80% of the institutional offering.
