At least 137 Ukrainians have been killed in the invasion, and Russian "sabotage groups" aim to decapitate Ukraine's government. The city is under bombardment, with missile strikes and a rocket crashing into a residential building, and residents are urged to stay indoors.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 17.83 points to 1,591.72 on Friday, with a trading volume of 3.248 billion lots worth RM2.927 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 700 to 318. The market's gains come as investors remain optimistic despite uncertainty surrounding US trade policies.

site_title: Insurance costs of shipping through Black Sea soar
summary: Insurance costs for merchant ships passing through the Black Sea have soared due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Insurers have increased the "breach" premium by 1-5% of insurance costs, adding hundreds of thousands of dollars to ship voyages. This follows the suspension of commercial shipping at Ukraine's ports and the launch of a full-blown assault on Ukraine. Freight rates have jumped, with average earnings for smaller tankers increasing to over $100,000 a day, while shipping companies, including MSC and Maersk, have suspended sailings through the region.

site_title: Haw Par H2 earnings up almost 100% to S$57.1m; board proposes S$0.15 dividend
summary: Haw Par Corporation reported a 98.4% year-on-year jump in net profit to S$57.1 million for the second half of FY2021, driven by higher consumer spending and strategic investments. Revenue rose 149.8% to S$75.3 million, while earnings per share improved to S$0.258. The company expects to benefit from the economic recovery as borders reopen, but notes that a worsening pandemic situation or geopolitical tensions may disrupt the recovery. A dividend of S$0.15 is proposed for H2 FY2021, bringing the total dividend payout for FY2021 to S$0.30.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng unit serves termination notice for Park Hotel Alexandra operator
summary: Chip Eng Seng Corporation's wholly-owned subsidiary CEL-Alexandra has served a 6-month termination notice to Park Hotel Group Management, operator of Park Hotel Alexandra. The hotel will be temporarily closed for refurbishment and rebranded under a new operator. The closure is expected to reduce revenue contribution for FY2022, but not significantly impact Chip Eng Seng's net tangible assets and earnings per share. The hotel is expected to reopen in Q1 2023.

site_title: CapitaLand Development inks MOU for S$1.3b Vietnam investment
summary: CapitaLand Development signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to invest S$1.3 billion in Vietnam, focusing on industrial parks, logistics assets, and township development. The partnership will span over 400 hectares across Bac Giang province, with plans to accelerate growth in data centers, logistics, and industrial parks over the next five years. This move reinforces CapitaLand's long-term commitment to Vietnam's economic development.

site_title: Singapore factory growth falls to single digits in January as high base starts to bite
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector experienced a slowdown in January, with factory output growing 2.0% year-on-year, below the 11.6% estimate. The electronics cluster, a key driver of the sector, inched up 0.1%, despite chip production nearing capacity. Analysts attribute the decline to a high base effect from 2020 and 2021, as well as weaker external demand due to the ongoing war in Europe. Despite this, some sectors, such as transport engineering and chemicals, are expected to contribute to growth, with manufacturing forecast to expand 4.0% in 2022.

site_title: UK says Russia plans to take whole of Ukraine but is failing
summary: British Defence Secretary Ben Wallace stated that Russia intends to take the whole of Ukraine, but failed to achieve its main objectives on the first day of President Vladimir Putin's invasion. The Russian army lost over 450 personnel and missiles pounded the Ukrainian capital. Wallace described Putin's actions as illogical and criticized the Russian claim that Ukraine is an illegitimate state. The UK has unveiled its toughest sanctions yet on Russia and is pushing allies to cut off Russia from the SWIFT global interbank payments system.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rebound from Ukraine sell-off
summary: Europe's major stock markets rebounded by over 1% in opening deals on Friday, Feb 25, following a slump the previous day due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Frankfurt stocks rallied 1.3%, London gained 1.3%, and Paris rose 1.1%. The rebound is attributed to gains in mining and healthcare shares, with US-EU trade talks also in focus.

site_title: India's Bharti Airtel to buy 4.7% stake in Indus Towers from Vodafone
summary: Bharti Airtel to acquire a 4.7% stake in Indus Towers from Vodafone Group for an undisclosed price, with proceeds to be infused back into Vodafone Idea. The deal follows India's telecoms market changes, including Reliance Industries' Jio Infocomm's launch in 2016, forcing several rivals out of the market. Debt-laden Vodafone Idea has paid 78.54 billion rupees in dues but still owes 500 billion rupees.

images.alt_text: Indian telecom operator Bharti Airtel said on Friday (Feb 25) it would buy a 4.7 per cent stake in cell tower firm Indus Towers from Vodafone Group.

site_title: Fuel pump prices up again, by up to S$0.08 in less than 2 weeks
summary: Fuel pump prices in Singapore have increased again, with Esso seeing the largest jump of 8 cents per liter over the past 10 days. Caltex and Shell also raised their prices, with 92-octane fuel increasing by 7 cents per liter. The price hike is attributed to the rise in crude oil prices, which have shot above US$105 a barrel following Russia's attack on Ukraine.

site_title: Chinese firm to build Covid facilities as Hong Kong infections spiral
summary: Hong Kong has contracted a Chinese firm to build 8 isolation and treatment facilities with a combined capacity of 50,000 beds to combat the worsening Covid-19 outbreak. The facilities, to be completed as soon as possible, will be spread across the city, including on private land lent for free. This move comes as daily cases in Hong Kong surged beyond 10,000, a new record, in a bid to maximize site utilization and equip the city for the fight against the epidemic.

site_title: Russian invasion of Ukraine 'justified', says Myanmar junta
summary: The Myanmar junta has backed Russia's invasion of Ukraine, calling it "justified" for the sustainability of Russia's sovereignty. The junta's statement, made in support of major ally Russia, comes amid international outrage over the invasion and sanctions imposed by the US and its allies. The junta has also received military aid from Russia, including fighter jets and armoured vehicles, despite a bloody crackdown on dissent in Myanmar, resulting in over 1,500 civilian deaths since the coup last year.

site_title: China's anti-graft body criticises central bank, regulators
summary: China's top disciplinary watchdog criticized over 2 dozen financial regulators, state banks, insurers, and bad debt managers for failing to meet the Communist Party's objectives, citing gaps in implementing major strategies, insufficient awareness, and slow progress in financial reforms. The criticism comes amid a wave of property sector defaults and ongoing focus on financial risks. The investigation's findings suggest a need for improvement in preventing financial risks and implementing reforms.

site_title: Ophthalmology: Looking on the bright side
summary: New options in vision correction treatment have emerged in the past two years, driven by the need for elective procedures to be performed during the pandemic. Advances include new eye treatments such as injections for macula diseases and devices like lens and glaucoma drainage implants. In the field of cataract surgery, improved lens designs have increased effectiveness, and laser-assisted cataract surgery has shown benefits in surgical uniformity and minimizing collateral damage. New laser vision correction treatments, such as the Clear treatment for myopia/short-sightedness and astigmatism, have also been introduced, offering improved customization and alternatives to traditional methods.

site_title: Isetan Singapore's managing director to resign in April
summary: Isetan Singapore's managing director, Koji Oyama, will resign in April after the company's annual general meeting. Oyama will step down to take on an executive role in Isetan Mitsukoshi Holdings, the holding company for Mitsukoshi and Isetan department stores. He will remain at Isetan until a new managing director is appointed. The company has not announced the identity of the new managing director yet.

site_title: SPH selling sgCarMart to Toyota consortium for S$150 million
summary: SPH is selling its automotive marketplace sgCarMart to a Toyota consortium for S$150 million. The deal includes sgCarMart's intellectual property and subsidiaries Quotz and Quotz (Taiwan), valued at S$150 million. The acquisition is a result of SPH's efforts to divest assets as part of its capital recycling initiatives. sgCarMart has been profitable for the past 5 years, with over 4 million users and contributing to 70% of second-hand car transactions in Singapore.

site_title: Kiwi house price rises to halt this year, Australia to follow in 2023: survey
summary: New Zealand's house prices are expected to decline by 1.0% this year due to rising interest rates and wages failing to keep pace with living costs. The country's property market, the least affordable among OECD nations, will slow down after a record 30% rise over the past year. Australia's house prices, which have nearly doubled since 2007, are forecast to rise 6.7% this year before falling 5% in 2023 as interest rates increase. Higher interest rates will put a dent in housing demand, shifting the balance of power towards buyers.

images.alt_text: A multi-year boom in house prices based on near-zero interest rates has gifted homeowners with record piles of equity but is pushing the dream of home ownership further out of reach for first-time buyers, especially those on lower incomes.

site_title: Venture Corp H2 2021 net profit rises 2.9%
summary: Venture Corp reported a 2.9% increase in H1 2021 net profit to S$171.7 million, driven by diversified growth across technology domains. Revenue rose 1.7% to S$1.68 billion. Earnings per share increased to S$0.591. The company proposed a final dividend of S$0.50 per share, with a total dividend for the year of S$0.75. Full-year net profit rose 5% to S$312.1 million, with net profit margins at 10%. Cash flow from operations fell due to negative trade receivables and inventories.

site_title: Hiap Hoe back in the black for H2 FY21, posts S$13.8m net profit
summary: Hiap Hoe, a Singaporean property developer, reported a net profit of S$13.8 million for the 6 months ended Dec 31, 2021, compared to a loss of S$15.6 million in the same period last year. Revenue increased by 32% to S$48.3 million, driven by a 30.7% rise in hotel operations. The company reversed impairment losses of S$15.6 million and S$3.3 million, boosting other income. For the full year 2021, net profit was S$21.2 million, a significant improvement from a net loss of S$36.8 million in 2020.

site_title: Hong Kong's first SPAC wins exchange approval for IPO, sources say
summary: Hong Kong's first special purpose acquisition company (SPAC), Aquila Acquisition, has won approval for an initial public offering (IPO) worth approximately $300 million. The funds will be used to acquire a tech-enabled company in the "new economy" sectors. This marks the first SPAC listing in Hong Kong, following the release of the city's rulebook for blank-check companies in December. The approval comes as Hong Kong struggles to cope with the ongoing Covid-19 outbreak and a slowdown in global IPOs.

images.alt_text: A blank-check company backed by China Merchants Bank's overseas asset management arm has become the first to win approval for an initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong, according to people familiar with the matter.

site_title: Singapore services receipts up 15.4% in Q4, higher than pre-Covid figures
summary: Singapore's services industries saw a 15.4% year-on-year increase in business receipts for the fourth quarter, surpassing pre-Covid figures. This growth was also higher than the 7.2% quarter-on-quarter increase. The fourth quarter's business receipts were the highest since the fourth quarter of 2019, before the pandemic.

site_title: Man faces charge for helping Ng Yu Zhi leave Singapore unlawfully while under probe
summary: A Singaporean man, Ang Yew Teck, faces charges for obstructing justice by offering to help businessman Ng Yu Zhi leave the country unlawfully while under investigation for a $1.1 billion nickel trading scam. Ng, director of Envy Asset Management, is currently under investigation and faces 93 charges. Ang allegedly offered Ng plans to leave Singapore in August 2021, committing an act that has a tendency to obstruct the course of justice.

site_title: Five taxi operators lodge fare adjustments with PTC, following hikes by CDG announced 2 weeks ago
summary: Five Singapore taxi operators, including Trans-Cab and Prime Taxi, have lodged fare increases with the Public Transport Council (PTC), following a fare hike by ComfortDelGro (CDG) in February. The operators cited rising fuel prices and inflation as reasons for the fare adjustments, which are expected to take effect in March 2022.

site_title: Hong Kong's Omicron-fuelled outbreak spreads within prisons
summary: Hong Kong's prisons are experiencing a worsening coronavirus outbreak fueled by the Omicron variant, with over 200 inmates infected and more than 7,200 people detained. The city's COVID-19 wave, which has seen thousands of cases daily, has overwhelmed hospitals and government efforts to isolate infected individuals. The outbreak has breached the city's prisons, where visitors have been suspended and one facility converted to isolate infected prisoners. The situation highlights the challenges of Hong Kong's "zero-Covid" strategy in the face of the highly transmissible Omicron variant.

images.alt_text: The Tai Lam Centre for Women in Hong Kong. Prison visits have been suspended since the beginning of February, while one correctional facility was converted to isolate infected prisoners.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's factory output growth slowed sharply to 2% in January, below expectations. Services receipts rose 15.4% year on year for the fourth quarter, higher than pre-Covid figures. Taxi fares are set to increase after five operators lodged fare adjustments with the Public Transport Council. Visitor arrivals and hotel takings declined in January due to tightened border restrictions. Online marketplace sgCarMart is being sold to a Toyota consortium for S$160 million. Singapore shares rebounded 0.6% on Friday, driven by Wall Street's overnight reversal.

images.alt_text: Jurong Island, as seen from Singapore's mainland. Chemicals output fell year on year in January, despite higher petroleum refining throughput.

site_title: Toyota agrees to union's pay hike demands
summary: Toyota Motor has accepted labor union pay demands, with CEO Akio Toyoda stating the offer "fully met the union's demands" during annual wage negotiations. The agreement was made with Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's backing, amid government calls for firms to lift wages. The exact size of the pay rise has not been disclosed.

site_title: Plastic treaty would be historic for planet: UNEP chief
summary: The world is on the cusp of a historic plastics treaty, with over 50 countries backing a legally binding agreement to tackle plastic trash. The treaty, being negotiated in Nairobi, aims to limit plastic production, phase out single-use products, and curb litter. UN Environment Programme chief Inger Andersen says it's a "big moment" and "one for the history books," but notes that addressing the source of plastic pollution is crucial. The treaty's framework is still being hammered out, with a two-year process expected to finalize the terms, and the goal is to prevent 400 million tonnes of new plastic from being manufactured annually by 2040.

site_title: 2 more Evergrande property assets taken over by state-owned firms
summary: China Evergrande Group has seen two more property assets taken over by state-owned enterprises (SOEs), according to corporate registry records. These developments come as the company struggles with over $300 billion in liabilities. The assets include a theme park in Guangzhou and a residential development in Guangdong province, which were transferred to Minmetals International Trust Co and China Everbright Group, respectively. The takeovers are part of Beijing's efforts to ease liquidity pressure on cash-strapped real estate firms by encouraging SOEs to acquire their assets.

site_title: Singapore companies remain keen on Vietnam amid pandemic, with Singapore as largest foreign investor: Tan See Leng
summary: Singapore remains a keen investor in Vietnam, with nearly US$10.7 billion in foreign direct investment in 2021, accounting for 34.4% of Vietnam's total foreign capital investments. The country's bilateral trade with Vietnam saw a 18.7% increase in 2021, reaching S$26.9 billion. Ten Vietnam-Singapore Industrial Parks have attracted US$15.6 billion in investments and created over 290,000 jobs. A memorandum of understanding on economic and trade cooperation was signed between Vietnam's Ministry of Industry and Trade and Singapore's Ministry of Trade and Industry to enhance collaboration in the digital economy and facilitate business partnerships.

site_title: Sembcorp, Keppel ink 6 agreements with Vietnam partners to develop energy, urbanisation solutions
summary: Sembcorp and Keppel have signed six agreements with Vietnamese partners to support the country's energy transition and sustainable development. The agreements cover energy solutions, urban development, and innovation centers, with a focus on smart grids, renewable energy, and sustainable technologies. The collaborations aim to enhance efficiency, reliability, and adoption of industry 4.0 technology in Vietnam's manufacturing industry. The partnerships are expected to promote sustainable development and accelerate the adoption of green technologies in Vietnam.

site_title: Singapore visitor arrivals fall month on month to 57,140 in January; hotel takings down
summary: Singapore's international visitor numbers dropped 38.4% to 57,140 in January, with hotel takings falling 23.1% to S$101.2 million, compared to the previous month. This decline is attributed to tightened border restrictions amid the Omicron variant. Despite this, hotel industry takings were still up 43.9% year-on-year.

site_title: China Aviation Oil H2 profit falls 50.8% to US$16.1m despite higher revenue
summary: China Aviation Oil (CAO) reported a net profit of US$16.1 million for the second half of FY2021, down 50.8% from US$32.6 million in the same period last year. Revenue grew 74.1% to US$8.95 billion, driven by higher oil prices and volume. However, the decline in net profit was attributed to decreased gross profit and associate results, impacted by the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Singapore shares rebound on Friday; STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.6% on Friday, driven by a surprise overnight reversal on Wall Street, as sanctions on Russia were not as severe as expected. The Straits Times Index ended at 3,294.47, with Sembcorp Industries, Singtel, and Singapore Airlines leading the gains. Investors are cautious, waiting to see how events unfold over the weekend, with managing partner Stephen Innes noting markets are not yet in "investing mode".

site_title: Australia imposes more sanctions on Russia, criticises China's response
summary: Australia imposed additional sanctions on Russia, targeting elite citizens and lawmakers, amid criticism of China's easing trade restrictions with Moscow. The sanctions, announced by Prime Minister Scott Morrison, aim to increase pressure on Russia. Morrison described China's decision as "unacceptable" and called for a stronger response to Russia's invasion of Ukraine. New Zealand also imposed targeted travel bans and prohibited goods trade with Russia.

site_title: Singapore factory output growth slows sharply to 2% in January, below expectations
summary: Singapore's factory output growth slowed sharply to 2% in January, below expectations of 11.6%. The slowdown was attributed to a contraction in the biomedical cluster, with a 10.6% year-on-year decline in biological products output. Excluding biomedical manufacturing, overall factory production was up 4.7%. Despite this, other manufacturing clusters, such as general manufacturing and precision engineering, posted double-digit growth. Economists attributed the slowdown to the high production base from a year ago, but noted that industrial production was otherwise stable.

site_title: Airline industry shifts attention to Russia risks after Ukraine closure
summary: Airlines are shifting attention to Russia risks amid the Ukraine crisis, with some routes closed and others facing potential safety concerns. Japan Airlines cancelled a flight to Moscow, while Britain closed airspace to Russian airlines, including Aeroflot. Airlines are assessing contingency plans and making minor routing changes to avoid impacted airspace, with Emirates reporting slightly longer flight times. The conflict's impact on the industry is expected to be felt beyond Ukraine, with concerns over sanctions, oil prices, and disruptions to dealings with Russian companies.

site_title: US$300b Russia cash pile can roil money markets, says Credit Suisse strategist
summary: Russia holds approximately $300 billion in foreign currency offshore, enough to disrupt global money markets if frozen by sanctions or moved suddenly to avoid them, according to Credit Suisse strategist Zoltan Pozsar. This liquid wealth, combined with Russia's vast financial surpluses, could impact FX swaps and US dollar Libor fixings. The Bank of Russia's US dollar exposure is estimated to be around 50% of its total, and Russia has almost $1 trillion of liquid wealth, with a significant portion held in US dollars. This could substantially shift funding markets if Russia's currency holdings are affected.

site_title: Bank of International Settlements rolls out Asian green bond fund
summary: The Bank for International Settlements (BIS) launched a new Asian Green Bond Fund to help finance environmentally friendly projects in the Asia-Pacific region, which is prone to natural disasters. The fund, open to central banks worldwide, invests in US dollar-denominated green bonds issued by Asian governments, institutions, and companies. With a combined $3.5 billion in green bonds, the fund aims to promote greening of economies in the region and assess climate risk accurately to prevent financial stability risks. The fund will conduct annual reviews to adapt to changing global green finance landscape.

site_title: Amazon's India partner Samara Capital plans US$500m fund
summary: Samara Capital, an India-focused private equity firm and Amazon's local partner, plans to raise up to $500 million for a new fund targeting companies in Asia's third-largest economy. The fund will invest in businesses such as retail, healthcare, technology, and finance, with a focus on consumer markets. Samara aims to close the fund in the second half of 2022 and plans to invest $50 million to $400 million in mid-market companies for a controlling stake.

site_title: British house prices to continue rising even as BOE hikes rates: poll
summary: A Reuters poll of 18 property market experts found that British house prices are expected to rise 4.0% this year and 3.0% next year despite the Bank of England's interest rate hikes, which are expected to increase borrowing costs for home buyers. Experts cited a lack of supply and the ongoing trend of remote working as factors contributing to sustained house price growth. The median forecast for the bank rate to reach 1.50% this year to significantly slow housing market activity was not met, with only 4 economists predicting it would reach that level.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end higher, mark worst week in 4 on Ukraine crisis
summary: South Korean stocks closed 1% higher on Friday, rebounding from a 1-month low, but marking their worst week in four due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The Kospi index rose 27.96 points, or 1.06%, to 2,676.76. The benchmark index has lost 10.1% so far this year. US President Joe Biden imposed new sanctions on Russia, while South Korea's exports are expected to increase for a 16th month in February. Foreigners were net sellers of 122 billion won worth of shares, and the won ended 0.07% higher against the dollar.

site_title: Australia: Shares end week 3% lower with Ukraine crisis in focus
summary: Australia's shares ended the week 3.1% lower, their worst since October 2020, due to the Ukraine crisis and investor caution. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed 0.1% higher on Friday after US President Joe Biden imposed more sanctions on Russia. Technology stocks surged 8.1%, with Block leading the rally, while domestic gold stocks slid 4% and financial stocks lost 1%. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to raise interest rates for the first time in over a decade in the July to September quarter.

site_title: Six new directors appointed to board of SPH Media Holdings
summary: SPH Media Holdings has appointed six new directors to its board, joining Patrick Daniel, with SMT chair Khaw Boon Wan as chairman and Teo Lay Lim as deputy chairman. This move comes as the holding company of SPH Media Group oversees corporate and operational aspects. The new directors will work alongside existing directors to make key decisions for the company. The appointments were made in accordance with the company's governance structure.

site_title: Riot Games expands publishing business with new Apac offices
summary: Riot Games, a Tencent-owned game developer, has announced plans to expand its publishing business in the Asia-Pacific (Apac) region by opening new offices in the Philippines, India, Indonesia/Malaysia, and Thailand. The company has appointed Alex Kraynov as its new managing director for Apac, with a focus on hyper-localization and diversifying its operating model. Riot aims to establish a strong presence in the region, with plans to grow its leadership team and appoint country managers for Thailand and India. This move is seen as a natural step in progression for Riot's publishing business in the region.

images.alt_text: Riot's most recently published game titles include Valorant, League of Legends: Wild Rift and Legends of Runeterra.

site_title: HDB launches 7th solar tender for 1,290 blocks and 99 government sites
summary: The Housing Development Board (HDB) launched its 7th solar tender, offering a 75 MWp solar capacity for 1,290 HDB blocks and 99 government sites. The tender, part of the SolarNova programme, aims to accelerate solar deployment in Singapore and meets the HDB's target of 540 MWp of solar PV capacity by 2030. Installation of solar PV systems is expected to be completed by 2025, with 21 government organisations joining the programme. The tender will also require the installation of smart electrical sub-meters to monitor energy consumption patterns.

images.alt_text: The 1,290 blocks, which will be located in areas under the Bishan-Toa Payoh, Tanjong Pagar and Jurong-Clementi Town Councils, will have a combined solar capacity of 50.5 MWp.

site_title: Gold rises with Russia-Ukraine situation in focus
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to $1,909.06 per ounce on Friday, steadying after a volatile session amidst the Russia-Ukraine situation and fresh sanctions against Moscow. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy vowed to stay in Kyiv as Russian invaders advance on the capital. US President Joe Biden imposed sanctions, impeding Russia's ability to do business in major currencies. Commodity prices surged on Thursday, driven by prospects of tighter supplies and transport disruptions.

site_title: Companies shut Ukraine operations, assess impact of sanctions on Russia
summary: Companies have shut operations in Ukraine due to Russia's invasion, including Carlsberg, Japan Tobacco, and a Coca-Cola bottler. UPS and FedEx suspended services in and out of the country. Western sanctions have been imposed on Russia, including measures to impede its ability to do business in major currencies and block access to key technologies and markets. Shares in companies with significant exposure to Russia, such as Uniper and BASF, have plummeted. The conflict may impact supplies of key raw materials and disrupt global shipping, with companies like Maersk and DSV halting operations in Ukraine.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares track Wall Street higher, tech shines
summary: Japanese shares rose 1.95% on Friday, snapping a 5-session losing streak, led by technology stocks. The Nikkei ended at 26,476.50, while the Topix gained 1% but fell 2.5% for the week. The market followed a sharp rebound on Wall Street, where US stocks surged 3% overnight, driven by a 3% gain in the Nasdaq, following US President Joe Biden's new sanctions against Moscow.

site_title: Asia: Shares track Wall Street rally; markets eye long-term Ukraine risk
summary: Asian shares rebounded on Friday, following a Wall Street rally, as US President Joe Biden imposed harsh sanctions on Russia for its invasion of Ukraine. The MSCI Asia-Pacific index rose 0.68%, while Japan's Nikkei and Hong Kong's Hang Seng added 1.53% and 0.16%, respectively. Oil prices rose due to concerns about supply disruptions, while gold prices fell as investors sought safe haven. Analysts warn that any rallies might be fleeting, with a protracted conflict expected to add to global inflationary pressures.

site_title: Japan will strengthen sanctions against Russia, target banks
summary: Japan will strengthen sanctions against Russia, targeting financial institutions and military equipment exports, following a similar move by the US. The sanctions will be imposed immediately and will also include individuals. Japan aims to limit the economic impact on itself, ensuring a stable energy supply, and will step up measures to control rising fuel prices. The country has approximately 240 days' worth of crude oil reserves.

site_title: Malaysia ex-central bank chief's husband denies 1MDB bribe
summary: Malaysia's former central bank chief Zeti Akhtar Aziz's husband, Tawfiq Ayman, has denied receiving bribes in connection with the 1MDB scandal. Tawfiq stated he never received any bribe throughout his life, after being implicated by former Goldman Sachs banker Tim Leissner. Tawfiq claimed not to know Leissner or his subordinate Roger Ng, and had never met or communicated with them. He plans to seek legal advice on the next course of action.

images.alt_text: Tawfiq Ayman spoke after Tim Leissner, an ex-Goldman Sachs Group banker, said Tawfiq had been bribed before a large sum of money was transferred in connection with the scandal, according to the report.

site_title: China's property market expected to rebound this year: poll
summary: China's property market is expected to rebound this year after a soft start in the first half due to a liquidity crunch and COVID-19 outbreaks. Analysts predict a 1% decline in average home prices in the first half, but a 2% increase for the full year. Authorities have introduced measures to boost sales and sentiment, including easing credit conditions and regulatory policies. Property transactions in first- and second-tier cities are expected to be better than third- and fourth-tier cities, with demand predicted to slump 14% in the first half.

site_title: Canada clears world's first plant-based Covid vaccine
summary: Canada has approved the world's first plant-derived COVID-19 vaccine, Covifenz, developed by Medicago and GlaxoSmithKline. The vaccine, made from plant-grown proteins, has been shown to be 71% effective against multiple variants of the virus. It will be available for adults aged 18-64 and offers a novel option for those hesitant to take traditional vaccines. The approval aims to boost vaccination rates in countries struggling with low rates. Medicago has secured a contract with the Canadian government for up to 76 million doses and is in talks with other countries for potential agreements.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks flat at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened marginally higher on February 25, 2022, following a Ukraine-induced sell-off the previous day. The Hang Seng Index rose 6.54 points to 22,908.10, while the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.45% and the Shenzhen Composite Index rose 0.85%. The increase was attributed to softer-than-expected sanctions on Russia.

site_title: SEC probes Elon Musk, brother Kimbal over Tesla share sales
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) is investigating whether Tesla CEO Elon Musk and his brother Kimbal Musk violated insider trading rules by selling shares of the electric carmaker. Kimbal Musk sold $108 million worth of Tesla shares a day before Elon Musk polled Twitter users on selling 10% of his stake. The investigation began last year, and Elon Musk has previously accused the SEC of harassing him. This probe escalates Musk's battle with regulators, who are also scrutinizing his social media posts and Tesla's treatment of workers.

site_title: Indonesia to start making mRNA vaccines with WHO tech transfer
summary: Indonesia is set to start producing its own mRNA vaccines, following a technology transfer from the World Health Organisation (WHO). State company Bio Farma, one of the region's largest vaccine manufacturers, will produce doses after being chosen as a vaccine hub in South-east Asia. The move aims to empower Indonesia's self-reliance in vaccine production, addressing a significant shortage in the country. With a capacity to produce 3.2 billion doses a year, Indonesia hopes to inoculate its 270 million population and supply neighboring countries.

site_title: Energy at the frontline of global economic war caused by Russia-Ukraine crisis
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin has launched a global economic war by invading Ukraine, causing energy prices to rise and economic sanctions to be imposed on Russia. The US, Germany, and other Western countries have responded with economic sanctions, including freezing Nord Stream 2 pipeline and imposing price controls on natural gas. Russia's energy sector is expected to suffer, with Gazprom shares falling by over 30% and oil prices trading above $100 a barrel. The economic war is likely to have a significant impact on global markets, with stocks selling off heavily and interest rates potentially being raised to combat inflation.

site_title: Broom sweeps up US$3m funding for Indonesian auto-financing business
summary: Broom, an Indonesian startup, has secured US$3 million in pre-seed funding led by AC Ventures, Quona Capital, and founders of Kopi Kenangan and Lummo. The platform, which provides financial solutions for auto dealer inventories, plans to roll out new products and services, expand its presence in major cities, and double its team by 2022. With 2,000 used car dealerships on board, Broom aims to tap into the US$14 billion annual transaction value of the used car industry, particularly targeting micro, small and medium enterprises with limited access to affordable financing.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 7.39 points or 0.47% to 1,581.28 on Friday, driven by gains. Volume was 94.8 million lots worth RM64.2 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 248 to 89.

site_title: EV company Rivian 'making progress' on production ramp-up, sets market share goal
summary: Rivian Automotive CEO RJ Scaringe stated the company is making progress in increasing production at its Illinois assembly plant, which is starting to ramp up. Rivian aims to take a 10% share in the electric vehicle market by 2030. The company idled the plant for the first 10 days of January to make changes and boost output. Following this, shares closed up 10.7% at $63.71.

site_title: Brokers' take: RHB downgrades EC World Reit to 'neutral'; DBS lowers target
summary: RHB downgraded EC World Reit to 'neutral' from 'trading buy', lowering its target price to S$0.76 from S$0.87 due to high yield and limited downside potential. Analyst Vijay Natarajan cited minimal medium-term catalysts and potential risks such as tighter regulations and a challenging macro environment.

site_title: Doctors, nurses struggle to cope as Covid-19 patients flock to A&E depts
summary: Doctors and nurses in Singapore's A&E departments are struggling to cope with a surge of Covid-19 patients, many with mild or no symptoms, overwhelming hospital resources. Despite the Ministry of Health's efforts to ease pressure by opening free test centers, patients continue to flood A&E departments, stretching waiting times and straining manpower. Healthcare workers express frustration with patients who display an "entitled" attitude, demanding immediate attention despite not requiring it. The situation has led to increased wait times, workload, and mental stress among healthcare staff, highlighting the need for patients to be more understanding and cooperative.

site_title: E-scooter startup Beam secures US$93m in Series B funding
summary: Beam, an e-scooter sharing company, secured US$93 million in Series B funding led by Affirma Capital. The funding will be used to expand into Asia-Pacific, introducing new shared micro-mobility vehicles and safety technologies, including the fifth-generation Beam Saturn e-scooter with improved safety features. The company plans to deploy its Mars technology, which enhances control of city spaces and encourages safer usage, in new markets such as Japan, Indonesia, and Turkey. Beam aims to bring lower-cost, greener, and safer mobility to cities across the Asia-Pacific region.

images.alt_text: Beam has secured US$93 million in Series B funding led by private equity firm Affirma Capital, the e-scooter sharing company announced on Friday (Feb 25).

site_title: Volkswagen, top shareholder strike framework deal for Porsche IPO
summary: Volkswagen and Porsche SE have agreed on a framework deal for a potential listing of Porsche AG through an initial public offering (IPO). The deal would see Porsche's share capital split into preferred and ordinary shares, with up to 12.5% of the total share capital placed on the market. Ordinary shares would not be publicly listed, and the deal would give Porsche more entrepreneurial freedom while maintaining group synergies. Volkswagen would buy 25% of Porsche's ordinary shares, and shareholders would receive 49% of the gross proceeds from the sale of preferred and ordinary shares.

site_title: Nomura to further expand its Singapore and Hong Kong wealth hubs
summary: Nomura Holdings plans to further expand its wealth management business in Singapore and Hong Kong, targeting the growing pool of affluent Asian clients. The firm has already hired over 50 relationship managers and aims to manage $25-35 billion in assets by 2025. Head of Nomura's international wealth management unit Ravi Raju credits external studies showing Asia's wealth growth at 8-10% per year. Despite not being in the top 20 ranks of private banks in Asia, Nomura is doubling down on its expansion efforts, with plans to hire another 50 relationship managers and potentially expand into Dubai as a marketing center.

site_title: Motor racing: Leclerc puts Ferrari top of F1 testing timesheets
summary: Charles Leclerc led Ferrari to the top of Formula One testing timesheets with a lap time of 1:19.689 seconds on the second day of testing in Barcelona. He was followed by Pierre Gasly for AlphaTauri and Daniel Ricciardo for McLaren. Ferrari and McLaren emerged as the most promising contenders in the sport's new era, with Ferrari leading the mileage charts for the second day in a row. Other top performers included Lando Norris for McLaren and Carlos Sainz for Ferrari.

site_title: Singapore stocks climb at Friday's open; STI up 1.6%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.6% to 3,328.30, driven by gains in US stocks after President Joe Biden unveiled harsh sanctions against Russia. The most actively traded counters were Disa 532 and Singapore Telecommunications, while local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC also saw gains. European stocks hit 9-month lows, and Asian markets followed, with Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index climbing 0.9%.

site_title: Hot stock: Samudera Shipping up 27% after declaring high FY21 special dividend
summary: Samudera Shipping Line declared a special dividend of S$0.1275 per share, resulting in a 27% surge in its shares to an all-time high of S$0.73. The company posted a net profit of US$128.6 million for FY2021, driven by higher freight rates in its container shipping segment. Analysts believe the special dividend may indicate the company's limited growth potential due to its asset-light capital structure. Freight rates are expected to decline in FY2022, and deliveries of newly built vessels may alleviate supply chain bottlenecks.

site_title: US hits major Russian banks with sanctions over invasion of Ukraine
summary: The US has imposed sanctions on Russia in response to its invasion of Ukraine, targeting its two largest banks, Sberbank and VTB, as well as wealthy individuals and their families. The US Treasury Department has severed correspondent banking ties with Sberbank and its subsidiaries, aiming to hurt the Russian economy. The sanctions also include restrictions on US persons dealing in Russian sovereign debt and equity. Washington has warned that further sanctions are possible if Russia escalates its aggression against Ukraine, with a senior administration official stating that "we still have all options on the table."

site_title: Why Russia and Ukraine are fighting for Chernobyl disaster site
summary: Russian forces have taken control of the Chernobyl disaster site, sparking a dispute with Ukraine over the strategic location of the still-radioactive site. The area's proximity to Ukraine's capital, Kyiv, and its role as a key invasion route for Russian troops make it a significant factor in the ongoing conflict. Western military analysts argue that the capture of Chernobyl is not to protect it from further damage, but rather to advance Russia's invasion strategy, which also includes attacks on other Ukrainian cities.

site_title: Amazon accused of violating US labour law after union supporters' arrests
summary: Amazon is facing a US labor law charge after a group of workers, the Amazon Labor Union, alleged the company violated a settlement reached with the National Labor Relations Board. The charge claims Amazon arrested union supporters, including organizer Christian Smalls, outside a warehouse in New York. The alleged retaliation comes ahead of a vote at the JFK8 Staten Island warehouse, where workers will decide whether to form a union. The Amazon Labor Union is also challenging Amazon's interference in the upcoming election at its Bessemer, Alabama warehouse.

site_title: Ukraine's president vows to stay put as Russian invaders approach
summary: Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelenskiy vowed to remain in Kyiv as Russian invaders advanced on the capital, with the US and Ukrainian officials saying Russia aims to capture the city and topple the government. Russian troops seized the Chernobyl nuclear power plant north of Kyiv, and an estimated 100,000 people fled as explosions and gunfire rocked major cities. The US and European Union imposed harsh sanctions on Russia, with China facing pressure for not calling the invasion an invasion. At least 137 military personnel and civilians have been killed, and hundreds wounded, with Ukrainian forces downing a Russian aircraft over Kyiv.

site_title: Alpha DX receives S$1.9m letter of demand from vendor
summary: Alpha DX Group has received a letter of demand from Kydon Holdings for S$1.9 million, related to the acquisition of Kydon Learning Systems Institute (KLSI) in 2020 for S$12 million. The amount includes remaining consideration and interest charges. Alpha DX is in negotiations with Kydon and is assessing the claims. If the sum is not paid by Feb 28, Kydon plans to commence legal proceedings and hold Alpha DX liable for costs. The company's shares ended flat at S$0.153.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS prefers Sea amid market share competition with Grab, GoTo
summary: DBS Group Research has upgraded Sea to a "buy" call with a target price of US$272, citing growing e-commerce and delivery businesses. Analyst Sachin Mittal expects Sea's e-commerce business to break even in the second half of 2022. In contrast, DBS downgraded Grab to a "hold" call, lowering its target price to US$5.60, citing concerns over slowing earnings growth in the second half.

images.alt_text: Internet company Sea will likely gain from its growing e-commerce and delivery businesses, although at the cost of Grab and GoTo, DBS Group Research said.

site_title: Facebook, Twitter highlight security steps for users in Ukraine
summary: Facebook and Twitter have taken security steps for users in Ukraine amid the ongoing conflict. Facebook set up a special operations centre to monitor the conflict and launched a feature to lock user profiles for security. Twitter posted safety tips in multiple languages, including English, Russian, and Ukrainian, to help users secure their accounts against hacking and spread of disinformation.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Capitaland Investment, ST Engineering, CDL, AEM, First Resources
summary: Key companies reported financial results, including CapitaLand Investment (net profit of S$647 million for the second half of 2021), ST Engineering (net profit of S$274.4 million for the six months), City Developments Limited (net profit of S$129.7 million for the second half), First Resources (H2 profit of US$128.6 million), and Singapore Airlines (net profit of S$85 million for the third quarter). These developments may affect trading of their securities.

site_title: SingPost's Q3 operating profit rises 46% to S$38m
summary: SingPost reported a 46% year-on-year increase in Q3 operating profit to S$38 million, driven by seasonal peak and e-commerce logistics growth. Revenue grew 24% to S$437 million, while group operating expenses rose 23% to S$400 million. The company's domestic post and parcel e-commerce logistics segment saw a 50% increase in volumes. SingPost is pressing on with its Future of Post initiative to capture e-commerce growth in Singapore and is working towards integrating its international operations.

site_title: Dell expects PC backlog to balloon in Q1 amid supply chain snarls
summary: Dell Technologies expects a significant PC backlog in Q1 due to global supply chain constraints and a pandemic-fueled demand for PCs. The company reported a quarterly profit miss and lower-than-expected earnings, with shares down 7% in extended trading. Revenue surged 16% to $28 billion in the fourth quarter, but longer lead times and parts shortages have led to higher component and freight costs. Dell's finance chief attributed the higher opex as a percentage of revenue to investments in the business.

site_title: Ukraine shuts ports as conflict threatens grain supplies
summary: Ukraine has suspended commercial shipping at its ports due to the ongoing conflict with Russia, which could disrupt global grain supplies. Russia has closed the Azov Sea to commercial vessels, but its ports in the Black Sea remain open. Global grain exporters are concerned about the impact on Ukraine's exports of corn, wheat, and barley, which are mainly destined for China and the European Union. The conflict has already led to cancellations of international purchasing tenders for wheat and has halted port calls in Ukraine, with shipping companies including Maersk and Bunge shutting operations.

site_title: Beyond Meat shares fall on dimmer than expected forecasts
summary: Beyond Meat's shares fell after the company reported annual revenue below estimates, with forecasted revenue of $560-620 million, down from analyst estimates of $637.3 million. The company attributed the decline to increased competition and flat demand for plant-based protein. Sales to US grocers and retailers declined 19.5% in the fourth quarter, and the company posted a larger-than-expected loss of $1.27 per share. Despite this, CEO Ethan Brown expressed optimism that growth should resume this year, citing partnerships and new product launches.

site_title: Three Russian banks shrug off impact of US sanctions after Ukraine invasion
summary: Three Russian banks, including Sberbank, Gazprombank, and Alfa-Bank, have downplayed the impact of US sanctions imposed after Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The US Treasury has restricted US banks from serving them, while Britain has imposed asset freezes. However, the Russian central bank has stated it will provide support and maintain stability. The banks have reported no restrictions on withdrawing or depositing currencies, and operations are continuing normally.

images.alt_text: Three Russian banks including the country's biggest, Sberbank, on Friday (Feb 25) played down the impact of sanctions imposed on them by the United States after Russia's invasion of Ukraine and said they were continuing to work normally.

site_title: Ara Logos Logistics Trust, ESR-Reit to vote on merger on Mar 21
summary: Ara Logos Logistics Trust (ALog Trust) and ESR-Reit will hold separate extraordinary general meetings (EGMs) on March 21 to vote on the proposed merger via a trust scheme arrangement. Unitholders will receive S$0.097 in cash and 1.7729 new ESR-Reit units for each ALog Trust unit, a revised scheme consideration following recommendations from proxy advisory services. Both Reit managers have reiterated the illustrative value of the merger and recommended unitholders vote in favor. The merger aims to address overlapping mandates and conflicts while allowing the enlarged ESR-Logos Reit to leverage resources and drive growth.

site_title: HRnetGroup H2 profit rises 14.2% to S$29.6m; posts record profit for FY2021
summary: HRnetGroup, a recruitment company, reported a 14.2% increase in net profit to S$29.6 million for the second half of 2021, driven by revenue growth in its flexible staffing and professional recruitment segments. Earnings per share rose to 2.95 cents, up from 2.58 cents a year ago. This marked a record profit for FY2021.

site_title: Stablecoins gain as Bitcoin, Ether fall after Russia invades Ukraine
summary: Stablecoins rose 0.3% in market capitalization to $182.5 billion, while their trading volume surged 75% to $108.1 billion, amid a sell-off in risk assets like Bitcoin and Ether following Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Bitcoin and Ether dropped to 1-month lows, with Bitcoin down 3.1% at $36,121 and Ether down 4.1% at $2,475. The demand for digital dollars increased, with stablecoin USD Coin up 0.1% at $1, and Fei USD and Liquity USD also gaining.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks rebound on US gains despite Ukraine invasion
summary: Tokyo stocks rebounded on Friday, February 25, 2022, following gains on Wall Street despite Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.93% to 26,213.20, while the Topix index added 0.43% to 1,865.66. This rebound was partly due to the US market's gains, which helped to lift Tokyo's stocks despite ongoing tensions.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Friday (Feb 25), rebounding from losses in previous sessions and following gains on Wall Street despite Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

site_title: AEM Holdings records 47% higher H2 profit; proposes S$0.05 final dividend
summary: AEM Holdings, a semiconductor equipment maker, reported a 47% increase in H2 profit to S$62.4 million, driven by a volume ramp-up in new system level testing handlers and peripheral tools. Revenue grew 52% to S$373.2 million. Earnings per share rose 35%. The company proposed a final dividend of S$0.05 per share, bringing the total dividend per share to S$0.076. AEM expects demand for its products to remain strong in FY2022 and FY2023.

site_title: Ukraine calls on hacker underground to defend against Russia
summary: Ukraine is calling on its hacker underground to defend against Russian cyberattacks, with requests for volunteers appearing on hacker forums. The Defense Ministry has asked cybersecurity experts to submit their skills and experience, including malware development, to help protect critical infrastructure and conduct digital espionage operations against Russian forces. The initiative comes as Russian forces attack cities across Ukraine, and is seen as a late effort to build a cyber military force, with the country having no dedicated military cyber force previously.

site_title: Google faces sanctions dilemma with pro-Russia YouTube channels
summary: Google's YouTube faces pressure to remove or cut ties with pro-Russian channels amid US, UK, and EU sanctions on Russia. Channels with over 1 million subscribers, including Vladimir Solovyov's, could be targeted due to their hostile views on Ukraine and praise of the Russian government. EU sanctions would also impact YouTube's ad partnerships with Russian companies. The platform has a history of removing content from opposition figures and Russian state-backed media, but critics argue it has a deep commercial relationship with groups close to the Russian government.

site_title: CDL surprises shareholders with distribution of CDLHT units
summary: CDL, a Singapore-based property and hospitality group, has proposed a total payout of 31.1 cents to shareholders for FY2021, with 11.7% coming from a special distribution of CDLHT units. The company swung into the black with a net profit of S$129.7 million for its second half, reversing a net loss of S$1.92 billion in the previous year. CDL's hotel operations segment returned to profitability in the second half, with revenue rising 38.4% to S$1.43 billion. The company's board recommends a final dividend of 8 cents and a special final dividend of 1 cent.

site_title: Mental health for the great return to office
summary: Leaders and employers must prepare for a surge in mental health challenges among workers as they transition back to the office after the pandemic. A 2021 survey found that nearly half of employees anticipate a negative impact on their mental health from returning to work, with those with children and millennials being more likely to experience this. To address this, leaders must set the tone from the top by openly discussing their own mental health struggles, normalizing conversations about mental health, and breaking down stigma. Authenticity and vulnerability can help build trust and create a safe environment for employees to discuss their mental health challenges.

site_title: US: Wall Street rallies as West hits Russia with new sanctions
summary: US stocks surged on Thursday, led by a 3% gain in the Nasdaq, after President Joe Biden unveiled harsh new sanctions against Russia in response to its invasion of Ukraine. The S&P 500 rose 1%, while the Dow ended in positive territory. Investors were reassured by the US's coordinated efforts with other nations to release oil from global reserves, potentially mitigating higher fuel prices. Despite initial selling, the market reversed, with the Nasdaq closing at a record high.

site_title: First Resources H2 profit more than doubles to US$128.6m
summary: First Resources reported a net profit of US$128.6 million for the second half of FY2021, more than doubling from the previous year. Sales grew 62% to US$619.4 million, driven by higher average selling prices and volumes. The company's gross profit improved 61.7% to US$288.3 million, with a gross profit margin of 46.5%. A final ordinary dividend of S$0.051 per share is proposed, following a revised dividend policy. CEO Ciliandra Fangiono expects global vegetable oil supply to remain tight due to weather influences and labor shortages.

site_title: Europe: Ukraine invasion fears send stocks to 9-month lows
summary: European stocks plummeted to 9-month lows on February 24, 2022, after Russia launched an invasion of Ukraine, with banks and automakers bearing the brunt of the selloff. The Stoxx 600 index fell 3.3% to its lowest since May 2021, with European banks experiencing significant losses. US President Joe Biden and Western leaders vowed to impose tough sanctions on Russia, while analysts predicted a material global recessionary shock.

site_title: Block beats profit estimates as Square, Cash App record growth
summary: Block, the payments platform formerly known as Square, beat profit estimates in its fourth quarter with net revenue of $4.1 billion and a profit of $1.2 billion. The company's Cash App generated $2 billion in bitcoin revenue, up 12% year over year, despite volatile cryptocurrency prices. Block expects to prioritize investments in Cash App and Square, which it believes will drive long-term profitable growth. Despite the positive earnings report, Block's shares fell 4.5% after-hours due to increased operating expenses.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Frencken Group reported a 38% increase in net profit to S$58.7 million for FY2021, with earnings per share rising to 13.75 cents. Straits Trading Company posted a net profit of S$234.3 million, with earnings per share increasing to 57.6 cents. Both companies recommended higher dividends, with Frencken proposing 4.13 cents and Straits proposing 8 cents per share.

site_title: HKEX posts worst quarterly profit since China crackdown
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing (HKEX) reported its worst quarterly profit in 2 years, dropping 8.6% to HK$2.67 billion due to China's tightening scrutiny on offshore listings and a crackdown on markets. This marks the third straight quarterly profit decline. The bourse's decline has wiped out over $1.5 trillion of market value last year. HKEX chairman Laura Cha expects the global economic recovery to continue, but faces challenges from pandemic uncertainty, geopolitical risks, and interest rate hikes.

site_title: Star witness against ex-Goldman banker says wives used to disguise 1MDB kickback
summary: A former Goldman Sachs banker, Roger Ng, is on trial for allegedly conspiring to commit money laundering and violating an anti-corruption law. Tim Leissner, a star government witness, testified that he received kickback payments from Malaysian intermediary Jho Low for helping to embezzle funds from 1MDB through bond sales. Leissner said he transferred half of the $35 million payment to Ng, who had previously received a similar payment from Low. The trial stems from one of the biggest financial scandals in history, with US prosecutors alleging $4.5 billion of the $6.5 billion raised by Goldman for 1MDB was diverted through bribes and kickbacks.

site_title: Morgan Stanley discloses US probe into its block-trading business
summary: US regulators are investigating Morgan Stanley's block-trading business, with the company cooperating with requests from the US Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York and the Securities and Exchange Commission. Authorities are examining communications involving employees and outside money managers to determine if dealmakers improperly tipped off investors to transactions affecting share prices. Morgan Stanley, the largest block trader in the industry, has put a key executive on leave amid the probe, but no one has been accused of wrongdoing. The investigation's outcome is unclear.

site_title: Rouble sinks to record low, Russia stocks sink 45% in biggest-ever fall
summary: Russia's military attack on Ukraine has triggered a global market crisis, with the rouble sinking to a record low and Russian stocks plummeting 45% in the largest-ever fall. The Bank of Russia intervened in the foreign exchange market for the first time in years, offering 1 trillion roubles to calm volatility. US President Joe Biden vowed to announce "further consequences" for Russia, including tougher sanctions, while British Prime Minister Boris Johnson described Putin as a "dictator" facing "massive" Western sanctions. The crisis has raised concerns about the potential for a rate hike and the impact on the Russian economy.

site_title: ST Engineering H2 profit increases 3.8%; to up dividend payout frequency to 4 times
summary: ST Engineering reported a 3.8% increase in H2 net profit to S$274.4 million, driven by revenue growth across all three business segments. Revenue rose 12.7% to S$4 billion, with commercial aerospace seeing a 25% increase. The company will increase its dividend payout frequency to 4 times, with a final dividend of S$0.10 per share. ST Engineering aims to generate over S$11 billion in revenue by 2026 and has an order book of S$19.3 billion as of Dec 31, 2021.

images.alt_text: Above: A view of the ST Engineering pavilion at the Singapore Airshow. ST Engineering reported a net profit of S$274.4 million for the 6 months ended Dec 31, 2021 on Friday (Feb 25).

site_title: Global finance grapples with Ukraine crisis as shares slump
summary: Financial firms worldwide experienced significant share price drops on February 24, 2022, due to the Russia-Ukraine crisis and imposed sanctions. Despite Russia being the EU's fifth-largest trading partner with a 5% share of trade, US trade with Russia accounts for less than 1%. Deutsche Bank has contingency plans in place, while other banks rushed to advise clients on how to respond to the crisis. The impact of the crisis on global finance remains uncertain, with ongoing sanctions and economic uncertainty affecting trade and investment.

site_title: European currencies hammered amid Ukraine crisis
summary: Russia's invasion of Ukraine led to a surge in safe-haven currencies, including the US dollar, Swiss franc, and Japanese yen, while European currencies like the euro, Swedish krona, Hungarian forint, and Polish zloty plummeted, with some losing over 1%. The Russian rouble hit a record low, and volatility across foreign exchange markets soared, with the US dollar index reaching a 3-week high. Investors are bracing for the fallout from the war and potential Western sanctions on Russian assets, favoring risk-off sentiment.

site_title: CapitaLand Investment reverses year-ago loss to post H2 profit of S$647m
summary: CapitaLand Investment Limited (CLI) has reversed its year-ago loss to post a second-half profit of S$647 million, driven by growth in its fee income-related business and real estate investment business. The company aims to increase its assets under management (AUM) to S$200-300 billion in Asia over the next five years, with a focus on China and the US. CLI's board proposes a dividend of S$0.15, and the group is targeting S$100 billion in FUM by 2024, with its lodging units under management rising 8% to 133,000 units.

images.alt_text: Above: Westgate, owned by CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust, which is one of CapitaLand Investment's listed entities. The real estate investment manager's revenue for the half year increased by 26.2 per cent year on year to S$1.24 billion from S986 million.

site_title: China vows to keep property market stable, meet demand
summary: China's housing minister vows to maintain stability in the real estate market this year, ensuring genuine demand for homes is met despite recent regulations aimed at reining in debt. Measures include smaller down payments for first-time home buyers and lower mortgage rates. China aims to offer 2.4 million affordable rental housing units this year, targeting 3 million people. The government will eliminate project delivery risks by eliminating debt defaults by individual property developers.

site_title: Oil tops US$105 after Russia attacks Ukraine
summary: Oil prices surged to a 9-year high after Russia's invasion of Ukraine, with Brent crude reaching $105.79 a barrel, the highest since 2014. The US and UK imposed harsh sanctions on Russia, while China warned of the impact on global energy security. Despite easing later, Brent crude remained above $100 a barrel, with analysts predicting prices will remain high until alternative supplies become available. Global energy supplies remain tight, with the US and Iran engaged in nuclear talks that could lead to the removal of sanctions on Iranian oil sales.

images.alt_text: The banks have stopped issuing letters of credit in US dollars for trades involving Russian oil and liquefied natural gas.

site_title: Meet the Million-dollar Mercedes-Maybachs
summary: Mercedes-Maybach re-enters Singapore with new luxury car models, including the GLS 600 SUV and S-Class limousines, despite the introduction of luxury car taxes. The brand's president & CEO, Claudius Steinhoff, is not concerned about the tax hike, citing high interest from customers. The GLS 600 starts at S$894,888, while the S-Class limousines, including the S 680L, priced from S$879,888 and S$1,085,888, respectively. The Maybach label is a nod to engineer Wilhelm Maybach, who worked for Mercedes-Benz's founder.

site_title: Coinbase says revenue tops estimate, cautions on trading volume
summary: Coinbase reported revenue of $2.5 billion in the fourth quarter, exceeding analyst estimates of $2 billion. The company's monthly transacting users reached 11.4 million, beating estimates of 9.8 million. However, Coinbase cautioned that trading volume will decline in the first quarter due to a decline in crypto asset volatility and prices. The company expects average transaction revenue per user to fall to pre-2021 levels and forecasts a range of 5-15 million annual retail monthly transacting users.

images.alt_text: Coinbase Global shares slumped about 3 per cent in post-market trading after the biggest US cryptocurrency exchange cautioned that trading volume will decline in the first quarter.

site_title: Hong Kong Jan home prices at 11-month low on new Covid surge
summary: Hong Kong's private home prices dropped 1.1% in January, the largest monthly decline in 11 months, amid a new wave of Covid-19 cases. The prices eased from a revised 0.1% fall in December. The property market, considered one of the world's most expensive, is expected to decline 5% in the first quarter but rebound 3-5% in the full year. Some property agents have lowered their full-year price forecast due to the surge in coronavirus infections and government restrictions.

site_title: With Ukraine under large-scale attack, West ramps up sanctions on Russia
summary: Ukraine faced a large-scale attack by Russia, prompting the West to ramp up sanctions. The assault brought a calamitous end to diplomatic efforts to avert war, with at least 70 people reported killed. Ukrainian forces battled Russian invaders on three sides, and tens of thousands fled their homes. The attack marked the biggest assault on a European state since World War Two.

site_title: Europe's inflation challenge amplified as energy prices soar
summary: Europe's inflation challenge has intensified as global energy prices surged following Russia's invasion of Ukraine, pushing oil above $105 a barrel for the first time since 2014. Central banks in Europe may reassess plans for tighter monetary policy due to the trade-off between curbing inflation and supporting economic growth. The Bank of England and European Central Bank will hold policy meetings next month to address the dilemma, with some officials warning of a delayed stimulus exit.

site_title: Digital exchanges should start eating what they cook
summary: Cryptocurrency exchanges are increasingly relying on traditional institutional investors and public equity markets to raise capital, rather than their own digitally-native communities. This contradicts the promise of decentralization and democratization of finance. The author argues that exchanges, which are the best business model in the digital asset world, should offer communities the chance to own real equity in the platforms they helped build, rather than defaulting to institutions that dominate legacy capital.

site_title: Companies shut Ukraine operations, brace for sanctions on Russia
summary: Companies worldwide have suspended operations in Ukraine and braced for sanctions on Russia following the invasion. Danish brewer Carlsberg and Coca-Cola bottler shut plants in Ukraine, while logistics firms UPS and FedEx suspended services. Global shipping giant Maersk halted port calls and closed its office in Odessa. Western sanctions are expected to impact trade in Eastern Europe, with some companies, such as Uniper and BASF, experiencing share price drops.

site_title: Porsche Taycan Cross Turismo review: Hot Cross fun
summary: The Porsche Taycan 4S Cross Turismo is a luxurious, high-performance electric vehicle that offers a unique blend of speed, handling, and versatility. With its 571 horsepower and 650 Newton-metres of torque, it accelerates from 0-100km/h in just 4.1 seconds. The car features a comfortable ride, connected steering, and a spacious boot with ample headroom. Despite its high price tag of around S$520,000, the Taycan 4S Cross Turismo is an attractive option for those seeking a premium electric vehicle experience.

site_title: Centurion posts higher full-year net profit, proposes S$0.005 final dividend
summary: Centurion Corp reported a net profit of S$52.7 million for FY2021, up from S$17.2 million the previous year, driven by lower fair-value losses and revenue from newly leased assets. The company also proposed a final dividend of 0.5 Singapore cent. Revenue increased 11% to S$143 million, despite lower occupancy rates in Singapore and Australia due to Covid-19 disruptions. The board recommended a final dividend, and the company's earnings per share rose to 6.27 cents.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims fall; Q4 GDP growth revised slightly higher
summary: US jobless claims fell 17,000 to 232,000 for the week ended Feb 19, slightly more than expected. The labor market recovery is gaining traction, with near-record 10.9 million job openings at the end of December. Many Federal Reserve officials view labor market conditions as already at or near maximum employment. The US economy's GDP growth was revised slightly higher to 7.0% annualized rate in Q4, with retail sales surging in January and business activity rebounding in February.

site_title: Cashless conundrum
summary: Singapore is experiencing a shift towards a cashless economy, with many small merchants deploying QR codes and NETS terminals for e-payments. However, the upcoming end of a transaction fee waiver in December 2023 may lead to a resurgence in cash use. Experts argue that banks and payment ecosystem players must find ways to discourage cash use, as the current incentives do not align with the benefits of going digital. The government and financial institutions must work together to create a more favorable environment for e-payments.

site_title: Russia-Ukraine tension overshadows Food Empire's results; net profit dips 27.2%
summary: Food Empire's net profit dipped 27.2% to US$19.5 million for the financial year ended December 2021 due to lower margins from higher commodity costs and ocean freight rates. Revenue rose 17.5% to US$320.6 million, with Russia's largest market contributing 15.4% growth. The company remains confident in its local manufacturing facilities and expects businesses in Vietnam and Malaysia to improve as lockdown measures ease. A first and final dividend of 1.62 Singapore cents a share was recommended, lower than the 2.2 cents for 2020.

site_title: 2022 BMW 2 Series Active Tourer review: Tourer de force
summary: The 2022 BMW 2 Series Active Tourer has received a revamped design, hybrid engine, and improved cabin features, making it a more appealing option as a premium car. The car's wider stance and aerodynamic drag reduction enhance its high-speed refinement and handling, while the mild hybrid system provides a seamless boost. The cabin now feels luxurious and tech-enabled, with features such as a 10.25-inch driver's display and floating console. The car's practicality remains, but it now better lives up to its BMW heritage.

site_title: Oil, commodity prices to soar due to Russia invasion, driving up inflationary pressures
summary: Russia's invasion of Ukraine is expected to drive up oil prices and inflationary pressures, potentially hurting Singapore's GDP growth. Economists warn that a full-blown war could lead to a recession in Europe, an oil price shock of $150, and inflation rates exceeding 5% and 3% respectively. However, Singapore's exposure to Russia is limited, with only 0.1% of total exports and 0.8% of total imports. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is expected to tighten monetary policy to guard against inflation, with some economists predicting a recession in Singapore if the conflict escalates.

site_title: Jack Ma's Ant Group posts 21% profit rise on investment gains
summary: Billionaire Jack Ma's Ant Group likely saw a 21% profit rise in the September quarter, driven by investment gains. The fintech firm contributed 5.81 billion yuan to Alibaba Group's earnings, translating to an estimated 17.6 billion yuan in profit. This comes despite regulatory scrutiny, with Chinese authorities recently ordering a fresh round of checks on Ant's financial exposure. The company has ramped up its capital base and built firewalls to address concerns, amid Beijing's efforts to rein in tech giants and create a more equitable distribution of wealth.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims fall; Q4 GDP growth revised slightly higher
summary: US weekly jobless claims fell 17,000 to 232,000 for the week ended Feb 19, beating expectations. The labor market recovery is gaining traction, with a near-record 10.9 million job openings at the end of December. Many Federal Reserve officials view labor market conditions as already at or near maximum employment, boosting wage growth and inflation. The US economy's GDP growth was revised slightly higher to 7.0% annualized for the fourth quarter, up from the previously reported 6.9%.

site_title: LA is paying US$600,000 apiece for units to house homeless people
summary: Los Angeles has approved a plan to pay $600,000 each for 10,000 units of income-restricted supportive housing to address the city's homeless crisis. Despite a $1.2 billion bond approved five years ago, only 14% of the planned units have been built, with costs increasing 12% to an average of $596,846 per unit. The pace of construction remains slow, with many projects expected to open between 2023 and 2026. The city's homelessness issue has become a top concern, with over 66,000 homeless people across LA County, and efforts to address it are seen as disjointed and lacking transparency.

images.alt_text: Tents line sidewalks, parks and other public areas in the city. A report by Committee for Greater LA showed homelessness has become the No 1 concern for LA residents.

site_title: British Airways owner IAG weighs asset sales to raise cash
summary: IAG, the owner of British Airways, is considering asset sales to raise cash amid subdued global travel due to the pandemic. The company is exploring options such as selling planes, its frequent-flier program, and cargo unit. A strategic review is underway, potentially leading to stake sales, partnerships, and joint ventures. This move could bolster the company's balance sheet and attract industry players and investment funds. No final decision has been made, and IAG could still decide against any disposals or partnerships.

site_title: Russia-exposed stocks plunge as tougher Western sanctions loom
summary: Shares of Russia-exposed companies plummeted across US and European markets after Russia's invasion of Ukraine, fueling fears of tougher Western sanctions. Yandex lost half its value, while QIWI and Ozon Holdings slumped 17% and 38%, respectively. The White House warned of new restrictions on US chip exports to Russia, and European stocks fell 3.4% as shares of Sberbank and Gazprom plummeted 74.6% and 37.9%, respectively. The US President and EU foreign affairs chief promised new sanctions, with US President Joe Biden indicating Moscow would face a steeper price for continued aggression.

site_title: E-commerce firm fabric hits valuation of US$1.5b after SoftBank-led funding
summary: E-commerce firm fabric has reached a valuation of US$1.5 billion after a funding round led by SoftBank. The Seattle-based company, founded in 2017, offers a "headless" commerce platform as a service to retailers and sellers. The funding will be used to ramp up product development and expand into more markets. Fabric's clients include major brands such as Chico's FAS, McDonald's, and The Honest Company.

site_title: Moderna's 2022 shot orders edge up amid easing pandemic
summary: Moderna's 2022 Covid-19 vaccine orders rose modestly to $19 billion, up from $18.5 billion in January, but options for 2022 orders decreased to $3 billion from $3.5 billion. The company is still waiting for new booster orders from the US for later this year. This comes as concerns about the pandemic fade and rivals compete for market share.

site_title: US: Nasdaq tumbles over 3% at open as Russia invades Ukraine
summary: US stocks plummeted at the open on Feb 24, with the Nasdaq Composite dropping 3.45% and the S&P 500 falling 1.65%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average also declined 0.91%. The invasions of Ukraine by Russia triggered the market downturn, which may confirm a bear market and correction.

images.alt_text: The Nasdaq Composite index tumbled at the open on Thursday (Feb 24), dropping more than 20 per cent from its record closing high in November last year and on track to confirm a bear market, after Russia launched an all-out invasion of Ukraine.

site_title: K-pop kings BTS get global music crown for 2nd year running
summary: BTS, a seven-member K-pop boy band, has won the 2021 IFPI Global Recording Artist of the Year award for the second consecutive year, becoming the first act to achieve this feat. The group's global success is attributed to their unique global appeal demonstrated through their performances in three languages. BTS topped the US Billboard Hot 100 chart with singles "Butter," "Permission to Dance," and "My Universe," a joint release with Coldplay. They also achieved a milestone in Japan with their Japanese-language album, topping the Oricon Year End Album Chart for the first time in 37 years.

site_title: Taiwan lifts GDP, inflation outlook as rate hike draws near
summary: Taiwan's government has raised its forecast for economic growth to 4.42% and inflation to 1.93% for 2022, citing a robust growth outlook and stubbornly high inflation. A possible rate hike is expected, with economists predicting borrowing costs may rise for the first time since 2011. The country's currency remains a primary concern, but a stronger dollar could help restrain further rate hikes, potentially normalizing rates back to pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: Samudera Shipping declares S$0.1275 a share special dividend as FY2021 net profit rises
summary: Samudera Shipping Line reported a net profit of US$128.6 million for FY2021, up from US$7.2 million the previous year, driven by better performance from its container shipping segment due to higher freight rates.
