The company proposed a special dividend of 12.75 Singapore cents a share and a final dividend of 0.75 cent, with revenue rising 51.5% to US$527 million. The company secured 6 new container vessels to minimize service disruptions and expects upward pressure on freight rates and robust demand for shipping services.

site_title: Far East Orchard's full-year net profit rises to S$28.1m on fair-value gains
summary: Far East Orchard's full-year net profit rose to S$28.1 million, primarily due to fair-value gains on investment properties, despite a 4.8% decline in revenue to S$106.8 million. The hospitality business was impacted by the pandemic, but the PBSA sector contributed to offsetting losses. The company remains committed to delivering sustainable shareholder value, despite the ongoing Covid-19 impact and subdued travel and tourism sector. A first and final dividend of 3 Singapore cents was recommended for FY2021.

site_title: Straits Trading FY2021 net profit rises, proposes higher interim dividend
summary: Straits Trading Company reported a net profit of S$234.3 million for FY2021, a 353% increase from the previous year. Revenue rose 28.4% to S$396.6 million, driven by net fair value gains from investment properties and higher contributions from its real estate segment. The group proposed a higher interim dividend of 8 Singapore cents per share, up from 6 cents the previous year.

site_title: Ukraine swaps signal 90% chance of default as Russia attacks
summary: Ukraine's credit-default swaps surged to a 90% probability of default within 5 years after Russia attacked, with bond prices falling to record lows. The country's US$2.6 billion of bonds due in 2033 fell to 35 cents on the dollar. Russia's government bonds also saw a 45% chance of default within 5 years, with its swap curve inverting. The sell-off spread to corporate default swaps, with benchmark indexes in Europe reaching 20-month highs. Ukraine's government pleaded for international support and harsher sanctions, while Russia's military vehicles were reported in the northern region.

site_title: UK's Sunak makes low-tax pitch as leadership question looms
summary: UK Chancellor Rishi Sunak has made a low-tax pitch, appealing to Conservative Party members questioning Prime Minister Boris Johnson's leadership, amid scandals and a growing cost-of-living crisis. Sunak prioritizes cutting taxes on business investment and allowing individuals to make decisions about their money. He drew parallels with Margaret Thatcher's approach, pledging to cut taxes in a "responsible way." Sunak faces scrutiny over his record on tax, particularly with a record debt burden and energy prices squeezing consumer finances.

site_title: SIA posts first quarterly net profit of S$85m since onset of pandemic
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) posted its first quarterly net profit of $85 million since the onset of the pandemic, driven by increased air travel and strong yields in the cargo market during the year-end period. The airline's operating cash surplus reached $322 million for the 9 months to December, reversing previous losses. Passenger load improved 18.9 percentage points to 33.2%, while cargo revenue ticked up as yields and loads carried were supported by robust demand and tight capacity.

site_title: Oil, commodity prices to soar due to Russia invasion, driving up inflationary pressures
summary: Oil prices are expected to soar due to Russia's invasion of Ukraine, driving up inflationary pressures and potentially hurting Singapore's GDP growth. Higher commodity prices in the short term are also anticipated, with the European Union's sanctions against Russia not likely to deter Russia from continuing the conflict. The exact impact on Singapore's GDP remains uncertain due to the volatile situation.

site_title: US new-home sales decline for first time in 3 months
summary: US new-home sales declined 4.5% in January to an annualized pace of 801,000, marking the first decline in three months. This drop follows a surge in sales at the end of 2021, which may be attributed to rising mortgage rates. The decline in sales is seen as a sign that the jump in mortgage rates is starting to restrain demand.

images.alt_text: Sales of new US homes retreated in January after a flurry of purchases at the end of 2021, indicating a jump in mortgage rates may be starting to restrain demand.

site_title: Alibaba reports slowest quarterly revenue growth, misses expectations
summary: Alibaba Group reported its slowest quarterly revenue growth since going public in 2014, with a 10% increase to 242.6 billion yuan, missing analyst expectations. The company attributed the slowdown to a tepid growth in its core e-commerce business and intensifying competition from rivals like ByteDance and Kuaishou. Net income declined 74% to 20.43 billion yuan in the third quarter. The slowing Chinese economy, with consumers cutting back on discretionary spending, is also contributing to the decline.

site_title: European defence stocks rise as Russia invades Ukraine
summary: European defence stocks rose as Russia's invasion of Ukraine led to increased bets on bigger spending. BAE Systems, Rheinmetall, and Thales saw significant gains, with shares in US defence contractors also rallying. Analysts expect defence companies to benefit from rising geopolitical tensions, with potential Nato military involvement boosting defence budgets. The European defence sector trades at a 20% discount to the market, making it attractive for investors seeking diversification.

site_title: Banks brace for sanctions spiral after Russia invades Ukraine
summary: Western countries are set to unveil coordinated sanctions on Russia after its invasion of Ukraine, targeting banks and individuals. The US, EU, Britain, and their allies will impose tougher measures than previously announced, including freezing Russia's assets, halting its banks' access to European financial markets, and targeting "Kremlin interests". The sanctions are expected to hit Russian lenders hard, with the possibility of banning Russia from the global payment system Swift, which could lead to significant economic consequences.

site_title: Nato to step up deterrence measures after Russian attack, calls summit
summary: NATO announced plans to strengthen deterrence and defense measures after Russia's invasion of Ukraine, marking the biggest attack by one state against another in Europe since World War Two. NATO will create battle group structures, including in Slovakia, to protect its eastern flank and will hold an emergency summit on Friday to discuss the measures. The alliance's actions are aimed at ensuring the security and defense of all members, with measures described as preventive, proportionate, and non-escalatory.

site_title: South-East Asia's people back new nature goals, as nations bide time
summary: People in Indonesia, Malaysia, and the Philippines strongly back a global goal to protect 30% of the planet's land and oceans by 2030, with 96%, 98%, and 95% of respondents in each country supporting the "30x30" nature protection goal. The proposed goal is part of a draft global treaty to safeguard plants, animals, and ecosystems, which has been backed by over 80 countries. Despite high levels of concern and awareness about the biodiversity crisis, the three countries have not yet committed to the goal, with some speculating that a delay may be a tactic to secure more funding from richer countries.

site_title: SGX RegCo issues 'trade with caution' alert on LS 2 Holdings
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has issued a "trade with caution" alert on LS 2 Holdings due to significant selling by major shareholders after its listing on the Catalist board. The company's shares rose 340% from its IPO price to close at S$0.88, but the Straits Times Index fell 3.5%. SGX RegCo is reviewing trades and monitoring the situation, considering further actions if necessary. The watchdog noted a concentrated selling by connected accounts within the first hour of trading, with 166 out of 207 placees selling their allotments.

site_title: Samudera Shipping Line declares 12.75 Singapore cents special dividend as FY2021 net profit rises
summary: Samudera Shipping Line reported a net profit of US$128.6 million for FY2021, a 17.8-fold increase from the previous year, driven by higher freight rates and revenue from its container shipping segment. The company declared a special dividend of 12.75 Singapore cents, higher than the previous year, and secured 6 new container vessels to minimize service disruptions. Revenue rose 51.5% to US$527 million, with the container shipping segment contributing 53.7% to the total.

site_title: Hard to find assets that do well during rate hikes, but diversification can reduce risk: report
summary: A report by the Credit Suisse Research Institute found that assets tend to underperform during interest rate hike cycles, with US stocks and bonds experiencing lower annualized real returns during rate-rise periods compared to when interest rates were falling. However, diversification can help reduce risk, with global investment outperforming domestic investment in most countries over the past 50 years. The authors note that diversification can be particularly beneficial for investors in concentrated markets, but recommend that investors with lower risk tolerance focus on long-term returns rather than short-term correlations.

site_title: Antique props from hit royal drama 'The Crown' stolen in UK robbery
summary: Antique props from the hit Netflix series "The Crown" were stolen in a UK robbery near Doncaster, worth around £150,000. The stolen items include jewelry, candelabras, and a replica of a rare Fabergé egg. Despite the theft, filming for the show's fifth season is not expected to be delayed, with a new cast including Imelda Staunton as an older Queen Elizabeth and Elizabeth Debicki as Princess Diana.

site_title: Tesla plans new Shanghai plant to more than double China capacity: sources
summary: Tesla plans to build a new plant in Shanghai, China, to more than double its production capacity to 2 million cars per year. The new plant, located near its existing Lingang facility, will enable the company to produce cars on par with established brands in China. The expansion, if successful, will allow Tesla to meet growing demand in China and export markets. The cost and completion timeline of the project have not been disclosed. This move is part of Tesla's efforts to strengthen its presence in the world's largest auto market.

site_title: Mobius sees China as haven after Russia's attack on Ukraine
summary: Emerging-market veteran Mark Mobius advises investors to increase China exposure due to the country's reduced risk from the conflict in Europe. He views China as a "safe haven" for investors, citing its continued economic growth and low interest rates. Mobius also remains bullish on gold, predicting further price increases due to the crisis. Other Asian countries, such as Thailand and Vietnam, offer potential havens, but Mobius cautions against being overly optimistic, emphasizing the need for cautious stock-picking and careful consideration of rising interest rates.

site_title: Bullish bets on Asian currencies firm, Thai baht leads pack
summary: Investors have increased bullish bets on most Asian currencies, with the Thai baht seeing a significant surge, over the past two weeks. Long positions on the Thai baht have more than tripled, while positions on the Indonesian rupiah and Korean won have unwound. The Thai finance minister aims for a 4% economic growth this year, and the central bank has maintained a record-low interest rate. The bullish trend was driven by hopes of economic recovery and reduced pandemic risks, but regional currencies were hit by rising tensions between Russia and Ukraine.

site_title: Frencken FY2021 net profit up 38% at S$58.7m; company declares higher dividend
summary: Frencken Group, a MAINBOARD-LISTED manufacturer, posted a 38% increase in net profit to S$58.7 million for FY2021, driven by higher sales from its mechatronics and integrated manufacturing services divisions. Group revenue rose 23.6% to S$767.1 million. The company declared a higher final dividend of 4.13 cents per share. Frencken aims to strengthen its market position in the high technology industry and deliver sustainable growth.

site_title: US presents 'Buy American' plan to ease supply chain squeeze
summary: The Biden administration has announced several measures to ease supply-chain disruptions, including a new "Buy American" rule to pay more for domestic-made products, financing for US-based semiconductor makers, and a new program to encourage manufacturing of pharmaceuticals and essential health products. The moves aim to reduce US reliance on foreign imports and address supply-chain issues exacerbated by the coronavirus pandemic. However, senior officials note that more sweeping changes, such as a competition bill, are needed to address the issue, which is expected to continue into next year.

site_title: Europe: Stocks dive at open after Russia attacks Ukraine
summary: European stock markets plummeted at the open on Feb 24, with London sinking almost 3% and Frankfurt and Paris slumping over 4%. The decline followed Russia's attack on Ukraine.

site_title: Uefa to hold emergency meeting over Russian invasion of Ukraine
summary: UEFA is holding an emergency meeting on February 25 to evaluate the situation following Russia's invasion of Ukraine. The meeting comes amid concerns that Russia, which hosts the Champions League final in May, could be stripped of the event due to its involvement in the conflict. UEFA has a major sponsorship deal with Gazprom, the Russian state energy giant. British Prime Minister Boris Johnson has stated that Russia has "no chance" of hosting the tournament if it invades Ukraine, amid calls for the event to be relocated.

images.alt_text: Uefa is to hold an emergency meeting on Friday (Feb 25) to evaluate the situation concerning Russia's invasion of Ukraine with the former set to host the Champions League final in Saint Petersburg in May.

site_title: UK retail sales growth slows in Feb, price pressures moun
summary: UK retail sales growth slowed in February to +14, down from +28 in January, as Omicron cases eased. Demand was better than expected, but sales face challenges due to rising energy prices and transport costs. The CBI expects prices to rise even faster over the next three months. This slowdown follows faster-than-expected growth in January, which was boosted by lockdown comparisons. The UK economy shrunk for the second month, adding to concerns about a tough year ahead due to rising inflation and squeezed household income.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Russian forces attacked cities across Ukraine after President Vladimir Putin ordered an operation aimed at demilitarizing the country. Markets plummeted as oil prices soared. Singapore postponed plans to ease Covid-19 restrictions due to a surge in cases. South Korea's central bank maintained interest rates despite back-to-back hikes. Shares in LS 2 Holdings rose 47.5% on its trading debut. Singapore's STI index fell 3.5% as Russia invaded Ukraine.

site_title: 1/3 of Hong Kong eateries, bars, to close as curbs linger
summary: Hong Kong's Covid-19 restrictions have led to thousands of restaurants and bars shutting down, with about 1/3 of eateries considering permanent closure. Over 1,200 restaurants have suspended business and 300 have permanently closed. The government's relief package, which includes a HK$10,000 spending voucher, is deemed too little, too late, with business owners citing high rent costs and uncertain revenue. The restrictions have severely impacted the city's economy, with the restaurant sector experiencing a 75% decline in business and unemployment rates projected to reach 15% by March.

site_title: Mental Health for the Great Return to Office
summary: The return to office poses significant mental health challenges for workers, with many experiencing higher rates of stress, anxiety, and depression due to the pandemic's unprecedented psychological upheaval. A 2021 survey found that 44% of respondents anticipate a negative impact on mental health from returning to work, with 50% of those with children and millennials being particularly concerned. To address this, leaders must prioritize mental health, normalize conversations, and demonstrate vulnerability. By doing so, they can create a safe environment where mental health issues can be raised and talked about, ultimately driving a culture change and building trust among employees.

site_title: Taiwan's UMC to spend US$5b on new chip plant in Singapore
summary: Taiwan's United Microelectronics Corp (UMC) plans to invest US$5 billion in a new microchip factory in Singapore, with production expected to start in 2024. The factory will produce 22 and 28 nanometre chips, primarily for 5G and auto electronics. The investment is backed by customers with multi-year supply agreements, indicating robust demand for UMC's technologies in the coming years.

site_title: World economy inflation shock set to worsen from oil at US$100 a barrel
summary: Oil prices surged to $100 a barrel for the first time since 2014, exacerbating the world economy's inflation concerns and denting growth prospects. The US Federal Reserve and central banks face challenges in managing inflation without derailing post-pandemic recoveries. Energy exporters will benefit from the price boom, but most of the world will feel the impact of rising energy costs, food, transportation, and heating expenses, squeezing consumer spending power.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts raise Sembcorp targets on strong FY21 results, solid outlook
summary: Brokerages have raised their target prices for Sembcorp Industries after the company reported a net profit of S$279 million for FY21, driven by higher core return on equity and a strong conventional energy segment. Analysts, including DBS Group Research and UOB Kay Hian, now estimate Sembcorp Industries at S$3.20 and S$2.95 respectively, citing a growing renewable energy portfolio and longer-term prospects. The company's renewable-energy transformation is expected to contribute to its growth.

site_title: Tempura with style at Tentsuru
summary: Tentsuru, a new restaurant in The St Regis Singapore, offers a unique tempura experience with a delicate batter and pristine ingredients. The restaurant's clean, hinoki-accented interiors provide a serene atmosphere. Tentsuru is open for lunch and dinner, Tuesdays to Sundays, from 12pm to 2.30pm and 6pm to 10pm. The chef's expertise in creating a magic batter is highlighted as the key to achieving the perfect tempura.

site_title: China tech rout resumes on policy jitters before Alibaba results
summary: China's tech stocks plummeted 4.3% on the Hang Seng Tech Index, the largest drop in 7 weeks, amid policy jitters and concerns over regulatory tightening. Alibaba Group's shares fell 6.7% ahead of its earnings release, while Kuaishou Technology and Bilibili also declined. The tech sector's decline is attributed to Beijing's yearlong crackdown, which has erased $1.6 trillion from technology stocks, and recent measures such as fee cuts and warnings against illegal fundraising schemes. The market's downturn is also linked to global tensions, including Russia's attack on Ukraine.

site_title: Hong Kong's biggest builder Sun Hung Kai warns of slowdown as profit dips
summary: Hong Kong's largest builder, Sun Hung Kai Properties, reported a 15% decrease in first-half profit due to a slowdown in the residential housing market. The company attributed the decline to low local stock market levels, increasing Omicron infections, and social-distancing measures hindering home sales. Despite this, gross rental income from properties, including offices and malls, rose 2.2%. The developer warned that 2022 will remain challenging, citing uncertainties and a high number of vacant office spaces.

site_title: 2022 Singapore International Festival of Arts primed to be a winner
summary: The Singapore International Festival of Arts 2022 (Sifa) is set to be a groundbreaking event, premiering on May 20, with a diverse lineup of local and international performances. Festival director Natalie Hennedige has crafted a unique program that blends tradition and avant-garde art, featuring Indian bharatanatyam, Malay kompak, and fashion shows. The festival's theme, "ritual," aims to dissolve categories and invite artistic collaboration. Sifa X, an alternative component, offers experimental performances, while the festival's designers have created a cohesive aesthetic across multiple productions.

site_title: Companies in EU could be liable for violations in supply line
summary: The European Union has proposed a due diligence law that could hold companies liable for environmental violations and human rights abuses in their supply chains. The law would require businesses to establish regulations to detect and prevent breaches, with victims able to sue for compensation in EU member nations. The proposal applies to companies with over 500 employees and annual revenue over 150 million euros, with the range expanding to smaller businesses in high-impact sectors after two years. The legislation has sparked concerns from businesses, with some arguing it will harm competitiveness, while others see it as a step towards greater accountability.

site_title: Russia-Ukraine conflict: Singapore calls for immediate stop to military action
summary: Singapore calls for an immediate stop to military action in Ukraine following reports of Russia's land and air attacks, after weeks of troop build-ups on the border. The country strongly condemns any unprovoked invasion and urges a peaceful settlement of the dispute in accordance with the UN Charter and international law. Singapore's concerns are shared by other Western countries and Asian nations, with Indonesia calling for negotiation and diplomacy. The country's foreign ministry advises Singaporeans in Ukraine to leave the country as soon as possible, as Russia's actions have been criticized by the international community.

site_title: Geo Energy H2 net profit rises to US$129.8m on stronger coal prices, proposes final dividend of S$0.05
summary: Geo Energy Resources, an Indonesian coal producer, reported a net profit of US$129.8 million for the second half of 2021, up 87% from the previous year, driven by stronger coal prices. Revenue rose to US$421.6 million due to increased sales volume and higher average selling prices. The company proposed a final dividend of S$0.05 per share, citing undervaluation by the market. CEO Tung Kum Hon expects the company to perform well in FY2022 if coal prices remain elevated, despite volatile market conditions and environmental concerns.

site_title: US Justice Department to end Trump-era programme targeting threats posed by China
summary: The US Justice Department will end its "China Initiative" program, which targeted Chinese espionage and intellectual property theft, and shift its focus to a broader range of hostile nations. The program faced criticism for its "myopic" approach and allegations of racial profiling, resulting in at least 20 academic researchers being charged. The new strategy will prioritize cases involving espionage, export control, sanctions violations, and defending democracy from authoritarian regimes, with Assistant Attorney General Matt Olsen stating that the department will "not be taking any tools off the table" when bringing future cases.

site_title: Russian stocks slump most on record, wiping out US$180 billion in value
summary: Russian stocks plummeted 45% in value, wiping out over $180 billion, amid military attacks in Ukraine and increased Western sanctions threats. The rouble hit a record low, while eurobonds sank. The Bank of Russia intervened in the foreign exchange market for the first time in years to tame volatility. President Vladimir Putin's operation to "demilitarise" Russia sparked international condemnation and US sanctions threats. The global market downturn was fueled by risk aversion, with the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq also reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: STI tumbles 3.5% as Russia invades Ukraine on Thursday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) plummeted 3.5% on February 24, 2022, as Russia's invasion of Ukraine sent shockwaves through global markets. The benchmark index closed at 3,276.06 points, with other regional markets also experiencing significant declines. The invasion marked a significant turning point in the global economic landscape, leading to heightened market volatility and uncertainty.

images.alt_text: The benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) tumbled 3.5 per cent or 116.94 points to close at 3,276.06.

site_title: Work and play get a green boost
summary: A new 51-storey integrated development, CapitaSpring, has incorporated extensive green spaces, including a 90,000 sq ft landscaped area and a spiral botanical promenade known as the Green Oasis. The building features a cafe, yoga alcoves, exercise stations, and an amphitheatre, and is open to the public. Similar green spaces can be found in other developments, such as Guoco Tower's Urban Park and Paya Lebar Quarter. Developers say these spaces attract tenants and contribute to employee well-being and sustainability. The trend is expected to continue, with more buildings incorporating green spaces to support corporate purpose and employee retention.

images.alt_text: Located on level 51, the Sky Garden is a publicly accessible observatory deck that offers a 360 degree view of the surroundings
An aerial view of the Urban Park at Guoco Tower.
The Green Oasis at CapitaSpring a spiral botanical promenade located 100m above ground, from levels 17 to 20.

Water Garden at Guoco Midtown is a garden of serenity featuring freshwater waterside plants such as the native Paku Wangi, Sakat Hitam and flowering plants such as the Giant Spider Lily and the Bamboo Orchids.
The green corridor at ESR Biz Park @ Changi which not only provides a better spatial experience but enhances work life.
Paya Lebar Quarter comprises office towers, a mall and residences has over 100,000 square feet of landscaped, green spaces and an outdoor playground.

site_title: ECB meets as invasion of Ukraine complicates path to higher rates
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is holding an emergency meeting amid Russia's invasion of Ukraine, which threatens to derail economic growth in the eurozone and complicate the ECB's path to higher interest rates. The meeting, originally scheduled for March 10, is now expected to focus on the economic outlook and policy moves due to the crisis. Analysts predict the ECB may delay the decision to taper bond purchases and may not put a firm end date on its Asset Purchase Programme, citing the potential for higher energy costs and financial turmoil.

site_title: New wines from old Spanish vines
summary: Spanish wine producers are focusing on old, ancient vineyards, some dating back to the 2nd century, to produce high-quality wines. These heritage vineyards offer unique insights into traditional viticultural practices and cultural continuity. Producers like Envínate, Laura Lorenzo, and Goyo García Viadero are reviving the notion of Spanish wines, using minimal manipulation and no chemicals. Their wines, such as Envínate's Benje Tinto, Laura Lorenzo's Camino de la Frontera Tinto, and Goyo García Viadero's Joven de Viñas Viejas, showcase the potential of these old vines, with complex flavors and aromas. This shift towards heritage wines reflects a growing appreciation for tradition and cultural heritage in the Spanish wine industry.

site_title: European gas jumps 41% after Russia attacks Ukraine targets
summary: European gas prices surged 41% after Russian forces attacked Ukraine, targeting the capital Kyiv and other regions. Benchmark Dutch futures rose as high as 41%, and German power prices jumped 31% in March. The West vowed further sanctions against Russia, which aims to maintain gas supplies abroad. The crisis puts fuel supplies in Europe at risk, with the continent relying on Russia for over 1/3 of its gas supply. Analysts forecast higher prices through the remainder of the year due to a deficit in fuel used in power generation, industry, and heating.

site_title: Lloyds on 'heightened alert' for Russian cyberattacks on banks: CEO
summary: Lloyds, Britain's largest domestic lender, is on "heightened alert" for potential cyberattacks from Russia due to the crisis in Ukraine. CEO Charlie Nunn stated that the bank has been preparing for this possibility for several months and has reviewed its cyber risk controls. Lloyds, which is not directly exposed to Russia, is preparing for stricter sanctions from Western governments. The bank has been working closely with the government and other financial service organizations to ensure it is ready to enforce current sanctions and adapt to any new areas.

site_title: Digital exchanges should start eating what they cook
summary: A cryptocurrency exchange CEO argues that digital asset platforms should raise equity from their digitally-native communities rather than relying on traditional public and private equity markets. The author claims that this approach would align with the promise of decentralizing finance and increasing access to capital. Several examples, including Coinbase and FTX, are cited as hypocrisy, where institutional investors dominate despite platforms' claims to represent a shift towards a more inclusive financial architecture. The author concludes that digital asset firms should "start eating what they cook" and offer community ownership in the form of tokens.

site_title: Electric and luxury models boost Mercedes-Benz earnings
summary: Mercedes-Benz reports a significant boost in earnings for 2021, with annual adjusted earnings before interest and taxes (EBIT) more than doubling to 13.9 billion euros. Revenue from top-end and electric vehicles drove the increase, with top models generating 30% more revenue and electric passenger cars seeing a 64% increase. The company prioritizes sales of top-end and electric vehicles, while deepening its relationship with chip producers to manage supply chain constraints. A proposed dividend of 5 euros per share is also announced, a significant jump from last year.

site_title: First look at Watches & Wonders
summary: Watches & Wonders 2022, a major luxury watch event, is returning to Geneva after a two-year hiatus due to the pandemic. Several watch brands, including Roger Dubuis and TAG Heuer, are unveiling new timepieces before the main event. The Roger Dubuis Excalibur Knights of the Round Table features intricate micro-sculpture and manual assembly, while the TAG Heuer Connected Calibre E4 combines smartwatch features with traditional high-end design. Additionally, Zenith has released the DEFY Extreme E "Desert X Prix" watch, which supports the Extreme E electric car rally series and incorporates recycled elements.

site_title: EU to hit Russia with new sanctions over 'barbaric' attack on Ukraine
summary: The European Union is set to impose new sanctions on Russia due to its "barbaric attack" on Ukraine, with freezing of assets, halting of bank access, and targeting of "Kremlin interests". The sanctions come after President Vladimir Putin authorized a special military operation in Ukraine. EU leaders, including Ursula von der Leyen, have condemned Putin's actions and vowed to hold him accountable.

site_title: Rolls-Royce CEO East to step down after turbulent reign
summary: Rolls-Royce CEO Warren East is set to step down at the end of 2022 after leading the company through a challenging period, including the COVID-19 pandemic. East struggled to make the company more efficient, and despite cost cuts and a restart of long-distance travel, Rolls-Royce reported a disappointing earnings forecast for 2022. The company expects revenue growth of less than 10% and little change in profit margin. East's departure comes after a 7-year tenure, during which he implemented a restructuring that cut thousands of jobs and improved underlying profit to £414 million.

site_title: Taiwan to reopen to business travellers in March
summary: Taiwan plans to reopen to business travelers starting March 7, easing restrictions that have been in place since last May. The 14-day mandatory quarantine for all arrivals will be cut to 10 days, and a mask mandate will be eased from March 1. Foreigners, including Chinese nationals, will need to apply in-person or online to enter the country for business purposes. The decision aims to boost the economy while maintaining control over the pandemic. The move comes after Taiwan successfully kept Covid-19 at bay for the first year of the pandemic.

site_title: Biden says US will impose 'further consequences' on Russia
summary: President Joe Biden announced plans to impose "further consequences" on Russia following Vladimir Putin's order of troops into eastern Ukraine, which Biden described as an "unprovoked and unjustified attack." Biden vowed a "united and decisive" response with US allies and partners, without specifying the punishments. He will outline the penalties in an address to the American people on Thursday.

site_title: Budweiser sees strong demand for premium beer in China
summary: Budweiser APAC, Asia's largest beer company, plans to promote high-end beer in China, capitalizing on strong demand for limited edition beer gift sets priced over 1,500 yuan. The company currently holds 45% of China's premium and super premium beer market, with a growing trend of consumers drinking less but better beer. Budweiser reported an 84.8% surge in net profit for 2021, driven by premium sales. The high-end market is expected to drive growth in the beer industry, with major brands also launching super high-end products in China.

site_title: ECB must keep buying bonds to cushion Ukraine fallout: policymaker
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) should continue its bond-buying stimulus program until the end of the year to cushion the economic fallout from a potential conflict in Ukraine, according to ECB policymaker Yannis Stournaras. Stournaras, the Greek central bank chief, urged the ECB to err on the side of caution due to the economic uncertainty, suggesting the program should be kept open-ended. He also recommended that the ECB formally take rate cuts off the table but maintain flexibility in timing interest rate hikes.

site_title: Bitcoin tumbles as Putin orders military into Ukraine
summary: Bitcoin fell to a 1-month low of $34,783, 7.4% down from its previous value, amid Vladimir Putin's decision to conduct military operations in eastern Ukraine. The move has weighed down other cryptocurrencies, with Ether declining 8.7%. The Russia-Ukraine conflict has undermined the argument that cryptocurrencies offer a hedge in times of trouble, with experts warning of potential lower levels in the low $20,000s.

site_title: Brokers' take: SAC Capital initiates 'hold' on First Reit with S$0.32 target
summary: SAC Capital initiated coverage on First Reit with a "hold" call and a target price of S$0.32, based on the dividend discount model and a cost of equity of 12.5%. Analyst Lam Wang Kwan cited the restructured master lease agreements of 14 Indonesian properties as providing the trust with more sustainable income. The target price assumes a stable dividend yield and is in line with the company's recent restructure.

images.alt_text: Above: One of the 12 properties of First Reit's acquisition in Japan. SAC Capital initiated coverage on First Reit with a "hold" call and a S$0.32 target price.

site_title: Singapore flags concern to India over ban on Sea's game: sources
summary: Singapore has expressed concerns to India about the ban of Free Fire, a gaming app owned by Sea Ltd, citing the impact on investors and the potential for a broader crackdown on Chinese apps. The ban led to a $16 billion drop in Sea's market value. Singapore has asked Indian authorities why the app was targeted, despite Sea's headquarters being in the country. This move is seen as the first diplomatic intervention following the ban, which has raised worries about potential extension to Shopee, Sea's e-commerce app.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts mixed on OCBC after Q4 results miss consensus
summary: Analysts at Maybank Securities downgraded OCBC to "hold" from "buy" after the bank's Q4 FY2021 results missed consensus expectations by 19%. Despite a higher interest income due to rising rates, Maybank analysts believe OCBC is exposed to volatility and lower earnings due to its large dependence on market-linked income sources. RHB and DBS Group Research maintained their "buy" calls on OCBC with different target prices, citing potential growth and improved net interest margins. OCBC's new strategy to drive growth and deepen wealth capabilities has also been met with mixed views.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end lower after Russia launches attack on Ukraine
summary: South Korean stocks ended lower on Thursday, marking their worst day in a month, after Russia launched an attack on Ukraine. The benchmark Kospi fell 70.73 points, or 2.6%, to 2,648.80, its sharpest decline since January 27. Chip giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix led the decline, while the won fell to a 3-week low. The Bank of Korea kept interest rates steady but raised inflation forecasts and signaled a possible quicker pace of tightening due to the Ukraine crisis.

site_title: Limited impact on chips yet as Russia invades Ukraine, future uncertain
summary: Russia's invasion of Ukraine has raised concerns about the impact on the global semiconductor chip supply chain, but large chip companies predict limited disruption due to raw material stockpiling and diversified procurement. Ukraine supplies 90% of US semiconductor-grade neon, and Russia is a significant source of palladium. Companies such as ASML Holding and Intel Corp have already started examining alternative sources for neon, and most chipmakers are confident about their supply chains. However, some industry sources worry about the longer-term impact and the potential for further disruptions if Russia retaliates against US export curbs.

site_title: Malaysia debt turns into emerging market haven as Fed hikes near
summary: Malaysia's debt has become an emerging market haven as investors flock to the country's bonds, driven by higher oil prices and demand from domestic pension funds. In January, overseas investors bought $1.1 billion of Malaysian bonds, the largest in 9 months, while local demand rose due to institutional investors seeking assurance on government securities. Despite global market volatility, Malaysian bonds remain attractive due to the resilient ringgit and relatively low yields, expected to continue in the first half of 2022.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks sink on Ukraine invasion
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 3.21% on February 24, 2022, amid Russia's invasion of Ukraine, fueling fears of a major war in eastern Europe. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 22,901.56, while the Shanghai Composite Index fell 1.70% and the Shenzhen Composite Index shed 2.36%. The losses followed recent declines in tech firms.

site_title: Oil breaches US$100 after Russia attacks targets across Ukraine
summary: Oil prices surge above US$100 a barrel for the first time since 2014 after Russia's attack on cities across Ukraine, sparking fears of a disruption to the region's energy exports. The escalation has pushed prices to a 8-year high, with Brent oil reaching US$101.51 a barrel, and West Texas Intermediate at US$96.11 a barrel. The Opec+ coalition's struggles to restore production quickly enough has led to concerns of a tight market, with some predicting prices will average US$110 in the second quarter and US$90 by the end of the year.

site_title: Australia: Shares see worst day in 1-1/2 years as Russia-Ukraine crisis worsens
summary: Australian shares plummeted 3% on Feb 24, marking their worst day in nearly 1.5 years, amid heightened geopolitical tensions following Russia's military operation in Ukraine. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell to 6,990.6, with miners and banks leading the losses. Technology stocks suffered the biggest percentage decline, while gold stocks rose 4.3% after gold prices surged to a 1-year high. The benchmark is on track for its first weekly loss this month.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei ends down 1.8% on Ukraine crisis
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index fell 1.81% on February 24, 2022, as investors reacted to Russian President Vladimir Putin's announcement of a "military operation" in Ukraine, prompting fears of a full-scale war. The benchmark index closed at 25,970.82. Despite concerns, market strategist Hirofumi Yamamoto believes the market may not worsen if the situation doesn't escalate. Other Asian markets, such as the Topix index, also declined, with several airlines and retailers experiencing sharp drops.

site_title: Nanofilm eyes growth in renewables, micro-lens array as it grows product portfolio
summary: Nanofilm Technologies, a mainboard-listed company, is poised for growth with increased capacity from its Shanghai Plant 2, which is twice the size of Plant 1. The company recorded 8% net profit growth in FY2021 to S$62.2 million, driven by its micro-lens array (MLA) technology and industrial equipment business unit. MLA has various use cases, including heart rate sensors and automotive applications, while the industrial equipment business grew 81% year on year to S$45 million. Nanofilm will continue investing in research and development, with a focus on renewable energy and consumer technology.

site_title: Aluminium jumps to record as Russian attack boosts supply risks
summary: Aluminium prices surged to a record in London due to rising supply risks amid the Ukraine crisis. US President Joe Biden warned Russia faces "severe sanctions" after Vladimir Putin's military attack, potentially disrupting Russian aluminium shipments to Europe. Analysts expect disruptions to Russia's natural gas exports to increase energy costs at European smelters, further hampering aluminium production. The market will closely monitor the situation, anticipating potential sanctions that could affect Russian supplies of the metal.

site_title: Cloudflare to buy Area 1 Security in its biggest acquisition
summary: Cloudflare has agreed to buy email protection provider Area 1 Security for $162 million, its largest acquisition to date. The deal is expected to close in the second quarter and aims to tackle potential cyber vulnerabilities for businesses. Cloudflare co-founder Matthew Prince notes that "email is still the No 1 place where security threats come from" and the acquisition is expected to lead to a significant uptick in adoption and revenue. The deal follows Cloudflare's release of its own email security tool in 2021, which has led to robust demand from customers.

site_title: Brokers' take: RHB upgrades Riverstone to 'neutral', calls current valuation fair
summary: RHB upgraded Riverstone Holdings to "neutral" from "sell" with a target price of S$0.74, citing a fair current valuation. The upgrade comes as Riverstone trades at 16 times earnings estimates for FY2023, in line with its historical average. The new target implies a 6.3% potential downside from the current trading price of S$0.79.

site_title: SUTL scraps plans for Puteri Harbour marina, to terminate membership scheme
summary: SUTL Enterprise has scrapped plans for its ONE°15 Puteri Harbour Malaysia marina due to sluggish demand for long-term memberships and an unfavorable macro environment. The company will terminate its membership scheme and offer compensation to existing members, with plans to sell the assets after the program is terminated. This decision is not expected to have a material effect on the company's financials for the year ending Dec 31, 2022.

site_title: Food inflation risks balloon as prices of wheat to palm oil soar
summary: Food prices are expected to rise as wheat, palm oil, and soybeans surge due to the Russia-Ukraine crisis, which has disrupted global supply chains. Wheat prices have reached their highest level since 2012, while drought in South America has reduced soybean supplies. Palm oil, used in thousands of products, has also seen record-breaking gains due to a labour shortage in Malaysia. The crisis is likely to further squeeze household budgets already strained by rising inflation, with a measure of global food costs nearing a record high.

site_title: China says will keep real estate market stable this year
summary: China's housing minister, Wang Menghui, announced that the country will maintain a stable real estate market this year, focusing on eliminating project delivery risks and refining property policies. Genuine demand for housing remains firm, according to Wang. The country will also step up coordination to address individual property developers' debt defaults. These measures aim to stabilize the market and prevent further risks.

site_title: Singapore delays plans to 'reset' Covid-19 rules as cases cross 20,000 mark for 2 days
summary: Singapore has delayed plans to "reset" its Covid-19 rules due to a surge in daily cases exceeding 20,000 for two consecutive days. The Ministry of Health announced that the current rules will remain in place until a revised effective date is announced. The original plan, set to streamline safe management measures into 5 core parameters, will be postponed. The decision comes as the country struggles with an Omicron wave, with healthcare providers under significant pressure.

site_title: Russia says it is targeting Ukraine's military infrastructure: RIA
summary: Russia claims it is targeting Ukraine's military infrastructure, air defense, and air forces with high-precision weapons, contradicting Kyiv's assertion that Moscow is launching a full-scale attack on the country. The Russian defense ministry stated that Ukrainian cities are not being attacked.

site_title: F&B outlets, gyms, bank branches face ad-hoc closures amid Covid-linked staff crunch
summary: Covid-19 linked staff absences are disrupting business operations in Singapore, resulting in temporary closures and reduced services. F&B outlets, gyms, and bank branches have been affected, with some temporarily shutting down due to staffing issues. The multi-ministry taskforce on Covid-19 warned of high case numbers potentially disrupting manpower resourcing, prompting firms to prepare business continuity plans. Some businesses, such as UOB and Ritual Gym, have had to temporarily close branches or outlets, while others, like Bernard Tay's Jinjja Chicken, have reduced working shifts and delivery orders to manage workload.

site_title: Regional markets fall as Russia orders strikes on Ukraine
summary: Regional markets plummeted on Thursday as Russia ordered strikes on Ukraine, with Singapore's Straits Times Index falling 4.1% and Japan's Nikkei hitting a 15-month low. The US Dow futures dropped 600 points, while Brent oil prices surged above $100 a barrel. Global stocks declined, with multiple indices in Asia and Australia recording declines, and cryptocurrencies also fell. US President Joe Biden condemned the action as "unprovoked and unjustified" and announced further consequences for Russia.

site_title: AIA Group to sell some Australian assets to Resolution Life
summary: AIA Group has agreed to sell its Australian superannuation and investments business to Resolution Life for over A$8 billion, transferring funds under management from 2017. The sale will streamline AIA's portfolio, adding 162,000 new customers to Resolution Life, and allow the company to capitalize on its digital platform investments. The transaction will be completed within 18 months, with AIA Australia providing transitional services during this period.

site_title: Asean central banks to hike rates from end-Q2, starting with Malaysia, Philippines: UOB
summary: ASEAN central banks are expected to hike interest rates from the end of Q2 2022, starting with Malaysia and the Philippines, according to UOB's research team. The Bank Negara Malaysia and Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas are projected to increase their rates by 25 basis points each, while the Bank of Thailand is expected to follow with a 25 bps hike in the third quarter. The Bank Indonesia is expected to deliver the most hawkish rate hikes, with a cumulative increase of 100 basis points in the second half of 2022.

site_title: URA tender of Pine Grove plot could net bids of up to S$1,300 psf ppr: observers
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has announced the sale by public tender of a residential plot, Pine Grove (Parcel A), in the Clementi area. The site, with a site area of 22,534.7 sq m, is expected to attract 7-8 bidders with top bids potentially reaching S$1,300 psf ppr. The lease period will be 99 years, and the maximum building height is 153 metres. The tender will close on Jun 2, 2022.

site_title: Exxon's workforce falls by 9,000 in 2021 amid cost cuts
summary: ExxonMobil reported a 9,000-person workforce reduction in 2021 as part of its cost-cutting program. The global workforce fell to 63,000 regular employees, down from 72,000 in 2020 and 74,900 before the pandemic. The company aims to boost shareholder returns after a historic loss in 2020. Exxon plans to combine its refining and chemicals businesses, cut $6 billion in operating costs by next year, and has sold assets to reduce costs. The restructuring efforts helped the company post its best annual profit in 7 years in 2021.

site_title: Bank of Japan won't roll back stimulus soon but watching rising costs: Kuroda
summary: The Bank of Japan's Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated that the central bank has no immediate plans to roll back its massive stimulus despite rising import costs. Kuroda emphasized the yen's movement aligns with economic fundamentals, countering criticism that ultra-low interest rates and a yen decline are driving up households' living costs. The BOJ will monitor public perceptions and rising global inflation, maintaining ultra-loose monetary policy until Japan's inflation reaches the desired level.

site_title: Asia: Markets down, oil up as Ukraine keeps traders on edge
summary: Asian markets plummeted, with major indices in Hong Kong, Tokyo, Shanghai, and others falling, as Russia's military operation in Ukraine sent oil prices soaring to nearly US$100 per barrel. The US and international community remain on edge, with warnings of a devastating global impact and potential refugee crisis. World leaders struggle to de-escalate the situation, and the threat of a major war in Europe has sent markets spiraling, fueling concerns about inflation and the global economic recovery.

site_title: Russia invades Ukraine after Putin orders strikes; oil soars, markets dive
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin ordered strikes against Ukraine, prompting widespread attacks on cities across the country. Putin claimed the operation was aimed at demilitarizing Ukraine, but Ukraine's foreign minister described it as a "full-scale invasion." The US and its allies have condemned the move, with President Joe Biden vowing to hold Russia accountable. Global markets have been severely impacted, with oil prices soaring and stock markets plummeting. The US 10-year Treasury yield fell to 1.90%, while gold hit its highest since early 2021.

images.alt_text: Black smoke rises from a military airport in Chuguyev near Kharkiv on Feb 24, 2022. Russian President Vladimir Putin announced a military operation in Ukraine on Thursday with explosions heard soon after across the country.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at Thursday's open; STI down 1%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 1% on Thursday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) down 34.29 points to 3,358.71, due to losses on Wall Street. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 fell 1.4% and 1.8%, respectively, amid worries over the Ukraine crisis and shifting Federal Reserve policy. European stocks also declined, while Asian markets, including Tokyo, opened lower.

site_title: LS 2 Holdings ends Catalist debut at S$0.88, up from IPO price of S$0.20
summary: LS 2 Holdings, a cleaning services company, ended its debut on the Singapore Exchange's Catalist board at S$0.88, up from its IPO price of S$0.20. The company raised S$5.6 million, with S$4.4 million going towards business expansion and S$1.4 million for working capital. CEO Alvin Ong stated that the listing will boost brand value and create new business opportunities, with plans to diversify services to include horticultural and infrastructure-level cleaning services.

site_title: Hong Kong invokes emergency powers to allow in China medics
summary: Hong Kong's government invoked emergency powers to allow Chinese mainland doctors and nurses to practice in the city, amid a spiraling coronavirus outbreak. The city reported a record 8,674 new Covid-19 infections on Wednesday and is preparing for compulsory testing of its 7.4 million people. The government has tightened restrictions, including a vaccine passport requirement and mask mandates, and is building community and isolation units to address the shortage of healthcare workers and facilities. The city's healthcare system is expected to be insufficient to handle the surge in cases.

site_title: Australia: Shares fall on Ukraine jitters; CIMIC Group soars
summary: Australia's shares plummeted nearly 2% on Thursday, hitting their lowest in over two weeks, amid rising fears of a full-scale Russian invasion of Ukraine. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 1.8% to 7,077.80. In contrast, CIMIC Group soared 30% after a bid from Hochtief, its highest in four months. Global markets reacted sharply to Ukraine's state of emergency and US State Department warnings of a potential Russian invasion. Miners, tech stocks, and Qantas Airways also fell, with iron ore prices slumping due to concerns about demand in China.

images.alt_text: Australian shares dropped nearly 2 per cent on Thursday to hit their lowest in more than two weeks, as Ukraine announced a state of emergency amid rising fears of a full-scale Russian invasion, while CIMIC Group soared over 30 per cent following a bid from Hochtief.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Thursday, down 4.69 points or 0.30% to 1,581.45. Losers outnumbered gainers 218 to 134. The market saw a decline in volume, with 120.16 million lots worth RM87.93 million traded.

site_title: Global economy downshifting towards trend growth: Moody's
summary: Moody's Investors Service expects the global economy to expand 4.3% in 2022, down from 5.9% in 2021, but still above long-term trend growth. The forecast is challenged by elevated commodity prices, demand-supply imbalances, inflation, and volatile financial markets. Supply bottlenecks are expected to ease in the second half of 2022, but the outlook varies by country, with China facing significant risks due to its zero-Covid policy. Emerging markets, such as Mexico and Brazil, are experiencing slower recoveries, while advanced economies like the US, Canada, and Europe are experiencing similar growth dynamics.

site_title: Emerging markets drive global debt to record US$303t: IIF
summary: The global debt has reached a record US$303 trillion in 2021, driven by emerging markets, particularly China, which accounts for over 80% of the increase. Emerging market debt is approaching US$100 trillion, posing significant refinancing needs for these countries. Despite a slowdown in debt accumulation, emerging market governments remain reliant on off-budget borrowing, and the global debt-to-GDP ratio fell to 351% in 2021, still above pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: Sunseap to shelve IPO plans after S$1.1b buyout; Temasek sold all 12% of its stake
summary: Sunseap Group, a Singapore-based renewable energy company, has shelved its initial public offering (IPO) plans after being acquired by EDP Renewables (EDPR) for S$1.1 billion. EDPR, the world's fourth-largest renewable energy producer, will invest S$10 billion by 2030 to establish its Asia-Pacific headquarters in Singapore through Sunseap, creating over 750 green jobs. Sunseap's founders will remain part of the top management team, and EDPR's involvement will provide much of the funding required for Sunseap's upcoming projects.

site_title: Cross-border e-commerce startup OpenCommerce Group secures US$7m in Series A round
summary: Vietnam-based cross-border e-commerce startup OpenCommerce Group (OCG) has secured US$7 million in Series A funding led by VNG and Do Ventures. Since its launch, OCG has enabled 86,700 sellers across 195 countries to set up e-commerce stores, generating US$670 million in gross merchandise value. The startup plans to utilize the funding to improve its services, expand in the US and Europe, and corner a major market share in China, aiming to lower the threshold of entrepreneurship for sellers of all ages and backgrounds.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks drop in opening trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 1.66% in the opening trade on February 24, 2022, due to concerns over a potential Russian invasion of Ukraine. The Hang Seng Index fell to 23,268.03, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also declined. The market's decline was triggered by separatists seeking help from Moscow, fueling fears of a Russian invasion.

site_title: Meta's Zuckerberg unveils AI projects aimed at building metaverse future
summary: Meta CEO Mark Zuckerberg unveiled AI projects aimed at building a metaverse future, where users can interact in virtual environments. The company is researching AI to generate worlds through speech, improve voice assistant interactions, and translate languages. Zuckerberg sees the metaverse as the successor to the mobile internet, with AI playing a key role in unlocking its advances.

site_title: Macron 'to kick off re-election bid in March'
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron is set to launch his re-election bid on March 5 with an inaugural campaign rally in Marseille. Polls indicate he is likely to win the first round of voting on April 10, but securing a second term in the run-off vote two weeks later is uncertain due to strong opposition from far-right parties. Macron faces competition from Marine Le Pen, Eric Zemmour, and Valerie Pecresse.

site_title: Oil steadies as US seen unlikely to sanction Russian exports
summary: Oil prices steadied on Wednesday, holding below 2014 highs, after US officials indicated Russia's energy supplies would not be sanctioned due to the escalating tensions between Russia and Ukraine. Brent crude and US West Texas Intermediate crude futures remained unchanged, settling at $96.84 and $92.10 per barrel, respectively. This news led to a stabilization of oil prices, preventing a potential surge.

site_title: Gold rises as escalating Ukraine crisis spurs safe-haven bids
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to a 9-month high of $1,913.89 per ounce as investors sought refuge in safe havens amid the escalating Ukraine crisis and Western sanctions on Russia. Spot gold rose to $1,912.40 per ounce, while US gold futures climbed 0.2% to $1,913.20. The crisis led to a decline in the rouble and increased tensions in the energy market, with palladium hovering near a 6-month peak.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower on Russia-Ukraine tensions
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday, extending falls on Wall Street, amid rising tensions between Russia and Ukraine. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.61% and the Topix index fell 0.53%, as investors avoided risks. This follows global market trends, with US stocks reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Ho Bee Land buys London office tower The Scalpel for £718m
summary: Ho Bee Land has acquired London office tower The Scalpel for £718m, with a deposit of £35.9m paid and the balance payable upon completion on March 7. The 36-storey building offers 406,000 sq ft of Grade A office space and a 10-year secure long-term income of £29m. The acquisition is expected to positively contribute to Ho Bee Land's consolidated earnings per share and net tangible assets per share for the financial year ending December 31, 2022.

site_title: Qantas points to improving outlook after Omicron delays recovery plans
summary: Qantas Airways posted a A$1.28 billion underlying loss in the first half of 2022, despite a significant boost from the reopening of Australia's borders. The Omicron Covid-19 outbreak delayed business recovery plans by around six months. The airline cut domestic and international capacity plans by one third due to the variant, but expects a surge in demand for the upcoming Easter holiday period. Qantas remains on track to finalize orders for 40 Airbus planes and A350 widebody jets, and is optimistic about its outlook.

site_title: Blackstone plans to double headcount in Asia targeting wealthy
summary: Blackstone plans to double its headcount in Asia to target wealthy individuals, with a focus on Singapore, Hong Kong, and Tokyo. The US firm aims to provide innovative solutions for high-net-worth investors through partnerships with private banks and wealth advisors. This move follows a broader recruitment drive to boost allocations to its funds, as the region's rich invest heavily in alternative assets to escape low-interest rates and volatile markets.

site_title: South Korea's central bank stands pat after back-to-back rate hikes
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, maintained its benchmark interest rate at 1.25% after two consecutive rate hikes. The decision comes as the economy faces challenges from surging COVID-19 cases and geopolitical risks. The Bank of Korea raised its inflation forecast to 3.1% for 2022, and analysts expect the central bank to resume rate hikes in the second quarter, targeting a base rate of 1.75% by the end of 2022.

site_title: Airlines should stop flying over all of Ukraine's airspace: conflict zone monitor
summary: Airlines should stop flying over all of Ukraine's airspace due to the risk of unintended shootdowns or cyber attacks targeting air traffic control amid tensions with Russia, according to Safe Airspace, a conflict zone monitor. The organization has increased its risk level to "do not fly" despite no actual Russian military movements in Ukraine. The extreme level of tension and uncertainty in Ukraine poses significant risks to civil aviation. This decision is based on the potential for an unintended incident, rather than actual military actions.

site_title: Retail Reits get a boost from 2-step GST hike but still lack growth catalysts
summary: Retail Reits in Singapore, which are exposed to retail malls, are expected to benefit from a delayed and staggered Goods and Services Tax (GST) hike, with some seeing tenant sales rise above pre-pandemic levels. The staggered increase, initially set for 2023 and 2024, is seen as a positive for consumer spending, with Frasers Centrepoint Trust and SPH Reit's suburban malls reporting increases in tenant sales. However, the lack of acquisition-led growth and concerns over potential interest rate hikes may hinder the sector's long-term growth.

site_title: Sunak extols lower taxes as UK tax burden heads for 70-year high
summary: British Finance Minister Rishi Sunak reaffirmed his support for lower taxes, stating that a lower-tax economy brings economic freedom and prosperity. The government's tax take is set to reach a 70-year high due to increased social security contributions and a sharp jump in corporation tax rate in 2023. Sunak emphasized the need for responsible tax cuts to tackle long-term challenges, dismissing the claim that 'tax cuts always pay for themselves' as unfounded.

site_title: UK pledges £160m to global vaccine drive
summary: The UK has pledged an additional £160 million to the Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations (CEPI) to support global vaccine development, aiming to produce a global shot within 100 days of any future pandemic. This funding, on top of the existing £276 million, will help CEPI develop "variant-proof" vaccines against multiple Covid-19 strains. The announcement comes ahead of the Global Pandemic Preparedness Summit in London, which will raise funds for CEPI's goal and bring together global leaders to discuss pandemic preparedness.

site_title: US truckers launch 'The People's Convoy' in pandemic protest
summary: US truckers have launched "The People's Convoy" in a 11-day drive to protest against pandemic restrictions, including mask mandates and vaccination requirements. The convoy, which began in southern California on February 23, aims to reach Washington DC by March 5. The movement, which includes both Republicans and Democrats, has attracted over $450,000 in donations and features supporters calling for an end to government restrictions in favor of freedom and liberty. The convoy's route does not include entering the city itself, but has raised concerns among authorities, who have mobilized 700 National Guard members to provide security.

site_title: Biden slaps sanctions on Russia's Nord Stream 2 pipeline
summary: US President Joe Biden announced sanctions on Russia's Nord Stream 2 natural gas pipeline project, joining Germany in retaliation for Moscow's military pressure on Ukraine. The project, which bypasses Ukraine and supplies energy to the European Union, has been built but not used. The sanctions, which include halting the project, are seen as a significant blow to Russia's geostrategic initiative and may tighten Russia's grip on European nations. The move comes amid escalating tensions between Russia and Western countries.

site_title: Australia business investment bounces in Q4, outlook upgraded
summary: Australian business investment rose 1.1% in Q4 to A$33.3 billion, missing forecasts of a 2.6% increase, but spending plans for the year to June 2022 were upgraded to A$144.8 billion, above analysts' estimates. The modest growth suggests business confidence weathered pandemic disruptions, with miners benefiting from high resource prices. The upgraded spending plans indicate a positive outlook for the country's economy.

site_title: Koufu privatisation offer closes with 98.19% valid acceptances; trading suspended
summary: Koufu's founders' voluntary conditional cash offer for the company closed with 98.19% valid acceptances, resulting in the offeror, Jun Yuan Holdings, gaining control. The offeror tendered 428 million shares, representing a 77.41% stake in the company. Trading of Koufu's shares was suspended due to the loss of its free float.

site_title: Italy to exit Covid-19 state of emergency on March 31
summary: Italy will end its Covid-19 state of emergency on March 31, allowing for the gradual lifting of pandemic-related rules, Prime Minister Mario Draghi announced. The move comes after more than two years of a health crisis that has killed over 153,000 people. The country will initially roll back rules for outdoor activities, including fairs, sports, and festivals, but will continue to monitor the pandemic situation and be prepared to intervene if necessary.

site_title: US home ownership jumps, but race gap widens: data report
summary: US home ownership surged 1.3% in 2020, the largest annual increase since 1960, but a racial gap widened as more Black households were priced out. Home ownership rates for Black Americans decreased to 43.4% in 2020, below the 44.2% in 2010. The racial gap between White and Black households grew, with White households owning 72.1% of homes and Black households at 43.4%. High home prices and mortgage denial rates contribute to the persistence of the racial wealth gap.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slip after Ukraine issues state of emergency
summary: European stocks declined 0.3% on Wednesday, weighed down by concerns over the Russia-Ukraine conflict. Ukraine declared a state of emergency and warned citizens in Russia to flee, while Moscow began evacuating its Kyiv embassy. Western sanctions on Russia and strong corporate earnings updates helped limit losses. The Stoxx 600 index slipped despite 63% of reported companies beating analysts' profit estimates. Energy prices remain elevated, increasing stagflation risks, and investors worry about the impact of sanctions on oil supplies.

site_title: Google allows some US employees to work from office, eases Covid-19 norms
summary: Google is allowing some US employees to return to the office, easing Covid-19 norms as cases ease in the US. Employees who choose to work from the office must be fully vaccinated or have an approved accommodation, and will be required to wear masks. The company is also lifting its weekly Covid-19 testing policy and restoring office amenities such as fitness centers and cafes. About 30% of Google's Bay Area employees worked onsite last week, with working from the office remaining voluntary.

site_title: Hong Kong budget offers Covid relief with tax breaks, handouts
summary: Hong Kong's government has announced a budget offering tax breaks, handouts, and subsidies to mitigate the impact of the city's strict social restrictions to curb the spread of COVID-19. The 2022/23 budget proposes HK$807.3 billion in spending, including a 100% reduction in salaries tax and handouts of HK$10,000 consumption vouchers. The measures aim to support small businesses, residents, and directly impacted businesses, with total countercyclical measures totaling over HK$170 billion.

site_title: US: Stocks tumble again on worries over Ukraine, Federal Reserve
summary: US stocks plummeted on Wednesday, marking the fourth consecutive drop, amid concerns over the Ukraine crisis and shifting Federal Reserve policy. Russian President Vladimir Putin's recognition of two eastern provinces' independence fueled worries. Ukraine's parliament imposed a national state of emergency in response to the threat of a full-scale Russian invasion. The market's decline was exacerbated by uncertainty over the Fed's policy stance, with investors awaiting guidance on interest rates.

site_title: UN warns of dire global impact of a Russian invasion of Ukraine
summary: The UN has warned of a dire global impact if Russia invades Ukraine, with UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres stating that a conflict could displace up to five million people, sparking a new "refugee crisis." The US and Ukraine's foreign minister have also warned of devastating consequences, including a potential food crisis and economic instability. The UN General Assembly meeting, attended by all 193 member states, condemned Russia's actions, but a formal resolution is unlikely due to Russia's veto power.

site_title: Euro edges higher, but focus still on Ukraine
summary: The euro edged higher against the dollar on February 23, driven by investors' optimism about a peaceful resolution to the Ukrainian crisis. Analysts at Ebury expect a "risk-on" currency market if the crisis is resolved, while SEB Group analysts warn of a cautious message from the European Central Bank at its March meeting if further escalation occurs. The Russian rouble weakened, and China's yuan reached a fresh 4-year high against the dollar amid increased foreign demand.

site_title: PropNex Q4 profit soars 90.5% on higher commission income
summary: PropNex, a Singapore-based real estate agency, reported a net profit of S$14.3 million for Q4 FY2021, up 90.5% year-over-year, driven by higher commission income and increased transactions. Revenue rose 56.1% to S$242 million. The company's earnings per share increased by 90.1% to S$0.0386. A final dividend of S$0.07 per share and an interim dividend of S$0.055 are proposed, totaling S$0.125. The board attributes the growth to improving economic and Covid-19 conditions, with the company projecting a strong 2022.

images.alt_text: Above: Ismail Gafoor, chief executive officer, chairmain and co-founder of PropNex. The profit comes as revenue for the 3 months went up to S$242 million.

site_title: US home prices saw biggest jump in 34 years in 2021
summary: US home prices surged 18.8% in 2021, the largest jump in 34 years, according to the S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller US National Home Price index. The US real estate market saw the most existing homes sold in 15 years, with sales topping six million despite a supply shortage. Material costs and worker shortages contributed to the price increase, which was most severe in cities like Phoenix, Tampa, and Miami. Experts predict the housing market may cool due to rising interest rates and easing supply chain issues.

site_title: Ukraine to declare nationwide state of emergency; EU set to ban Russia bonds in sanctions response
summary: Ukraine is set to declare a nationwide state of emergency in response to Russia's recognition of two breakaway regions, which will last 30 days and grant officials the power to impose restrictions on movement and media. The European Union is also imposing sanctions on Russia, including a ban on purchasing its government bonds, in response to Moscow's actions. The move is part of a broader effort to punish Russia for its actions in Ukraine, with the US and UK also imposing sanctions. Despite the measures, China has expressed opposition to sanctions, and investors see limited impact on Russia's economy.

site_title: Certis donates S$30,000 to help persons with disabilities realise their sporting ambitions
summary: Certis has donated S$30,000 to support the "Dare to Dream" initiative, a new program encouraging persons with disabilities to pursue their sporting ambitions in partnership with the Singapore Disability Sports Council. The initiative includes the "Certis Superheroes Challenge" and will match participants with suitable sports. The program aims to provide more opportunities for persons with disabilities to experience sports and lead active lives. The donation will support the national goalball women's team's overseas participation in competitions leading up to the Asean Para Games 2022.

site_title: Ukraine and the Crisis of American Self-Belief
summary: The US involvement in the Ukraine crisis has sparked skepticism about America's self-belief, with questions about its history of invasions and interventions, domestic record of slavery and discrimination, and foreign record of supporting dictators. The article suggests that the US should proceed with more self-awareness, humility, and respect for the reality of unintended consequences. Meanwhile, Russian President Vladimir Putin has chosen to make a move on Ukraine due to a combination of factors, including the country's weak state, lack of resources, and desire to expand his sphere of influence. Putin's greatest advantage is his self-belief, which has allowed him to maintain a convincing narrative about Ukraine's non-existence as a true state.

site_title: Three plead guilty to white supremacist plot to attack US power grid
summary: Three US men, Christopher Cook, Jonathan Frost, and Jackson Sawall, pleaded guilty to planning a white supremacist plot to attack power grids, aiming to cause economic damage and spark a race war. The plot involved providing material support to terrorists, and the defendants admitted to furthering white supremacist ideology. Assistant Attorney General Matthew Olsen stated that the defendants' actions were "disturbing" and aimed to "stoke division" in the country. The men face federal charges and will likely receive prison sentences for their roles in the plot.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher after modest sanctions on Russia
summary: US stocks opened higher on Wednesday after modest sanctions on Russia, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 0.25%, the S&P 500 gaining 0.47%, and the Nasdaq Composite increasing 0.97%. The sanctions, imposed by Western nations, have investors keeping a close watch on the Russia-Ukraine crisis.

site_title: US mortgage businesses seen laying off thousands as volume drops
summary: US home mortgage lenders are expected to lay off thousands of workers as the volume of home lending decreases. The number of mortgage brokers has surged 50% since 2019, reaching a 13-year high. However, this hiring spree may be reversed, with some experts predicting a wave of layoffs. The decline in lending volume is attributed to various factors, including rising mortgage rates.

site_title: Living in the metaverse: Are we there yet?
summary: The metaverse, a merging of virtual, augmented, and physical reality, is gaining excitement as companies like Meta, Microsoft, and Activision Blizzard announce plans to support it. However, achieving its full potential requires significant upgrades to digital infrastructure, including 1,000 times greater computational efficiency and ultra-low latency. To overcome these challenges, enterprises must adopt a metaverse-ready digital infrastructure, including a digital core, ecosystem, and edge. By deploying these components, organisations can unlock the true promise of the metaverse and gain a competitive advantage.

site_title: Carving a new growth engine while balancing environmental and economic concerns
summary: Singapore's Budget 2022 aims to create a new growth engine by balancing environmental and economic concerns. The government plans to expedite its green plan, with a projected gross value added (GVA) of $1.8 billion to $5.6 billion in carbon services by 2050. The current carbon tax will be raised to $80 a tonne by 2030 to achieve net zero emissions by 2050. The government also plans to promote a strong green finance ecosystem and support the growth of the voluntary carbon market, which is projected to reach $10-25 billion by 2030.

site_title: US consumer confidence slips; house prices maintain upward trend
summary: US consumer confidence fell to a 5-month low in February, with 110.5 reading, the lowest since September, amid concerns about the short-term economic outlook. However, the labour market remains strong, and the index remains above pandemic lows. Retail sales surged in January, and the manufacturing sector rebounded in February. Inflation expectations rose to 7.0%, leading to fewer plans to buy homes, cars, and take vacations. Despite this, economists expect a modest economic slowdown, with business activity regaining speed in the coming months.

site_title: EU rules take aim at illegal data transfer to non-EU govts
summary: The European Union has published a draft legislation, the Data Act, aimed at preventing non-EU governments from accessing EU data. The law requires cloud and data processing services providers, such as Amazon and Microsoft, to set up safeguards to protect EU data. The measure is part of the EU's efforts to curb the power of US tech giants and achieve its digital and green objectives. The law is expected to free up 270 billion euros of data for use, adding to the EU's GDP by 2028, and will also impose contractual requirements and interoperability standards on cloud services.

site_title: World awaits crucial IPCC climate report
summary: The UN-convened Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) is set to release a crucial climate report at the end of this month, which will outline the effects of climate change, future risks, and benefits for business and society. The report, issued every 5-7 years, will provide a no-holds-barred update on climate change and its impacts.
