The stakes are high, with the report expected to have significant implications for global efforts to combat global warming. The report's release will likely have far-reaching consequences for businesses, governments, and societies worldwide.

site_title: To fill empty retail space, landlords in US tap doctors and dentists
summary: US healthcare providers are expanding into retail space, taking advantage of depressed rents and pandemic-depressed demand. Known as "medtail," this trend involves former stores being repurposed for offices and clinics, with some landlords now seeking out healthcare tenants to fill vacancies and boost foot traffic. The trend has accelerated since the pandemic, with about 20% of leased medical space now in retail buildings, up from 16% in 2010. While it remains to be seen if this trend can put a dent in retail vacancies, healthcare providers are finding success in suburban malls and former department stores.

site_title: K-pop band BTS to return to US for in-person concerts
summary: BTS, a South Korean boy band, will return to the US for a series of concerts in Las Vegas in April, part of their "Permission to Dance on Stage" tour. The concerts, postponed due to the coronavirus pandemic, will be held on Apr 8-9 and Apr 15-16. The band, which has been touring internationally since 2013, previously played its first in-person concerts since the pandemic in November in Los Angeles. The shows will be the band's first live performances in the US since the pandemic began.

site_title: Enjoying green working spaces
summary: Private developers are incorporating green elements, such as rooftop farms and urban parks, into office buildings to blur the line between work and life. This trend is seen in commercial buildings like CapitaSpring and Guoco Tower, allowing tenants to enjoy nature while working. The integration of green spaces into office developments is becoming increasingly popular, promoting a healthier work-life balance.

site_title: World must brace for wilder fires, yet govts are ill-prepared
summary: The UN warns that major wildfires worldwide will increase sharply due to global warming, despite ambitious efforts to curb greenhouse gas emissions. A report by the UN Environment Programme concludes that the probability of extreme fire events will rise by 31-57% by the end of the century. Climate change is turning landscapes into "tinderboxes," fueling stronger, hotter, and drier winds that fan the flames, causing devastating impacts on people, wildlife, and the economy. Governments are ill-prepared to handle the death and destruction caused by mega-blazes, and the report calls for a rethink on how to tackle the problem, prioritizing prevention and risk reduction.

site_title: Covid fraud will cost UK up to £15.7b: MPs
summary: A UK parliamentary committee estimates £15.7 billion in Covid-related fraud and errors will cost taxpayers, citing £5.3 billion in losses from the furlough programme. The government has spent £261 billion on pandemic measures, with £370 billion expected over its lifetime. Committee Chairman Meg Hillier blames "lack of preparedness and planning" for the mistakes, waste, and opportunities for fraudsters.

site_title: Lim How Teck to take leave of absence as Heliconia chairman
summary: Heliconia Capital chairman Lim How Teck is taking a leave of absence from his role due to his arrest as lead independent director of Raffles Education Corp. following investigations into the company by the Monetary Authority of Singapore and Commercial Affairs Department. Lim was released on bail and will assist the authorities in investigations. He and other directors have not been charged, but will travel outside of Singapore if cleared beforehand. Acting chairman Koh Poh Guan will oversee the company during this time.

site_title: 20,312 new Covid-19 cases, 1,587 patients hospitalised
summary: Singapore reported 20,312 new Covid-19 cases on February 23, with 1,587 patients hospitalized, down from a record 26,032 on Tuesday. 46 cases were in the ICU, and 200 required oxygen support. Seven deaths were also reported. The weekly infection growth rate stood at 1.49, dipping from 1.57 the day before. As of February 23, Singapore has 642,605 total cases and 963 deaths, with 91% of the eligible population fully vaccinated.

site_title: PropertyBT: Will demand for Grade A office space return? (Ep 4)
summary: Senior correspondent Leslie Yee discusses his article arguing that Grade A office space will outperform despite the rise of remote working. He cites physical offices as relevant and cites industry players' opinions on the future of Singapore's office buildings. Property analysts are divided on the matter, with some predicting a decline in demand for Grade A office space, while others believe it will continue to be in demand due to the importance of face-to-face interactions and networking opportunities.

site_title: Aramco closes US$15.5b BlackRock-led gas pipeline deal
summary: Saudi Aramco has closed a $15.5 billion deal to sell a 49% stake in its natural-gas pipelines to a BlackRock-led consortium. The 20-year lease and leaseback agreement is part of Saudi Arabia's asset sale drive to fund new industries, including electric vehicles and artificial intelligence. This deal follows a similar $12.4 billion sale of oil pipeline stakes to investors in April, as the country seeks to diversify its economy and increase oil and gas production.

site_title: A 'just transition': How to ensure no one's left behind
summary: A "just transition" is essential to prevent individuals and communities from being left behind in the coming decade's transformations. The concept focuses on achieving greater equity, justice, and regeneration by prioritizing universal human rights. In the renewable energy sector, a shallow transition is on track, with issues including price pressures, human rights, governance, jobs, and power dynamics. To achieve a transformative transition, four levels of change are proposed: "Perpetuation of Status Quo," "Managerial Reform," "Structural Reform," and "Transformational." The latter involves shifting from extractive to regenerative models, addressing multiple challenges, and creating a lasting development opportunity.

site_title: High numbers indicate the Omicron wave will likely peak soon, say experts
summary: Singapore's Omicron wave is expected to peak soon, according to experts, with Associate Professor Alex Cook predicting the peak will occur within a fortnight. The wave, which started in December, has seen record-high infection numbers, with 26,000 cases reported on Tuesday. Experts agree that the peak will be followed by a fall in numbers, signaling the end of the wave. However, they also warn that the strain on the healthcare system will continue, and some measures may be unnecessary, citing the need to evaluate the effectiveness of COVID-19 restrictions.

site_title: ARA H-Trust posts US$2m distributable income
summary: ARA US Hospitality Trust (ARA H-Trust) posted a full-year distribution income of US$2 million, reversing a loss in the previous year. Net property income increased to US$24.9 million, while revenue rose 67.2% to S$130.7 million. Operating profit jumped 218.7% to US$40.5 million. The trust's portfolio benefited from recovering domestic travel and hotel demand, leading to sequential improvements in quarterly performance. The company secured new 3-year unsecured loan facilities of US$95 million to refinance maturing loans.

site_title: Oscars to pre-tape some awards in bid for 'tighter' show
summary: The Oscars will pre-tape the announcements of 8 winners to make the televised ceremony "tighter and more electric", freeing up time for musical performances, comedy, and tributes. The move aims to boost viewership, which has declined by 56% since 2020, with last year's ceremony watched by just over 10 million viewers. The pre-taped awards will be edited into the live broadcast, while winners' speeches will still be featured. The 94th Academy Awards will also include a new "fan favourite" prize and be hosted by Wanda Sykes, Amy Schumer, and Regina Hall.

site_title: Guinness launches scheme for an environmentally friendly pint
summary: Guinness has launched an agricultural pilot program to reduce carbon emissions by its barley suppliers. The program, which begins this year, will work with 40 Irish farms to promote regenerative agriculture practices, such as better soil health and reduced synthetic fertilizer use. The collaboration aims to lead to enhanced biodiversity and is expected to expand over the next three years. The initiative has the backing of the Irish government and will inform how Guinness sources its raw materials globally, with results to be shared with other farms.

site_title: Microsoft wants to secure all your clouds, including Amazon and Google
summary: Microsoft is expanding its Microsoft Defender for Cloud security product to include Google Cloud Platform, three months after adding support for Amazon Web Services. The product, which uses open programming interfaces to monitor security weak spots in cloud-computing, aims to simplify cybersecurity for customers using multiple cloud platforms. With the rise of damaging cyberattacks, Microsoft hopes to make it easier for security professionals to keep track of various products and protect customers. The move is part of Microsoft's efforts to bulk up its security software business, which saw a 45% increase in sales in 2021.

site_title: Intel challenges Chinese Bitcoin mining suppliers
summary: Intel has unveiled its first major Bitcoin mining chip, the BonanzaMine, which could challenge Chinese rig manufacturers that have dominated the market for years. The chip is set to be delivered to companies like Block, Griid Infrastructure, and Argo Blockchain later this year. This move could potentially disrupt the market, offering a more efficient and powerful alternative to traditional mining solutions.

site_title: Moderna, Thermo Fisher partner to manufacture Covid vaccine, other drugs
summary: Moderna has partnered with Thermo Fisher Scientific to manufacture its Covid-19 vaccine, Spikevax, and other mRNA-based experimental medicines for 15 years. Thermo Fisher will provide dedicated US manufacturing capacity for fill/finish services and labeling/packaging. This deal expands on their previous partnership, which helped scale up Spikevax production. Moderna's vaccine has received full US approval for adults and is cleared for use in over 70 countries, and the company is developing new vaccines based on mRNA technology.

site_title: Singapore banks optimistic on global economic recovery, rate hikes
summary: Singapore banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB reported strong earnings growth in 2021, driven by rising customer loans and deposits, as well as higher current account and savings account (CASA) ratios. Analysts forecast better net interest margins (NIMs) for 2022, with DBS and UOB expected to benefit from interest rate hikes. The banks have guided for NIMs to rise 1.5-1.55% and loan growth to be in the mid-to-high single digit. Despite some concerns over credit costs and geopolitical tensions, the banks remain optimistic about the global economic recovery and growth prospects.

images.alt_text: Singapore banks are sounding an optimistic note heading into 2022, with the global economic recovery and interest rates hikes among the bright spots.

site_title: Archaeologists find 7,000-year-old ritual hunt site in Jordanian desert
summary: Archaeologists in Jordan have discovered a 7,000-year-old ritual hunt site in the desert, featuring structures that demonstrate humans rounded up and hunted gazelles earlier than previously thought. The site, which includes over 250 artifacts, includes exquisite animal figurines used in rituals and the oldest artistic pieces found in the Middle East. The "desert kites" – long stone walls used to trap gazelles – are the oldest, best-preserved, and largest of their kind, showcasing sophisticated mass hunting strategies. The site reveals the inhabitants were not just hunting for their own needs but also exchanged with neighboring settlements.

site_title: Ukraine declares state of emergency, summons citizens home from Russia
summary: Ukraine declared a state of emergency on February 23, 2022, and advised citizens in Russia to return home amid escalating tensions with Russia. Shelling intensified at the eastern Ukraine border, where Russian President Vladimir Putin recognized two rebel regions and deployed troops as "peacekeepers." The situation remains uncertain, with no clear indication of a potential Russian military assault.

images.alt_text: Ukrainian soldiers at a front line position in Kryakivka, in eastern Ukraine.Shelling intensified at the line of contact in eastern Ukraine, where Russian President Vladimir Putin recognised the independence of two Moscow-backed rebel regions this week.

site_title: mm2 Asia to sell 390m new shares at S$0.05 apiece to 2 investors
summary: mm2 Asia plans to sell 390 million new shares at S$0.05 apiece to two investors, Goi Seng Hui and Oei Hong Leong, raising S$19.3 million in net cash proceeds. The placement represents 14.4% of the enlarged share capital and will be used to reduce bank borrowings and increase working capital. The price is a 9.58% discount to the volume weighted average price, and shares ended Wednesday at S$0.055.

site_title: Governments should prepare to restructure, liquidate badly scarred firms, says IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) advises governments to restructure or liquidate badly scarred firms as they withdraw support provided during the Covid-19 crisis. Global corporate debt reached $83 trillion, or 98% of GDP, at the end of 2020, with advanced economies and China accounting for 90% of the increase. As central banks raise interest rates to combat inflation, firms' debt servicing costs will rise, exposing corporate vulnerabilities. This shift highlights the need for governments to bolster insolvency systems and prepare for potential restructuring or liquidation of distressed firms.

site_title: Europe's pivot to Africa unveils a big Belt and Road-style initiative
summary: The European Union has launched its "Global Gateway" project, a Belt and Road-style initiative aimed at connecting Europe with Africa through infrastructure development and investment. The €300 billion project, set to be completed by 2027, focuses on renewable energy, digital connectivity, and education, with half of the funds allocated to Africa. This move is seen as a counterweight to China's Belt and Road Initiative, with the EU aiming to promote a rules-based, multilateral approach to world order. The initiative marks a significant shift in the EU's economic focus towards Africa, with individual nations such as France and the UK also increasing their engagement with the continent.

site_title: Singapore O&G net profit down 11.9% to S$8.4 m in FY2021
summary: Singapore O&G reported a 11.9% decline in net profit to S$8.4 million for FY2021 due to a S$200,000 net loss from a joint venture and higher professional fees. Revenue rose 6.3% to S$42.4 million, driven by contributions from dermatology and paediatrics segments. However, cancer-related and obstetrics and gynaecology segments saw lower revenue. The company's earnings per share and net asset value per share decreased, and a final dividend of 0.90 cent per share was declared.

site_title: Hong Leong Finance H2 net profit up 46.5% to S$40.1m
summary: Hong Leong Finance reported a 46.5% increase in 6-month net profit to S$40.1 million, driven by cost management and lower loan loss allowances. Full-year earnings rose 32.7% to S$84.8 million. The company recommended a final dividend of S$0.0825 per share, up from S$0.055 in FY2020. Net interest income and hiring charges rose 37.2% to S$88.7 million, with the strategic management of deposits resulting in a substantial saving in funding cost.

site_title: Puma says China boycott, cost pressures weigh in 2022
summary: Puma expects 10% sales growth in 2022, but warns of a consumer boycott in China and cost pressures limiting profit growth. The company forecasts 2022 operating earnings of 600-700 million euros, below analyst expectations. Puma's shares fell 0.9% due to the disappointing outlook. The company attributed the boycott to a response to its decision to end sponsorship of the 2022 Beijing Winter Olympics, where China is the host country.

site_title: Europe: Stocks open higher with all eyes on Ukraine
summary: European stock markets rose on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 advancing 0.5% and the eurozone's DAX and CAC 40 indices gaining 0.8% and almost 1% respectively. The market mood was lifted by softer-than-expected sanctions on Russia, but trading remains cautious amid concerns of an impending war between Russia and Ukraine.

site_title: Scammers have moved to using QR codes, including Singpass
summary: Scammers in Singapore are using QR codes, including SingPass, to dupe victims. The Sengkang Neighbourhood Police Centre warned of a scam involving a printed flier and a QR code that requests personal details. Grab clarified it did not create the flier and does not have promotions requiring QR code redemption. The police centre advises the public to be cautious and verify the authenticity of QR codes before providing personal details.

images.alt_text: By scanning the QR code and authorising the transaction, victims would be tricked into giving the scammers access to these online services.

site_title: Michelangelo's three 'pietas' united in historic first Gildas
summary: Michelangelo's three 'Pieta' sculptures, created at different stages of his life, are on display together for the first time at Florence's Opera del Duomo museum. The exhibit features the original "Bandini" and casts of the "Pieta" and "Rondanini" sculptures, showcasing the artist's intellectual maturation and evolution in style over 50 years. The display highlights the contrasts between the variations, which depict different phases of Michelangelo's life, and offers a unique opportunity to observe his artistic development and the link between life and art in a religious sculptor.

site_title: Sembcorp Industries' UK unit secures 15-year contract for 150MW battery storage
summary: Sembcorp Industries' UK unit, Sembcorp Energy UK, secured a 15-year contract for a 150MW battery storage system, bringing its total capacity to 420MWh in the UK. The 150MW tranche is part of a planned 360MW system, one of Europe's largest, and will aid the UK's low-carbon transition. The system is expected to be operational by 2023, providing a secure and stable energy system that can supply power to the national grid within milliseconds. This expansion supports the UK's Net Zero 2050 goal and the company's commitment to energy transition.

site_title: Ukraine security council calls for state of emergency
summary: Ukraine's security council has approved plans to declare a state of national emergency due to the growing threat of a Russian invasion. The measure requires stepped-up document and vehicle checks in all regions except two Russian-backed separatist areas. The council's secretary, Oleksiy Danilov, said the "preventive" measures aim to enforce public order and would be applied regionally, depending on necessity. The plan must be formally approved by Parliament, with lawmakers expected to approve the added security measures this week.

site_title: SBS Transit posts 67.3% fall in H2 profit
summary: SBS Transit reported a 67.3% decline in net profit for the second half of 2021, with a net profit of S$15.2 million, due to government reliefs amounting to S$21.7 million. Revenue increased 6.7% to S$670 million, but operating costs rose due to reduced government reliefs. The company attributed low ridership on buses and trains to ongoing Covid-19 restrictions and work-from-home trends. SBS Transit attributed the decline to lower rail revenue and higher operating costs, but noted growth in other commercial services, with a 39.5% increase in revenue from these services.

site_title: EC World Reit Q4 DPU up 7.7% to S$0.01537
summary: EC World Reit announced a 7.7% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 1.537 Singapore cents for Q4, up from 1.427 cents in the previous year. Gross revenue grew 8.2% to S$31.9 million, while net property income (NPI) rose 5.9% to S$28.8 million. The company's China-focused e-commerce logistics landlord saw a strong performance, with Q4 results indicating a positive outlook for the sector.

site_title: Olam adds raft of banks to IPO of US$18b food unit
summary: Olam International has added several banks to its initial public offering (IPO) of its food unit, valued at approximately US$17.7 billion. The IPO, led by Citigroup, HSBC, JPMorgan, and Morgan Stanley, is expected to raise about £2 billion (S$3.65 billion). The listing would boost London's flagging IPO market, which has seen just one IPO of over US$50 million this year. The move comes as investors have become cautious due to geopolitical tensions and tightening monetary policy. The IPO is expected to be completed in the first half of the year.

site_title: Sanofi reports positive Covid vaccine results after delays
summary: Sanofi reported positive results from its Covid-19 vaccine trials, developed with GSK, indicating 100% effectiveness against severe Covid disease and hospitalizations. The vaccine will seek regulatory authorization in the US and EU, following phase 3 trials involving thousands of people. The results come after nearly a year of delays, putting Sanofi behind rivals in the vaccine race.

images.alt_text: French pharmaceuticals giant Sanofi said on Wednesday (Feb 23) that its Covid-19 vaccine, developed with Britain's GSK, had delivered positive results after nearly a year of delays left it lagging far behind rivals in the race for a jab.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall on Wednesday, bucking regional trend as OCBC drags STI down
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.2% on Wednesday, bucking regional trends, as OCBC's 6.3% drop in stock price and weak fourth-quarter earnings dragged it down. Major Asian markets, however, rose between 0.5% and 0.9% after the US and its allies settled on modest penalties over Russia's Ukraine incursion. The STI closed at 3,393 points, with DBS and UOB closing up 0.7% and 0.6% respectively.

site_title: Singapore may join Russia sanctions; no major hit to trade sector, but risks remain
summary: Singapore is reportedly considering joining international sanctions against Russia amid a dispute with Ukraine, but experts say the country is unlikely to take a direct economic hit. The Russian market accounts for only 0.1% of Singapore's total exports, and sanctions would not significantly impact trade. However, extended sanctions or retaliation could lead to global commodity price spikes and inflation risks, particularly if tensions escalate and oil prices rise.

site_title: Zoom unveils new call centre product after failed Five9 deal
summary: Zoom Video Communications has unveiled its new call center product, Zoom Contact Center, aimed at enhancing customer support for businesses. The move comes after a failed $14.7 billion bid for Five9 last year. This updated product is part of Zoom's efforts to expand beyond its video conferencing platform, which experienced significant growth during the pandemic. Investors remain concerned about the company's ability to capitalize on its growth.

site_title: Proposed merger with MNACT will address lack of growth: Mapletree Commercial Trust
summary: Mapletree Commercial Trust (MCT) plans to merge with Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust (MNACT) to address its lack of growth. The merger will bring long-term sustainable growth through enhanced geographic diversification, reduced single asset concentration, and improved tenant diversification. Under the proposal, MNACT unitholders will exchange their units for MCT units or cash, and the merged entity, Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust, will have a new management fee structure. The merger is expected to deliver 7.5-8.9% accretion to distribution per unit, with total management fees estimated at S$68.3 million.

images.alt_text: MNACT's scale and reach in North Asia offers long-term sustainable growth for MCT.

site_title: Sheng Siong H2 net profit rises 4.8% to S$66.9m on boost from new store openings
summary: Sheng Siong Group's net profit for the second half of fiscal year 2021 rose 4.8% to S$66.9 million, driven by new store openings. However, the full-year net profit decreased 4.2% to S$132.8 million due to a 1.7% decline in revenue. Comparable same-store sales were down 4.8%, but new store openings partially offset this decline. The company has proposed a final dividend of S$0.031 per share, and its board of directors attributed the robust financial performance to new store openings and revenue growth.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singtel plans to redevelop its Comcentre HQ for over S$2 billion. COE premiums surged to over S$100,000 in the latest bidding exercise, driven by higher luxury car taxes. Singapore's core inflation rose to 2.4% in January, its highest level in nearly 10 years. Tanglin Shopping Centre was sold for S$868 million, while Genting's gaming stocks are expected to re-rate in 2022. Singapore stocks fell on Wednesday, dragged down by OCBC's Q4 profit decline.

site_title: Raffles Education director Lim How Teck to take leave of absence as Heliconia chairman
summary: Heliconia Capital chairman Lim How Teck is taking a leave of absence from his role at the Temasek unit due to his arrest as lead independent director of Raffles Education Corp. Lim was among five directors notified of their arrest by the Monetary Authority of Singapore and Commercial Affairs Department following investigations into Raffles Education related to a claim by Affin Bank. Lim has been released on bail with conditions that require him to assist in investigations and may travel outside Singapore with prior clearance. Acting chairman Koh Poh Guan will oversee the company in the interim.

site_title: IHH Healthcare Q4 net profit up 8%, declares higher final dividend
summary: IHH Healthcare's Q4 net profit rose 8% to RM453.6 million, driven by growth in domestic and foreign patient loads as the pandemic subsides. Revenue increased 19% to RM4.5 billion, while Ebitda rose 7%. The company expects a slowdown in Covid-19 services but expects core operations and medical tourism to improve. A higher final dividend of 6 sen per share was declared, bringing total full-year dividend to 12 sen per share.

site_title: United Hampshire US Reit H2 DPU up 0.7%; Reit to divest 2 self-storage assets
summary: United Hampshire US Reit reported a 0.7% increase in second-half distribution per unit (DPU) to US$0.0305, up from US$0.0303 in the same period last year, driven by contributions from newly acquired assets. The Reit's full-year DPU rose 26.8% to US$0.061, exceeding forecasts. The company also announced a conditional sale-and-purchase agreement to divest its two self-storage properties for US$49 million, with an estimated net proceeds of US$47.5 million. This sale is part of the Reit's proactive portfolio management strategy to maximize operational performance and enhance financial flexibility.

site_title: SATS to take additional 16.4% stake in Asia Airfreight Terminal Co for HK$339.5m
summary: SATS, a ground handler and caterer, will acquire an additional 16.4% stake in Asia Airfreight Terminal Co for HK$339.5 million (S$58.5 million). The acquisition, part of SATS' strategy to expand its cargo handling network, will give the company a 65.4% stake in AAT. SATS will also acquire shares from FedEx and Torres Investments, while Eastern Option Limited (EOL) will acquire shares from Torres Investments. The deal is expected to accelerate innovation and drive sustainable business growth for SATS.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares rose on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index increasing 9.18 points to 1,586.14. Gainers outnumbered losers 621 to 372, with a total volume of 2.971 billion lots worth RM2.686 billion.

site_title: White House announces US$450m to ease port congestion
summary: The US Transportation Department has announced a $450 million grant program to ease port congestion and improve the movement of goods. The program, part of the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law, aims to bolster capacity and reduce costs for American families. Major US ports, including Los Angeles and Savannah, are eligible for the funds, with 25% allocated for smaller ports. The program is the largest ever investment in the Port Infrastructure Development Program, nearly doubling last year's investment. Applications are due May 16, with awards expected in the fall.

site_title: China's yuan hits 4-year high as Russia-Ukraine crisis boosts foreign demand
summary: China's yuan reached a near 4-year high against the dollar, closing at 6.3178 per dollar, amid the Russia-Ukraine crisis boosting foreign demand for Chinese assets. The yuan's strength, which hurts Chinese exports, could prompt the People's Bank of China to intervene, but analysts expect Russia to increase yuan holdings due to western sanctions. This could benefit Chinese government bonds, with some predicting a potential alternative currency bloc. However, the central bank may limit yuan appreciation due to domestic economic weakness, setting a near-term floor at 6.3 per dollar.

site_title: Singapore banks optimistic on economic recovery, rate hikes
summary: Singapore banks are optimistic about the economic recovery in 2022, with interest rate hikes expected to boost net interest margins. DBS, OCBC, and UOB reported growth in customer loans and deposits, and higher CASA ratios, which analysts predict will lead to better net interest margins this year. The banks' earnings season kicked off with DBS' results, which showed a 9% loan growth in 2021, while OCBC and UOB reported stable and rising net interest margins, respectively. The impending interest rate hikes are expected to provide a gradual uplift in interest income, supporting the banks' growth outlook.

site_title: Vietnam hit by fuel shortages as hundreds of retailers run dry
summary: Vietnam is experiencing fuel shortages due to a combination of insufficient supplies, Covid-19 cases among workers, and a surge in crude oil prices. Nearly 300 petrol retailers have halted sales, prompting Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh to order an investigation. The government plans to auction petrol from national reserves and has ordered extra inspections to prevent hoarding. The shortage is part of a global trend, with several refineries in Asia set to undergo scheduled maintenance, potentially tightening supplies.

site_title: SATS posts S$5.1m Q3 net profit; provided S$10.7m for Genting overdues
summary: SATS, a Singapore-based inflight caterer and ground handler, reported a net profit of S$5.1 million for the third quarter, reversing a loss of S$2.8 million a year ago. Revenue rose 22.6% to S$307.8 million, driven by the "gradual recovery" of the travel industry as borders reopened. State reliefs also contributed to the firm's earnings.

site_title: In Hong Kong's all-out fight against Covid, Singapore is winning
summary: Hong Kong is ceding ground to Singapore in its fight against Covid, with Singapore easing pandemic-linked restrictions to boost its economy. Bloomberg Economics analysts Tamara Mast Henderson and Eric Zhu have cut Hong Kong's economic growth forecast to 1.4% this year, while expecting Singapore's GDP to grow 4.7%. Hong Kong is doubling down on strict social-distancing rules, while Singapore is transitioning to living with the virus. This shift is driven by businesses shifting to Singapore, which has established quarantine-free travel lanes and emphasized vaccinations.

site_title: Thailand eases rules for foreign visitors to reboot tourism
summary: Thailand is easing rules for foreign visitors starting March 1, in an effort to boost its tourism industry. Vaccinated visitors won't need a mandatory PCR test, and can instead use a self-antigen test. The minimum medical insurance coverage for visitors is also being lowered to $20,000 from $50,000. Despite a recent spike in Covid cases, Thailand's healthcare system is handling the outbreak, and the country's currency is expected to benefit from the eased visa rules. This move aims to attract more tourists to the nation's famous beaches, temples, and national parks.

site_title: BT's Top Stories from Last Week
summary: A younger generation of super-wealthy in Singapore, who made their money in non-traditional areas, are buying the island's priciest homes. Meanwhile, a former GIC CIO's low-key Singapore fund has amassed US$10 billion for a global foray. Other key news includes Malaysia's plans to seize assets worth RM3 billion from Daim Zainuddin, China's slowing GDP growth, and Citigroup's target of 1,150 for MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026.

site_title: ST Engineering to collaborate with SMRT's business arm for overseas transport projects
summary: ST Engineering has signed a memorandum of understanding with Strides International Business, the business arm of SMRT, to collaborate on overseas land transportation projects. The companies will jointly provide expertise in electric vehicles, intelligent road transportation, and rail electronics. ST Engineering will contribute its expertise in EV retrofit, smart metro solutions, and fleet management, while Strides will offer its expertise in operations, maintenance, and service of transport and rail networks. The collaboration aims to strengthen smart mobility offerings and expand global presence.

site_title: China's delay in cutting rates further turns off bond investors
summary: China's reluctance to aggressively ease its monetary policy has led to a shift among bond investors, with AllianceBernstein slashing its duration risk on China bonds. The People's Bank of China's cautious approach may limit future yield increases, according to Brad Gibson, co-head of Asia Pacific fixed income. This move marks a reversal for Chinese sovereign debt, which was a haven for investors during the global selloff in the past year. Investors are now calling time on the strategy, citing a need to take a breather and reassess their risk positions.

site_title: Demystifying the 'just transition': How can we ensure no one is left behind
summary: The concept of a "just transition" aims to ensure no one is left behind in a changing world, particularly in the fossil fuel transition and other interconnected transitions. However, conversations have focused on job distribution and levies, rather than rewiring systems for greater equity and justice. A just transition requires a deeper approach, addressing underlying causes of inequality and injustice. The Indian renewable energy sector is a case in point, where more justice is needed to address issues like price pressures, human rights, and governance. A four-level transition model, including "Perpetuation of Status Quo", "Managerial Reform", "Structural Reform", and "Transformational", offers a path towards a just and regenerative future.

site_title: Singapore's core inflation could exceed 3% by Q2, further monetary policy tightening likely in April
summary: Singapore's core inflation has reached a 10-year high of 2.4% in January, surpassing market expectations. This could lead to a second round of monetary policy tightening in April, as economists predict core inflation could exceed 3% by Q2. The increase in core inflation is driven by higher energy prices, particularly electricity and gas inflation. Economists attribute the rise to elevated crude oil prices and the deepening Russia-Ukraine crisis. Monetary policy tightening is expected to curb imported inflation, with most economists predicting a re-centering of the Singapore dollar's nominal effective exchange rate (S$NEER) policy band.

images.alt_text: Core consumer price index, which excludes accommodation and private transport, reached 2.4 per cent in January, outpacing the previous month's 2.1 per cent, according to data from the Monetary Authority of Singapore and the Ministry of Trade and Industry.

site_title: Heathrow Covid losses reach £3.8b with travel on hold
summary: Heathrow Airport reported a loss of £3.8 billion due to 2 years of Covid disruption, with passenger numbers slumping to 19.4 million in 2021, the lowest since 1972. The airport is counting on a summer travel rebound and regulatory clearance to raise prices to restore finances. With £15.4 billion in net debt, Heathrow aims to achieve a full-year target of 45.5 million passengers and has already achieved £870 million in cost savings. The airport's CEO is urging regulators to set higher fees to avoid delays and longer queues.

site_title: Modernised, powerful digital infrastructure needed to enable the metaverse
summary: The concept of the metaverse, a merged virtual, augmented, and physical reality, has gained significant interest, with major companies like Meta and Microsoft announcing plans to develop it. However, to achieve the metaverse's full potential, modernised, distributed digital infrastructure is needed, requiring computational efficiency 1,000 times greater than current capabilities. Enterprises must break free from traditional IT approaches and deploy metaverse-ready digital infrastructure, including the digital core, ecosystem, and edge, to support real-time computing and immersive interactions. Proactive deployment of this infrastructure is crucial to unlocking the metaverse's transformative power.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the day with gains, paring losses from the previous three days, as investors await developments in the Russia-Ukraine crisis. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.60% to 23,660.28, while the Shanghai Composite Index climbed 0.93% and the Shenzhen Composite Index jumped 1.75%. The gains come despite ongoing market uncertainty.

site_title: Nanofilm sees revenue boost from 3C, automotive segments
summary: Nanofilm Technologies reported a 13.2% increase in net profit to S$44.3 million for the half-year ended Dec 31, 2021, driven by a 6.8% rise in revenue to S$150.1 million. The company's industrial equipment business unit saw a 81.6% increase in revenue, while its advanced materials business unit remained stable. Nanofilm also reported a 7.7% increase in full-year net profit to S$62.5 million, with revenue rising 13% to S$246.7 million. The company expects to benefit from diversification of revenue streams and investments in new production capacity.

images.alt_text: The tech manufacturer said that it is closely monitoring the situation.

site_title: Multi-concept stores gain appeal for differentiation, 'survival'
summary: Multi-concept stores, which combine retail and other offerings like food and beverage, are gaining appeal in Singapore as a way to differentiate themselves from e-commerce and higher rental costs. This format allows businesses to offer "differentiated retail experiences" and collaborate for survival and longevity. Examples include Mac.Infinity, which offers laptop repair and Acai bowls, and Bynd Artisan, which shares a space with a dessert store to provide an immersive shopping experience. The trend is expected to continue, with the Singapore Retailers Association noting that partnerships allow brands to share resources and save on marketing costs.

site_title: Rio Tinto sets record US$17b dividend as higher iron ore prices propel profit
summary: Rio Tinto reported a record US$16.8 billion full-year dividend and US$21.38 billion underlying earnings, driven by higher iron ore prices and strong demand from China. The company's iron ore production and unit cash costs for 2022 are expected to be impacted by labour shortages. Despite this, Rio Tinto's shares rose 1.2% after the announcement. The company attributed its financial success to the global economy's recovery, which led to significant price strength for its commodities.

site_title: Budget 2022: A strategic mind map to tackle the tax challenges ahead
summary: Singapore's Budget 2022 introduced a series of tax changes aimed at addressing challenges ahead. The government delayed the GST rate hike to 2023, staggering the increase into two phases to cushion the impact on consumers. The top income tax rate for individuals will increase to 24%, while the corporate tax rate remains at 17%. The government also emphasized the need for progressivity in the fiscal framework, focusing on property tax rate recalibration and introducing a more targeted approach to direct cash support for lower-income groups. The budget aimed to balance compassion and conviction in tax policy.

site_title: Hong Kong raises property tax for owners of expensive homes
summary: Hong Kong's government plans to raise property taxes for luxury homes, affecting approximately 42,000 homes, or 2% of private domestic properties. The new tax rate will be progressively higher, replacing the standard 5% tax on annual rental value, and is expected to generate US$97.4 million in government revenue annually, starting in 2024. The move aims to increase revenue and is part of the government's broader efforts to address housing affordability and taxation.

images.alt_text: About 42,000 homes, or 2 per cent of the total number of private domestic properties, will be affected by the plan.

site_title: SFA, SLA open tender for fish farming plots on Pulau Ketam
summary: The Singapore Food Agency (SFA) and Singapore Land Authority (SLA) have launched a joint tender for a 69,543.7 square metre land parcel on Pulau Ketam, east of Pulau Ubin. The land can be used for fish farming, production of fish fingerlings, and maintaining broadstock for eggs. The tender, which will close on April 20, 2022, aims to optimize sea space for food production and achieve Singapore's "30 by 30" goal of producing 30% of the country's nutritional needs by 2030.

site_title: Genting's Asean-listed gaming stocks 'set for winning streak' and higher dividend yields: UOBKH
summary: UOB Kay Hian (UOBKH) predicts Genting Group's gaming stocks in Southeast Asia will experience a "winning streak" as countries transition to an endemic Covid-19 phase, with business normalisation in 2022. The brokerage expects Genting Malaysia, Genting Singapore, and Genting Berhad to match pre-pandemic dividends with yields of 6.7%, 4.7%, and 4.4% respectively. Valuations for Asean-listed gaming stocks remain depressed, but UOBKH forecasts significant earnings recoveries and growth in 2022, driven by reopening borders and a strong tourism sector.

site_title: Big car COE premiums hurtle towards S$100,000 in wake of higher luxury car tax
summary: COE premiums surged across the board in Singapore's latest bidding exercise, with Category B COE prices reaching S$93,590, an 8.69% increase from the previous auction. The Open Category COE also rose to S$93,102, defying expectations that the new luxury car tax would reduce demand. The prices were attributed to factors such as the sale of luxury cars at the Singapore Airshow and the registration of VIP cars for the HSBC Women's World Championship.

site_title: Aston Martin posts lower 2021 loss on surging sales
summary: Aston Martin reported a narrower annual loss in 2021, with sales surging 82% to nearly 6,200 units. The company expects further improvements in 2022, launching new models and raising prices, despite ongoing supply chain disruptions. Aston Martin plans to launch its first fully-electric vehicle in 2025 and all new car lines will have an electric option by 2026. The company's operating loss decreased to £76.5 million in 2021, down from £323 million the previous year.

site_title: Alibaba halts talks to raise US$1b before Lazada IPO
summary: Alibaba Group has halted talks to raise $1 billion for Lazada before its potential IPO, citing a failure to secure its envisioned valuation. The move comes as markets remain volatile, with shrinking valuations for tech companies and increased scrutiny of the industry. Despite this, Alibaba remains intent on spinning off Lazada as a separate company to compete with rivals like Sea's Shopee and Indonesia's GoTo.

site_title: World's first octopus farm stirs ethical debate
summary: A Spanish company, Nueva Pescanova, plans to open the world's first commercial octopus farm, investing 65 million euros, pending environmental approval. The farm aims to meet soaring demand for seafood, but scientists warn it could be an ethical and environmental disaster due to the complex nature of octopuses and their habitat needs. The farm's director, Roberto Romero, calls it a "global milestone," but experts express concerns about the potential consequences of large-scale octopus farming.

images.alt_text: Spurred on by soaring demand for seafood, a Spanish company plans to open the first commercial octopus farm next year but as scientists discover more about the enigmatic animals some warn it could be an ethical and environmental disaster.

site_title: Hong Kong weighs easing listing rules for large tech firms
summary: Hong Kong is considering easing listing requirements for large, advanced technology firms to boost fundraising and meet capital needs for research and development. The Securities and Futures Commission and Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing are reviewing the Main Board listing rules to accommodate "large-scale advanced technology enterprises." This move comes as Hong Kong's ranking as a top listing venue globally has declined, with Shanghai surpassing it in 2021. The Hong Kong government is also exploring the possibility of trading yuan-denominated stocks via the southbound Stock Connect.

site_title: China's gas prices surge to record as world grapples with shortage
summary: China's domestic liquefied natural gas price surged to a record 8,114 yuan per ton, or about US$27.5 per million British thermal units, due to frigid temperatures. This may prompt China to import more liquefied natural gas (LNG) from the international market, further tightening global supplies and boosting competition with neighboring importers. Colder weather has depleted inventories across northern China, and the country's largest importer may be spurred to procure spot cargoes from the international market. This could lead to a global shortage of LNG.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end higher after 2 days of decline
summary: South Korean shares ended higher on Wednesday, recovering from two straight sessions of losses, with the benchmark Kospi closing up 12.74 points, or 0.47%, at 2,719.53. The gains were capped by concerns over the Russia-Ukraine crisis, with the Korean won weakening and bond yields rising. Foreigners were net sellers of 265.1 billion won worth of shares, and South Korea reported 171,452 new coronavirus cases, a daily record.

site_title: Shimao misses payment as US$948m debt talks drag on
summary: Shimao Group Holdings, a Chinese real estate builder, missed trust payments totaling US$948 million, as debt talks with Citic Trust, the nation's largest trust firm, remain unresolved. Shimao did not reach an agreement to extend repayments, and the trust firm will continue to urge the builder to repay. The missed payments are part of Shimao's short-term investments due this month and maturing between April and August. The company's financial struggles have raised concerns about its ability to meet its debt obligations.

site_title: Barclays annual profit nearly trebles as bad loans ebb
summary: Barclays reported a nearly tripled annual profit of £8.4 billion in 2021, driven by a decline in bad loan charges. The bank's investment bank continued to perform strongly amid market volatility. Barclays announced plans to buy back £1 billion of shares and increase its dividend to 4 pence per share. New CEO C S Venkatakrishnan reaffirmed the bank's investment banking strategy, while CFO Tushar Morzaria is retiring and will be replaced by Anna Cross.

site_title: China to prevent 'excessive hoarding' of iron ore to cool prices
summary: China's state planner has taken measures to prevent "excessive hoarding" of iron ore, aiming to stabilize prices. The National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) has guided port firms to reduce inventories and increase costs for traders who hold iron ore for extended periods. This follows a symposium that studied measures to control prices, which had risen over 15% since the last NDRC notice. Stocks of imported iron ore at Chinese ports reached a record high of 160.95 million tonnes as of February 18.

site_title: Prevention key to tackling scams, customers bear responsibility too: OCBC CEO
summary: OCBC CEO Helen Wong emphasizes prevention as key to addressing scams, even as new modus operandi emerge. The bank has strengthened its surveillance systems, and customers bear responsibility in safeguarding their own money and credentials. Following a recent SMS phishing scam affecting 800 customers, OCBC made full goodwill payouts to victims totaling S$13.7 million, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore and banks introducing measures to enhance digital banking security, including cooling-off periods and minimum delay for activating mobile tokens.

site_title: World awaits crucial climate report
summary: The UN's Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) is set to release a crucial climate report at the end of the month, providing an update on climate change's impact on humans and the planet. The report will outline the risks and benefits of adapting to a warmer world for businesses and societies. This comes amid growing concerns over climate change, with a recent poll showing it's seen as a bigger threat than war by a majority of people in top economies, with top concerns including global warming, habitat destruction, and extreme weather.

site_title: QR code scam: What you should know before scanning codes via SMS
summary: A new QR code scam has emerged, tricking people into using their Singpass app to scan QR codes sent via SMS to access digital services. The police warned that scammers can misuse the access for illicit purposes, such as registering businesses or opening new bank accounts. Scammers can also use the access to subscribe for new mobile lines. The police advise against scanning QR codes via SMS and messaging platforms, and not clicking on embedded links in messages. This scam is similar to phishing attacks, and victims should be cautious when receiving suspicious QR codes or links.

site_title: Leonardo DiCaprio invests in French champagne brand Telmont
summary: Leonardo DiCaprio has invested in French champagne house Telmont, joining a growing trend of luxury brands partnering with celebrities to attract younger customers. The actor, known for films like "The Revenant" and "Titanic," expressed his commitment to environmental sustainability, citing Telmont's efforts to reduce its carbon footprint. This deal follows a similar partnership between LVMH's Moet Hennessy and Jay-Z's Armand de Brignac champagne brand in 2021, as historic brands seek to expand their appeal.

site_title: Singapore's January core inflation hits 10-year high at 2.4%, headline inflation flat at 4%
summary: Singapore's core inflation rose to a 10-year high of 2.4% in January, driven by rising food and energy prices. Headline inflation remained flat at 4%, but is a 9-year high. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) expect core inflation to rise further in the near term, reaching 3% by mid-2022. Global inflation is expected to stay high due to elevated crude oil prices and labor shortages.

site_title: China's solar power growth to soar in 2022 on project pipeline
summary: China is forecast to add a record 75-90 gigawatts of solar power capacity in 2022, driven by a massive renewable build-out to reach climate targets. This represents a massive increase over last year's record haul of 54.93 gigawatts. Through 2025, China aims to average 83-99 gigawatts of new solar capacity annually, with global installations rising to 232-286 gigawatts per year. Despite high material costs, Chinese companies are expected to boost polysilicon output to over 700,000 tons this year, aiming to maintain their dominant global solar market position.

site_title: Tanglin Shopping Centre sold for S$868m to Tanoto family's Pacific Eagle Real Estate
summary: The freehold Tanglin Shopping Centre in Singapore has been sold for S$868 million, with a price of S$2,769 per square foot per plot ratio, surpassing the reserve price by 10%. The buyer is Pacific Eagle Real Estate, a privately held Singaporean real estate investor and developer controlled by the Tanoto family. The sale is subject to the Strata Titles Board's approval and marks the fourth collective sale attempt by the centre, with Savills Singapore acting as the exclusive marketing agent.

site_title: Ukraine and the crisis of American self-belief
summary: The US involvement in the Ukraine crisis has sparked skepticism about America's role in lecturing other nations on national sovereignty and international law. The question "Who are we?" is central to this skepticism, given the US' own history of invasions, interventions, domestic injustices, and foreign policy failures. Putin's advantages in Ukraine include a desire for control, attention span, will, and self-belief, which the West lacks conviction in defending. The US' own self-belief in the past, including its ideals of human progress and moral principles, has led to both triumphs and blunders, and may be lacking in its current response to Ukraine.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher with Russia-Ukraine stand-off in focus
summary: Australia shares closed 0.6% higher on Wednesday, recouping losses from the previous day, amid the Russia-Ukraine stand-off. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 7,205.70. Healthcare and mining stocks led the gains, while gold stocks fell 1.8% due to flat bullion prices. Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison announced the first tranche of sanctions on Russia, marking Australia's entry into the crisis. Investors remained cautious, with uncertainty continuing to impact the market.

site_title: Europe's pivot to Africa, with Belt and Road-style initiative
summary: The European Union launched its "Global Gateway" project, a Belt and Road-style initiative aimed at connecting Europe with Africa, in response to China's Belt and Road Initiative (BRI). The EU aims to strengthen economic ties with Africa, rivaling China's influence in the region. The EU's initiative was announced at a summit between EU leaders and 40 African nations, following China's 80 visits to over 40 countries in the past decade, boosting trade from $765 million to $170 billion. The EU seeks to promote economic development and counterbalance China's growing presence in Africa.

site_title: Hong Kong budget proposals offer Covid-19 relief with tax breaks, handouts
summary: Hong Kong has announced a budget with tax breaks, handouts, and subsidies to support small businesses and residents amid a new wave of social restrictions to curb Covid-19 infections. The measures total over HK$170 billion, with spending on anti-epidemic measures exceeding HK$54 billion. The "dynamic zero Covid" strategy aims to eradicate all outbreaks, despite the city facing thousands of infections daily. The restrictions, the most draconian yet, are expected to last until April 20 and include a 100% reduction in salaries tax and handouts of HK$10,000 consumption vouchers.

site_title: Brokers' take: CGS-CIMB lowers target on Wilmar; UOBKH, DBS maintain 'buy'
summary: CGS-CIMB lowered its target price on Wilmar International to S$5.69 from S$6.15, despite the company's record-high net profit in FY2021. Analyst Ivy Ng attributed the revision to the market capitalization of two subsidiaries, Yihai Kerry Arawana and Adani Wilmar. Ng sees mixed signals for the food product segment due to higher raw material prices and government regulations, but remains positive on the company's upstream palm oil business. UOBKH and DBS maintained "buy" calls on Wilmar, with target prices of S$6 and S$6.67, respectively.

site_title: Australia housing to slow for 'couple of years', says Stockland
summary: Stockland, Australia's largest property developer, expects the country's housing market to enter a prolonged period of weakness due to affordability issues and a tightening cycle by the central bank. Despite this, the firm sees elevated demand for cheaper housing options. The company plans to shift its business toward residential housing and apartments, reducing exposure to the aged care industry. House prices are expected to fall 10% next year, with a 12% drop in Sydney, and the government is likely to increase immigration to fill a near-term skills shortage gap.

site_title: Thai economy seen growing 3% to 4% this year: deputy PM
summary: Thailand's economy is expected to grow 3% to 4% this year, driven by increased investment and foreign tourist arrivals, Deputy Prime Minister Supattanapong Punmeechaow said. The government will maintain energy price caps to maintain competitiveness. This growth follows the 1.6% expansion last year, one of the slowest in the region.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS lowers target on APAC Realty on lower earnings, near-term decline
summary: DBS Group Research has maintained its "hold" call on APAC Realty, lowering its target price to S$0.67 from S$0.88 due to lower transaction volume assumptions and revised earnings projections. The real estate services provider reported strong FY2021 results, but DBS analyst Ling Lee Keng attributes the change to cooling measures and rising interest rates affecting the property market. APAC Realty's transaction value is expected to ease 30% in FY2022, with a 24% drop in earnings for FY2022 and 22% for FY2023.

images.alt_text: Above: CEO of APAC Realty and ERA, Marcus Chu. DBS Group Research has maintained its "hold" call on APAC Realty on Wednesday (Feb 23), with a lower target price of S$0.67 from S$0.88 previously.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts lower targets for Aztech Global post FY2021 results
summary: DBS Group Research and Maybank Securities have lowered their price targets for Aztech Global to S$1.48 and S$1.13, respectively, following the company's FY2021 results. Analysts factor in lower gross margin assumptions, resulting in a 4% downward earnings revision for FY2022 and FY2023. Despite this, both analysts maintain a "buy" call, citing the company's strong order book and projected net margins. The new targets are pegged to a peer average of 12 times FY2022 earnings estimates, representing a 15% discount to global electronics manufacturing services peers.

images.alt_text: Michael Mun, executive chairman (right) and CEO, and Jeremy Mun, executive director and COO for Aztech Global.

site_title: Asia: Most markets rise after Russia sanctions but nerves on edge
summary: Asian markets rose on Wednesday as investors tracked developments in the Russia-Ukraine crisis, with oil prices stabilizing after less harsh sanctions were imposed on Russia. Despite Russian President Vladimir Putin's forces entering Ukraine, global markets remained on edge, with oil prices nearing US$100 mark. The US and other countries have imposed sanctions, including targeting Russian banks and oligarchs, providing some relief for investors. However, the risk of further escalation remains, and oil prices could surge above US$100 a barrel if the situation escalates.

site_title: New Zealand raises interest rate, signals more aggressive tightening
summary: New Zealand's central bank, the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ), raised interest rates by 25 basis points to 1.0% to counter rising inflationary risks, exceeding market expectations. The move signals a more aggressive tightening path and aligns with hawkish forecasts from economists. The RBNZ also plans to sell NZ$50 billion in bonds and reduce its holdings at a pace of US$5 billion annually. This decision aims to cool a heated economy amid a 5.9% inflation rate, the highest since 2008.

site_title: LNG giant Australia sees 500% growth prize in emerging Asia
summary: Australia aims to capitalize on growing demand for liquefied natural gas (LNG) in emerging Asia, particularly in India, Indonesia, and Vietnam. The country, a top LNG shipper, plans to step up efforts to win deals in 7 markets, boosting demand from 40 million tonnes in 2020 to 255 million tonnes by 2050. Australia's LNG exports earned A$32 billion in the year to June 2021, with forecasts indicating a rise in gas production value through 2050. Climate campaigners argue that wider LNG adoption will stall efforts to tackle climate change, calling for a faster shift to renewable energy.

site_title: Peter Lim partners UK school Wellington College to set up Singapore campus
summary: Business magnate Peter Lim's company, WCI Regional Management, has partnered with UK boarding school Wellington College to establish international schools in Singapore, Indonesia, and Malaysia, targeting 2,000 students each. The schools, staffed by an international faculty, will follow the English National Curriculum and culminate in the International Baccalaureate (IB) diploma. Fees will be around S$30,000 a year or more, and the schools aim to meet demand from expatriates and local families seeking a high-end international education experience.

site_title: Gold flat as higher US yields counter safe-haven bid
summary: Gold prices remained steady at $1,898.63 per ounce, holding near its 9-month high, as safe-haven demand was countered by rising US Treasury yields following sanctions on Russia for its actions in Ukraine. The US, EU, and Britain announced plans to target banks and elites, while Germany halted a major gas pipeline project. Higher yields and interest rate hikes reduce gold's appeal, making it less attractive compared to other investments.

site_title: Energy sector methane emissions underreported: report
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) reports that energy sector methane emissions are underreported by 70%, with human activities responsible for 60% of methane emissions. Cutting global methane emissions by 30% by the end of this decade could have a significant impact on global warming, equivalent to shifting the entire transport sector to net zero CO2 emissions. The IEA identified significant methane emissions in Texas and Central Asia, with Turkmenistan alone responsible for one-third of large emissions events. The energy industry is a major source of methane emissions from leaks and operations, but investments to capture methane and reduce leaks could quickly pay off.

site_title: Catherine He joins Colliers as head of research for Singapore
summary: Colliers has appointed Catherine He as director and head of research for Singapore. She joins from CBRE, where she was director of research for South-east Asia. He will lead Colliers' research capability in Singapore, producing strategic and actionable research to integrate the company's services across South-east Asia. Her appointment is expected to enhance Colliers' team capabilities to better serve clients, particularly in Singapore, which remains a key international business hub. He will report to managing director Tang Wei Leng.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares begin with gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks began trading higher on February 23, 2022, following a 3-day sell-off. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.42% to 23,592.99, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also edged up. Investors remain cautious due to concerns over a potential Russia-Ukraine war.

site_title: Singtel to redevelop its Comcentre HQ for more than S$2b
summary: Singtel has announced plans to redevelop its Comcentre headquarters in Singapore for over S$2 billion, aiming to maximize the site's potential and increase building efficiency. The new Comcentre, expected to be completed by 2028, will feature Grade A office buildings, retail space, and a retail component, with a total gross floor area of over 110,000 square meters. The redevelopment aims to unlock value from the property and enhance the company's operations.

images.alt_text: Above: Singtel's Comcentre headquarters on 31 Exeter Road. The telco plans to incorporate sustainable designs and digital technologies into the office, styling it as a "next-generation office development" that will house Singtel's headquarters and offer hybrid workplaces to its other tenants.

site_title: Sembcorp Industries posts strong H2 earnings on higher energy prices
summary: Sembcorp Industries reported a net profit of S$233 million for the 6 months ended Dec 31, 2021, reversing a loss of S$866 million a year ago. The company's turnover from continuing operations increased by 59% to S$4.5 billion, driven by higher energy demand and fuel prices. Earnings per share grew 18% to S$0.1306, and the board proposed a H2 FY2021 final dividend of S$0.03 per share. The company aims to make 70% of its net profit from sustainable solutions and has secured 2.9 GW of new renewable energy projects.

site_title: OpenSea NFT heist likely triggers drop in activity
summary: A phishing attack on OpenSea, the world's largest NFT marketplace, likely led to a significant drop in activity, with estimated losses of US$2-3 million. The attack involved 254 stolen NFTs, including 4 Bored Apes, which were later sold for a combined US$667,000. Trading volume on OpenSea plummeted 37% and the number of traders dropped by 19%. The marketplace's CEO has acknowledged the need for increased awareness about security issues surrounding off-chain signatures among NFT traders.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 4.43 points higher at 1,581.39, up 0.28% on Wednesday, with 197 gainer lots and 123 loser lots.

site_title: Hot stock: OCBC down 6.3% after Q4 net profit misses analyst estimates
summary: OCBC's Q4 net profit fell 14% to S$973 million, missing analyst estimates of S$1.18 billion. The bank's shares dropped 6.3% to S$12.52, with peers DBS and UOB performing better. OCBC's full-year net profit rose 35% to S$4.86 billion, driven by strong non-interest income and lower allowances. Analysts expressed disappointment with the results, citing elevated credit costs and a lack of dividend policy guidance.

site_title: Intel challenges the reign of Chinese bitcoin mining rig makers
summary: Intel's new Bitcoin mining chip, BonanzaMine, is set to challenge the dominance of Chinese manufacturers Bitmain and MicroBT in the market. The chip, unveiled in January, is the first major competitor to the proprietary technology used by Chinese makers. Intel's entry is expected to weaken Chinese manufacturers' pricing power and offer better maintenance services, thanks to its proximity to miners in North America. The first batch of chips will be delivered to mining firms Block, Griid Infrastructure, and Argo Blockchain later this year, with some miners welcoming the competition due to the current pricing model and operational costs.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS lowers target price on Sea to factor in Free Fire India ban
summary: DBS Group Research lowered its target price on Sea to US$272, citing the ban of Free Fire in India, which affects the company's gaming business. Despite this, DBS maintains its "buy" call on the stock, expecting potential upside of 116.4% from the current price of US$125.72. The research team believes Sea's e-commerce and fintech businesses will drive growth, with projected values of US$185 and US$10 per share, respectively.

site_title: ADNOC, Singapore's AG&P agree FSU lease for Philippines first LNG terminal launch
summary: ADNOC Logistics & Services (ADNOC L&S) has agreed to supply a floating storage unit (FSU) to AG&P, a Singapore-based LNG logistics company, to launch the Philippines' first LNG import terminal at Ilijan in Batangas Bay. The 11-year charter agreement is extendable by 4 years, and the FSU will have an offshore storage capacity of 137,000 cu m. The terminal, named PHLNG, will have an initial capacity of 5 million tonnes per annum and is set to be commissioned on July 1, with commercial operations starting soon afterwards.

site_title: Putin moves on Donbass but signals deeper designs on Ukraine
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin has escalated the Ukraine crisis, signing friendship treaties with separatist regions in eastern Ukraine, despite international condemnation and sanctions. Putin's televised speech portrayed Ukraine as an artificial nation with no statehood, suggesting his ultimate goal is to destroy or divide the country. The move has heightened anxiety among the Russian elite, and analysts believe Putin is seeking to justify deeper aggression against Ukraine and a possible new invasion. The risk of an open war between Russia and Ukraine increases, with Putin affirming the right to send troops and build military bases in the region.

site_title: Tokyo: Markets closed for holiday on Wednesday
summary: Japan's financial markets closed on Wednesday for a public holiday, resuming trading on Thursday. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks continued their 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday. In other news, Airalo raised US$220 million in a new funding round, lifting its valuation past US$1 billion, and traders in Asia brushed off new Trump threats to extend their stocks rally.

site_title: Australia: Shares wobble as investors weigh Ukraine crisis; Woolworths gains
summary: Australian shares wavered on Wednesday as investors weighed the Russia-Ukraine crisis, with the S&P/ASX 200 index up 0.1% at 7,174. Global investor sentiment remains jittery, with gold stocks falling 2% and technology shares gaining 1.5%. Woolworths rose 4% after beating earnings estimates, while Domino's Pizza dropped 14.6% after missing profit forecasts. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.3%. The market's volatility reflects the ongoing uncertainty surrounding the Ukraine crisis and its impact on global markets.

site_title: Australian wages pick up in Q4, still not fast enough
summary: Australian wages increased 0.7% in the December quarter, the largest increase since 2013, driven by a tightening labour market. The annual rate rose to 2.3%, slightly missing forecasts of 2.4%, which led to a dip in the local dollar. The private sector saw 2.4% growth, while public payroll growth lagged at 2.1%. Despite the increase, wages still haven't reached levels that would justify interest rate hikes, according to policymakers.

site_title: Omicron variant no more severe than original strain: WHO
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) has stated that the BA.2 variant of the Omicron coronavirus strain is not more severe than the original strain. According to Maria Van Kerkhove, a senior WHO official, the severity and risk of hospitalization remain similar for both BA.1 and BA.2 variants. This conclusion is based on a sample of people from various countries, providing relief to countries where the BA.2 variant has circulated widely, such as Denmark.

site_title: Oscars to pre-tape some awards in bid for 'tighter' show
summary: The Oscars will pre-tape the announcements of eight winners to make the televised ceremony "tighter and more electric." The move, aimed at boosting TV ratings, will free up time for musical performances and comedy. The ceremony will still feature winners' speeches, and the streamlining measure will also include a new "fan favourite" prize. This comes after the 2022 Oscars saw a 56% decline in viewership to 10 million, with some categories being pre-taped last year but being unpopular among members.

site_title: Cromwell E-Reit H2 DPU drops 2.8% to 0.08459 euro
summary: Cromwell E-Reit's CWBU distribution per unit (DPU) fell 2.8% to 0.08459 euro for the 6 months ended Dec 31, 2021, with net property income (NPI) growing 10.4% to 65.8 million euros. This growth was mainly due to new acquisitions in the Czech Republic, Slovakia, and other countries. Disposals and lower income from pandemic-affected properties partially offset the rise in NPI.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OCBC, Sembcorp Industries, Q&M Dental, Cromwell, Singtel
summary: Several Singapore-listed companies reported new developments that may impact trading on Wednesday. OCBC posted a 14% decrease in net profit to S$973 million for its fourth quarter, while Sembcorp Industries reported a 59% year-on-year increase in turnover. Q&M Dental Group saw its earnings fall 47% despite revenue growth, and Cromwell European Real Estate Investment Trust's distribution per unit decreased by 2.8%. Singtel announced plans to jointly redevelop its headquarters, with an estimated cost of over S$2 billion.

images.alt_text: OCBC on Wednesday posted a 14 per cent decrease in net profit for its fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2021 to S$973 million, from S$1.13 billion a year ago.

site_title: Facebook launches Reels globally, betting on 'fastest growing' format
summary: Facebook is launching Reels globally to over 150 countries, expanding its fastest-growing content format. The move follows Meta's recent earnings report, which highlighted Reels as a key priority. Reels, launched on Instagram in 2020 and Facebook in 2021, competes with TikTok. Meta is introducing new ways for creators to monetize Reels, including bonuses and overlay ads. The company also plans to roll out Reels in new places, such as Stories and the Watch tab, and to introduce suggested Reels in some countries.

images.alt_text: Facebook is launching its short video feature Reels to more than 150 countries, its owner Meta Platforms said on Tuesday (Feb 22), in a move to expand its fastest growing content format.

site_title: Q&M Dental's Q4 earnings fall 47% on higher costs, expenses
summary: Q&M Dental Group reported Q4 earnings of S$3.2 million, a 47% year-on-year decline due to higher costs and expenses. Total revenue grew 22% to S$53.3 million, driven by stronger contributions from its Covid-19 medical laboratory business. The company's EPS fell 46% to S$0.0034, and it declared a fourth interim dividend of S$0.01 per share. For the full year, the group's earnings were 55% higher at S$30.5 million, with revenue growing 49% to S$205.6 million.

site_title: Hong Kong's tiny apartments increase pain of Covid isolation
summary: Hong Kong's Covid-19 outbreak has left tens of thousands of patients struggling to isolate themselves due to the city's tight living spaces. With over 30,000 patients waiting at home, hospitals are stretched to their limits, and residents are forced to recuperate in cramped conditions. The city's affordable housing crisis exacerbates the issue, with many young people living with their parents due to high property prices and rents. Authorities have been criticized for their handling of the outbreak, and China has intervened, urging the city to take "all necessary measures" to control the outbreak.

site_title: US hits Russian banks, elites with sanctions over Ukraine crisis
summary: US President Joe Biden imposed new sanctions on Russian elites and two banks, targeting those responsible for the ongoing Ukraine crisis. The sanctions, announced in response to Russian President Vladimir Putin's troop deployment into eastern Ukraine, are part of the West's efforts to deter an all-out invasion. The European Union, Germany, and Britain also plan to impose financial penalties on Russia. Moscow has consistently denied plans for further incursion, but the US and its allies fear a further escalation of the crisis. The sanctions are aimed at punishing Moscow for its actions and pressuring Putin to withdraw troops.

site_title: US home prices saw biggest jump in 34 years in 2021
summary: US home prices saw the largest jump in 34 years in 2021, with a 18.8% increase, according to the S&P CoreLogic Case-Shiller US National Home Price index. This is the biggest jump since 1988. Existing homes sold at a record six million, despite a low supply, driven by double-digit increases in material costs and worker shortages. The inflation wave is expected to ease this year as interest rates rise and supply chain issues improve, potentially cooling the housing market.

site_title: Aoxin Q&M H2 loss narrows to 1.2m yuan despite revenue decline
summary: Aoxin Q&M Dental Group reported a narrowed net loss of 1.2 million yuan for its second half, despite a 6.9% revenue decline to 77.9 million yuan. The company attributed the decline to reduced revenue from dental equipment and supplies segments. However, an increase in revenue from its primary healthcare segment partially offset the decline. Net loss per share narrowed to 0.31 fen, and no dividend was declared for the half year. The company is conserving cash for working capital needs amid a challenging environment due to recurring lockdowns in China.

images.alt_text: Aoxin Q&M Dental Group on Wednesday (Feb 23) said its net loss narrowed to 1.2 million yuan (S$255,177) for its second half ended Dec 31, 2021, from 1.6 million yuan a year ago.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at Wednesday's open; STI down 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.4% on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dropping 13.78 points to 3,386.8, amid rising US-Russia tensions. The US market declined sharply overnight, with the Dow Jones and S&P 500 indices falling 1.4% and 1%, respectively. Locally, OCBC tumbled 4.5% and DBS climbed 0.03%, while UOB fell 0.03%. Trading was heavy, with ComfortDelGro and Thai Beverage among the most actively traded counters.

site_title: Higher property taxes further dent investment case of Singapore private homes
summary: Higher property taxes in Singapore, set to rise from 10-20% to 11-27% for non-owner-occupied homes and 5-23% to 6-32% for owner-occupied homes, will further dent the investment case of private homes. The increase in property taxes is expected to impact the top 7% of owner-occupied homes, with higher taxes bearing down on more expensive homes. The higher taxes weaken the attraction of homes as a source of recurrent income, potentially shifting focus to commercial and industrial properties.

site_title: Oil settles near 2014 high on Russia-Ukraine escalation
summary: Oil prices surged near 2014 highs after Russia ordered troops into two Ukrainian regions, prompting Western sanctions and fears of a full-scale Russian invasion. Oil prices peaked at $99.50 a barrel for Brent crude and $96 a barrel for US West Texas Intermediate, before settling at $96.84 and $92.35 respectively. The US and EU imposed sanctions targeting Russian banks and politicians, while Germany halted the Nord Stream 2 gas pipeline project. The Ukraine crisis added support to the oil market, which has been driven by tight supplies and recovering demand.

site_title: Nord Stream 2 shelving will 'relieve Russia's geostrategic chokehold over Europe': US official
summary: A US official stated that shelving the Nord Stream 2 pipeline project will "relieve Russia's geostrategic chokehold over Europe" by reducing its control over natural gas supply. The $11 billion investment and prized pipeline, meant to supply gas to Germany, will now go to waste. The official described the project as "President Vladimir Putin's prized pipeline." This development is seen as a major turning point in the world's energy independence from Russia.

site_title: OCBC Q4 profit falls 14% to S$973m; pays S$0.28 in dividends
