summary: OCBC Bank reported a 14% decline in fourth-quarter profit to S$973 million, missing analyst estimates of S$1.18 billion. Despite this, CEO Helen Wong expressed cautious optimism about economic recovery, citing pre-pandemic levels of profitability. The bank's net interest income rose 4% year-on-year, while non-interest income grew 1%. OCBC aims to grow its sustainable financing portfolio to S$50 billion by 2025 and targets a 10% compound annual growth rate for its banking income over the next three years.

site_title: 'Most beautiful building on Earth' opens in Dubai
summary: Dubai unveiled its Museum of the Future on Tuesday, claiming it as the world's most beautiful building. The seven-storey, hollow silver ellipse is decorated with Arabic calligraphy and LED lights, located on Sheikh Zayed Road. The museum will feature design and technology innovations, taking visitors on a journey to the year 2071, although its contents have yet to be revealed.

site_title: US opposes Canada's digital services tax proposal
summary: The US Trade Representative's office opposes Canada's proposed digital services tax, urging Canada to abandon plans and instead implement the OECD/G-20 agreement. The US raised concerns that the tax would single out American firms while excluding national firms. The Canadian government proposed the tax to protect Canadian interests and remains in talks with the US over the issue. The US had previously withdrawn its threat of tariffs against European countries with digital services taxes as part of a global tax regime deal.

site_title: There is more to market volatility than Ukraine
summary: Market volatility is being driven by structural issues beyond the Russia-Ukraine conflict, including a shift in liquidity provided by central banks. The US Federal Reserve's efforts to tackle high inflation and contract its balance sheet may lead to higher interest rates and reduced liquidity, affecting equity valuations. Additionally, the erosion of market liquidity due to reduced risk absorption capacity by intermediaries has resulted in increased price gaps and volatility. These factors may lead to unsettling market fluctuations, requiring investors to be cautious and adapt their strategies.

site_title: US consumer confidence slips in February
summary: US consumer confidence slipped to a reading of 110.5 in February, down from 111.1 in January, amid concerns about the short-term economic outlook. Expectations about short-term growth prospects weakened, leading to a likely moderation in growth over the first half of 2022. Consumers also reduced plans to purchase homes, automobiles, and vacations over the next six months.

site_title: An obscure corner of Wall Street is making billions trading inflation
summary: Nikhil Choraria, a Goldman Sachs partner, leads a small group of traders profiting from inflation trading, a niche business that has generated billions for major banks and hedge funds. The market, known as "the widow maker," has seen a surge in interest rates, with average daily trading in inflation-linked government bonds and derivatives up 30% on a year ago. Traders are betting on inflation, with some generating hundreds of millions of dollars in revenue, while others are hedging bets in other assets like Bitcoin and sterling-based inflation products.

site_title: Punishing Putin: How Biden could cut Russia off from world tech
summary: The US is considering expanding export controls on Russia, which could cut off the country from a vast array of low- and high-tech goods, including commercial electronics, semiconductors, and aircraft parts. The measures, part of a suite of export control penalties, aim to damage Russia's economy and target critical technology inputs. If Putin escalates further, the US will escalate further with financial sanctions and export controls, targeting industrial production and high-tech sectors. The package could include restrictions on firms that use US tools to make technology overseas, and would be enforced with a strict "policy of denial" standard of review.

site_title: Citigroup maps out expansion of commercial banking across Africa
summary: Citigroup is expanding its commercial banking operations in Africa, starting services in South Africa, Nigeria, Kenya, and Egypt, targeting international businesses in these countries. This move follows the bank's efforts in countries like Australia, where it set up a commercial-banking business in 2019. Under CEO Jane Fraser, Citigroup is focusing on building its wealth management arm, creating hubs in the UAE, Singapore, and London to serve ultra-rich clients, and recruiting private bankers in the UAE to serve the ultra-rich.

site_title: Amazon faces another complaint over tactics in Alabama union vote
summary: Amazon faces another complaint over its tactics in an Alabama union vote, with a labour group accusing the company of "unfair labour practices" to interfere with employees' right to organise. The National Labor Relations Board will begin counting ballots on March 28, following a previous ruling that Amazon violated rules in an April 2021 vote. Amazon removed pro-union literature from break rooms and subjected employees to "anti-union propaganda" during mandatory meetings, violating workers' rights, according to the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union. Amazon claims it has complied with the law.

site_title: What the pandemic taught us about customer service by banks
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic accelerated the shift towards digital banking in Singapore, with 70% of adults using online banking frequently and 80% likely to continue post-pandemic. Banks must adapt to changing customer preferences, with 21% of respondents expressing dissatisfaction with mobile services and 19% feeling their bank needed more support. To retain customers, banks must prioritize digital customer experience, leveraging technologies like AI, ML, and data analytics to deliver personalized services and improve customer satisfaction.

site_title: US: Stocks tumble as Biden announces new Russia sanctions
summary: US stocks plummeted 1.4% on Tuesday as President Joe Biden announced new sanctions on Russia following its escalation in the Ukraine crisis. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 480 points, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes dropped 1.0% and 1.2%, respectively. The move was seen as a response to Russian President Vladimir Putin's decision to send troops into eastern Ukraine. The sanctions include cuts to Moscow's sovereign debt and Western financing. The market downturn was also attributed to concerns over rising consumer prices and potential Fed tightening.

site_title: Investors should reward, not penalise telcos that shift from yield to growth
summary: StarHub, a Singaporean telco, is shifting its focus from yield to growth, despite being viewed as a traditional yield stock due to its generous dividend payouts in the past. The company has announced plans to cut costs, improve operational efficiency, and invest in new business segments, such as enterprise and data services. However, this shift may lead to a decline in dividends and lower valuations. Analysts are advising investors to reward the company for its growth strategy, rather than penalizing it for reduced dividend payouts.

site_title: Europe: Stocks flat as Russia-Ukraine jitters keep investors on edge
summary: European stocks ended flat on Tuesday, despite gains in auto and travel shares, due to geopolitical risks from Russia's troop deployment in Ukraine. Western countries, including Germany and Britain, imposed sanctions on Russia, with Germany freezing a new gas pipeline and Britain hitting Russian banks. Analysts predict limited sanctions will not stoke more inflation, and European banks are bracing for fallout.

site_title: Preparing for a post-Covid Asia-Pacific
summary: Asia-Pacific business leaders gathered in Singapore for the first in-person meeting of the Apec Business Advisory Council (ABAC) since February 2020, marking a significant milestone in the region's post-pandemic recovery. The meeting aimed to promote sustainable growth and cooperation among member countries, with a focus on advancing recommendations on regional economic integration, sustainability, and digital trade. Senior officials and business leaders discussed strategies to overcome challenges, including uneven vaccinations and closed borders, and explored ways to construct a Free Trade Area of the Asia-Pacific (FTAAP) to cope with the post-pandemic world.

site_title: Euro volatility jumps on escalation of tensions in Ukraine
summary: The euro experienced its highest one-month volatility in 15 months due to rising tensions in Ukraine and a surge in gas prices, leading to a 0.2% increase against the US dollar. Russian President Vladimir Putin ordered troops into two breakaway regions in Ukraine, prompting the West to vow sanctions. The euro edged 0.2% higher to US$1.1331, while the Russian rouble rose above 80 to the US dollar. Safe-haven currencies, such as the yen and Swiss franc, saw increased demand, and the euro drifted below 1.04 against the Swiss franc.

site_title: AEW selling 55 Market Street to Kajima unit for nearly S$287m
summary: US-based real estate investment manager AEW is selling its 16-storey, 999-year leasehold building 55 Market Street in Singapore's Raffles Place financial district to an indirect wholly-owned Singapore-based unit of Tokyo-based Kajima Corporation for nearly S$287 million. The sale price works out to about S$3,450 per square foot on the net lettable area. The building, mostly vacant, is expected to be refilled with tenants, but Kajima may consider an exit strategy via strata sales later.

site_title: Pan-United posts S$18.7m net profit for FY21
summary: Pan-United Corporation posted a net profit of S$18.7 million for FY21, up from S$1 million in the previous year, driven by a higher share of results from its associate and a 45% increase in revenue to S$586.9 million, largely attributed to the recovery of construction activities in Singapore.

site_title: Companies exposed to Russia brace for new sanctions
summary: Foreign companies with ties to Russia are preparing for new Western sanctions, with contingency plans in place to mitigate potential disruptions. Renault's Avtovaz, Nokian Tyres, Coca-Cola HBC, and Metro are among those watching the Ukraine situation closely, while others like Nestle and Danone are focusing on employee safety. The EU and US are expected to announce measures targeting energy, technology, and financial services, potentially affecting companies like BP, Shell, and Uniper.

site_title: Singapore Medical Group net profit up 78.8% to S$15.6m in FY21
summary: Singapore Medical Group (SMG) reported a 78.8% rise in net profit to S$15.6m for FY21, driven by a 15.5% increase in revenue to S$100.8m. Despite pandemic disruptions and diminished medical tourism, the company's diversified operations and strong demand for specialist healthcare services contributed to the growth. SMG plans to strengthen its position in women's and children's healthcare and expand its aesthetics segment, with new clinics and specialist appointments.

site_title: Certified sustainable palm oil - how the industry can decarbonise
summary: The palm oil industry faces significant environmental challenges, including deforestation, land clearance, and biodiversity loss, which contribute to the climate crisis. To meet global demand for vegetable oil by 2050, land for oil palm cultivation is expected to double, leading to potential deforestation and habitat loss. However, certified sustainable palm oil (CSPO) can help mitigate these issues, emitting 35% less greenhouse gas emissions and associated with a 20% lower impact on biodiversity compared to non-certified palm oil. Integrating climate resilience across palm oil supply chains is crucial to achieving net-zero status by 2050, and the industry must work towards sustainable land conversion, GHG emissions reduction, and empowering local communities.

site_title: Britain sanctions Gennady Timchenko and five banks
summary: Britain has imposed sanctions on Gennady Timchenko and five Russian banks due to Russia's troop deployment in eastern Ukraine, labeling the country heading towards "pariah status." British Prime Minister Boris Johnson warned that the world must prepare for a full-scale invasion. The sanctions target Timchenko and three other billionaires, as well as Rossiya, IS Bank, GenBank, Promsvyazbank, and the Black Sea Bank.

images.alt_text: 5 banks - Rossiya (above), IS Bank, GenBank, Promsvyazbank and the Black Sea Bank - were being sanctioned, along with three people - Timchenko, and the brothers Igor and Boris Rotenberg.

site_title: Fire is still the big enemy at sea
summary: A fire on the roll on-roll off (Ro-Ro) passenger vessel Euroferry Olympia in the Ionian Sea near Greece has resulted in the loss of 11 lives. This incident highlights the significant danger posed by fire at sea, which can have catastrophic consequences for crew, ship, cargo, and the environment. The tragedy serves as a grim reminder of the importance of fire safety measures on ships and the need for vigilance to prevent such incidents.

images.alt_text: Smoke rises from the Italian-flagged Euroferry Olympia, which is on fire, off the coast of the Greek Ionian island of Corfu, on Feb 21.

site_title: Brewing Russia-Ukraine tensions : No clean hands in the crisis
summary: Russia's President Vladimir Putin officially recognized two breakaway Ukrainian regions as independent states, but did not launch a full-scale invasion. This move has sparked tensions with the West, with NATO and Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelenskyy preparing for potential conflict. The situation is complex, with both Russia and the West having made promises and broken agreements over the years. Putin claims Ukraine is a special case, but Ukraine's desire for EU and NATO membership is unlikely to be met. The crisis is a result of both sides' actions, with Russia's annexation of Crimea and the US's role in the 2014 Maidan uprising contributing to the current tensions.

site_title: Over 25,000 Covid-19 cases reported, public urged to visit hospitals only for emergencies
summary: Singapore reported a record high of over 25,000 Covid-19 cases on Feb 22, surpassing the previous highest of 19,420 on Feb 15. While oxygen demand is not high, hospital bed demand has increased for patients with underlying illnesses to recover. Many are visiting hospitals with mild symptoms for Antigen Rapid Tests, adding to the workload of healthcare providers. The Ministry of Health urges the public to visit hospitals only for emergencies, diverting non-emergency cases to urgent care clinics.

site_title: Thailand approves tax breaks for EVs, 'high potential' foreigners
summary: Thailand's cabinet approved tax incentives to promote electric vehicles and attract high-potential foreigners. The incentives include reduced import duty for EVs and lower income tax rates for skilled foreign professionals. The government aims to increase EV production to 30% of total auto production by 2030 and attract 1 trillion baht (US$31 billion) in domestic spending over a 5-year period. The measures are part of a broader goal to boost the economy and keep pace with other regional automakers.

site_title: LHN unit to purchase River Valley Road property for S$8.5m
summary: LHN Limited announced the purchase of a 205.4 sq m freehold property at 298 River Valley Road in Singapore for S$8.5 million. The property will be developed into a co-living space under the Coliwoo brand, expanding LHN's portfolio and increasing brand value. The subsidiary paid a deposit of S$850,000 and will fund the remaining balance of S$7.65 million through internal sources and bank borrowings. The sale is subject to approval from the Controller of Residential Property.

site_title: The wealthy should not be expected to bear most or all of Singapore's tax burden: Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore Finance Minister Lawrence Wong stated that expecting the wealthy to bear most or all of the country's tax burden is "grossly unfair" and unsustainable. The government has introduced tax changes, including higher personal income tax rates for top earners and luxury car levies, to raise revenue for pressing social needs, such as healthcare and an ageing population. Wong emphasized the importance of a progressive system, where those with greater means contribute more, and highlighted the government's efforts to ensure wages continue to rise beyond inflation.

site_title: EU countries agree to admit travellers vaccinated with WHO-approved shots
summary: The European Union (EU) has agreed to lift travel restrictions for non-essential travel from outside the bloc for individuals vaccinated with WHO-approved Covid-19 shots, including those from India and China. The decision, effective March 1, applies to those who received their final vaccine dose within 14-270 days and boosted travellers. Travelers may also need a negative PCR test taken 72 hours prior to departure. EU states can apply additional measures such as quarantine or isolation for those vaccinated with non-EU approved shots.

site_title: Capitalising on opportunities for growth
summary: Singapore Finance Minister Lawrence Wong's Budget 2022 aims to renew and strengthen the country's social compact for a post-pandemic world. The budget includes measures to capitalize on opportunities for growth, such as a green finance framework and a carbon tax, which will help businesses transition to sustainable practices. The government plans to support businesses through productivity solutions grants, company training committees, and temporary bridging loans. The budget also emphasizes the importance of workforce development, with initiatives to attract and retain talent in the green industry. The government expects the budget to be expansionary, with rising costs but improved productivity and value-addedness.

site_title: Only 9% of plastic recycled worldwide: OECD
summary: The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) reports that only 9% of plastic waste worldwide is recycled, with 460 million tonnes of plastics used in 2021, nearly doubling since 2000. The majority (50%) ends up in sanitary landfills, while 22% is disposed of in uncontrolled dumpsites. The OECD calls for coordinated global solutions and proposes measures to increase recycling, reduce production, and promote sustainable waste management, ahead of expected talks on an international treaty on plastic pollution.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as Ukraine war fears, sanctions rattle investors
summary: US stocks opened lower on Tuesday, Feb 22, amid escalating Russia-Ukraine tensions and fears of war, rattling investors. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 105.09 points, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined. Energy stocks surged as oil prices hit their highest since 2014, but overall market sentiment remained cautious. The tensions have raised concerns about potential sanctions, further weighing on investor confidence.

site_title: Thailand approves tax breaks for EVs, 'high potential' foreigners
summary: Thailand's cabinet has approved tax incentives to promote electric vehicles (EVs) and attract high-potential foreigners. The measures include reduced import duty for EVs priced up to 2 million baht and a 40% reduction for those priced between 2-7 million baht. Additionally, income tax rates will be slashed for skilled foreign professionals from 35% to 17% for a period of 5 years. The goal is to boost the economy and achieve 30% of auto production as EVs by 2030, with the aim of adding 1 trillion baht to domestic spending.

images.alt_text: Thailand's cabinet on Tuesday (Feb 22) approved tax incentives to promote a shift to electric vehicles (EVs), and to attract "high potential" foreigners to help boost the economy, the finance minister said.

site_title: In Singapore, capitalists gain from redistribution too
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Lawrence Wong announced plans to explore a Minimum Effective Tax Rate (METR) to bring the country's corporate tax regime in line with the Base Erosion and Profit Shifting initiative (BEPS 2.0). This move aims to ensure multinational enterprises (MNEs) pay their fair share of taxes. Businesses in Singapore are seen as stabilizers in society and are expected to spur growth and innovation, with the government providing support for investments in the digital economy and green initiatives. Singapore aims to become a hub for digital and data flows, with a goal of becoming a net-zero emissions economy by mid-century.

site_title: Indonesia records US$2b budget surplus in January: Finance Minister
summary: Indonesia recorded a US$2 billion budget surplus in January, driven by tax revenues and a stronger economic recovery. The surplus underscores the country's sound fiscal position and reaffirms GDP growth expectations of 4.8-5.5% this year. Overall revenues rose 54.9% in January, with tax collection up 65.6%. The government plans to reduce pandemic-era fiscal stimulus and reinstate a 3% fiscal deficit ceiling next year, as it repaid more bonds than issued, reducing net negative issuance to 15.9 trillion rupiah.

site_title: Opec+ sees no need to pump faster as oil heads toward US$100
summary: Opec+ members, including Iraq and Nigeria, do not plan to accelerate oil production despite oil prices reaching $100 a barrel, citing a strategy of gradual increases to balance the market. The group, led by Saudi Arabia and Russia, will review data on supply and demand at its March meeting and may increase production by 400,000 barrels a day. The decision comes amid worsening tensions over Ukraine and concerns about commercially-stored oil. Oil prices rose 3.6% to $98.94 a barrel as Brent crude extended its 27% gain this year.

site_title: Delfi's FY2021 net profit grows 67.5% to US$29.3m
summary: Delfi Ltd, a chocolate confectionery company, reported a 67.5% increase in net profit to US$29.3 million for FY2021, excluding non-recurring items. Revenue rose 5.2% to US$405.1 million, driven by improved sales and profit margins. The company declared a total dividend of 2.83 US cents per share. CEO John Chuang expressed confidence in the company's growth initiatives and strong balance sheet, predicting better business performance in 2022.

site_title: China broadens real estate lending support to bigger cities
summary: China's central bank has urged commercial banks to accelerate real-estate loans and ensure growth in residential mortgages and developer loans in cities like Shanghai and Guangzhou. Banks in Guangzhou have started cutting mortgage rates, with seven lenders lowering rates by 20 basis points, and regulators in Shanghai have issued guidance to support mortgage growth. The moves aim to engineer a soft landing for the property market and stabilize growth amid a cash crunch among developers.

site_title: Trump-linked SPAC's shares surge as Truth Social app tops Apple downloads
summary: Shares of Digital World Acquisition, the blank-check company behind former US President Donald Trump's new social media venture, Truth Social, rose 14% after the app topped Apple's App Store downloads. Truth Social was downloaded 170,000 times since its launch, and Digital World's shares jumped to $96.36. The stock's surge is driven by hype, but experts are skeptical about the app's long-term prospects. Trump's return to social media could attract his massive following, but it depends on the app's quality.

images.alt_text: Shares of Digital World Acquisition, the blank-check company behind former US President Donald Trump's new social media venture, Truth Social, rose about 14 per cent on Tuesday (Feb 22) as the app topped downloads on Apple's App Store after its launch late on Sunday.

site_title: Left-wing Democrats are facing a backlash
summary: US President Joe Biden and the Democratic Party are facing a backlash due to their failed efforts to pass major spending bills and shifting public opinion. Economists refer to this as the "recognition gap," where the time delay between economic shocks and the realization of their impact. The Democratic Party's progressive wing has promoted a narrative of a transformed America, but recent polls show a shift towards the center, with a majority opposing "defunding the police." The defeat of progressive Democrats in the Virginia and New Jersey gubernatorial elections and the recent San Francisco school board recall election demonstrate the party's dead-end. Many Democratic candidates are distancing themselves from the party's leftward shift, but it may be too late to change voters' attitudes in the 2022 primaries.

images.alt_text: Future historians would probably try to figure out why President Biden entered the White House operating under the assumption that he received a political mandate from the American people to spend trillions of US dollars on restructuring the American social-economic system.

site_title: London Stock Exchange buys TORA to boost digital drive
summary: London Stock Exchange Group (LSEG) has agreed to acquire US cloud-based technology provider TORA in a $325 million deal, aiming to boost its digital assets and trading tools. The acquisition will enable LSEG to deliver 'at trade' capabilities for the buy side and compete in Asia and North America. TORA's presence in Hong Kong, New York, Singapore, and Tokyo will support LSEG's expansion. The deal is part of a growing trend of major financial institutions acquiring digital firms to upend trading processes.

site_title: Riverstone full-year net profit up 119.1% to RM1.4 b
summary: Riverstone Holdings, a Malaysian glove maker, reported a 119.1% increase in full-year net profit to RM1.4 billion (S$449.9 million) for FY2021, driven by higher sales volumes and average selling prices for healthcare and cleanroom gloves. Revenue rose 68.5% to RM3.1 billion, with gross profit increasing 112.4% to RM1.91 billion. The company recommended a special interim dividend of 10 sen and a final dividend of 28 sen. Despite increased sales, expenses rose, and the board delayed plans to increase capacity by 1.5 billion gloves to end 2022.

site_title: Private equity firm Apollo launches US$100m foundation
summary: Apollo Global Management has launched a US$100 million foundation to provide grants to organizations focused on workplace diversity, skills development, and access to capital for aspiring professionals and entrepreneurs. The foundation, run by Apollo's employees, will partner with non-profits and utilize a similar process used for deal-making to identify and fund recipients. This move aims to expand opportunities for underrepresented groups in the private equity industry, building on Apollo's existing initiatives to promote diversity and inclusion.

site_title: Carbon tax hike a 'strong signal' Singapore is serious about green targets: Tan See Leng
summary: Singapore's carbon tax rate is set to increase to S$50 to S$80 per tonne by 2030, significantly higher than the original target of S$10 to S$15 per tonne. This move, announced by Finance Minister Lawrence Wong, is seen as a strong signal to the world that Singapore is serious about reaching its ambitious climate goal of achieving net zero emissions by the mid-20th century. Second Minister for Trade and Industry Tan See Leng believes the tax increase will create opportunities in the green economy, leading to millions of jobs globally and benefiting Singapore workers.

site_title: Singapore Land's net profit up 267% to S$331.2m on fair value and disposal gains
summary: Singapore Land Group's net profit rose 267% to S$331.2 million in FY2021 due to fair-value gains and a one-off disposal gain. The company anticipates uneven property market recovery and notes ongoing US-China relations and Covid-19 pandemic impacts on the global economy.

site_title: LMIRT Q4 DPU up 125% to 0.09 Singapore cent
summary: LIPPO Malls Indonesia Retail Trust (LMIRT) reported a 125% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) to 0.09 Singapore cents in Q4 2021, driven by a 86.2% rise in gross revenue to S$50.9 million. Net property income and rental revenue also increased, largely due to the addition of the newly acquired Lippo Mall Puri. The trust's average portfolio occupancy stood at 80.9% at the end of 2021, higher than the industry average.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Russia-Ukraine standoff has intensified, fueling price increases in oil and gold. A tight commodities market has been exacerbated by the crisis, with prices shooting up. This development has significant implications for global markets, indicating a heightened sense of uncertainty and volatility. The ongoing conflict between Russia and Ukraine continues to have far-reaching economic effects, with investors closely monitoring the situation for potential market shifts.

site_title: Many companies still looking to expand abroad once borders reopen: OCBC's Linus Goh
summary: Linus Goh, head of global commercial banking at OCBC Bank, says many companies are still looking to expand abroad once borders reopen, as being physically present is crucial for seeking customers and partners. Sustainability is an emerging area, with a significant shift in companies recognizing going green as good for business. Digitalization is also expected to continue, with firms that have pivoted to go digital outperforming those that have not by 4 times in sales performance.

images.alt_text: OCBC Bank head of global commercial banking Linus Goh at The Business Times - Budget Dialogue 2022, presented by OCBC Bank.

site_title: Europe: Stocks tumble at open on Ukraine escalation
summary: Europe's main stock markets plummeted on Tuesday as the Russia-Ukraine crisis escalated, triggering Western sanctions against Moscow. London's FTSE 100 index fell 1.2%, Frankfurt's DAX dropped 2%, and Paris's CAC 40 retreated 1.8%. The decline was attributed to heightened tensions and uncertainty.

site_title: ThaiBev to revive unit's US$2b Singapore IPO, sources say
summary: Thai Beverage, a Thai conglomerate, plans to revive its US$2 billion initial public offering (IPO) of its Singapore brewery unit, BeerCo, after shelving the initial attempts due to the COVID-19 pandemic. The IPO could value the brewery arm at around US$10 billion and would be Singapore's largest since 2011. ThaiBev, controlled by Thailand's richest man Charoen Sirivadhanabhakdi, is working with financial advisers to gauge investors' interest. The sale could take place as early as the second quarter of 2022, pending regulatory approvals.

site_title: Hong Kong Budget: What to expect from vouchers to interest rates
summary: Hong Kong's government is expected to unveil a budget that will further deepen the city's fiscal deficit, driven by the ongoing Covid-19 outbreak. The budget is forecast to be the fourth consecutive year of a deficit, with a median estimate of a HK$74.5 billion shortfall, or 1% of GDP. Financial Secretary Paul Chan is expected to introduce support measures, including consumption vouchers and tax rebates, to cushion the economy. However, economists warn that the measures will have limited effect in curbing the economic fallout, and Hong Kong's economic outlook remains dark, with top banks downgrading their annual growth forecasts and Fitch Ratings predicting a worst outlook among 120 economies.

images.alt_text: To cushion the economy, Financial Secretary Paul Chan is expected to keep the fiscal taps open, driving the government's budget to its fourth deficit in a row in the coming fiscal year, the longest period of shortfalls in almost a decade.

site_title: HSBC under investigation in US over WhatsApp use
summary: HSBC is under investigation by US regulators over bankers' misuse of services like WhatsApp for business communications. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) is looking into the use of mobiles and messaging platforms to ensure appropriateness. HSBC is cooperating with the probe, with CEO Noel Quinn stating it's part of a broader investigation across all financial institutions. The CFTC previously fined JPMorgan $200 million for similar misuse of platforms.

site_title: StarHub EPL rights could pose short-term cost challenge: Analysts
summary: StarHub's 6-year exclusive partnership with the English Premier League (EPL) for broadcast rights may pose short-term cost challenges due to unfactored costs. Analysts note that the company's earlier Ebitda margin guidance did not include the cost of the rights, which could pressure margins in FY2023. The EPL rights may also be subject to the Infocomm Media Development Authority's cross-carriage measure, reducing StarHub's competitive edge.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed 5.73 points lower on Tuesday, at 1,576.96. The index saw 4.330 billion lots traded worth RM3.164 billion. Losers outpaced gainers 779 to 286.

images.alt_text: Malaysia share prices closed lower on Tuesday (Feb 22) with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 5.73 points to 1,576.96.

site_title: Hong Kong to mass test city within 3 months to tame outbreak
summary: Hong Kong will conduct a mandatory citywide virus testing program within 3 months to combat a growing outbreak. The program will test residents 3 times based on their identity card numbers and year of birth. Most social-distancing restrictions will remain in place until mid- to late April, and the ban on inbound flights from 9 countries, including the US, UK, and Australia, will be extended to April 20.

site_title: Scholz says Germany halting Nord Stream 2 project
summary: German Chancellor Olaf Scholz announced the suspension of the Nord Stream 2 pipeline project with Russia due to Moscow's recognition of two breakaway regions in Ukraine. The decision halts the review process by the German regulator, preventing certification and operation of the pipeline. Scholz stated that the move is a "concrete" step, with further sanctions against Russia possible, and expressed confidence in the European Union agreeing to a "robust and massive" sanctions package targeting Russia.

images.alt_text: The Nord Stream 2 project has long been a source of tension with Berlin's allies, who have argued that it would give Moscow too much leverage by increasing Germany's energy dependence.

site_title: Health tech startup Miyahealth bags S$6.5m from ST Engineering Ventures, Elev8
summary: Singapore-based health tech startup MiyaHealth secured S$6.5 million in a pre-Series A funding round led by ST Engineering Ventures and Elev8. The funding will be used to expand operations, introducing MiyaPayor to Indonesia, deploying MiyaPatient to Europe, and launching MiyaProvider across Malaysia. With the fresh funds, MiyaHealth plans to increase its presence in the region and build on its partnerships with over 3,000 medical providers and 12,000 physicians. The total capital raised by MiyaHealth now exceeds S$9 million.

site_title: Wilmar posts record H2 net profit of US$1.1b, to pay record full-year dividend
summary: Wilmar International posted a record second-half net profit of US$1.1 billion, up 23.4% from the same period last year. The company's full-year profit reached US$1.9 billion, also a record high. Wilmar's core net profit excluding non-operating items and changes in fair value of biological assets rose 24% to US$1.8 billion. The company's board has proposed a record full-year dividend of S$0.155 per share, with a total payout of S$0.155, the highest since its listing.

site_title: Singapore stocks hit 1-week low on Ukraine developments; STI down 1%
summary: Singapore stocks ended the day 1% lower, hitting a 1-week low, amid escalating tensions between Russia and Ukraine. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,400.58, with all 30 constituents falling or ending flat. Analysts attribute the decline to Russian President Vladimir Putin's decision to order Russian forces to perform peacekeeping functions in eastern Ukraine, which has quashed certainty over a US summit regarding Ukraine.

site_title: Budget measures will make Singapore a more attractive 'magnet global city'
summary: Singapore's Budget 2022 aims to strengthen its social compact and build resilience in the face of the pandemic crisis. The government will channel tax revenues back to people and the economy, with a focus on building productivity and increasing value-addedness. Key measures include the Progressive Wage Model, Jobs Growth Incentive, and financing schemes, which will be offset by higher costs for businesses and households. Despite these costs, the government expects productivity to rise pari-passu with the increase in cost structure, making Singapore an even more attractive "magnet global city" to attract talent and investment.

site_title: No clean hands in Ukraine crisis
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin's decision to recognize two breakaway Ukrainian regions as independent states and send peacekeepers falls short of a full-scale invasion, sparking a UN Security Council meeting. The move is seen as a response to NATO's eastward expansion, which Russia views as a breach of a 1990s agreement not to expand beyond Germany's eastern borders. However, the West has also played a role in the crisis, with evidence suggesting US involvement in the 2014 Maidan uprising that ousted Ukrainian President Viktor Yanukovych. Both sides have questionable hands in the crisis, with the West's actions in Iraq serving as a precedent for the conduct of superpowers.

site_title: ST Group Food Industries unit to take majority control in Papparich Australia for A$1.4m
summary: ST Group Food Industries Holdings acquired a 40% stake in Papparich Australia Pty Ltd from Papparich Group Sdn Bhd for A$1.4 million. Following the acquisition, STG Food Industries will increase its equity interest in PAPL to 90%, gaining majority control. The deal allows the group to conduct the business and affairs of PAPL. PGSB is a joint venture partner, not a subsidiary, and will retain a minority stake. The acquisition strengthens ST Group's presence in the Australian market.

site_title: APAC Realty H2 profit more than doubles to S$18 mil as property transactions surge
summary: APAC Realty's second-half profit more than doubled to S$18.3 million, driven by a 71.5% increase in total revenue to S$381.3 million, primarily due to a surge in real estate brokerage fees and related services. The company logged its best-ever results since its initial public offering in 2017, with full-year earnings rising 115.3% to S$35.4 million. APAC Realty's market share of the new homes segment increased 4.8 percentage points to 33.7%, while the private residential resale market recorded a 87.9% increase in sales volume.

site_title: Myanmar upheaval prompts Axiata to delay listing telco unit
summary: Axiata Group, Malaysia's largest mobile carrier, has delayed the listing of its telecommunication unit edotco due to the ongoing political unrest in Myanmar. Axiata president Izzaddin Idris cited the challenge of having Myanmar as part of the portfolio if edotco were to be listed. edotco manages over 1,800 towers in Myanmar, while the company has a significant presence in other Southeast Asian nations. This move follows similar concerns from other companies, including Amata and Kirin Holdings, which have also been impacted by the military coup in Myanmar.

site_title: In Singapore, capitalists gain from redistribution too
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Lawrence Wong announced plans to implement a Minimum Effective Tax Rate (METR) of 15% for multinational enterprises (MNEs) in the country, aiming to bring the corporate tax regime in line with the Base Erosion and Profit Shifting initiative (BEPS 2.0). The move is part of Budget 2022, which also includes investments in the digital economy, green initiatives, and support for businesses to spur growth and innovation. The government aims to strengthen Singapore's proposition as a destination for foreign MNEs, startups, and research, with a focus on creating a compact between the government and businesses.

site_title: Left-wing Democrats facing a backlash
summary: US President Joe Biden and his Democratic Party are facing a backlash due to the reality gap between their post-2020 election hopes and the current political reality. The party's progressive wing, led by figures like Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez, has promoted a narrative of a transformed America ready for huge federal spending and identity politics. However, recent polls and elections, such as the Virginia and New Jersey governor's races, and the San Francisco school board recall, show that the public is rejecting this agenda. The Democratic Party is now trying to distance themselves from progressive policies, but it may be too late to change voters' attitudes ahead of the 2022 primaries.

site_title: There is more to market volatility than Ukraine
summary: Market volatility has been driven by structural issues beyond the Russia-Ukraine conflict, including the Fed's shift in liquidity regime and the erosion of market liquidity. The US Federal Reserve's efforts to tackle high inflation and contract its balance sheet have created uncertainty, making it challenging for investors to navigate. With a 10% probability of a comfortable soft landing and three more worrisome scenarios, investors are advised to anticipate unsettling volatility and favor individual name selection over indices, subjecting holdings to granular quality reviews.

site_title: Better Bite launches US$15m fund to back alternative protein startups
summary: Better Bite Ventures, a newly-established venture capital firm, has launched a US$15 million fund to invest in early-stage Asia-Pacific startups developing alternative proteins. The fund's initial portfolio includes 10 companies, including Next Gen Foods, Umami Meats, and Green Rebel Foods. Backed by prominent investors, Better Bite will primarily invest at the founding, pre-seed, and seed stages, with a focus on home-grown companies with local insights taking a leading role in the rapidly growing alternative protein market.

site_title: Aztech Global earnings up 33.5%, expects to benefit from demand for IoT products
summary: Aztech Global, the technology unit of Aztech Group, reported a 33.5% increase in net profit to S$74.4 million for the full year ended Dec 31, 2021, driven by a 28.9% rise in revenue to S$624.4 million. IoT devices and data-communication products were key growth drivers, accounting for 95.6% of total revenue. The company's order book has grown to S$762 million, and it has secured additional orders of S$266.2 million. Despite a tough operating environment, Aztech Global expects to benefit from the IoT trend and has recommended a final dividend of S$0.05 a share for FY2021.

site_title: Riot police clash with New Zealand anti-vax protesters
summary: New Zealand anti-vaccine protesters clashed with riot police in Wellington, resulting in three officers being hospitalized with injuries from a suspected acid attack. The protest, which began as a movement against vaccine mandates, has grown to 1,500 people and encompasses various grievances, including anti-government and anti-media slogans. Authorities have been taking a largely hands-off approach, but Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern has condemned the violence, urging protesters to leave. Police Commissioner Richard Chambers warned that further violence will result in enforcement action, as the protest continues to block roads and disrupt daily life.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower as Ukraine crisis intensifies
summary: Australia's benchmark S&P/ASX 200 index closed 1% lower on Tuesday, reaching a 2-week low, amid heightened tensions between Ukraine and Russia. Financial stocks and miners led declines, with the "Big Four" banks and technology stocks falling 1.5% and 3.2%, respectively. Investors sought safe-haven commodity stocks, driving domestic gold and oil stocks higher.

site_title: Certified sustainable palm oil - how the industry can decarbonise
summary: The palm oil industry faces a critical climate crisis, with deforestation and land conversion projected to double by 2050, threatening ecosystems and exacerbating the climate crisis. To mitigate this, the industry must decarbonize, with certified sustainable palm oil (CSPO) emerging as a key solution. CSPO emissions are 35% lower and biodiversity impacts are 20% lower than non-certified palm oil, according to LifeCycle Assessments. The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is working to strengthen certification schemes, improve transparency, and empower local communities, but more collective action is needed from stakeholders to address the industry's climate and social challenges.

site_title: Vladimir Putin: Crafty strategist or aggrieved and reckless leader?
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin's troop buildup around Ukraine has sparked debate over his intentions, with some analysts suggesting he may be bluffing and others that he has changed amid the pandemic. Putin's recent public appearances have been characterized by irritation and a lack of interest, leading some to speculate about his mental state. Analysts believe a full-scale invasion would be irrational and potentially disastrous for Putin, who could face economic headwinds and social unrest at home. Many in Moscow subscribe to the Kremlin narrative that the West is the aggressor, and Putin's goal may be to compel the West to accept his vision of a revised map, achieved through "special, asymmetric or hybrid means."

images.alt_text: Many analysts remain convinced that the Russian president is essentially rational, and that the risks of invading Ukraine would be so great that his huge troop buildup makes sense only as a very convincing bluff.

site_title: Brokers' take: DBS downgrades Japfa to 'hold' on subdued near-term outlook, margin pressures
summary: DBS Group Research downgraded Japfa to 'hold' from 'buy', citing subdued near-term outlook due to high raw material and logistics costs, and margin pressures extending into 2022. The analyst cut its target price to S$0.67 from S$0.89, citing weak performance in the third quarter and a more conservative margin outlook. Japfa's share price has corrected by around 10% since its third quarter results announcement, and the analyst prefers to wait for better signs of recovery before revising its forecast.

site_title: JTC launches confirmed list site at Jalan Papan for tender
summary: JTC has launched a confirmed list site for tender at Jalan Papan, Plot 4, spanning 0.56 hectares with a 20-year tenure and gross plot ratio of 1.4. Zoned B2 for heavy industrial use, the site is the first of three confirmed list sites for the first half of 2022's industrial government land sales programme. The tender closes on April 19, 2022, regardless of demand, and is open for all developers.

site_title: Volkswagen is in advanced talks on potential Porsche IPO
summary: Volkswagen is in advanced talks to potentially list Porsche through an initial public offering (IPO), aiming to boost its parent's valuation and fund electric vehicle development. A framework agreement has been negotiated, with VW's management and supervisory boards still required to sign off. Estimated valuations of Porsche range from 60 billion to 85 billion euros, compared to the current market value of around 112 billion euros for the entire group. A separate Porsche listing could offer new funding options, as VW's convoluted shareholder structure limits its ability to raise fresh equity capital.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close with big losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks declined 2.69% on February 22, 2022, due to fears of a Russia-Ukraine war and concerns over a potential crackdown by China on tech firms. The Hang Seng Index closed at 23,520.00, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices fell 0.96% and 1.23%, respectively. The decline was attributed to increased market volatility and uncertainty.

site_title: Hong Kong seniors who refused vaccines are 'ticking time bomb'
summary: Hong Kong's vaccination rate among seniors is alarming, with only 43% of those 80 or older receiving at least one dose. Experts warn that this under-inoculated population is a "ticking time bomb" for a surge in fatalities, particularly in nursing homes. If current trends continue, Hong Kong could see nearly 100 deaths per day by late March and a total of around 3,200 by mid-May. The city's healthcare system is already overwhelmed, and officials are urged to prioritize vaccination efforts over mass testing.

site_title: HSBC targets 34% cut to emissions from oil and gas clients by 2030
summary: HSBC has set a target to cut emissions from oil and gas clients by 34% by 2030, marking the bank's first commitment to such a goal. The target is part of its broader sustainability efforts, which include a 75% reduction in intensity of financed emissions for power and utility clients. HSBC's plan is seen as a significant step for the bank and could set a tone for other lenders in the region, but critics argue that absolute targets are necessary to meet global climate goals.

site_title: LTA awards 2 civil contracts worth S$864m for Cross Island Line Phase 1
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has awarded two civil contracts worth S$864 million for the Cross Island Line (CRL) Phase 1. The contracts cover the design and construction of Defu and Tampines North stations and tunnels, valued at S$467 million and S$397 million respectively. Construction is expected to begin in the second quarter of 2022, with passenger service set to start in 2030. LTA emphasized safety measures during excavation works and will closely monitor the construction process to ensure stability and minimize inconvenience to stakeholders.

site_title: War, market jitters threaten Europe's IPO launch season
summary: Europe's IPO launch season is threatened by war and market uncertainty, with companies putting plans to go public on ice due to a 79% decline in IPO proceeds this year compared to the same period last year. The pipeline of deals is under pressure, with several companies delaying their listings, including Spanish bank Ibercaja and German artificial limb maker Ottobock. Fears of a full-scale invasion of Ukraine and inflation concerns are dampening investor risk appetite, leading to a decrease in the FTSE Renaissance IPO Index for Europe, Middle East, and Africa by 23.5% this year.

site_title: Five Raffles Education directors to be formally arrested, bail set at S$30,000 each
summary: Five directors of Raffles Education Corporation, including the CEO and chairman, have been formally arrested and set bail at S$30,000 each following investigations by the Monetary Authority of Singapore and Commercial Affairs Department. The directors are cooperating with authorities and will continue to serve their roles in the interim. The investigations are related to disclosures made by the company about a claim by Affin Bank against certain subsidiaries.

images.alt_text: Above: Interior of the Raffles Design Institute, the flagship campus of Raffles Education. The company shared that several directors had been notified to attend the CAD's offices to effect their formal arrest.

site_title: How investors can update their income strategies
summary: Investors face a challenge in finding reliable income to compensate for low bond yields without taking excessive risk. Traditional methods, such as bonds, stocks, and property, are still prevalent in Asia, but investors may have missed out on the growth stock rally in recent years. Innovative fund managers have developed strategies, including dividend capture and alternative asset investing, to meet income needs without limiting portfolio diversification or capping upside potential. These strategies aim to maximize income while not missing out on market growth, offering investors a new universe of opportunities to build diversified income portfolios.

site_title: European gas surges as Putin orders forces to separatist areas
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin has ordered the deployment of "peacekeeping forces" to two separatist areas in Ukraine, prompting a surge in European natural gas prices. Gas traded in the Netherlands rose 13% as oil and gold also surged. The move escalates tensions with the West, with the US and UK planning to announce sanctions on Tuesday, which could disrupt energy trading and threaten Russian gas supplies to Europe. The European Union is set to discuss a plan for sanctions, with the EU Commission President calling Russia's recognition of the separatist territories a "blatant" violation of international law.

site_title: Billionaire buys Paris mansion for 200m euros from Qatari prince
summary: French billionaire Xavier Niel has purchased the 43,000 square-foot Hotel Lambert in Paris for over 200 million euros, beating the 100 million euros paid for the Hotel de Soyecourt in 2011. The historic mansion, built in 1640, was previously owned by Qatari prince Abdullah bin Khalifa al-Thani. Niel plans to use the property for a cultural foundation, not for personal residence. The acquisition is one of the largest ever deals for a private property in Paris, amid a surge in house prices globally.

site_title: Japan wants to showcase gold mines' history. Just not all of it
summary: Japan is seeking UNESCO World Heritage designation for three gold and silver mines on Sado Island, but the nomination has sparked controversy due to the island's dark history of conscripting 1,500 Koreans to work in the mines during World War II. The Japanese government claims the workers were "legally mobilized" as citizens of the Japanese empire, but South Korea denounces the nomination, calling for Japan to acknowledge the forced labor. The move has worsened relations between Japan and South Korea, with both countries accusing each other of not atoning for colonial abuses.

site_title: Porsches, Lamborghinis lost at sea may cost VW US$155m
summary: A cargo ship carrying approximately 4,000 Volkswagen vehicles, including Porsches and Lamborghinis, caught fire off Portugal's Azores Islands, estimated to cost Volkswagen at least $155 million. The vessel, Felicity Ace, was on its way to the US when the fire broke out on February 16. The ship remains stable, and no oil leakage has been confirmed. The fire is being tackled by a salvage team and firefighting equipment, with a total value of $401 million of vehicles estimated to be lost, including $246 million worth of vehicles from other manufacturers.

site_title: Beijing Olympic ratings were the worst of any winter games
summary: The Beijing Winter Olympics drew an average of 11.4 million viewers per night, the smallest prime-time audience on record for any Winter Games. Total viewership across NBCUniversal platforms reached 160 million over two weeks, despite dramatic storylines and memorable episodes. The Games were marred by empty stands, a doping scandal, and geopolitical tensions, leading to a lack of emotional connection with audiences. Experts say the Olympics brand is struggling, with a need for a "superhero story" or "star quality" to captivate viewers, who now see the Olympics as more personal rather than a true sporting event.

site_title: Users should be allowed to sue US tech giants under EU rules, civil groups say
summary: A coalition of 31 groups and academics is urging EU lawmakers to allow individual users to sue US tech giants for breaching EU rules, such as the Digital Markets Act. The rules, proposed by EU antitrust chief Margrethe Vestager, aim to curb the power of online gatekeepers like Apple, Google, and Facebook. Currently, only business users are allowed to sue violating companies. The coalition believes this should change to enable users to bring enforcement actions before national courts, ensuring their needs are reflected in the Commission's decisions.

site_title: Getting an edge in mid-cycle investing
summary: The current mid-cycle investing environment bears similarities to the late 1990s, characterized by a strong US economy, rising interest rates, and a tech-led rally. As the global economy transitions to the "summer" phase, investors can expect fiscal and/or monetary tightening, slower growth, and improving economic sentiments. Despite valuations concerns, the continued economic reopening will provide an uplift in corporate earnings, supporting bull markets. However, investors should be selective, adjusting their portfolio weights to lower risk exposure, particularly in US growth stocks, and favoring value stocks in cyclical sectors.

images.alt_text: Among the many memorable quotes by American novelist and travel writer Mark Twain, one of the most-oft used in the investing circle is "history never repeats itself, but it does rhyme".

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares down at open
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index fell 1.98% to 23,692.54 after Russian President Vladimir Putin ordered troops into Ukraine, raising conflict expectations. The Shanghai Composite Index lost 0.5% and the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.59%. Global markets reacted to the geopolitical tensions, with US stocks reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: HSBC's annual pre-tax profit more than doubles, brings forward key target
summary: HSBC Holdings reported a more than doubling of annual pre-tax profit to US$18.9 billion, exceeding analyst estimates. The bank reversed hefty credit charges and now expects to meet its key profitability goal a year ahead of schedule. With central bank interest rates expected to rise, HSBC expects to hit a double-digit return on equity in 2023. The bank's momentum is driven by lower-than-expected impairment charges and government support packages in markets affected by the pandemic. CEO Noel Quinn attributed the success to the bank's strategy, particularly its focus on Asia and wealth management.

images.alt_text: HSBC Holdings on Tuesday reported annual pre-tax profit more than doubled as the Asia-focused bank reversed hefty credit charges booked previously, saying it now expects to meet a key profitability goal a year ahead of schedule.

site_title: HSBC says Hong Kong Covid clampdown may hurt ability to hire, keep staff
summary: HSBC warns that Hong Kong's strict COVID-19 measures are hurting the economy, affecting staff retention, and impacting the city's status as a financial hub. The lender's annual profit more than doubled, but it expects a weaker performance in its wealth management business. Economists predict a contraction in the economy without relief measures, and global banks are facing staff departures due to travel curbs. The city's "zero-Covid" policy is driving expats to leave, and experts fear it could harm Hong Kong's financial sector in the long run.

site_title: Russia: Stocks extend slump as Ukraine tensions ratchet higher
summary: Russian stocks plummeted 6.9% on Tuesday, their steepest decline since 2014, amid rising tensions with Ukraine. President Vladimir Putin's recognition of separatist republics in eastern Ukraine and deployment of forces to the breakaway regions have sparked concerns of potential US sanctions. The benchmark MOEX index fell, and the ruble weakened 0.6% against the dollar. Investors await a response from the US and EU on penalties, which could take days to finalize. The situation remains uncertain, with Russia denying plans to invade Ukraine.

site_title: Listcos with diverse leadership are more profitable, NUS study finds
summary: A study by the National University of Singapore Business School found that Singapore-listed companies with diverse leadership, including equal numbers of male and female leaders, tend to perform better financially. The study, which analyzed 577 publicly-listed companies, found that a 10 percentage point increase in the proportion of female leaders contributes to a 0.44 percentage point increase in return on assets (ROA). In contrast, companies with older leadership (above 60 years old) tend to perform poorer, with a 0.63 percentage point drop in ROA.

images.alt_text: An inaugural study covering all 577 publicly-listed companies in Singapore has found hard evidence that a company peaks in financial performance when it has an equal number of male and female leaders in senior management and board positions.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks mark worst day in a week as Ukraine crisis deepens
summary: South Korean shares closed down 37.01 points, or 1.35%, on Tuesday, marking their worst session in a week amid escalating tensions between Russia and Ukraine. The crisis has led investors to rush to safe-haven assets, causing the Korean won to weaken and the benchmark bond yield to fall. The Kospi has lost 9.1% this year, with chip giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix falling 1.08% and 1.15%, respectively. The Bank of Korea is expected to maintain its rate decision on Thursday.

site_title: Markets brace for headwinds, inflationary shocks as Ukraine-Russia crisis looms
summary: Equity markets are bracing for potential headwinds and inflationary shocks due to the escalating Ukraine-Russia crisis. Russia President Vladimir Putin's recognition of breakaway regions in eastern Ukraine as independent entities has raised fears of new sanctions and a major war. Analysts predict a significant risk to global markets, with a Ukraine crisis culminating in a full-scale Russian invasion potentially delivering an inflationary shock. Investors are advised to be cautious and consider hedging strategies, with commodities and defensive sectors potentially offering protection against inflation and volatility.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei ends lower for fourth day as Ukraine crisis worsens
summary: Japan's Nikkei index fell 1.71% to 26,449.61, marking a fourth consecutive day of losses, amid escalating tensions in Ukraine. The broader Topix index dropped 1.55% as consumer sectors, including basic materials and tech, suffered significant losses. Healthcare and energy sectors managed gains, with oil prices boosting the latter. Russian President Putin's deployment of troops to eastern Ukraine has worsened the crisis, with market players anticipating potential near-term bad news.

site_title: Federal Reserve official says March rate hike will depend on data
summary: US Federal Reserve official Michelle Bowman expects high inflation to persist through the first half of 2022, supporting a March interest rate hike. She anticipates "uncomfortably high inflation" and plans to monitor data closely to determine the size of the hike. Bowman also notes labour market conditions are consistent with full employment, and the Fed's balance sheet reduction will help slow inflation. Markets anticipate a 50 basis-point rate hike, with Bowman suggesting additional increases may be necessary if inflation persists.

site_title: Indian 16-year-old stuns chess world champion Carlsen
summary: Indian 16-year-old chess grandmaster Rameshbabu Praggnanandhaa stunned world chess champion Magnus Carlsen in an online championship, winning a 39-move game against the Norwegian. Praggnanandhaa, who became the youngest international master at 10, is now the youngest player to beat Carlsen since 2013. The victory has garnered praise from Indian cricket superstar Sachin Tendulkar and five-time world champion Viswanathan Anand, with Carlsen himself acknowledging a "magical" win.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 0.8% on Tuesday, with the index down 12.92 points to 1,569.77. The stock market saw 223 losers and 127 gainers, with a total volume traded of 205.57 million lots worth RM102.42 million.

site_title: China Haida, Libra Group get delisting notices; Design Studio has no exit offer
summary: China Haida, Libra Group, and Design Studio have received delisting notices from the Singapore Exchange for failing to meet listing rules. China Haida's notice was issued in June 2021 due to financial issues, while Libra Group was noted for failing to announce financial results and having inadequate directors on its audit committee. Design Studio, an insolvent furniture manufacturer, has also been issued a delisting notice and is exploring a reverse takeover deal. The companies have been given deadlines to appeal the notices or submit exit offers to shareholders.

site_title: Q Investment Partners announces £40m exit deal for Edinburgh projects
summary: Q Investment Partners (QIP) has announced a £40m exit deal for two purpose-built student accommodation (PBSA) projects in Edinburgh, UK. The projects, valued at £40m, have been sold to a core plus equity fund managed by QIP. The exit delivers total annual returns of over 18%, exceeding QIP's initial target of 16%. This deal highlights the attractive risk-adjusted investment return available in the UK PBSA sector, which is seeing high demand from institutional investors. QIP's core plus equity fund aims to invest in stabilised PBSA projects across the UK.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts lower targets on Raffles Medical as Singapore goes endemic
summary: Analysts from RHB and DBS Group Research have lowered their target prices on Raffles Medical Group due to tapering pandemic-related revenue as Singapore transitions to endemic living. Analysts expect the healthcare provider to benefit from increased elective procedures, medical tourism, and the return of foreign patient load. RHB reduced its target price to S$1.55, while DBS cut its target price to S$1.63, implying potential upside of 21.1% and 27.3%, respectively. Analysts maintain "buy" calls on the company despite reduced earnings estimates.

site_title: Bitcoin extends dip below US$40,000 as Ukraine tensions boost gold
summary: Bitcoin dropped to a 2-week low of $36,831 on Feb 22 due to escalating tensions between Russia and Ukraine, weighing on risk appetite. The cryptocurrency has weakened as gold reached its highest level since June, potentially pushing bullion to an all-time high. Analysts predict Bitcoin may fall below $30,000 as traders favor gold, undermining the argument that cryptocurrencies are a haven in times of geopolitical turmoil.

site_title: Oil, gold prices shoot up as Russia-Ukraine standoff deepens
summary: Russia's standoff with Ukraine has intensified, fueling concerns over supply cuts and sanctions, driving oil prices to multi-year highs and gold prices to an eight-month high. The US and Europe's potential imposition of sanctions on Russia could limit global oil and natural gas supply, impacting countries heavily reliant on Russian energy. Geopolitical tensions have also raised concerns over the impact on other commodities, including aluminium, nickel, copper, palladium, and platinum. Experts predict oil prices could reach $100 per barrel and gold prices could surge to $2,000 per ounce, but caution that these prices may be short-lived if tensions ease.

site_title: Great Eastern Q4 profit falls 33% but posts full-year increase
summary: Great Eastern Holdings, the insurance arm of OCBC Bank, reported a 33% year-on-year decline in Q4 net profit to S$229.8 million, driven by a one-off positive tax impact in the prior year. However, its insurance business saw an operating profit increase of 126% to S$173.9 million. The company's full-year net profit rose 16% to S$1.11 billion, driven by favourable market conditions and higher operating profit. A final dividend of S$0.55 per share is recommended for the second half-year, up from S$0.50 in the previous year.

site_title: South Korea approves extra budget amid largest coronavirus wave
summary: South Korea's Parliament approved a 16.9 trillion won ($19.1 billion) extra budget to compensate losses from the country's largest coronavirus outbreak, which has forced strict quarantine measures and weighed on economic growth. The budget, aimed at supporting small-scale merchants and micro businesses, will be the seventh since the pandemic began, with over 90% of funds allocated to these businesses. The government's spending measures have pushed up the country's debt-to-GDP ratio to 50.1%.

site_title: 10 things I learnt from owning Suntec Reit for 17 years
summary:
A seasoned investor reflects on his 17-year investment in Suntec Reit, one of Singapore's oldest listed Reits. Key takeaways include: 

Suntec Reit was not the first Reit listed in Singapore, but a quarterly dividend stalwart, and has increased its portfolio assets by over five-fold since its IPO in 2004. The Reit has never conducted a rights issue or preferential offer, instead relying on private placements and asset divestments to fund its acquisitions. Its overseas forays into Australia and the UK have expanded its portfolio, and its distributions have exceeded the investor's initial investment by 186.7%.

site_title: Xi counts some diplomatic wins after polarising Winter Games
summary: Chinese President Xi Jinping concluded the Beijing Winter Olympics without major diplomatic incidents or protests, scoring diplomatic wins despite a US-led boycott and tensions over Ukraine. Xi held 18 bilateral meetings with developing nation leaders, inking economic agreements and strengthening ties with countries like Argentina, Pakistan, and Serbia. The Olympics showcased China's ability to host the Games amid a global pandemic, bolstering Xi's ambitions and demonstrating the country's governance model's performance legitimacy. Despite some criticism, Xi emerged with a soft-power coup, with American-born freestyle skier Eileen Gu winning medals for China.

site_title: Flood of Japanese cash ready to buy treasuries after Fed
summary: Japanese investors, the largest foreign holders of US bonds, are poised to buy more Treasuries as US yields slide and the Federal Reserve's rate hike path becomes more uncertain. Despite recent auctions showing strong overseas demand, momentum has been building for a ramp-up in purchases after the volatile March period ends. Fund managers are waiting for clearer monetary policy guidance before positioning for the new fiscal year in April, with benchmark yields trading near 2% and 10-year yields trading close to 2%.

site_title: SoftBank seen trimming Alibaba stake to fill shortfall: analyst
summary: SoftBank is likely to trim its stake in Alibaba to fill a cash shortfall, according to Jefferies analyst Atul Goyal. The group needs $40 billion to $45 billion in cash this year, mainly for investments in startups and share repurchases. SoftBank sold 20 million Alibaba shares in the last quarter and plans to sell more in 2022. The company is prioritizing its second Vision Fund, which has taken stakes in over 200 companies, and CEO Masayoshi Son has hinted at selling assets, including the public Vision Fund portfolio, to raise funds.

site_title: Hong Kong finds Covid in samples from packaging of pork, beef imports
summary: Hong Kong authorities have found Covid-19 in samples taken from the packaging of imported frozen beef from Brazil and frozen pork skin from Poland. The Centre for Food Safety collected samples from two batches, finding positive results in one outer and two inner packaging samples of beef and one inner packaging sample of pork skin. The government has ordered the disposal of the affected products and will increase inspections of similar imports. This discovery is part of Hong Kong's "dynamic zero Covid" strategy, which aims to eradicate outbreaks at all costs, following mainland China's approach.

site_title: England scraps compulsory self-isolation period for Covid-19 cases
summary: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced the end of compulsory self-isolation for COVID-19 cases in England, effective Thursday. The government will also stop providing free home testing kits from April 1. Despite scientific unease and opposition from Labour and health experts, Johnson urged a shift to relying on vaccines and treatments as the primary defense against the virus. The changes come as Johnson faces scandals and a police probe into lockdown-breaching parties in Downing Street.

images.alt_text: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced on Monday all pandemic legal curbs in England would end later this week, urging a shift from government intervention to personal responsibility.

site_title: Singapore-based data centre operator raises US$500m from investors including Mubadala, Warburg Pincus
summary: Singapore-based data centre operator Princeton Digital Group (PDG) has raised US$500 million in an equity funding round led by Abu Dhabi state fund Mubadala, with existing backers Warburg Pincus and Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan Board also participating. The funding will enable PDG to potentially double its secured capacity of 600 megawatts over 5 years, as demand from global cloud providers fuels the sector's growth. PDG plans to deepen its presence in Singapore, India, China, Japan, and Indonesia, and may explore a public listing in the next 12-24 months.

site_title: Asia: Equities tumble, oil rallies on red-hot Ukraine tensions
summary: Russia's Vladimir Putin ordered troops into 2 separatist regions in eastern Ukraine, escalating geopolitical tensions and fears of a conflict. Asian markets plunged, with Tokyo and Hong Kong falling over 2%, while oil prices surged, reaching a 1-year high, as investors sought safe havens. The US, France, and Germany warned of sanctions against Russia, and the White House announced an executive order to prohibit new investment in the rebel regions. The move has sparked concerns about commodity supplies and inflation, battering equity markets and pushing gold to a 1-year high.

site_title: Chinese tech stocks drop to new crackdown lows, led by Alibaba
summary: Chinese technology stocks plummeted, led by Alibaba's 2.7% drop, as investors worry about Beijing's regulatory plans. The Hang Seng Tech Index reached its lowest close since 2020. Tencent and Meituan also declined, with Tencent denying a new crackdown on its core businesses. The decline follows a Bloomberg report on Alibaba's fintech business arm and comes amid global equity market weakness due to escalating Ukraine tensions. The sector's earnings could be impacted by increasing social responsibility requirements, but details are scarce.

site_title: Some hope for malls but only fittest will thrive in tough climate
summary: Retail landlords face challenges as the pandemic has led to a decline in rental rates and vacancy rates, with retail spending expected to be dampened by the impending goods and services tax and inflation. However, some malls may thrive due to economic growth and rising income, particularly those with attractive offerings, high-quality property management, and deep pockets. Suburban malls may fare better than downtown malls, and larger malls with more experiences and choices are likely to prevail.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower on Ukraine crisis
summary: Tokyo's Nikkei 225 index fell 2.01% or 540.09 points to 26,370.78, following Russian President Vladimir Putin's order to troops into 2 Moscow-backed rebel regions of Ukraine, defying Western threats of sanctions. The broader Topix index also declined 1.74%.

site_title: Australia pledges A$804m for surveillance, research in Antarctica
summary: Australia has pledged A$804 million (S$778.7 million) to enhance its surveillance and research capabilities in Antarctica over the next 10 years. The funding will support the purchase of drones, helicopters, and mobile stations, aiming to bolster Australia's strategic and scientific capabilities amidst China's increasing presence in the continent. The initiative aims to maintain Antarctica as a place of science and conservation, free from conflict and exploitation.

site_title: Europe: Shares plunge as investors assess Ukraine crisis
summary: European shares plummeted to a four-month low, falling 1.3% as investors assessed the Ukraine crisis. The technology sector led losses, with a 2.6% drop to its lowest since March 2022, marking its fourth straight day of losses. The crisis has led to concerns over a resolution, quelling hopes for a resolution.

site_title: Knight Frank expands private client advisory business to Singapore
summary: Knight Frank has expanded its private client advisory business in Singapore, establishing its fourth private office globally. The new office aims to capitalize on the growing family office industry in Singapore and provide high-net-worth clients with one point of contact for residential and commercial property needs. Nicholas Keong, former head of prime sales at Knight Frank Singapore, leads the private office. The move is part of the consultancy's strategy to become a market-leading global private client and family office adviser in real estate.

images.alt_text: Real estate consultancy Knight Frank has expanded its private client advisory business in Singapore, establishing its fourth private office globally.

site_title: EU expands Myanmar junta sanctions over crackdown
summary: The European Union has added 22 officials and 6 companies from Myanmar's military junta to its sanctions list due to the ongoing crackdown since the 2021 coup. The move brings the total number of targeted officials to 65 and firms to 10. The EU expressed deep concern over the escalating violence and calls for an immediate cessation of hostilities, with over 1,500 civilians killed in the military crackdown.

site_title: Putin recognises Ukraine rebel regions, sends troops on what Moscow calls peacekeeping mission
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin recognized two Ukrainian rebel regions as independent, ordering a peacekeeping mission with Russian troops. This move defies Western warnings and may torpedo a potential US-Russia summit. Putin described Ukraine as an integral part of Russia's history, but the US and Europe vowed new sanctions. The rouble plummeted against the dollar as Putin's decree was announced, potentially escalating tensions and sparking a major war.

site_title: Crypto firm Amber gets Temasek funding at US$3b valuation
summary: Singaporean state investment firm Temasek invested US$200 million in cryptocurrency-trading platform Amber Group, valuing the company at US$3 billion. Existing shareholders, including Sequoia China and Pantera Capital, also participated in the funding round. The deal comes as Singapore tries to balance regulating the crypto industry while encouraging institutional participation. Amber will use the funds to expand its European and American presence and enhance its mobile application. The company's client assets grew by over US$5 billion last year, with senior executives relocating to Singapore to tap into the city-state's emerging crypto hub.

site_title: CDLHT in £24.1m deal for 4-star hotel in Manchester, UK
summary: CDL Hospitality Trusts (CDLHT) has indirectly acquired a 4-star hotel in Manchester, UK, for £24.1 million (S$43.8 million). The hotel, Hotel Brooklyn, has a remaining lease term of 196 years and provides a fixed income stream for CDLHT. The acquisition is expected to be accretive, with a 1.1% increase in distribution per stapled security. The hotel's net asset value is £4.4 million, and CDLHT plans to finance the acquisition through debt.

site_title: Elon Musk's attorney accuses SEC of leaking details of probe
summary: Elon Musk's attorney, Alex Spiro, accused the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) of leaking details of its investigation into Musk.
