summary: Singapore will strengthen its current tax system, particularly on wealth, to generate revenue and mitigate social inequalities. Finance Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the importance of wealth taxes, but acknowledged the challenges in implementing them effectively. Currently, Singapore taxes wealth through property tax, stamp duties, and motor vehicle registration fees. Wong noted that other countries, such as Germany and France, no longer levy taxes on net wealth, and the number of OECD countries doing so has declined. Singapore aims to build a fairer society through its tax system.

site_title: Tee International ordered to provide various documents to CAD
summary: Tee International has been ordered by the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD) to provide various documents to assist with an investigation into potential offences under the Securities and Futures Act (SFA). The company must provide access to information and documents, financial records, and corporate emails related to claims made against it. The investigation relates to matters between Jan 1, 2020, and Jul 31, 2021, and does not appear to affect the company's ongoing debt restructuring exercise or business operations.

site_title: Budget 2022: Basic Retirement Sum to be raised to help retiring seniors
summary: Singapore's Basic Retirement Sum (BRS) will be raised by 3.5% for 5 cohorts from 2023 to 2027, providing higher monthly Central Provident Fund (CPF) payouts for retirees. Those setting aside BRS by 2027 will receive approximately S$1,000/month payouts from age 65. Finance Minister Lawrence Wong also announced a 2023 increase in CPF contribution rates for senior workers, with a total increase of 3-4 percentage points over 2 years.

site_title: Budget 2022: Foreign worker quotas cut for construction and process sectors
summary: Singapore's government has announced plans to cut foreign worker quotas for the construction and process sectors, aiming to reduce dependency on foreign workers and spur productivity improvements. The new policies, set to take effect in 2024, will reduce the dependency ratio ceiling (DRC) to 1:5 from 1:7 and replace the man-year entitlement framework with a new levy framework. The goal is to encourage companies to support more offsite work and employ higher-skilled foreign workers, while Singapore remains open to talent from around the world.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end sharply lower
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended sharply lower on Friday, February 18, 2022, with the Hang Seng Index shedding 1.88% to 24,327.71. Investors were concerned about the Russia-Ukraine crisis, the Federal Reserve's rate-hike plans, and daily record Covid-19 infections. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.66% and the Shenzhen Composite Index on China's second exchange increased 0.42%.

site_title: China port delays slow shipments from iron ore to electronics
summary: Port congestion in China is slowing shipments of iron ore and electronics due to tightened Covid-19 quarantine requirements and reduced manpower. Deliveries are taking 1-2 weeks longer, affecting companies relying on stockpiled inventories. Hong Kong's port congestion is also delaying shipments of electronics and petrochemicals, with 23 container ships waiting to berth in January. This may mute the impact on iron ore prices, which have plummeted 15% this week due to China's efforts to cool rising prices and curb hoarding.

site_title: Budget 2022: S$6b to be drawn from past reserves for Covid-19 relief
summary: Singapore's government has proposed a S$6 billion draw from past reserves to fund Covid-19 public health expenditure in FY2022. This brings the total expected draw to up to S$42.9 billion. The cumulative draw is less than the initial S$52 billion agreed for FY2020, due to a swift response to the pandemic and a stronger-than-expected economic rebound. Finance Minister Lawrence Wong also announced a 1% cut in ministries' budgets starting from FY2023, to be channeled to new priorities.

images.alt_text: The Singapore government has proposed to fund Covid-19 public health expenditure through a S$6 billion draw on past reserves in FY2022.

site_title: Budget 2022: Enhancements to schemes to support social mobility, vulnerable groups
summary: Finance Minister Lawrence Wong announced measures to improve Singapore's social fabric in the 2022 Budget, including enhancements to schemes supporting low-income families and vulnerable groups. The KidSTART programme will be scaled up to support 5,000 children by 2023, and a scheme to help second-timer low-income families buy a home will be enhanced with more details to be provided. The budget aims to address social mobility and support vulnerable groups, aiming to improve Singapore's social fabric.

site_title: Budget 2022: Higher taxes for top earners with chargeable income above S$500,000
summary: Singapore's top marginal personal income tax will increase to 23% for income above S$500,000 and 24% for income above S$1 million, starting from the 2024 year of assessment. This represents a 1 percentage point and 2 percentage point increase from the current 22% rate. The changes aim to raise S$170 million of additional tax revenue per year, affecting the top 1.2% of taxpayers, with Finance Minister Lawrence Wong citing "room for greater progressivity" to encourage higher earners to contribute more.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rebound at open
summary: European stock markets rebounded slightly at the open on Friday, February 18, 2022, as traders focused on the Ukraine crisis and inflation outlook. London's FTSE 100 index gained 0.3% to 7,556.25 points, while the eurozone's DAX and CAC 40 indices rose 0.1% to 15,283.48 and 6,952.68 points, respectively. This follows a highly volatile week for equities, with investors taking a cautious stance ahead of US-EU trade talks and amid ongoing concerns about inflation.

images.alt_text: European stock markets rebounded slightly at the open on Friday (Feb 18), the end of a highly volatile week for equities as traders focus in particular on the Ukraine crisis and inflation outlook.

site_title: Budget 2022: Singapore to explore Minimum Effective Tax Rate amid global tax developments
summary: Singapore is exploring a Minimum Effective Tax Rate (METR) to address global tax developments, including the Base Erosion and Profit Shifting initiative (BEPS 2.0). The government aims to top-up the effective tax rate of multinational enterprise (MNE) groups in Singapore to 15% to align with the Global Anti-Base Erosion (GloBE) rules. The Inland Revenue Authority of Singapore will study the METR further and consult the industry on its design. Finance Minister Lawrence Wong noted that it's premature to determine the fiscal impact of the proposed changes.

site_title: Mitsubishi, Petronas to sell stakes in Myanmar Yetagun gas field
summary: Mitsubishi and Petronas are divesting their stakes in Myanmar's Yetagun gas field due to technical and economic challenges. Mitsubishi, which indirectly holds a 1.93% stake, has decided to quit the project and is in talks with other partners. Petronas, which owns 40.9% of the field, has signed agreements for the sale of its entities related to upstream operations in Myanmar. This exit follows last year's military coup and the withdrawal of TotalEnergies and Chevron from the country.

site_title: Budget 2022: New Progressive Wage Credit Scheme, Workfare enhancements to uplift lower-wage workers
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Lawrence Wong announced the introduction of a Progressive Wage Credit Scheme (PWCS) to co-fund wage increases for lower-wage workers from 2022 to 2026, with an initial S$2 billion fund. The scheme will provide 50% funding for workers earning up to S$2,500 and 30% for those above S$2,500. Additionally, the Workfare Income Supplement will be enhanced with a raised monthly income cap and new minimum income criterion to encourage part-timers to take up full-time work. The government expects to spend S$9 billion over 5 years.

images.alt_text: The government is introducing a new Progressive Wage Credit Scheme (PWCS) to co-fund the wage increases of lower-wage workers between 2022 and 2026.

site_title: Budget 2022: Broadband infrastructure to be upgraded, additional S$200m for digital capabilities
summary: Singapore's Budget 2022 includes upgrades to broadband infrastructure to increase speeds by 10 times over the next few years. The government will also invest in 6G technologies and additional funding for digital capabilities in businesses and workers. An extra S$200 million will be allocated to support schemes like the Infocomm Media Development Authority's Advanced Digital Solutions initiative, which provides up to 70% funding support for businesses adopting advanced digital solutions.

site_title: Budget 2022: Property tax rates for homes to rise from 2023, analysts don't expect demand to dampen
summary: Singapore's property tax rates for owner-occupied and non-owner-occupied residential properties will increase in two steps starting from 2023. Non-owner-occupied properties will see rates rise from 10-20% to 11-27% in 2023 and 12-36% in 2024. Owner-occupied properties will see rates increase for properties above $30,000, with top-end properties facing steeper increases. Analysts expect demand for homes to remain unaffected, citing manageable holding costs and rising property values. The tax increase is expected to raise revenue by $380 million per year.

images.alt_text: Property taxes rates for both owner-occupied and non-owner-occupied residential properties will be revised in 2 steps starting from 2023.

site_title: Budget 2022: S$500m to support businesses and jobs as economy recovers
summary: The Singapore government has allocated S$500 million in its 2022 budget to support businesses and jobs as the economy recovers. The Jobs and Business Support Package includes a grant of S$1,000 per local employee for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in affected sectors, with a cap of S$10,000 per firm. The grant aims to help SMEs in the food and beverage, retail, tourism, and hospitality sectors recover from the impact of Covid-19 restrictions.

site_title: Budget 2022: Minimum salaries for Employment Pass, S-Pass holders to increase from September
summary: The Singapore government is increasing the minimum qualifying salaries for Employment Pass (EP) and S-Pass holders to ensure they are of the right calibre and quality. Starting September 1, 2022, the minimum salary for new EP holders will be S$5,000, and for S-Pass holders, it will be S$3,000, with further increases to S$5,500 for EP holders and S$3,500 for S-Pass holders by 2025. This aims to make EP holders comparable to the top one-third of local professionals and S-Pass holders comparable to the top one-third of local Associate Professionals and Technicians.

site_title: Budget 2022: Additional S$600m to help local companies improve productivity
summary: Singapore has set aside S$600 million over 4 years to support small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) through the Productivity Solutions Grant (PSG) to improve productivity. This is more than double the number of projects supported since 2018. The government will also launch new initiatives, including a Singapore Global Enterprises program and a Singapore Global Executive Programme, to help local companies expand overseas and develop talent. Additionally, the Enterprise Financing Scheme will be enhanced with expanded loan programs to support businesses with financing needs.

site_title: BMW brings new EV to Japan as country warms up to electric cars
summary: BMW has launched its 4-door i4 sports coupe in Japan, priced at 7.5 million yen to 10.8 million yen, with deliveries starting in March. This move comes as Japan's consumers show signs of embracing electric vehicles, with 8,610 imported EVs registered last year, up from 3,238 in 2020. Other major carmakers, including Toyota, Nissan, and Hyundai, are also set to introduce new EV models in Japan this year, further indicating a growing interest in electric cars in the country.

site_title: Budget 2022: Loan assistance for SMEs, construction sector extended by 6 months to a year
summary: Singapore is extending loan assistance programs for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and the construction sector for 6-12 months to support businesses during the current period of high prices. The Temporary Bridging Loan Programme (TBLP) and Enhanced Enterprise Financing Scheme - Trade Loan (EFS-TL) will be extended until September 30, 2022, with revised loan quantum and interest rate caps. The Enterprise Financing Scheme - Project Loan will also be extended to support construction enterprises in fulfilling domestic projects.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end flat amid hopes of easing Ukraine tension
summary: South Korean shares ended flat on Friday, closing 0.02% higher, but posting a second straight weekly loss amid cautious investor sentiment due to Ukraine tension. The Kospi index fell 0.12% for the week, with chip giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix weighing on the index. US Secretary of State Antony Blinken's planned meeting with Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov raised hopes of a Ukraine solution, offsetting concerns about record daily Covid-19 cases.

site_title: 7 things to look out for in Budget 2022
summary: The Singapore Budget 2022 was announced on February 18, 2022. Key highlights include increased support for low- and middle-income households, enhanced healthcare measures, and investments in education and infrastructure. The government aims to boost economic growth while addressing concerns about a worsening pandemic. The budget also allocates funds for sustainable development and financial planning. Overall, the budget is expected to stimulate economic recovery and improve living standards in Singapore.

site_title: Budget 2022: More resources provided to train workers, including mid-career ones
summary: Singapore's Budget 2022 announced measures to support companies in training workers and upskilling individuals. The SkillsFuture Enterprise Credit scheme will be waived for smaller businesses, doubling the number of eligible employers from 40,000 to 80,000. The government will also provide S$100 million to support the National Trades Union Congress in scaling up its Company Training Committees. Additionally, the SGUnited Mid-Career Pathways Programme will offer permanent company attachments for mature mid-career workers, and a new SkillsFuture Career Transition Programme will provide highly-subsidized courses for jobseekers.

site_title: China issues new measures to spur Covid recovery for services sector
summary: China's National Development and Reform Commission has issued new measures to promote a faster recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic in the services sector. The measures include tax incentives for catering, retail, tourism, and aviation industries, as well as lower operating costs for online food delivery platforms. The government will also provide financing support to retail firms for COVID-19 testing and subsidize the tourism industry. Additionally, China will stop collecting value-added tax from airlines for 2022 and continue to support key routes and small airports.

site_title: Indonesia sees first annual current account surplus in a decade
summary: Indonesia recorded its first annual current account surplus in a decade, with a US$3.3 billion surplus in 2021, equivalent to 0.3% of GDP. The surplus was driven by a commodity price boom and strong demand from trade partners. However, the balance of payments narrowed to a US$1.42 billion deficit in the fourth quarter, due to rising imports and freight costs. Analysts predict a return to deficits in 2022, with some forecasting a 2.15% deficit. The surplus is seen as a positive sign for the Indonesian rupiah, which may steady despite global liquidity tightening.

site_title: Budget 2022: S$560m support package to help families with bills, daily essentials
summary: Singapore will roll out a S$560 million support package to help families with daily expenses and rising utility costs. The package includes doubling GST Voucher - U-Save rebates to S$285 for eligible households, and S$100 in Community Development Council (CDC) vouchers for all Singaporean households. The government also provides extra support for education-related expenses, with S$200 top-ups for children under 21. The measures aim to help households tide over the current period of higher prices, driven by global demand and energy price rises.

site_title: G-20 finance leaders to warn of rising inflation, geopolitical risks
summary: Finance leaders from the G-20 major economies are set to warn of rising inflation and geopolitical risks threatening a fragile global recovery. The crisis in Ukraine and the pandemic's fallout will be a major focus, with central banks expected to use all available policy tools to address the pandemic's impacts. The finance chiefs also warn that future policy space will be "narrower and uneven" due to elevated inflation in many countries, caused by supply disruptions, rising commodity and energy costs. The warning comes ahead of a meeting of G-20 finance ministers and central bank governors on Friday.

site_title: Ship carrying 1,100 porsches and many other luxury cars is burning and adrift
summary: A cargo ship, Felicity Ace, carrying 1,100 Porsches and other luxury cars, caught fire and drifted off the coast of the Azores on February 17, 2022. The ship had departed from Germany on February 10 and was scheduled to arrive in Rhode Island. All 22 crew members were rescued by Portuguese forces using a helicopter, with no injuries reported. The ship is now adrift, and its fate remains uncertain.

site_title: Sime Darby Plantation posts Q4 profit, says output to pick up
summary: Malaysia's Sime Darby Plantation reported a Q4 net profit of RM468 million, up from RM149 million last year, driven by rising palm oil prices. Revenue increased 53% to RM5.6 billion. The company expects production to pick up in the second half of the year. This follows a severe labour crunch in Malaysian plantations, exacerbated by pandemic-induced border closures.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's Sime Darby Plantation reported a higher fourth-quarter net profit on Friday (Feb 18), fuelled by rising prices of palm oil, and said it expected production to pick up in the second half of this year.

site_title: Meituan tumbles after China asks delivery platforms to cut fees
summary: Meituan shares plummeted 18% after China's National Development and Reform Commission issued new guidelines requiring food delivery platforms to cut fees for restaurants. The move aims to reduce business costs amid the pandemic. The Hang Seng Tech Index also dropped 3.6%, while the broader Hang Seng Index fell 1.9%. The regulatory crackdown on China's tech sector continues to weigh on investors, with analysts expecting further granular measures this year.

site_title: Credit Suisse banker in cocaine-cash trial says murders dismissed by management
summary: A former Credit Suisse banker testified in a Swiss court that the bank was aware of murders and cocaine smuggling allegedly linked to a Bulgarian gang, but continued to manage cash from the gang, sparking charges of money laundering. The banker claimed that her managers were informed of the events but decided to pursue the business despite concerns. Credit Suisse denies any wrongdoing, citing legitimate businesses operated by the Bulgarian gang, and its managers said they trusted the matter to the bank's legal department. The trial is the first major bank case in Switzerland to focus on money laundering allegations.

site_title: Allianz hedge fund implosion results in 3.7b euro charge
summary: Allianz SE, a German insurance and financial services firm, will take a 3.7 billion euro charge due to the collapse of its Florida-based hedge funds during the 2020 pandemic-fueled market meltdown. The company expects to reach settlements with major investors and is in discussions with the US Securities and Exchange Commission and Department of Justice. Investors lost billions of dollars from the collapse, with some accusing Allianz of abandoning its stated investment mandate and doubling down on risky strategies. The charge overshadowed an otherwise strong quarterly earnings report, with net income rising 38% excluding the charge.

site_title: US challenges Russia to step back from Ukraine attack
summary: The US has challenged Russia to step back from Ukraine, warning that Moscow could order a massive military attack in the "coming days." US Secretary of State Antony Blinken said intelligence suggests Russia is preparing for an assault, despite Moscow's claim to be pulling forces back. The US and Western governments disagree with Russia's demands for a US and NATO pullback from eastern Europe. President Joe Biden warned of a "false flag operation" and called for diplomacy, while Russia threatens military-technical measures if its demands aren't met.

site_title: Cnooc's US$13b oil, gas deals show China's supply fears
summary: China National Offshore Oil Corp (Cnooc) signed US$13 billion deals with international firms to boost oil and gas supply, aiming to avoid a repeat of last year's energy crunch. The deals include contracts to jointly develop oil fields with TotalEnergies and ConocoPhillips, and imports of oil and LNG from Kuwait and US-based Energy Transfer. Cnooc will lift output by up to 40 million barrels this year, mainly from its oil fields in Bohai Bay and the South China Sea. The move is part of China's efforts to curb reliance on pricey imports and meet its long-term energy goals.

site_title: UK retail sales grow faster than expected in January
summary: UK retail sales volumes rose 1.9% in January, surpassing economists' forecasts of a 1.0% monthly rise, and outpacing last year's levels by 9.1% due to the Covid-19 lockdown. This growth indicates a stronger-than-expected UK economy, which may alleviate pressure on policymakers. The news comes as the UK economy shrinks for the second month, a fresh blow to Prime Minister Starmer.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end lower as risks of imminent Ukraine conflict recede
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average ended the day 0.41% lower at 27,122.07, as investors took solace from news of a US-Russia diplomatic meeting suggesting an imminent Ukraine conflict was unlikely. Growth stocks declined 0.45%, while chipmakers and factory robot maker Fanuc fell 2.42% and 5.79% respectively. Energy stocks tumbled 2.26% amid declining oil prices, while shippers and startup investor SoftBank Group rose 1% and 1.31% respectively. The Nikkei booked a 2.07% slide for the week, resuming declines after a 2-week respite.

site_title: UOB's Sydney branch prices A$900m in floating rate notes due 2027
summary: UOB's Sydney branch is issuing A$900 million in floating rate notes due 2027, with a coupon rate of 3-month bank bill swap reference rate plus 0.72% per annum, payable quarterly. The issuance reached an order book of A$1.16 billion, the highest UOB has garnered, and is expected to be rated Aa1 by Moody's, AA- by Standard & Poor's, and AA- by Fitch. This marks the bank's total issuance volume of A$3.6 billion since October 2020, with strong support from domestic and regional investors.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 5.16 points, or 0.3%, to 1,599.86 on Friday, with 86.3 million lots traded. Losers outpaced gainers 167 to 69.

site_title: Tesla changes South Korea ads after antitrust probe faulted batteries
summary: Tesla changed its South Korean advertisement for the Model 3 sedan to accurately reflect its battery specifications after the Korea Fair Trade Commission found the company had exaggerated mileage. The KFTC stated Tesla violated the Act on Fair Labeling and Advertising, but analysts believe the finding will not significantly impact Tesla's sales in the country. The US version of the advertisement still claims the Model 3 can travel up to 358 miles on a single charge.

site_title: China NEV sales drop 18.6% in January after subsidy cut
summary: China's new energy vehicle (NEV) sales dropped 18.6% in January after a 30% subsidy cut, reaching 431,000 units, a 135.8% annual increase. December sales surged 159.5% year-over-year before the subsidy cut, and total automotive sales in China rose 0.9% to 2.53 million vehicles in January. The decline is attributed to the impact of the Covid epidemic and a global chip shortage. Tesla, the only foreign automaker among the top 10 best-selling NEV brands in China, sold 59,845 China-made vehicles in January.

images.alt_text: Sales of new energy vehicles (NEVs) in China fell 18.6 per cent month-on-month in January after the country cut subsidies for NEVs by 30 per cent, industry data showed on Friday (Feb 18).

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower as banks drag amid crisis in Ukraine
summary: Australia's shares closed down 1% on Friday, their worst day in 3 weeks, as investors weighed rising tensions in Ukraine and concerns about a possible Russian invasion. The S&P/ASX 200 index ended at 7,221.7. Financial stocks, particularly banks, were dragged down, with QBE Insurance plummeting 8.7% and Magellan Financial soaring 18.5%. Technology stocks fell 1.9%, while gold stocks rose 1.9% due to the safe-haven appeal of gold.

site_title: China city is first to cut mortgage downpayments, media say
summary: China's city of Heze has become the first to cut mortgage downpayments for homebuyers, lowering the threshold to 20% from 30%. The move aims to boost flagging housing demand, which has been hurt by a worsening slowdown in the property sector. The cut in downpayment ratio is part of a broader effort by Chinese authorities to address the issue, with other municipalities potentially following suit. The move has sent a signal to the market that authorities are making efforts to meet demand from first-time homebuyers, with some analysts predicting further policy easing in the property sector.

site_title: Inflation risks new era of currency tensions for central banks
summary: Central banks are shifting their focus from weakening currencies to appreciating exchange rates to combat inflation, marking a "reverse currency war." A stronger currency can make imports cheaper, cooling prices. Strategists at Goldman Sachs predict a "new paradigm" where policymakers recognize a strong currency as a tool to quell inflation. This shift could favor currencies like the euro, Swedish krona, and Swiss franc, as central banks look to tighten monetary policy and raise interest rates to offset a stronger currency. The trend is particularly important for smaller economies like Poland and Switzerland.

site_title: Temasek-backed Zilingo seeking up to US$200m in funding: sources
summary: Zilingo, a Singapore-based startup backed by Temasek Holdings, is seeking US$150 million to US$200 million in its latest funding round, which could boost its valuation to over US$1 billion. The company, which provides technology to apparel factories and merchants, has reached out to investors to gauge interest. This fundraising round follows other South-east Asian companies, such as ShopBack and Voyager Innovations, in raising funds for expansion. Zilingo's valuation has previously reached US$970 million after its 2019 funding round.

site_title: Asian capital to double investment in London offices in 2022: report
summary: Knight Frank reports that the Asian capital is expected to double its investment in London offices in 2022, with £4.1 billion (39% of all inbound investments) coming from the Asia-Pacific region, primarily from Singapore. Singapore is projected to increase its investment to £1 billion, while Greater China is expected to increase its allocation by 50% to £1.5 billion. The total global capital investment in London offices is forecasted to reach £10.5 billion, with £5.3 billion deals already under-offer, driven by pent-up demand and a broader investor base seeking Grade A offices with sustainability credentials.

site_title: Police warn Canada protesters of 'imminent' action to clear them
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau warned protesters occupying central Ottawa that their actions are a threat to public safety, as police began making arrests to clear them from the capital. The protesters, mostly truckers, have been blocking roads since January 28 to oppose coronavirus mandates, and their actions have inspired anti-government protests in other countries. Police have issued warnings of "imminent" action, and several arrests were made on Thursday, including two main fundraisers and organisers. The protesters, who have been bracing for action, remain defiant, with some saying they will not leave until Trudeau talks to them.

site_title: HSBC shuts floors at main building in Hong Kong and bank branches
summary: HSBC has shut floors at its main office in Hong Kong and some branches due to several staff testing positive for Covid, taking a precautionary measure to safeguard employee and customer health. The bank closed floors BL1, L3, L5, and L6, as well as branches in Tuen Mun and Mei Foo, requiring employees to take virus tests. This move comes as Hong Kong faces its worst Covid wave since the pandemic, with insufficient hospital beds to accommodate over 5,000 new cases daily.

site_title: Stablecoin issuer's SPAC deal value doubles to US$9b
summary: Circle Internet Financial, issuer of USDC stablecoin, has doubled the value of its planned merger with SPAC Concord Acquisition to US$9 billion. The increase is attributed to improved financial outlook and growth in USDC's market share, now valued at over US$52 billion. This is a significant change from the initial US$4.5 billion deal announced in July. The merger will see Circle become a publicly traded company.

site_title: Iceland getting new arctic airline as tourism rebounds
summary: Iceland is set to welcome a new airline, Niceair, which plans to launch flights from Akureyri to the UK, Spain, and Denmark in June. The airline, backed by Iceland's Samherji fishing company, aims to capitalize on rebounding tourism in the region. With sufficient equity funding to sustain operations for at least two years, Niceair plans to offer flights on Airbus A319 aircraft, initially using a partner airline for maintenance and regulatory compliance. This new airline joins a busy air-travel market in Iceland, which is expected to see flying levels surpass 75% of pre-pandemic levels within Europe next month.

site_title: Olympics: China's Gu wins second gold as she wins women's halfpipe
summary: China's Eileen Gu won her second gold medal at the Beijing Olympics, claiming victory in the women's freestyle skiing halfpipe final. Gu dominated the contest with back-to-back 900s, scoring 95.25 in her second run. Canada's Cassie Sharpe took silver with a score of 90.75, while Rachael Karker secured bronze with 87.75. Gu, who switched to compete for China in 2019, was in command from the start and waved to the camera after her win, wiping away a tear.

site_title: Gold clears US$1,900 level as Ukraine standoff intensifies
summary: Gold prices surged to their highest level in 8 months, reaching US$1,902.20 per ounce, amid escalating tensions between Russia and the West over Ukraine. US President Joe Biden's statement that Russia planned to attack Ukraine lifted gold's safe-haven appeal, while lower US bond yields also contributed to the price increase. Spot gold rose 0.3% and US gold futures added 0.1%, setting up a third straight weekly gain.

images.alt_text: Gold prices on Friday (Feb 18) were at their highest since June 2021 as mounting tensions between Russia and the West over Ukraine lifted bullion's safe-haven appeal, buttressed by lower US bond yields.

site_title: Buffett says Berkshire's Activision purchase was 'no bonanza'
summary: Warren Buffett said Berkshire Hathaway's investment in Activision Blizzard was "no bonanza" after acquiring the company for approximately $1.1 billion. Berkshire purchased 14.7 million shares at $77 per share in October and November, with no prior knowledge of Microsoft's $68.7 billion takeover offer. Buffett stated that his investment manager could have bought the shares at a higher price after the merger announcement, and the investment was not a lucrative one for Berkshire. The shares have since fallen below Microsoft's takeover offer.

site_title: Australian M&A lacks big-ticket property deals, veteran banker says
summary: Veteran banker Julian Biggins says Australia's booming market for mergers and acquisitions (M&A) is lacking in big-ticket property deals. Despite a strong deal pipeline, Biggins notes that there are only a handful of large-scale targets in the real estate industry, making big investors hesitant to participate. This limited pipeline is partly due to intense competition for deals, as seen in the recent sale of Blackstone Group's Milestone Logistics warehouse portfolio for A$3.8 billion. Biggins still expects a positive outlook for deals in 2022, with his firm indicating a strong year and favorable comparison to other global markets.

images.alt_text: Australian real estate has been tipped as the next sector to find favour from the country's booming market for mergers and acquisitions (M&A).

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares down at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the day with losses, falling 0.64% to 24,633.66, following a sell-off on Wall Street due to resurgent fears of a possible Russian invasion of Ukraine. The Shanghai Composite Index also dropped 0.47% to 3,451.63.

site_title: Asia: Stocks steady on hopes for diplomacy in Ukraine
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken has agreed to meet with Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov, raising hopes for a diplomatic solution to the Ukraine crisis. The meeting, pending Russia's assurance it will not invade Ukraine, has eased selling pressure in Asian markets. Stocks in Asia, including Tokyo, Hong Kong, and Seoul, have pared losses, while US stock futures jumped 0.5-0.6% on the news. Despite the optimism, risks remain as one of the deepest crises in post-Cold War relations continues to unfold.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at Friday's open; STI down 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.2% at Friday's open, with the Straits Times Index (STI) dropping 8.29 points to 3,433.28. The decline follows overnight US stocks, which dropped due to growing concerns over Russia and Ukraine tensions. The most actively traded securities on Friday morning were Catalist-listed QT Vascular and Mainboard-listed Genting Singapore, with shares rising 25% and 0.6% respectively. Local banks UOB and OCBC fell, while DBS gained 0.2%.

site_title: Hong Kong says 20,000 hotel rooms earmarked for quarantine as Covid cases surge
summary: Hong Kong has identified over 20,000 hotel rooms for quarantine accommodation amid a surge in Covid-19 cases, exceeding the government's original target of 7,000-10,000 rooms. 21 hotels have expressed interest, with Sun Hung Kai Properties and New World Development committing to provide 1,000 and 700 rooms respectively. The move comes as hospital beds are over 90% full and cases have multiplied 60 times this month. Chinese President Xi Jinping's support has given confidence to the Hong Kong people, according to SHKP Chairman Raymond Kwok.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong has identified more than 20,000 hotel rooms for quarantine accommodation, leader Carrie Lam said on Friday (Feb 18), as property developers piled in to support the global financial hub's battle to curb a surge in Covid-19 cases.

site_title: Malaysian markets to brace for consolidation on Fed rate hikes from March: UOBKH
summary: Malaysia's markets are expected to experience consolidation from March due to projected interest rate hikes by the US Federal Reserve, according to UOB Kay Hian. The Fed is expected to raise its policy rate 5 times in 2022, with a 50 basis point hike in March. This is expected to prompt Bank Negara Malaysia to also raise the overnight policy rate twice, each by 25 basis points, in the second and third quarters of 2022.

site_title: Japan's inflation slows toward zero as global price gap grows
summary: Japan's inflation slowed to 0.2% in January, down from 0.5% in the previous month, according to the Ministry of Internal Affairs and Communications. This marks another sign that Japan's price dynamics are at odds with global trends of rapid inflation, prompting speculation about potential policy changes from the Bank of Japan. Despite the slowdown, the central bank remains committed to its stimulus framework and has reiterated its goal of keeping prices below a 2% target. The BOJ chief has repeatedly stated that policy adjustments are not necessary at this time.

site_title: Twitter CEO's paternity leave sparks question of how much is enough
summary: Twitter CEO Parag Agrawal announced plans for a few weeks of paternity leave following the birth of his second child, sparking debate on the amount of leave he should take. Agrawal's company offers 20 weeks of paternity leave, but he won't utilize the full amount. Reddit co-founder Alexis Ohanian urged Agrawal to take more leave, citing the importance of reinforcing to employees that it's safe to take parental leave. Only 23% of US workers have access to paid parental leave, with men taking fewer than 10 days off on average.

images.alt_text: When Twitter head Parag Agrawal said this week that he'll take "a few weeks" off following the birth of his second child, he was praised for breaking a taboo surrounding top executives and paternity leave. Others said his plans don't go far enough.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sasseur Reit, Singapura Finance, Genting Singapore, Challenger, Sing Holdings
summary: Key stocks to watch on Friday, February 18, 2022, include Sasseur Reit, Singapura Finance, Genting Singapore, Challenger, and Sing Holdings. Sasseur Reit's Q4 distribution per unit (DPU) decreased 1.8% to S$0.019, while Singapura Finance reported a 67% increase in net profit to S$4.7 million. Genting Singapore's second-half net profit fell 49% due to lower visitorship, while Challenger's net profit declined 38% to S$8.4 million. Sing Holdings' net profit dropped 24.7% despite higher revenue, with a proposed unchanged final dividend of S$0.01 per share.

site_title: Covid funding is drying up, White House warns US lawmakers
summary: The US government is warning lawmakers that COVID-19 funding is dwindling, with nearly all health-specific resources from the $1.9 trillion American Rescue Plan spent or allocated. The Biden administration is seeking $30 billion in new spending to combat the pandemic, including procuring treatments, vaccines, and sustaining testing capacity. Without additional funding, the US may be caught off-guard if another COVID-19 variant emerges, similar to the Omicron surge last year. Bipartisan consensus is crucial to ensuring the US has enough vaccines, tests, and treatments.

site_title: Air-conditioner maker Daikin readies billions to expand in warmer world
summary: Daikin Industries, the world's largest air conditioner manufacturer, plans to expand its operations and investments to capitalize on growing demand for air conditioning as global temperatures rise. The company has a cash pool of 756 billion yen and is willing to increase its mergers and acquisitions war chest if necessary. Daikin aims to cut its carbon footprint by 30% in 2025 and net zero greenhouse gas emissions by 2050, focusing on more efficient products and innovative technologies. The company sees opportunities in new markets and commercial cold supply chains, and is looking to acquire businesses worth more than 100 billion yen.

site_title: Meta Platforms falls from ranks of 10 most valuable companies
summary: Meta Platforms has fallen out of the world's 10 largest companies by market value, losing over $500 billion in market value since September. The company's stock has declined 46% from last year's record, with a current value of $565 billion, placing it in 11th place. This decline follows a dismal earnings report that revealed stagnating user growth. Tesla has taken Meta's place as the 6th-largest company, with a market value of $906 billion.

site_title: Shake Shack fails to shake off Omicron impact, forecasts dour sales
summary: Shake Shack forecasted first-quarter revenue below estimates due to the Omicron variant, which kept diners away and led to temporary restaurant closures. The company's shares dropped 10% in extended trading. CEO Randy Garutti attributed the decline to factors like office returns, events, and gatherings, which contribute to the chain's best results. Shake Shack also raised prices in October and plans to increase third-party delivery menu prices to protect margins. Same-store sales declined 4% in urban restaurants, but comparable sales at suburban restaurants gained 9%.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower on Ukraine, Wall Street selloff
summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on Friday, February 18, 2022, due to rising tensions over Ukraine and a Wall Street selloff. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index dropped 1.19% to 26,908.23 and the Topix index lost 1.01% to 1,911.74. This follows a decline in US stocks, which was driven by concerns over Ukraine and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: US adds e-commerce sites operated by Tencent, Alibaba to 'notorious markets' list
summary: The US has added e-commerce sites operated by China's Tencent and Alibaba Group to its "notorious markets" list, citing substantial trademark counterfeiting and copyright piracy. The list, released by the US Trade Representative's office, identifies 42 online markets and 35 physical markets that allegedly engage in or facilitate substantial counterfeiting. This marks the first time AliExpress and the WeChat e-commerce ecosystem are included on the list, highlighting significant China-based online markets facilitating trademark counterfeiting.

site_title: Elon Musk, Tesla attack SEC for 'unrelenting' harassment
summary: Tesla and CEO Elon Musk accused the US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) of harassing them with an "unrelenting" investigation over Musk's outspoken criticism of the government. The SEC is scrutinizing Musk's social media posts and Tesla's treatment of workers, including accusations of discrimination. The accusation comes after Tesla received a subpoena from the SEC about its compliance with a 2018 settlement. Musk and Tesla have agreed to pay $20 million in fines and allow lawyers to vet some communications in advance. The SEC has declined to comment on the accusations.

site_title: Shopify stock-price target gutted by analysts on slower growth
summary: Shopify's stock price target was significantly lowered by analysts after the company signaled slower sales growth, following a 17% drop in Toronto and a 57% revenue growth in 2021. The average price target is now at its lowest level since January 2021. Despite this, analysts remain largely positive on the stock, with only 1 sell rating and 27 buy ratings. The company's business surged during the pandemic but has since slowed, with shares tumbling 50% this year and a $100 billion loss in market value.

site_title: Oil slides 2% as Iran talks offset Ukraine crisis
summary: Oil prices fell 2% on Thursday as talks to revive a nuclear deal with Iran entered their final stages, potentially unlocking more crude supplies. The US and Iran are in indirect talks to salvage a 2015 deal limiting Tehran's nuclear activities, which could add 1.3 million barrels per day to the market. However, tensions over a possible Russian invasion of Ukraine continued to support oil markets, limiting losses.

site_title: SIA Engineering opens new S$9m aircraft engine services facility in Singapore
summary: SIA Engineering has opened a new aircraft engine services facility in Singapore, investing S$9 million, to provide maintenance services for French aerospace engine manufacturer Safran Aircraft Engines. The facility, which can perform 60 engine quick turns a year, offers on-site support and borescope inspection for CFM Leap-1A and 1B engines, used on Airbus A320neo and Boeing 737 Max. The new facility aims to increase engine repair network capacity, reduce turnaround time, and minimize aircraft downtime for airlines, supporting SIAEC's growth in engine-related services.

site_title: Europe: Stocks drop as Russia-Ukraine tensions escalate
summary: European stocks dropped 0.7% on Thursday as Russia-Ukraine tensions escalated, with banking and energy shares leading declines. Oil prices dropped and benchmark European bond yields fell, with investors seeking safety in bonds. US President Joe Biden warned of potential Russian invasion, while the Kremlin accused him of stoking tension. Despite some encouraging earnings reports, concerns about inflation and interest rates weighed on markets, with travel stocks particularly affected.

site_title: Chinese fashion firm Shein on Singapore hiring spree
summary: Shein, a Chinese fashion firm, is aggressively expanding its Singapore office after making the city-state its de facto holding company. Founder and CEO Chris Xu has become a permanent resident of Singapore and is reportedly considering changing his citizenship to bypass tougher Chinese rules for offshore IPOs. Shein aims to quadruple its Singapore employees to around 200 by year-end, as part of its growth strategy in the South-east Asian market.

site_title: UBS CEO Hamers plays down bankers' titles to soften hierarchy
summary: UBS CEO Ralph Hamers is reorganizing the bank's hierarchical structure, downplaying bankers' titles to encourage a more flexible work environment. The bank's internal directory now only displays a person's function, such as "head of a trading team" or "investment specialist for wealthy clients." This change aims to promote collaboration and reduce the emphasis on rank, as part of Hamers' efforts to modernize the lender.

site_title: Greenback steadies on Russia-Ukraine worries
summary: The US dollar steadied against a basket of rivals after a report of mortar fire in eastern Ukraine boosted safe haven bets, despite concerns that Russia may attack. The greenback broke a 2-day losing streak, while the Japanese yen and Swiss franc gained. Investors remain wary of the situation, but the dollar's safe haven appeal remains intact. The euro rebounded after falling on the Ukraine news, and the yield curve steepened after the minutes of the Fed's January meeting.

site_title: 18,545 new Covid-19 cases in Singapore, 1,472 patients hospitalised
summary: Singapore reported 18,545 new Covid-19 cases on Feb 17, with 1,472 hospitalised patients, marking the 13th consecutive day with hospitalisation numbers above 1,000. The total number of cases rose by 1,662 from the previous day.

site_title: Baidu, other Chinese tech names may join Hang Seng in reshuffle
summary: Chinese tech giant Baidu and other companies, including Nongfu Spring Co and Genscript Biotech, are among potential additions to the Hang Seng Index, according to Bloomberg Intelligence. The index compiler aims to expand the number of components while reducing financial and property shares. The results are set to be announced Friday, with analysts expecting a reshuffle that could include "new economy" plays. The changes are part of Hang Seng Indexes Co's ongoing review of its benchmark gauge.

site_title: Sasseur Reit posts 1.8% drop in Q4 DPU to S$0.019 after retention
summary: Sasseur Reit posted a 1.8% drop in Q4 DPU to S$0.019, down from a record high of S$0.01935 in the year-ago period, due to retention of S$2.2 million of distributable income. Distributable income rose 8.4% to S$25.3 million, driven by 2.2% increase in rental income. The Reit's gearing level dropped to 26.1% and interest coverage ratio improved to 5.1 times. Despite lower outlet sales due to Covid-19 outbreaks, the Reit's EMA rental income remained 4.1% higher.

site_title: Genting Singapore H2 net profit falls 49% to S$95.1m on lower visitorship
summary: Genting Singapore reported a 49% decline in H2 net profit to S$95.1 million due to lower visitorship amid rising Covid-19 cases and the Omicron variant. Revenue fell 17% to S$512.5 million, with gaming revenue down 16% and non-gaming revenue up 2%. The company plans a $400m expansion, including the addition of Minion Land to Universal Studios Singapore, starting in Q2.

site_title: UK's Johnson names new Brexit minister as trade delays and red tape persist
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson has appointed Jacob Rees-Mogg as the new Brexit minister, aiming to boost the UK economy and trade despite minimal evidence of significant deregulation and economic benefits from Brexit. Rees-Mogg, a prominent Leave campaigner, will focus on "Brexit opportunities and government efficiency." The UK's exit from the EU has led to increased trade costs due to delays and red tape, with non-EU imports now consistently higher than those from EU countries. Johnson's move aims to defy critics and capitalize on the UK's competitive devaluation of the pound since 2016.

site_title: Intel sees sales picking up in coming years as it makes comeback
summary: Intel expects revenue to rise in the low single digits this year, with growth picking up in later years as CEO Pat Gelsinger pursues a turnaround. Sales are predicted to climb by a high-single-digit percentage by 2023 and 2024, surpassing analysts' 1% growth projection. The company is investing in new factories and expanding into new markets, aiming to restore its dominance in the semiconductor business by 2025. Despite struggling to capitalize on booming demand, Intel remains confident in its turnaround plan, with shares expected to recover from a 23% decline in the past year.

images.alt_text: Intel expects revenue to rise by a percentage in the low single digits this year, with growth picking up in later years as chief executive officer Pat Gelsinger pursues a turnaround of the chipmaker.

site_title: Morgan Stanley expects US Fed to hike rates 6 times in 2022
summary: Morgan Stanley predicts the US Federal Reserve will raise interest rates 6 times in 2022, totaling 150 basis points, a faster increase than previously predicted. This follows hotter-than-expected inflation data and market speculation for a 50-basis-point hike. The predicted rate hikes are: 25bps at the end of March, May, June, and July, and 2 hikes in September and December. This marks a significant increase from Morgan Stanley's previous prediction of 125 basis points of policy tightening.

site_title: Trump, children are ordered to testify in NY attorney general probe
summary: A New York judge ordered former US President Donald Trump and his two adult children, Donald Trump Jr and Ivanka Trump, to testify under oath within 21 days in the state attorney general's civil probe into their family company. The probe uncovered "copious evidence of possible financial fraud," and the judge ruled that the attorney general, Letitia James, has the clear right to issue subpoenas. The Trumps must answer questions under oath regarding the probe, which aims to investigate financial dealings and potential wrongdoing.

site_title: Japan eases strict border controls; tourists still banned
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Fumio Kishida announced the easing of strict border controls, allowing 5,000 people to enter daily from March, excluding tourists. The move comes as the number of coronavirus infections declines, and semi-emergency measures in 17 regions will remain until March 6. The government has maintained the measures for 2 years, but critics argue they are obsolete and may hinder Japan's international reputation and ability to attract foreign workers and students.

site_title: Burnt Ends lights up at Dempsey
summary: Burnt Ends, a restaurant at 7 Dempsey Road, has reopened. However, no reopening date or details about the restaurant's reopening are mentioned in the article.

site_title: Singapura Finance H2 profit up 67% to S$4.7m, full year up 101.8%
summary: Singapura Finance reported a 67% increase in second-half net profit to S$4.7 million, with full-year profits rising 101.8% to S$9.6 million. The company attributed the growth to higher net interest income and lower impairment allowances. Earnings per share increased 66.9% in the second half and 102% in the full year. The board recommended a S$0.02 per share dividend, up from S$0.015 in the previous year, and expressed cautious optimism about the domestic operating environment in 2022.

site_title: G-20 warned of Ukraine threat to global recovery
summary: The G-20 nations are warning of a serious threat to the global economy's post-pandemic recovery due to the crisis in Ukraine, where fears of a Russian invasion are growing. Indonesian President Joko Widodo urged the G-20 to focus on collaborating to boost the global economy, rather than creating new tensions. The meeting also discussed reforming global health systems to prepare for future pandemics, with the US calling for urgent action to strengthen the global health architecture and mobilize funding.

site_title: Ex-GIC CIO's low-key Singapore fund amasses US$10b for global foray
summary: Ex-GIC CIO Ng Kok Song has built Avanda Investment Management into a US$10 billion asset management firm, with plans to expand globally. Founded in 2015, Avanda has doubled its assets and is seeking to invest in a wider variety of assets across Asia and the US. Ng, who was GIC's CIO from 2007 to 2013, aims to help investors invest globally and globally investors invest in Asia. He cites Warren Buffett and Charlie Munger as inspirations and believes that age brings better investing skills. Avanda has earned a 7.5% annualized rate of return and is looking to expand into alternative investments such as private equity and real estate.

site_title: Singapore vying for world's top equity gauge with Saudi Arabia
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index has risen 11% this year, rivaling Saudi Arabia's Tadawul All Share Index for the top spot globally. The index is expected to gain a similar magnitude over the next 12 months. The city-state's easing of virus curbs and surge in US Treasury yields have boosted the cyclical-heavy market. Financials make up the largest weighting in the benchmark, contributing to the rally.

site_title: Tennis: Djokovic ready to play 'better than ever'
summary: Novak Djokovic, the world number 1, expressed his readiness to "play better than ever" on the eve of his return to tennis after being deported from Australia. Djokovic aims to participate in big tournaments and the 2024 Paris Olympics, despite vaccination rules potentially conflicting with his stance on receiving the jab. He received supportive messages from fellow players, including Daniil Medvedev and Nick Kyrgios, after his detention in Australia. Djokovic will participate in the ATP 500 tournament in Dubai, where the anti-Covid vaccine is not mandatory.

site_title: Aviation's future intact but its recovery from pandemic will be patchy, players say
summary: Aviation industry players predict a patchy recovery from the pandemic, but a growing demand for freighters and increasing passenger traffic in Asia-Pacific are positive trends. Airbus forecasts 17,620 planes needed in the region over 20 years, with 55% of the world's population residing in Asia-Pacific. Industry players, including Pratt & Whitney and Airbus, expect recovery to take place between 2023 and 2025. However, analysts like Shukor Yusof and Mabel Kwan caution that the industry will need to adapt to changing business travel patterns and rising costs, with some predicting a "tepid recuperation" and wage inflation.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims unexpectedly rise
summary: US weekly jobless claims unexpectedly rose to 248,000 for the week ended Feb 12, exceeding economists' forecast of 219,000. Despite this, claims remain at levels associated with a tightening labor market, driven by an acute shortage of workers with 10.9 million job openings at the end of December. The labor market is expected to continue tightening, contributing to strong wage growth and high inflation, prompting the Federal Reserve to consider raising interest rates in March.

site_title: US: Stocks slide as heightened Ukraine tensions weigh
summary: US stocks slid on Thursday, with the S&P 500 experiencing its largest daily percentage drop in 2 weeks due to heightened Ukraine tensions and investors shifting to defensive sectors. US President Joe Biden warned of Russia's potential invasion, while Russia accused him of stoking tensions. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 1.78%, the S&P 500 lost 2.12%, and the Nasdaq Composite declined 2.88%. Safe-haven assets like gold rose, and some stocks, such as DoorDash and Hasbro, gained, while others, like Nvidia and Albemarle, plummeted.

site_title: Cathay flies only 797 passengers a day as Covid squeeze persists
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways expects to operate at 2% of pre-pandemic passenger capacity until Hong Kong lifts COVID-19 restrictions. The airline carried 24,699 passengers in January, down 99.2% from 2019, with an average daily load factor of 40%. Cathay's chief customer and commercial officer, Ronald Lam, attributed the decline to the ongoing pandemic and strict quarantine requirements for local aircrew. Rivals like Singapore Airlines are recovering faster, with January capacity nearing 50% of pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: Mortgage rates in US soar to 3.92%, highest since May 2019
summary: US mortgage rates surged to 3.92%, the highest since May 2019, according to Freddie Mac. This marks the second straight increase in borrowing costs, driven by rising yields for 10-year Treasuries. The Federal Reserve is considering rate hikes to combat 40-year-high inflation. Mortgage costs are over a full percentage point higher than a year ago, adding to the burden for Americans struggling to afford home purchases.

site_title: Sing Holdings net profit in H2 declines 24.7% to S$6.7m
summary: Sing Holdings reported a 24.7% decline in net profit for its second half to S$6.7m, despite a 5.4% rise in revenue to S$66.5m. Gross profit fell 20.2% to S$14.7m due to higher cost of sales. The company proposed a final dividend of S$0.01 per share, unchanged from the previous year. For the full year, net profit fell 40.6% to S$9.8m, and revenue declined 29.7% to S$121.7m. The company remains cautiously optimistic about its development properties, citing improving trends in Melbourne.

site_title: Goldman Sachs lifts key profit target in strategy update
summary: Goldman Sachs has upgraded its key profitability target and set new goals for its asset management, transaction banking, and consumer businesses for the next 3 years. The bank is reshaping itself after a turbulent decade, citing progress over the past 2 years. Despite headwinds like inflation and a slowdown in investment banking and trading activity, CEO David Solomon plans to build on that progress. The bank's new strategy aims to navigate the challenges and capitalize on opportunities in the changing financial landscape.

site_title: Singapore exports to post more modest growth after decade high
summary: Singapore's export growth is expected to moderate this year, after a decade-high growth in 2021. Despite a high base effect, the world economy faces downgrades to its growth outlook due to the Omicron strain of the novel coronavirus. However, Enterprise Singapore (ESG) maintains its forecast for non-oil domestic exports (NODX) to rise by 0-2% year-on-year in 2022, driven by rising selling and export prices for semiconductors and petrochemicals. Analysts expect NODX to range from 2-8% in 2022, with some predicting a modest 2% growth.

site_title: US housing starts fall in January amid freezing weather; permits surge
summary: US housing starts fell 4.1% in January to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.638 million units, amid freezing temperatures. Permits surged 0.7% to a record high of 1.899 million units, suggesting a rebound in the coming months. Single-family housing starts dropped 5.6% and single-family building permits rose 6.8%. The shortage of homes on the market and rising mortgage rates are expected to keep builders busy, despite challenges from soaring construction costs and production bottlenecks.

site_title: Hospitals under siege show Hong Kong squandered Covid edge
summary: Hong Kong's Covid Zero strategy, which involved mandatory hospitalization of all Covid-19 cases, has collapsed due to the highly-transmissible Omicron variant, overwhelming hospitals and health infrastructure. The city has seen its worst outbreak yet, with over 6,000 cases logged, and elderly patients are being left on gurneys in the street due to lack of space. The government's failure to prepare for the virus's infiltration and lack of a Plan B have left officials scrambling to cobble together measures to control the outbreak. Experts blame complacency and a failure to recognize the crisis, leading to preventable fatalities.

images.alt_text: Ting Chan has seen Hong Kong's pandemic situation lurch from over-the-top caution to outright chaos. A nurse at one of the city's public hospitals, she's been a ground-level participant in the strict Covid Zero strategy that has kept the financial hub largely free of the virus for the past 2 years.

site_title: Custodians of Malay heritage
summary: Malaysian researcher Khir Johari has released a 624-page book, "The Food of Singapore Malays: Gastronomic Travels Through the Archipelago," detailing the history and cultural significance of Malay cuisine in Singapore and beyond. The book, 11 years in the making, explores connections to Malaysia, Indonesia, and other parts of the Malay Archipelago. Johari's research took him to various institutions and involved traveling to remote islands to document rare tools and techniques used in traditional cooking. The book features over 400 photographs and 32 recipes, with hundreds of contributors from Singapore, Malaysia, and Indonesia.

site_title: Temasek joins investors in J&T Express US$2b funding round
summary: J&T Express, a logistics company, raised US$2 billion in a funding round led by Temasek Holdings, valuing the company at US$20 billion. Existing investors Hillhouse Capital, Boyu Capital, and Sequoia Capital China also participated, while new investors included the Chinese arm of Susquehanna International Group and Hidden Hill Capital. The funds will be used to expand the company's global delivery network, digitize its warehouse centers, and support cross-border businesses. J&T Express is considering a Hong Kong initial public offering, which could raise about US$1 billion.

site_title: Custodians of Malay heritage
summary: Malaysian food expert Khir Johari has released a 624-page book, "The Food of Singapore Malays: Gastronomic Travels Through the Archipelago," which explores the history and culture of Malay cuisine in Singapore, Malaysia, and Indonesia. The book took 11 years to complete and features over 400 photographs and 32 recipes. Johari, who was influenced by his upbringing in a multicultural neighborhood, traveled extensively to research and gather information, including rare tools and ingredients. The book aims to preserve traditional Malay cuisine and promote cultural understanding, with Johari dedicating it to the next generation of cooks.

site_title: Adidas says will grow in China in 2022
summary: German sportswear company Adidas expects to grow in China in 2022 despite pandemic restrictions and consumer boycotts of Western brands. The company reported a 15% fall in third-quarter sales in Greater China but stated it will still grow in 2022. Adidas has launched an action plan to revive its fortunes in China, including a dedicated studio for marketing and product creation specifically for the Chinese market. The company's sales chief had traveled to China in January to assess the situation, contrasting with rival Nike's 20% revenue fall in Greater China.

site_title: Nvidia underwhelms in first results since scrapping Arm deal
summary: Nvidia released its first quarterly results since scrapping its $40 billion acquisition of Arm, topping Wall Street estimates with $7.64 billion in sales and $1.32 per share in earnings. However, the company's shares fell 3% in pre-market trading due to high investor expectations. Despite strong growth, Nvidia faced weak spots, including lower-than-expected auto chip sales and supply constraints in its data-centre business. CEO Jensen Huang acknowledged the challenges but remains confident in the company's fundamental prospects and plans to increase Arm-based processor production.

site_title: Challenger H2 profit falls 38%, but proposes higher final dividend
summary: Challenger Tech reported a 38% decline in net profit to S$8.4 million for its second half, driven by reduced Covid-19 related government support and higher operating expenses. Revenue fell 3% to S$147.4 million. Despite this, the company proposes a higher final dividend of S$0.028 per share, up from S$0.027 last year. Challenger attributed the lower profit to the challenging retail sector amidst evolving Covid-19 uncertainty.

site_title: UAE readies national crypto licensing in push to embrace fintech
summary: The United Arab Emirates (UAE) is set to issue federal licenses for virtual asset service providers (VASPs) by the end of the first quarter, aiming to attract major crypto companies like Binance Holdings. The country is creating a hybrid regulatory framework, combining government oversight with input from the central bank. The move aims to balance a business-friendly environment with concerns over volatility and financial crime, while also preparing for potential FATF grey list inclusion.

site_title: Climate finance in S-E Asia lacking as Covid-19 stalls funding
summary: South-east Asia is struggling to secure the necessary funding to combat climate change due to the stalled US$100 billion annual climate finance pledge made by developed countries by 2020. A report by ISEAS-Yusof Ishak Institute calls for increased cooperation on climate financing to address the issue. The pandemic has hindered progress, and researchers urge governments to work together to build trust and provide adaptation aid to vulnerable nations.

site_title: StanChart bets on rate hikes to achieve lofty goals as full-year profit disappoints
summary: Standard Chartered has raised its core profitability goals and promised shareholders extra payouts, despite full-year profit undershooting expectations. The bank expects revenue to grow by 3% per year due to rising interest rates, aiming to hit double-digit returns by 2024. Analysts are doubtful the bank can meet its new targets, given its track record of undershooting in the past. StanChart's shares fell 4% after the announcement, and the bank also announced a $750 million share buyback and a 12 cents per share dividend for 2021.

site_title: More brew and less buzz, with low-alcohol beers
summary: Low-alcohol beers are gaining popularity, with breweries creating beers with 2-4% ABV, a range considered moderate-strength. The trend is driven by consumers seeking a lower-alcohol option without sacrificing flavor. Breweries are experimenting with different ingredients and brewing techniques to achieve this balance. Examples of low-alcohol beers include Hermit Thrush Brewery's Party Guy (3% ABV) and Wild East Brewing's Temperance (3.5% ABV). The growing demand for low-alcohol beers is expected to continue as the US craft brewing industry matures and consumers' drinking habits change.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.82 points to 1,605.02, closing higher on Thursday. The index saw a gain in volume, with 3.910 billion lots worth RM3.338 billion. Gainers outpaced losers 515 to 423.

site_title: Japan eases virus border rules for workers, students
summary: Japan is easing its virus border rules, allowing students and businesspeople to enter the country starting March 1, with a cap of 5,000 daily entrants. Tourists will still be barred. The move comes after Japan's Omicron-driven spike in infections has peaked, and follows pressure from the business community and academics to loosen border restrictions. Quarantine requirements will be eased for those who test negative, and removed for those with 3 vaccine doses from low-risk countries.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore maintained its 2022 export forecast despite downgraded international economic growth forecasts. Shell became the first supplier of sustainable aviation fuel in Singapore, and the country's property market is facing rising inflation and interest rates as the top risk factor. The STI index rose 0.1% on Thursday amid economic growth and simplified Covid-19 measures. Meanwhile, Citi moved senior equities staff from Hong Kong to Singapore and other markets due to the Chinese territory's zero-Covid approach.

site_title: Bungalow with masculine appeal
summary: A Singaporean bungalow designed by Carl Lim of Czarl Architecture stands out for its unique blend of Brutalist architecture and tropical climate. The 2-storey house on a sloping land was inspired by the design of the late President Ong Teng Cheong's first home, where it sits. The clients, a doctor and retiree, sought a "masculine home" with plenty of garden space, which Lim achieved with a cube-like structure, angular shapes, and minimalist design. The house features a basement, attic, and infinity pool, with courtyards and passageways connecting individual units, creating a unique and functional living space.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close higher
summary: Hong Kong stocks closed higher on Thursday, with the Hang Seng Index rising 0.30% to 24,792.77, driven by minutes from the Federal Reserve's latest meeting not providing any negative surprises. Despite Ukraine tensions weighing on sentiment, investors remained positive. In other markets, the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also saw gains.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks ended with gains on Thursday (Feb 17) as minutes from the Federal Reserve's latest meeting did not provide any negative surprises but Ukraine tensions continued to weigh on sentiment.

site_title: Voluntary offer for Roxy-Pacific Holdings closes with 98.16% acceptances
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings' voluntary offer for privatization closed with 98.16% acceptances, exceeding the 90% threshold required for compulsory acquisition. The offeror, controlled by Teo Hong Lim, valued the company at S$630.5 million. Trading will be suspended as the company's free float requirement is no longer met, and it will be delisted from the Singapore Exchange upon completion of the acquisition. The offeror will acquire dissenting shareholders at the offer price of S$0.485 per share.

site_title: London: Oil, banking stocks drag FTSE 100 lower as Ukraine tensions weigh
summary: The FTSE 100 index declined 0.7% on Thursday due to oil and banking stocks falling amid Ukraine tensions. Weaker crude prices, following reports of a potential nuclear deal between Iran and world powers, negatively impacted energy stocks. Banking stocks also fell, with Standard Chartered missing profit expectations. Despite this, the FTSE 100 has fared better than pan-European indices due to stronger energy prices, which have helped commodity-heavy stocks.

site_title: Genting Singapore H2 profit falls 49%; details of RWS expansion unveiled
summary: Genting Singapore reported a 49% decline in second-half net profit to S$95.1 million, due to lower visitorship amid rising community Covid-19 cases. Revenue fell 17% to S$512.5 million. The decline was attributed to the increase in Covid-19 cases and the emergence of the Omicron variant.

site_title: Sing Holdings H2 net profit falls 24.7%, maintains final dividend
summary: Sing Holdings reported a 24.7% decline in second-half net profit to S$6.7 million, despite a 5.4% increase in revenue to S$66.5 million. Gross profit fell 20.2% due to higher cost of sales. The company maintains its final dividend of S$0.01 per share. The group's full-year net profit was down 40.6% to S$9.8 million, and revenue fell 29.7% to S$121.7 million. Construction on an executive condominium project in Singapore is expected to be launched by April.

site_title: Singapore poised for further recovery in 2022 amid external headwinds, inflation
summary: Singapore's economy is poised for further recovery in 2022, driven by the manufacturing, finance, and insurance sectors, despite external headwinds. The country's GDP growth in 2021 was 7.6%, beating expectations, and economists forecast 3-5% growth for 2022, with some predicting higher growth rates. The Omicron variant and rising energy prices pose risks, but the expansion of Vaccinated Travel Lanes and easing of Covid-19 restrictions could boost consumer-facing sectors. Inflation is also a concern, with core inflation reaching 2.1% in December.

site_title: US: Wall St slips at open as Ukraine tensions mount
summary: US stocks opened lower on February 17 as escalating Ukraine tensions and disappointing earnings weighed on investors. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.22% to 34,858.47, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.42% and 0.85% respectively. Tensions between the West and Russia surrounding Ukraine have unnerved investors, with some fearing potential economic disruptions. The decline in US stocks follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks, which notched a gain ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Cathay Pacific flies only 797 passengers a day as Covid squeeze persists
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways operates at 2% of pre-pandemic passenger capacity, carrying 797 passengers per day, as Hong Kong battles a rapidly worsening Covid-19 outbreak. The airline expects this level of capacity to persist due to strict virus restrictions. Cathay's January passenger capacity was 99.2% lower than 2019, with load factor at 40%. The airline faces challenges from rivals like Singapore Airlines, which has seen a significant recovery, and cargo operations continue to be impacted by quarantine measures.

site_title: Dovish RBI inflation view pushes back India tightening calls
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) governor Shaktikanta Das lowered inflation and growth forecasts, prompting economists to revise their interest rate hike predictions. Citigroup now expects the RBI to raise interest rates no earlier than October, while HSBC has shifted its prediction to July-September. Barclays still predicts an August hike. Some economists warn that the delay may be risky, while others believe India's strong winter harvest will insulate it from global food price pressures.

site_title: Pimco downgrades Chinese sovereign debt to neutral
summary: Pimco has downgraded its recommendation on Chinese sovereign debt to neutral from overweight, citing policy divergence with the US and diminishing yield advantage. The investment giant previously held an overweight call on the securities for most of 2021. China's slowing inflation gives its central bank more room to ease monetary policy, but foreign institutional investors are already declining their purchases of Chinese debt. Analysts expect more monetary easing and see potential buying opportunities in the medium term, with yields predicted to fall to 2.2-2.5%.

site_title: Singapore exports to post more modest growth in 2022 after cresting a decade high
summary: Singapore's export growth is expected to moderate in 2022, after reaching a decade high in 2021. The country's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) are forecast to rise by 0-2% year on year, driven by higher selling and export prices for semiconductors and petrochemicals. Despite global economic headwinds, including a downgrade in the International Monetary Fund's outlook, the outlook remains positive, with economists predicting growth of 2-8% for NODX in 2022.

site_title: STI gains 0.1 per cent on Thursday amid economic growth, simpler Covid measures
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.1% to 3,441.57 on Thursday, its highest since June 2018, amid plans to ease Covid-19 measures and better economic numbers. The government is simplifying some Covid-19 rules and opening travel lanes with more countries, boosting investor confidence. The Singapore economy grew 7.6% in 2021, higher than an earlier estimate. Shares of Sembcorp Industries surged 3.6% to close as the top STI gainer, while Venture Corp fell 1.7%.

site_title: Classical Malay opera enjoys a resurgence
summary: Malay classical opera, bangsawan, is experiencing a resurgence in Singapore. Noor Azhar Mohamed revived the Anggerik Temasek Bangsawan troupe in 2019, which has since attracted new audiences and secured funding for its first festival. The troupe's shows now play to full houses, with audiences from all races and ages. Social media has played a key role in promoting bangsawan, with the troupe posting photos and videos on Facebook, YouTube, and Instagram. This revival is seen as a positive step, with the troupe encouraging young people to pursue the classical art form.

site_title: Europe: Shares little changed
summary: European shares remained flat on Thursday amid concerns over the Ukraine-Russia border, but received support from upbeat earnings updates from Kering and Reckitt. However, some stocks, such as Sinch and Standard Chartered, fell 9% and 3% respectively. Nestle was little changed despite defending its margins against cost pressures. The Stoxx 600 index was last flat on the day, marking choppy trading.

site_title: Gucci powers forecast-beating revenue growth at Kering
summary: Kering reported a 32% revenue increase in its fourth quarter, beating expectations, driven by Gucci's 17% surge. Gucci accounts for 60% of Kering's revenues and 70% of its profits, with marketing investments and the 100th anniversary promotion events contributing to its strong comeback. Kering's other brands, including Yves Saint Laurent, also performed well. The company's finance chief expressed confidence in improving profitability despite an inflationary environment and plans to pursue organic growth and potential acquisitions.

site_title: Firms' energy costs to continue upwards spiral in 2022; utilities main cost component to have risen in 2021
summary: Singapore manufacturers' utilities costs rose 0.9 points in 2021, contributing to a 3.3% decrease in manufacturing unit business cost (UBC). The increase was largely offset by declines in royalties and other expenses. Utilities costs surged due to a 179% year-over-year increase in wholesale electricity prices. In contrast, services UBC rose 1.5% in the first 9 months of 2021, driven by higher labour expenses. The overall unit labour cost (ULC) increased by 4.2% in 2021, with utilities, fuel, and transport costs expected to rise further in 2022 due to higher global oil prices.

site_title: Yellen urges G-20 to back global pandemic prevention fund
summary: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen urged G-20 members to support a proposed $75 billion global pandemic prevention fund, warning that failure to do so could lead to "devastating" costs. The fund, to be hosted at the World Bank, aims to reduce global vulnerabilities to future pandemics by investing in disease detection, research, and healthcare workforce development.
