Yellen sought to address concerns that the fund would divert resources from the World Health Organization, and emphasized its flexibility to mobilize additional resources from non-government sources.

site_title: Crisis in Eastern Europe may re-pivot America back to the Atlantic
summary: The US foreign policy establishment is re-evaluating its strategy due to a series of crises in Eastern Europe, potentially shifting focus back to the Atlantic. Despite the initial intention to pivot to Asia, the US has been stuck in the Middle East due to ongoing conflicts and military interventions. The continued involvement in the Middle East has allowed China to expand its economy and strengthen its military. Meanwhile, the US has been neglecting its alliances in Europe, including NATO, which has continued to expand despite earlier assurances not to target Russia. This shift may lead to a renewed Cold War with Russia, rather than a confrontation with China.

site_title: How Budget 2022 can help the tourism and entertainment sectors
summary: Singapore's tourism and entertainment sectors continue to struggle due to the ongoing Covid-19 pandemic. The government has provided significant support in previous budgets, but industry players are calling for an extension of the Job Support Scheme and Rental Support Scheme to aid in their recovery. The upcoming Budget 2022 is expected to focus on targeted actions rather than large-scale sector relief, with potential measures including tax credits for training expenditure and incentives for capacity building and innovation. The sectors' recovery will depend on factors such as the return of paying customers and the easing of restrictions, including the Goods and Services Tax.

site_title: Japan cuts economic assessment in Feb report as Omicron hits consumption
summary: Japan's economy has been downgraded in its February report for the first time in 5 months due to the Omicron variant's impact on consumption. The government expects a near-zero or contractionary growth in the current quarter, downgrading its private consumption forecast for the first time since September. Covid-19 curbs and disruptions to service consumption have led to this assessment, despite a solid annualised 5.4% gain in the previous quarter. The government also downgraded its assessment of housing construction and tweaked its view on wholesale inflation.

site_title: Tourists returning to Thailand find closed bars, empty streets
summary: Thailand's tourism industry is struggling to recover from the COVID-19 pandemic, with most businesses in the Patpong area of Bangkok closed due to the lack of foreign tourists. The government has relaxed travel restrictions, allowing vaccinated travelers to enter quarantine-free, but the industry is expected to take at least until 2024 to return to pre-pandemic levels. The tourism sector faces labor shortages, high costs, and limited demand, making it challenging for small businesses to reopen. The government is exploring bilateral travel bubbles with neighboring countries to attract tourists, but the industry's recovery will depend on the cooperation of travelers and the spread of COVID-19.

site_title: Knight Frank launches Vietnam arm with focus on commercial real estate
summary: Knight Frank has launched a joint venture in Vietnam to provide commercial real estate services, including brokerage and consultancy. The entity, led by managing director Alex Crane, aims to work with local and foreign clients in Ho Chi Minh City and Hanoi. Vietnam's real estate market is experiencing rapid growth, driven by foreign investment and a strategic position in global supply chains. The consultancy expects to capitalize on this growth, with prime residential real estate prices increasing 19% year-over-year to $2,800 per square meter.

site_title: Philippine central bank keeps rate steady, sees risks to growth outlook
summary: The Philippine central bank kept key interest rates unchanged for the 10th consecutive meeting, maintaining its accommodative policy stance to support the domestic economy's recovery. The rates remained at 2%, 1.5%, and 2.5% for the overnight reverse repurchase facility, overnight deposit, and lending facilities, respectively. The BSP expects inflation to remain manageable and will wait until the end of the year to raise interest rates, aiming for 7-9% GDP growth this year and 6-7% in 2023 and 2024.

site_title: Nestle posts higher 2021 profit, sales as prices hiked
summary: Swiss food giant Nestle reported a 38.2% increase in net profit to 16.9 billion Swiss francs in 2021, driven by higher sales and price hikes amid global inflation. Total sales rose 3.3% to 87.1 billion francs, with organic growth reaching 7.5%. The company's coffee and pet food businesses performed well, while sales in vegetarian and plant-based food grew at a double-digit rate. CEO Mark Schneider attributed the results to the company's focus on growth investments and cost management despite global supply chain challenges.

site_title: Pizza Hut International president Vipul Chawla to lead FairPrice group from April
summary: FairPrice Group has appointed Vipul Chawla as group CEO, replacing Seah Kian Peng, who will become deputy chairman. Chawla, currently Pizza Hut International president, joins from Yum! Brands on April 5. Seah will step down as CEO but remain chairman of FairPrice Foundation. Chawla brings international experience, having worked in over 110 countries and 215,000 team members. His relocation from Dallas, US, is expected to help FPG build an omnichannel business with superior customer experience.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares close lower on Ukraine jitters
summary: Japanese shares fell on Thursday, February 17, 2022, due to concerns over Ukraine and rising interest rates. The Nikkei share average lost 0.83% to close at 27,232.87, while the Topix slipped 0.79%. Investors sold stocks amid uncertainty in the Ukraine situation and worries about global inflation. Staffing agency Recruit Holdings led the decline, followed by Fast Retailing and SoftBank Group. However, shares of companies that would benefit from a reopening, such as railways and airlines, rose slightly.

site_title: Britain says Russia's Putin could drag out Ukraine crisis for months
summary: Britain's Foreign Secretary Liz Truss warns that Russian President Vladimir Putin may prolong the Ukraine crisis for months to challenge Western unity, despite no evidence of Russian troop withdrawal. The Russian military build-up shows no signs of slowing, indicating a brazen attempt to subvert Ukraine and test Western resolve.

site_title: New to art collecting? Join the Club
summary: Victor Chia, Lourdes Samson, and Charmaine Wai, founding members of One Piece Club Singapore, aim to help new art collectors navigate the art scene through a non-profit club that welcomes collectors willing to purchase at least one contemporary artwork a year. The club, modeled after the Japanese concept, holds public exhibitions of member artworks and organizes trips to galleries and artist studios to educate and engage members. With no membership fee, the club seeks to create a safe space for collectors to develop their tastes and opinions without commercial pressure.

images.alt_text: Victor Chia (left) and Lourdes Samson, two of the founding members of One Piece Club Singapore, posing with a work by emerging artist Kayleigh Goh at the club's inaugural exhibition.

site_title: Exhibition mines the rich history of the Malay archipelago
summary: A new exhibition at the Malay Heritage Centre in Singapore explores the rich history of the Malay archipelago, showcasing objects and artworks from Indonesia, Malaysia, Brunei, and Singapore. The exhibition, titled "Cerita" (Stories), includes a 1842 painting by Raden Saleh that symbolizes Indonesian nationalism, as well as ancient tin ingots, traditional dance costumes, and a circumcision chair. The show aims to connect the past with the present, featuring contemporary objects and works that spark conversations about the complex history of the region. The exhibition runs until July 31, 2022.

images.alt_text: Muhd Noor Aliff, senior manager of Collections & Exhibitions at Heritage Institutions, using a luxmeter to measure the light intensity on a spice container with five drawers. Called a botekan, the carved and gilded wooden structure is on show at the Malay Heritage Centre's Cerita exhibition.
A circumcision chair, on which a young boy would sit after his circumcision ceremony and be treated like royalty for a day, following an ancient custom.

This is a costume from the Tari Golek Menak (Dance of the Rod Puppet) on display at the Malay Heritage Centre's exhibition. Hailing from Yogyakarta, the dance first appeared in the early 40s, inspired by Wayang Golek Menak (rod puppet theatre).

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: SIA Engineering has agreed to acquire a 75% stake in SR Technics Malaysia for $3.75 million, forming an MRO joint venture. The deal complements SIA Engineering's existing services and fleet management programs. Meanwhile, Chip Eng Seng reported a net profit of $99,000 in H1 and reduced its H2 net loss to $31.6 million from $56.7 million in the same period last year.

site_title: Asia: Most markets up as traders eye Ukraine, Fed eases rate fears
summary: Asian markets mostly rose on Thursday as investors assessed the situation in Ukraine after Russia's troop withdrawal claims, easing concerns about a sharp rate hike by the Federal Reserve. Oil prices tumbled as Iran nuclear talks progressed, with Tehran's top negotiator stating an agreement was "closer than ever." Despite US skepticism, the Kremlin's conciliatory tone provided a lift to markets, while global equities were buoyed by the Fed minutes, which showed no surprise about rate hikes in March and a balance sheet runoff.

site_title: Amazon reaches agreement with Visa on payment fees
summary: Amazon has reached an agreement with Visa on payment fees, allowing customers in Singapore and Australia to use Visa cards without an extra fee. The agreement also ensures that Visa credit cards will not be turned off on Amazon's UK site. The deal marks a reversal of Amazon's previous threat to stop accepting Visa cards in the UK. The companies will collaborate on new payment initiatives to enhance customer experiences.

site_title: Temasek-backed Zilingo seeking US$200m in funding: sources
summary: Zilingo, a Singapore-based startup backed by Temasek Holdings, is seeking $150 million to $200 million in funding to boost its valuation to over $1 billion. The company, which provides technology to apparel factories and merchants, is working with Goldman Sachs Group on the fundraising deal. This comes as other South-east Asian companies, such as ShopBack and Voyager Innovations, also seek funding to expand their operations. Zilingo was valued at $970 million in 2019 after raising $226 million from investors, and its CEO has mentioned going public as an option to raise capital.

site_title: SGX RegCo reports Tee International for late disclosure of claims
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has reported Tee International to relevant authorities for potential offences under the Securities and Futures Act, citing the company's late disclosure of 121 letters of demand and overdue trade-related payables worth around S$38.8 million. SGX RegCo is investigating Tee International for potential listing rule breaches, as the claims were material information that would impact the company's ability to operate as a going concern. The company had announced the claims in June 2021, but claimed they were not material at the time.

site_title: Updates from Singapore Budget 2022
summary: Singapore Budget 2022 updates include no new information, as the article appears to be outdated. However, recent news includes Malaysia's intention to seize RM3 billion of Daim Zainuddin's assets, China's GDP growth expected to slow, and Citigroup predicting a 1,150 target for MSCI's global equity index by mid-2026. Additionally, Thai Prime Minister Thaksin is confident his daughter will be cleared in an ethics case, while the UK economy shrinks for a second month, and South Korea seeks a 'landing zone' in US trade talks. Malaysia's May industrial production rose 0.3%.

site_title: Shell supplies first sustainable aviation fuel to Singapore customers
summary: Shell has become the first supplier of sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) in Singapore, supplying the first batch to SIA Engineering Company and the Republic of Singapore Air Force. The SAF is made from waste products and sustainable feedstocks, reducing lifecycle emissions by up to 80% compared to conventional fuel. Shell plans to blend the fuel at its Singapore facility and establish a regional supply chain for SAF in Asia. This move aims to tackle the 3% of global carbon emissions attributed to aviation.

site_title: Sotheby's tips largest blue diamond at Hong Kong auction to fetch US$48m
summary: Sotheby's is set to auction the largest internally flawless step-cut vivid blue diamond, the 15.10-carat De Beers Cullinan Blue, in Hong Kong in April. The diamond is expected to fetch over US$48 million, surpassing the record price of the Oppenheimer Blue at US$57.5 million. The Cullinan Blue was cut from a rough stone discovered in South Africa in 2021 and is bigger than the Enigma, the largest cut diamond ever to come to auction at 555.55 carats. The sale will mark the first time a blue diamond over 15 carats has gone under the hammer.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks pare early gains on Ukraine tensions but end higher
summary: South Korea's benchmark Kospi index closed 0.53% higher at 2,744.09, despite reports of mortar fire in eastern Ukraine triggering a risk-off sentiment. The Korean won remained nearly unchanged, while the bond yield fell. Foreigners bought 648.7 billion won worth of shares, and chip giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix rose, while LG Energy Solution slid. The US Federal Reserve's rate-tightening campaign concerns took a step back after policy meeting minutes suggested a more measured approach.

site_title: Airbus posts sharply higher core profit and restarts dividend
summary: Airbus reported a record net profit of €4.2 billion in 2021, with core operating profit tripling to €4.9 billion, driven by a partial recovery in jet deliveries and higher defense and helicopter earnings. The company restarted its dividend after a 2-year hiatus and proposed a €1.5 share payout. Airbus predicts 720 plane deliveries and a core profit of €5.5 billion for 2022, with adjusted operating profit and revenues expected to continue growing.

site_title: JGB yield curve steepens; BOJ intervention caps 10-year yield gains
summary: Japan's 30-year government bond yield surged 5.5 basis points to 0.985%, its highest since 2016, while 20-year and 40-year yields also rose to fresh highs. The steepening yield curve is attributed to super-long tenors tracking US peers. The Bank of Japan's potential intervention to curb rising borrowing costs was cautious, capping gains in benchmark 10-year bond yields. The 10-year JGB yield rose 2.5 basis points to 0.535%, but stopped short of further gains.

site_title: Chinese fashion firm Shein on Singapore hiring spree after founder becomes PR
summary: Chinese fashion firm Shein is expanding its Singapore office after its founder, Chris Xu, became a permanent resident of the city-state. Shein, valued at around $50 billion, has made Singapore its de facto holding company and is hiring 200 new employees, aiming to quadruple its current staff in the city. The move is seen as part of Shein's plans to list in New York and bypass tougher Chinese rules for offshore IPOs, with Xu reportedly considering a change in citizenship to achieve this.

site_title: 7 things to look out for in Budget 2022
summary: Finance Minister Lawrence Wong will deliver Singapore's Budget 2022 on Feb 18, marking his maiden Budget. Key highlights include a potential GST hike from 7% to 9% by July, property-related 'wealth taxes', a revised carbon tax rate of $10-15 per tonne, and continued support for ailing sectors such as aviation and tourism. The government will also introduce measures to help firms tackle the current labour crunch and bolster industry transformation. Additionally, support for young couples starting families, including affordable housing and cash handouts, is expected.

site_title: Lure of 'S' in ESG debt wanes as issuers refocus on green goals
summary: The market for social bonds, which funds specific projects like job creation and affordable housing, is experiencing a decline as governments shift focus to longer-term climate goals and companies prioritize environmental and governance (ESG) aspects. Sales of social bonds in Europe have plummeted 60% this year, and similar declines are seen in the US. In contrast, sustainability and sustainability-linked debt issuance is booming, with volumes more than doubling. Moody's expects worldwide social bond sales to fall 25% this year, while green bonds are expected to drive a record $1.35 trillion in ethical issuance.

site_title: Standard Chartered plans US$750m buyback as optimism grows
summary: Standard Chartered plans to repurchase US$750 million in shares as the bank expects earnings growth to return this year, driven by rising interest rates. Adjusted pretax profits for 2021 rose 55% to US$3.9 billion, beating the company's estimate. CEO Bill Winters aims to deliver a 10% return on tangible equity by 2024 through a refreshed strategy. The bank's stock has risen on interest rate hikes, with analysts predicting further growth. This is Standard Chartered's second share buyback program in two years, following a US$250 million repurchase in 2021.

site_title: Kallang PLH launch surprises with lower median pricing than nearby BTO flats
summary: The HDB's new prime location housing (PLH) model has launched its second batch, King George's Heights in Kallang/Whampoa, with unit prices starting from S$353,000 for a 3-room flat and S$488,000 for a 4-room flat. The prices are lower than previous BTO launches in the area, attributed to a 10-year minimum occupation period and buying and selling restrictions. Strong demand is expected, with subscription rates predicted to exceed 3 and 7 times for 3-room and 4-room flats, respectively.

site_title: FAA administrator who oversaw 737 MAX return resigning
summary: FAA Administrator Steve Dickson will resign on March 31, following criticism over the 737 MAX return and the agency's stance on 5G wireless spectrum deployment. Dickson oversaw the 737 MAX's return to service after the grounding due to two fatal crashes. His resignation comes amid ongoing disputes between the aviation and telecommunications industries. The FAA's zero-tolerance policy for unruly passengers will also continue under his successor.

site_title: Brokers' take: KGI initiates 'outperform' on The Hour Glass as demand for luxury grows
summary: KGI Securities has initiated coverage on The Hour Glass with an "outperform" recommendation, citing strong demand for luxury goods and resilience in the face of inflation. The analyst targets S$2.32, implying a 14.9% potential upside from the current trading price. The research notes that luxury spending is expected to remain strong, driven by travel limitations and pent-up demand, particularly in China. The Hour Glass is seen as more attractive than peer Cortina, trading at a lower price-to-earnings ratio and historical price-to-book ratio.

site_title: Singapore property executives see rising inflation and interest rates as top risk
summary: Singapore property executives identify rising inflation and interest rates as the top potential risk factor for market sentiment over the next half year, surpassing rising construction costs. The Real Estate Sentiment Index fell for the third consecutive quarter to 5.4, down from 6.6 in Q3. Despite this, overall sentiments on the current and future conditions remain positive. Executives expect moderately fewer unit launches and higher prices in the next 6 months, with a cautiously optimistic outlook on the private residential market.

site_title: Australia: Mining stocks, Woodside drive shares higher
summary: Australian shares rose 0.4% to 7,316.3, driven by gains in mining stocks and Woodside Petroleum after a bumper earnings report. The benchmark rose 1.1% on Wednesday. Mining stocks jumped 1.3% after Chinese stainless steel futures surged, while Woodside shares rose 4.6% to their highest in two years. However, other sectors, such as retail and tech, fell due to concerns over rising geopolitical tensions and supply chain disruptions.

images.alt_text: Australian shares rose on Thursday, helped by gains in heavyweight mining stocks after steel prices jumped, while a jump in Woodside Petroleum shares after a bumper earnings report also supported the benchmark.

site_title: In Orlando, 25 Basquiats come under the magnifying glass
summary: A treasure-hunting picker found 25 Jean-Michel Basquiat paintings created in 1982, sold to screenwriter Thad Mumford for $5,000, and resurfaced 30 years later. The artworks, made on cardboard, were authenticated by handwriting expert James Blanco, University of Maryland professor Jordana Moore Saggese, and curator Diego Cortez. However, art world professionals remain skeptical due to the lack of provenance and institutional legitimacy. The paintings' value could be near $100 million, but the Basquiat estate's authentication committee closed in 2012, and major auction houses are hesitant to handle unproven works.

site_title: Australia: Shares pushed higher by gold stocks and Woodside Petroleum
summary: Australian shares rose 0.2% to 7,296.20, driven by gains in gold stocks and Woodside Petroleum, which reported a strong annual profit. Gold stocks jumped 2.1% and heavyweights Northern Star Resources and Newcrest Mining climbed 4.4% and 1.5%, respectively. The energy index rose 0.9% as crude oil prices surged overnight. Miners and South32 advanced, while technology stocks slipped 2.9%. The unemployment rate in Australia remained at 4.2% in January, supporting the Reserve Bank of Australia's decision to hold off on raising interest rates.

site_title: Hong Kong to mass test whole city for Covid with Beijing's help
summary: Hong Kong plans to conduct a citywide COVID-19 testing campaign with the help of Chinese medical experts, starting in early March. The mass testing effort aims to contain the outbreak, which has seen record-breaking cases and hospitalizations. The government is considering making the testing compulsory, with fines of up to HK$10,000 for those who refuse. Experts worry that the move may come too late, as the city struggles to cope with its overwhelmed healthcare system and public confidence in the government is low.

site_title: El Salvador's Bukele tells Bitcoin-wary US senators to stay out of internal affairs
summary: El Salvador President Nayib Bukele warned US senators to stay out of the country's internal affairs, following their call for an investigation into the economic risks of El Salvador's adoption of bitcoin as legal tender. The senators expressed concerns over the potential weakening of US sanctions policy and increased activity of criminal organizations. Bukele tweeted that the US has no jurisdiction over El Salvador, a sovereign and independent nation. The move comes amid deteriorating diplomatic relations between El Salvador and the US, following public denunciations of corruption in Bukele's government.

site_title: Australia's largest coal-fired power plant to close
summary: Australia's largest coal-fired power plant, Eraring, will close in 2025, 3 years earlier than planned, due to the low cost of renewables. Origin Energy cited the influx of cleaner and lower-cost generation sources such as solar, wind, and batteries as the reason. The plant, which supplies around a quarter of New South Wales' electricity, will be repurposed with a 700-megawatt battery, with a A$240 million plan. This move is part of a trend of early closures of coal assets in Australia, despite government support for new projects.

site_title: Macau casino stock rally points to risky bet on China ending Covid-zero
summary: Macau casino stocks surged 5.6% on Wednesday, with Sands China and Wynn Macau rising 6.8% and 6.3% respectively, amid speculation that China may pivot away from its Covid Zero policy. A derivatives trading surge and a bullish contract on Sands China stock suggest investors are betting on a potential reopening. However, S&P Global Ratings analysts remain cautious, cutting Las Vegas Sands to junk due to uncertainty over China's policies.

site_title: Japan finance minister warns of damage from inflation
summary: Japan's Finance Minister Shunichi Suzuki warned that recent rising prices could hurt household income and affect consumption if wages don't keep pace. Suzuki attributed the price rise to higher global fuel costs, rather than a weak yen. The government has already launched a temporary subsidy program to ease the impact on households and may take further measures. Japan's consumer inflation remains stuck at 0.5%, and the economy is vulnerable to oil price swings. The government's response to the issue is becoming a politically hot topic ahead of an Upper House election in July.

site_title: Covid-19 measures saved Singapore's resident unemployment from reaching 7.5% in 2021
summary: Singapore's COVID-19 measures prevented a 7.5% resident unemployment rate in 2021, saving 165,000 jobs, and boosted the economy by 0.8 percentage points. The measures also supported over 27,000 enterprises with loans of more than $24.7 billion and filled over 166,300 jobs and skills opportunities. The country's real GDP growth in 2021 was 7.6%, and annual resident unemployment stood at 3.5%. The measures also improved local wages and mitigated the impact of the pandemic on the economy.

site_title: Indonesia govt sets 5.3% to 5.9% GDP growth forecast for 2023
summary: Indonesia's government has set a 5.3% to 5.9% GDP growth forecast for 2023, exceeding its 2022 target of 5.2%. Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati said the budget will be designed with a deficit of under 3% of GDP. The country is gradually withdrawing pandemic-era fiscal support and reinstating strict fiscal rules. Key growth drivers include household consumption, investment, and new sectors like healthcare services and electronics manufacturing. Policymakers will monitor global monetary tightening and inflation, which could impact economic recovery.

site_title: Two 999-year strata office floors on Cecil Street put on market for S$30m
summary: Two 999-year leasehold strata office floors at the TPI building in Singapore's Cecil Street have been put up for sale via expression of interest for S$30 million, translating to about S$3,818 per square foot. The floors, located on levels 5 and 6, have existing tenants and can be sold collectively or individually, offering immediate rental income. Foreigners are eligible to purchase, and the property benefits from its central location near Telok Ayer and Raffles Place MRT stations. The sale is expected to attract strong interest due to the rarity of 999-year office floors available for sale in the central business district.

site_title: Disney to develop US residential communities, with local theme
summary: Disney is developing US residential communities with local themes, capitalizing on fans' enthusiasm beyond theme parks. The first community, Cotino, in Southern California's Rancho Mirage, features 1,900 housing units, shops, and a beachfront hotel. Disney park designers will create the communities' creative concepts, while employees will run a community association offering entertainment, activities, and Disney programming. This effort, dubbed "Storyliving by Disney," aims to bring Disney's control of detail and escapist experiences to residential living, with no direct theme park connection.

site_title: Gold prices near 8-month high as dovish Fed minutes weigh on dollar, yields
summary: Gold prices near an 8-month high due to dovish US Federal Reserve minutes, which suggested policymakers are not set on a particular pace of interest rate hikes, making gold more attractive to overseas buyers. The US dollar and Treasury yields also dipped, decreasing the opportunity cost of holding non-interest-paying bullion. The Ukraine crisis boosted demand for the safe-haven metal, with spot gold holding steady at $1,868.36 per ounce.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares flat at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks remained flat at the opening of trading on February 17, 2022, as investors weighed the Russia-Ukraine crisis and anticipation of the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike. The Hang Seng Index rose 3.98 points to 24,722.88, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices declined slightly. Market participants are focused on the Fed's plan and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Cisco projects sales growth constrained by further supply chain issues
summary: Cisco Systems reported a 3-5% sales growth for the current quarter, beating analyst projections. The company attributed the growth to strong demand for equipment driven by companies upgrading their infrastructure. However, Cisco's sales are constrained by supply chain issues, leaving the company unable to ship as many products as it has orders for. The company's backlog has grown to $14 billion, and it expects an improvement in the second half of fiscal 2022. Cisco also increased its share buyback program by $15 billion, bringing the total to $18 billion.

site_title: Citi moves HK equities staff to Singapore, other markets amid Covid woes
summary: Citigroup is relocating several senior equities staff from Hong Kong to Singapore and other markets due to the city's strict zero-Covid approach. The moves include 6 managing directors and 1 Asia-Pacific head of prime services sales trading, amid concerns over Hong Kong's status as a regional finance center. The bank aims to support staff who want to relocate due to family reasons or for client coverage, but the shift is seen as a response to client demand and plans to beef up its equities business in the region.

site_title: HDB launches second BTO project under prime location model in Kallang/Whampoa
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) launched its second Build-To-Order (BTO) project under the prime location public housing (PLH) model in Kallang/Whampoa, offering 398 units at a 6% subsidy clawback clause. The project, King George's Heights, starts from S$353,000 for a three-room flat and S$488,000 for a four-room flat, with a 59-month waiting period until completion in 2027. This marks a significant increase in waiting time compared to the pre-pandemic era.

site_title: Hot stocks: Aviation, tourism-linked counters rise on Singapore's reopening
summary: Singapore's reopening plans, including relaxed pandemic restrictions and new vaccinated travel lanes (VTLs), have led to a surge in aviation and tourism-linked stocks. Shares of Singapore Airlines, SIA Engineering, SATS, ComfortDelGro, and Genting Singapore rose 2-4% in morning trading. The move is seen as a timely boost for hotel operators and the aviation sector, which should benefit from relaxed border controls in the region. DBS Group Research expects a swift rebound in tourism from the second quarter of 2022.

site_title: Ready to go in 30 mins: Sunseap launches fast-charging EV network in Singapore
summary: Sunseap launches a fast-charging EV network in Singapore, with its "Turbo" line of fast chargers providing a direct current power rating of up to 120 kilowatts, allowing EV drivers to fully charge their vehicles in about 30 minutes. The company aims to have at least 50 fast-charging points by end-2022, representing Singapore's fastest public EV charging network. This expansion is expected to boost Singapore's transition to electric vehicles, with Charge+, the electric mobility unit of Sunseap Group, already operating 12 fast-charging points in the country.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 10.83 points or 0.68% to 1,614.03, driven by gains. The market saw 196 gainer shares and 95 loser shares, with a trading volume of 143.96 million lots worth RM91.19 million.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on Thursday, easing 0.11% to 27,431.44, amid investor uncertainty over Ukraine tensions and digesting US indicators. The broader Topix index lost 0.15%.

images.alt_text: Tokyo shares opened lower on Thursday as investors sought new cues while monitoring tensions over Ukraine and digesting healthy US indicators.

site_title: Singapore stocks climb at Thursday's open following 7.6% GDP growth; STI up 0.4%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.4% at Thursday's open, following the announcement of 7.6% GDP growth, exceeding the advanced estimate of 7.2%. The Straits Times Index (STI) climbed 12.71 points to 3,452.01. Gainers outnumbered losers 94 to 37, with 84.4 million securities changing hands. The rally comes ahead of GDP data and despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Australia jobs growth slows in Jan as Omicron hits hours
summary: Australia's employment rose 12,900 in January, exceeding market forecasts, but hours worked decreased 8.8% due to the Omicron wave, leading to record-high vacancies. The unemployment rate remained at 4.2%, the lowest in 13 years.

site_title: Japan's trade deficit soars to 8-year high as commodity imports soar
summary: Japan's trade deficit surged to an 8-year high in January, reaching 2.1911 trillion yen, as commodity imports skyrocketed 39.6% year-on-year due to high energy costs and supply chain disruptions. Exports declined 9.6% in the same period, mainly due to a contraction in car exports. The deficit is attributed to slowing demand from China, Japan's largest trading partner, and a record surge in imports of petroleum, coal, and liquefied natural gas. This highlights Japan's vulnerability to soaring commodity costs and slowing global demand.

site_title: Property agent commissions may not rise with higher developer ABSD: poll
summary: A survey by the National University of Singapore Real Estate (NUS+RE) found that property agent commissions in Singapore may not increase with higher developer Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD). The survey of 42 senior executives in the real estate sector, including 22 developers, revealed that commission rates have been driven by circumstances such as increased competition and deadlines, rather than the ABSD hike. The survey participants expect commission rates to remain steady despite the recent increase in ABSD to 35% for developers.

site_title: Nvidia underwhelms in first results since scrapping Arm deal
summary: Nvidia's shares slipped 2% after the company's latest forecast, despite topping Wall Street estimates with its quarterly results. Revenue is expected to be about $8.1 billion in the fiscal first quarter, exceeding analyst estimates. However, investors were underwhelmed due to weak spots in sales and adjusted gross margin. Nvidia's data-centre chip business is improving, but supply constraints continue to weigh on the company. Despite the setback, CEO Jensen Huang remains optimistic about the company's growth prospects, particularly in the artificial intelligence computing market.

site_title: New York attorney general fires back at Trump's defence of financial statements
summary: New York Attorney General Letitia James responded to former President Donald Trump's defense of company financial statements, stating that Trump's five-page statement contradicted a court filing by his attorneys. The statement was issued just one day after the filing. James is investigating whether the Trumps inflated real estate values to obtain bank loans and reduced values to lower tax bills. This public disagreement is rare and raises questions about the accuracy of Trump's defense.

site_title: US: Wall St slips at open on Fed, Ukraine jitters
summary: US stocks fell at the open on Wednesday, February 16, 2022, due to the Federal Reserve's potential to tighten policy after stronger-than-expected retail sales data. Geopolitical tensions over Ukraine added to caution. The Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite opened lower, with the Dow falling 0.11%, the S&P 500 0.34%, and the Nasdaq 0.71%.

site_title: Hot stock: UOB up 1.8% after strong FY21 results
summary: UOB shares surged 1.8% to an all-time high of S$33.33 after the bank posted a 48% net profit rise for FY2021. Analysts maintained "buy" calls, with DBS, RHB, and OCBC increasing their targets and forecasts due to strong business and interest rate hikes. The bank's strong fundamentals, resilient asset quality, and high allowance buffers were cited as key reasons for the positive outlook.

images.alt_text: Shares of UOB rallied on Thursday morning.

site_title: US manufacturing output rises moderately in January
summary: US manufacturing output rose 0.2% in January, a moderate increase, after dipping 0.1% in December. This marks a rebound from the previous month's decline, with output increasing 2.5% compared to January 2021. The increase was driven by a decline in motor vehicle output, which fell for the second consecutive month due to a global semiconductor shortage.

site_title: Singapore exports up by 17.6% in January on growth in non-electronics shipments
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) rose 17.6% in January, exceeding analysts' forecasts, driven by growth in non-electronics shipments such as ship structures, machinery, and petrochemicals. Electronics NODX grew 14%, while non-electronics shipments expanded 18.6%. Despite a slowdown in trade momentum, export momentum is expected to improve in the second half of 2022 as global supply chain disruptions ease. Strong demand from the US, mainland China, and the European Union drove growth, while shipments to Thailand, Hong Kong, and South Korea declined.

site_title: Las Vegas Sands cut to junk by S&P on slower Macau recovery
summary: Las Vegas Sands has been downgraded to junk by S&P Global Ratings due to a slower recovery in the Macau gaming market, caused by omicron cases and travel restrictions. The company is now rated BB+, one step below investment grade, but remains investment-grade by Moody's and Fitch. S&P expects significant stress on revenue and cash flow, forecasting a 30-40% decline in Macau's gross gaming revenues in 2022 compared to 2019. The stock fell 0.3% to $47.92 following the downgrade.

site_title: Singapore keeps 2022 export forecasts; 2021 NODX beats official estimates to grow 12.1%
summary: Singapore has maintained its forecast for key exports in 2022, despite downgraded international economic and trade growth forecasts. Non-oil domestic exports (NODX) expanded 12.1% year-on-year in 2021, beating official estimates, and is expected to rise by 0-2% in 2022. Total merchandise trade grew 19.7% in 2021, driven by oil trade and non-oil trade growth. The International Monetary Fund has cut its global outlook amid the spread of the Omicron variant, but Enterprise Singapore maintains its 2022 growth projections.

site_title: Malaysia hits new daily Covid record as Omicron surge continues
summary: Malaysia reports a new daily Covid record of 27,831 cases, driven by the Omicron variant, surpassing the previous record of 24,599 in August. The country's high vaccination rate, nearly 80% of the population completed their regime, and hospital occupancy rates remain manageable. Authorities have prepared for herd immunity and expect the Omicron wave to peak in the second half of March, with only 428 hospital admissions requiring oxygen support.

images.alt_text: The government has cut the private housing supply from its first-half 2019 land sales programme by 20 per cent from the current half, bringing it to the lowest level in 12 years.

site_title: Hong Kong exodus forces market watchdog staff into 12-hour days
summary: Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) is struggling to maintain its role as an international financial centre due to a brain drain caused by emigration and job switches. The watchdog lost 12% of its employees last year, including 25% of junior staff, forcing remaining staff to work 12-hour days to cover the workload. The SFC warned that without sufficient staff, it will not be able to deliver on its initiatives to develop Hong Kong as an IFC, putting the city's financial centre status at risk.

site_title: UK to sign £25m security deal with Australia
summary: The UK is set to announce a £25 million security deal with Australia, focusing on enhancing regional security in the Indo-Pacific, innovation in science and technology, and boosting business opportunities. The deal will be discussed during a video call between Prime Minister Boris Johnson and Australian PM Scott Morrison, with an emphasis on the AUKUS partnership. The agreement aims to drive cooperation on defence, trade, and technology collaboration, with a collective endeavour to provide Australia with a conventional-armed nuclear-powered submarine capability.

site_title: DoorDash revenue beats estimates as food-delivery boom continues, shares soar 24%
summary: DoorDash reported quarterly revenue that beat estimates, with a 34% increase to $1.30 billion, driven by consumer retention and new customer growth. The company's shares soared 24% as analysts expect strong growth for several years despite increased dining out. DoorDash forecasts $11.4 billion to $11.8 billion in marketplace gross order value for the first quarter. The company has also expanded its offerings to include non-restaurant items and tied up with retailers to attract more users. This indicates a permanent shift in ordering habits, supporting long-term growth.

site_title: US governors, Canadian premiers call for end to vaccine mandate
summary: A group of 16 US state governors and Canadian premiers called on the US and Canadian leaders to end the cross-border vaccine requirement, citing its impact on economies. The requirement, which mandated Covid vaccines to cross the border, sparked protests and briefly closed trade routes. The signatories requested exemptions for individuals with medical or religious reasons. The move aims to ease tensions and promote trade between the two countries.

site_title: Oil resumes rally as Russia-Ukraine tensions stay high
summary: Oil prices rose over 1% on Wednesday as investors weighed Russia's possible troop withdrawal from Ukraine, despite concerns about supply disruptions in a tight global market. Futures later fell after US and Iranian officials announced a closer agreement on nuclear development, potentially allowing Iran to increase global oil sales. Oil prices remain a concern, with some speculating they could reach US$100 a barrel due to Russia's threatening posture toward Ukraine.

site_title: Stocks to watch: OUE Commercial Reit, Prime US Reit, Chip Eng Seng, SIA, SIA Engineering
summary: Several Singaporean stocks are expected to see trading activity due to new developments. OUE Commercial Reit reported a 4.2% decline in second-half distribution per unit to S$0.0137, while Prime US Reit saw a 0.9% increase in second-half distribution per unit to US$0.0345. Chip Eng Seng, SIA, and SIA Engineering also saw price movements, with units of OUE C-Reit up 1.2%, Prime US Reit flat, and units of Chip Eng Seng ending at S$0.005 higher. The Singapore stock market saw a 0.4% gain on Thursday.

site_title: Residential assets grab spotlight in private-equity real estate market: panel
summary: Private equity investors are increasingly interested in the residential real estate market, driven by a need for stable income and diversification from other asset classes. Institutional investors, such as pension funds and sovereign wealth funds, are expected to increase their allocations to real estate in 2022, despite still being below their target allocations. The demand is fueled by a scarcity of quality assets and a shift towards multi-family housing, with investors seeking stable income and scalability. However, inflation fears may raise operational costs and development costs, potentially deterring new investors and creating opportunities for those with specific skills.

images.alt_text: Inflation may bring a bright spot for incumbents as it sustains barriers of entry, panellists said. Colliers' Paddy Allen also noted the emergence of distinct verticals in the market.
QIP's Peter Young said residential products ought to become "more tailored and curated", as people are getting "fussier" or more discerning.

site_title: SIA flights to Hong Kong suspended for 2 weeks after passengers test positive for Covid-19
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) has suspended flights to Hong Kong for 2 weeks after passengers tested positive for Covid-19. The ban affects SIA's 2 daily passenger services to Hong Kong until March 1. However, flights from Hong Kong to Singapore remain unaffected. SIA apologizes to affected customers and will offer assistance to minimize inconvenience. This suspension comes after Hong Kong tightened domestic and border restrictions in response to a growing Covid-19 wave.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Singapore Airlines planes sit on the tarmac at Changi Airport in Singapore December 8, 2020.  REUTERS/Edgar Su/File Photo  GLOBAL BUSINESS WEEK AHEAD

site_title: US: Stocks mixed after bombshell-free Federal Reserve minutes
summary: US stocks finished mixed on Wednesday after the Federal Reserve minutes showed central bankers favoring a more aggressive pace of interest rate hikes. Despite initial concerns, investors were already aware of the sentiment and stocks changed direction in relief. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.2%, while the S&P 500 gained 0.1%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index slipped 0.1%. Additionally, US retail sales jumped more than expected in January, and industrial production came in unexpectedly strong. Western officials expressed skepticism over Russian statements on troop withdrawals from Ukraine's border.

site_title: Bali welcomes back tourists with first international flight
summary: Bali welcomed its first international tourists in nearly 2 years with a Singapore Airlines flight carrying 109 international travelers and 47 Indonesians on February 16, 2022. The resumption of flights comes as Indonesia loosens quarantine rules despite a surge in Covid cases fueled by the Omicron variant. Foreign visitors must stay in designated hotels for 3-7 days, depending on their vaccine doses, with the goal of lifting quarantine obligations by early March if health protocols are followed.

site_title: Biden, Scholz demand 'real steps towards de-escalation' from Russia
summary: US President Joe Biden and German Chancellor Olaf Scholz have urged Russia to take real steps towards de-escalation in Ukraine, warning that no significant Russian troop withdrawal has been observed. They stated that the risk of further military aggression remains high and that any further action would invite "extraordinarily serious consequences." The leaders emphasized the need for Russia to take concrete steps to reduce tensions, renewing their call for de-escalation in the region.

site_title: Europe: Shares inch higher on strong commodity shares; geopolitics in focus
summary: European stocks rose 0.1% on Wednesday, driven by gains in commodity-heavy stocks amid Russia-Ukraine tensions. The Stoxx 600 index saw oil firms and miners lead the gains, despite concerns from the US and Nato that Russia is still building up troops around Ukraine. Shares of Ericsson fell 14.2% after an internal investigation revealed misconduct. Despite the volatility, analysts say geopolitical events tend to have a short-lived impact on markets.

site_title: US retail sales rise most in 10 months in broad-based rebound
summary: US retail sales rebounded with a 3.8% gain in January, the largest increase since March, as Americans continued to spend despite Covid-19 and inflation. The median estimate was 2% growth. Eight retail categories rose, with non-store retailers and motor vehicle sales surging 14.5% and 5.7% respectively. Services-oriented category, restaurants and bars, saw a 0.9% decline. The rebound suggests consumer resilience, but economists warn of potential headwinds from the expiration of child tax credit payments and inflation.

site_title: Blackstone expands further into rental housing in US
summary: Blackstone, the largest private equity firm in the US, is expanding its rental housing portfolio with a $6 billion acquisition of Preferred Apartment Communities. The deal, expected to close in Q2, adds 12,000 housing units to Blackstone's portfolio. The acquisition is part of the firm's efforts to offset inflation, with rental housing accounting for 70% of the deal's value. This expansion is the latest sign of Blackstone's ambitions in real estate, which has become a key contributor to the firm's performance, generating nearly half its earnings in 2021.

site_title: Global policy chiefs face hawkish market bets on inflation
summary: Global policy chiefs face hawkish market bets on inflation, with investors predicting the fastest pace of interest-rate hikes since 2010. Central banks are under pressure to manage expectations amid slowing growth, threats of war, and a pandemic. The Group of 20 nations' meetings this week will focus on balancing inflation concerns with economic stability. Experts warn that policy makers must avoid policy errors, as delayed responses to rising prices could lead to harsher measures, while a rushed tightening could harm economic recovery.

site_title: Federal Reserve officials see accelerated US rate hikes
summary: US Federal Reserve officials are considering an accelerated schedule for raising the benchmark borrowing rate due to stubbornly high inflation. They feel a faster pace of increases would be warranted compared to the previous cycle, with most economists predicting a half-point increase next month. The Fed has signaled readiness to begin rate hikes soon, with the economy facing decades-high inflation and a strong labor market. Inflation has accelerated for months, with US consumer prices rising 7.5% in January, its largest increase since 1982.

site_title: US retailers begin 2022 with a big jump in sales
summary: US retail sales surged 3.8% in January, more than regaining ground lost in December, despite high inflation. The rebound is attributed to consumers pulling forward holiday purchases, fearing shortages of popular items. The auto industry bounced back with a 5.7% jump in sales, while nonstore retailers saw a 14.5% increase. However, consumer prices rose 7.5% in the 12 months to January, driven by inflation. The White House hailed the data as a sign of economic growth, but experts noted that the sales surge may be less impressive than initially suggested due to price increases.

site_title: A revival of interest in things Malay
summary: A renewed interest in Malay heritage and art has been sparked by a new book on Singaporean Malay cuisine and the revival of bangsawan, a traditional Malay opera. The Malay Heritage Centre is also closing for renovation, featuring an exhibition showcasing the history and culture of the Malay world. Meanwhile, home interiors are taking on a masculine feel, and Burnt Ends has expanded its premises. These developments reflect a growing appreciation for Malay culture and its contributions to Singapore's culinary and design scenes.

site_title: US men's coach made US$1.2m while women's coach got US$357,000
summary: US men's national team coach Gregg Berhalter earned $1.2 million in the fiscal year ending March 31, 2022, while women's coach Vlatko Andonovski received $357,597. Despite the women's team's two-time Women's World Cup championship success, the pay gap persists. The US women's team has filed a lawsuit against US Soccer alleging unequal pay and gender discrimination, citing the disparity between their salaries and the men's team.

site_title: Crown Resorts posts half-year loss on Covid-19 restrictions, regulatory costs
summary: Crown Resorts reported a net loss of A$196.3 million for the six months ended Dec 31, due to pandemic-related restrictions and regulatory costs. The company's trading performance was impacted by the emergence of the Omicron variant, and it faces ongoing challenges from multiple Royal Commission enquiries. This marks the third consecutive half-yearly loss for Crown, following a loss of A$120.9 million in the same period last year. Regulatory costs and property shutdowns also affected smaller peer Star Entertainment Group Ltd, which reported a wider loss of A$73.7 million.

site_title: Singapore condo, HDB rents continue rise in Jan
summary: Singapore's condo and HDB rents continued to rise in January 2022, with condo rents increasing 1.6% month-over-month and 11.2% year-over-year. HDB rents rose 1.2% month-over-month and 11.2% year-over-year. The rental market benefited from easing border controls, a recovering labor market, and delays in new home construction. Overall, condo rental volumes climbed 3.9% to 4,646 units, while HDB rental volumes rose 2.4% to 1,806 units.

site_title: Singapore sticks to 3-5% growth forecast this year after expanding 7.6% in 2021
summary: Singapore's economy expanded 7.6% in 2021, surpassing the advance estimate of 7.2% and marking a turnaround from the previous year's 4.1% contraction. The manufacturing sector, driven by increasing output, grew 13.2% and the construction sector expanded 20.1%, while the services sector grew 5.6%. For 2022, the government maintains a 3-5% growth forecast, citing global supply bottlenecks and rising inflationary pressures. Experts predict uneven growth and possible upside risks, with core inflation forecast at 2-3%.

site_title: Cryptic 'token incentive plan' at heart of Lightnet's dispute with former staff
summary: Former employees of Singapore-based fintech startup Lightnet are suing the company over allegedly failed cryptocurrency token promises. Ilya Zusman and Crystal Ma claim Lightnet's "Velo Token Incentive Plan" (VTIP) never existed, contradicting the company's defense. The former employees are seeking US$1.37 million and a declaration that Lightnet will release remaining tokens. Lightnet's founders, Tridbodi Arunanondchai and Chatchaval Jiaravanon, are listed as chairman and vice-chairman of Velo Labs Technology, the entity behind the VELO token.

site_title: Singapore expands VTLs to new destinations
summary: Singapore expands its Vaccinated Travel Lanes (VTLs) to new destinations, including Indonesia and the Philippines, and restores quotas for existing ones, including the land link with Malaysia. The move aims to alleviate labor shortages and facilitate business travel. From Feb 21, only work permit holders and short-term visitors eligible to travel via VTLs will need to apply for a Vaccinated Travel Pass (VTP). Long-term pass holders will no longer require a VTP or Entry Approval to enter Singapore.

site_title: Opec+ must fix its million-barrel supply gap, says IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) urges Opec+ to address a widening oil production shortfall, warning that a supply gap of 1 million barrels a day could lead to US$100+ crude prices, fueling inflation and economic recovery concerns. Opec+ members are struggling to restore output halted during the pandemic, with the 23-nation alliance needing to narrow the gap between targets and production levels. The situation could worsen if tensions with Russia escalate, sending prices to US$125 a barrel.

site_title: Oil prices recoup losses as Russia-Ukraine tensions stay high
summary: Oil prices recouped losses due to rising tensions between Russia and Ukraine, despite a partial troop withdrawal announced by Moscow. Brent crude rose 1.4% to $94.56 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude increased 1.2% to $93.21. Prices are still near their highest levels since 2014, driven by tight global supplies and recovering fuel demand. Despite the partial pullback, NATO's Jens Stoltenberg said Russia's military build-up continues, and analysts predict prices could reach $100 a barrel.

site_title: STI outperforming in 2022 YTD, but may run into headwinds
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) has outperformed most regional and global markets in 2022, rising 10.1% as of February 16, its highest in over 3 years. Financials sector has driven the STI's performance, with local banks DBS, OCBC, and UOB leading the gains. Experts attribute the performance to sectors' heavy weighting on the local index, but caution that the strong momentum may not persist due to headwinds from geopolitical tensions, inflation, and interest rate hikes. The STI's rally may stall once rate hike expectations stop rising, with some analysts predicting a year-end target of 3,550.

site_title: Dollar falls for second day as Ukraine war fears lessen
summary: The US dollar fell for a second day, edging lower by 0.2% at 95.847 due to decreased concerns over Russia's invasion of Ukraine. Despite this, long-standing expectations of a US Federal Reserve rate hike limited the dollar's losses. The Canadian dollar and Norwegian krone strengthened, while the Australian and New Zealand dollars also rose. The euro and euro-swiss edged higher, while the British pound was up 0.1% against the dollar.

site_title: Xi tells Hong Kong's leaders to control Covid as infections spiral
summary: China's President Xi Jinping instructed Hong Kong's leaders to control the worsening Covid-19 outbreak, telling them to "stabilise and control" the situation to ensure the safety and health of the population. The daily Covid-19 infections in Hong Kong have reached a record 4,285 confirmed new cases, with hospitals and medical staff struggling to cope. Xi's directive comes as Hong Kong's Chief Executive Carrie Lam faces pressure to respond to the outbreak, with some considering postponing the upcoming chief executive election.

site_title: Hybrid working can save employers US$11,000 per worker a year: IWG
summary: IWG reports that hybrid working can save employers an average of US$11,000 per worker per year due to increased productivity, lower real estate costs, reduced absenteeism, and turnover. This comes from employees working remotely half of the week.

site_title: With S$11m price tag, Ardmore Park unit is most profitable resale deal in Q4
summary: A luxury unit at Ardmore Park in Singapore's District 10 was the most profitable resale deal in Q4 2021, with a profit of S$6.73 million after selling for S$11 million in November 2021. The 2,885 sq ft unit had been held for over 22 years, generating an annualised profit of 4.3%. In contrast, the top 5 loss-making deals by quantum were all in the Core Central Region, with losses ranging from 2.4% to 45%. The proportion of loss-making transactions in the resale market declined to 8.6% in Q4 2021, down from 11% in Q3 2021.

site_title: Coachella to return with no masks or vaccines required
summary: Coachella is set to return in April with no mask or vaccine requirements, following a 2-year hiatus due to the pandemic. The festival, which typically draws 125,000 fans per day, will not enforce COVID-19 protocols, acknowledging the risk of exposure. Organizers note that policies may change based on public health conditions. The move comes after a turbulent two years for the concert industry, with some events cancelled due to the virus. The festival will be headlined by Billie Eilish, Harry Styles, and Kanye West.

site_title: Hong Kong seeks property tycoons' help to house Covid patients
summary: Hong Kong's leader Carrie Lam has asked major property developers to find 10,000 hotel rooms to house Covid-19 patients, amid the city's biggest outbreak yet. The city's zero-tolerance approach is being challenged by the more transmissible Omicron variant. Developers, including CK Asset Holdings and New World Development, have agreed to review and identify suitable properties. The city has 80,000 hotel rooms, with 11,500 currently allocated for traveler quarantine, which is expected to increase. The move aims to isolate people infected with the virus while also alleviating pressure on hospitals.

site_title: Japan's firms see one-time bonuses, not permanent increases, lifting pay: poll
summary: Japan's firms are unlikely to raise base salaries this year, with over two-thirds of companies citing concerns about permanent increases. Instead, one-time bonuses are more likely to be offered, which may not boost household spending. A slim majority of firms plan to increase total pay, including bonuses, with 39% expecting a 1-3% rise. The government is pressing companies to raise wages to combat deflation and rising living costs, but economists predict that Prime Minister Fumio Kishida's wage policies will not trigger a virtuous growth cycle.

images.alt_text: More than two-thirds of Japanese firms don't plan to raise base salaries at this year's labour talks, a Reuters poll showed, with pay increases more likely to come from one-time bonuses that may not kickstart household spending.

site_title: Singapore Airlines should disclose impact of sustainable fuel adoption
summary: Singapore Airlines will begin a 1-year trial using a blend of refined jet fuel and sustainable aviation fuel starting in the third quarter, aiming to reduce carbon dioxide emissions by 2,500 tonnes. The use of sustainable fuels is a key step towards the airline's goal of net-zero carbon emissions by 2050. While sustainable fuels can cut emissions by up to 80% compared to fossil jet fuel, they are at least twice as expensive, and investors may be concerned about the cost impact. The airline should disclose the impact of sustainable fuel adoption to investors and prepare them for potential costs.

site_title: HSBC Singapore names first independent chair
summary: HSBC Singapore has appointed Penny Goh as its first independent chairman, effective February 16. Goh succeeds Mervyn Fong, who will continue to serve as chair of the risk committee and audit committee until his retirement in April 2022. Goh, a former Allen & Gledhill co-chairman, brings her expertise to the role, which HSBC Singapore CEO Kee Joo Wong described as a "fitting reflection of her strategic navigation of the bank." Goh's appointment aims to accelerate the bank's growth plans, including doubling the total wealth balances of its wealth and personal banking business in the next 5 years.

site_title: Indian tax authorities search premises of China's Huawei
summary: India's income tax authorities conducted searches at multiple Huawei premises in New Delhi, Gurugram, and Bengaluru as part of a tax investigation. The searches focused on financial documents, account books, and company records. Huawei confirmed the visit and stated it is confident its operations in India are compliant with laws and regulations. The move comes after India blocked access to 54 Chinese mobile apps over security concerns. The tax investigation is ongoing, with officials looking into Huawei's financial transactions and records.

site_title: 16,689 new Covid-19 cases and 13 deaths reported in Singapore
summary: Singapore reported 16,689 new Covid-19 cases and 13 deaths on Feb 16, with hospitalizations at 1,352 and 35 patients in intensive care. 12,714 local cases were detected through antigen rapid tests, and 194 new imported cases were reported. The weekly infection growth rate is at 1.29, down from 1.34 the day before. As of Feb 16, Singapore has recorded 514,880 cases and 926 deaths, with 94% of the eligible population completing the full vaccination regimen.

site_title: IMF chief urges G-20 to move faster on debt relief
summary: IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva urged the G-20 to immediately provide debt relief to developing nations struggling with debt burdens due to the COVID-19 pandemic. About 60% of low-income countries are at risk of debt distress, and Georgieva called for creditors to provide more grants and concessional financing to help these economies. The G-20's Debt Service Suspension Initiative ended in December, and the Common Framework for restructuring large debt loads remains uncertain, with only three countries having requested negotiations. Georgieva warned of dire consequences if creditors fail to act.

site_title: Crypto firm Fireblocks buys payments tech platform for US$100m
summary: Fireblocks, a cryptocurrency infrastructure provider, has acquired First Digital, a stablecoin and digital asset payments technology platform, in a US$100 million cash and equity deal. This acquisition follows Fireblocks' US$550 million funding round last month, which valued the company at US$8 billion. The deal aims to expand Fireblocks' offerings in the digital payments space and further solidify its position in the cryptocurrency market.

site_title: BTS to hit the stage in South Korea for first time since Covid began
summary: BTS, a South Korean boy band, is set to perform their first in-person concerts in Seoul since the COVID-19 pandemic began, with three shows scheduled at Olympic Stadium on March 10, 12, and 13. The concerts are part of their "Permission to Dance on Stage" tour, which was disrupted by the pandemic. The band's last concert for South Korean fans was in October 2019, and they have held online shows instead. The concerts will also be live streamed. The performances come after several band members, including V, RM, Jin, and Suga, contracted COVID-19.

site_title: SIA Engineering to take 75% stake in SR Technics Malaysia for US$3.75m
summary: SIA Engineering has agreed to acquire a 75% stake in SR Technics Malaysia for US$3.75 million, forming an MRO joint venture. The JV will complement SIA Engineering's existing services and broaden its component repair and overhaul offerings. The transaction is expected to have a minimal impact on SIA Engineering's net tangible assets and earnings per share. The joint venture will enable both partners to develop new repair capabilities and increase business volume.

site_title: Singapore expands VTL to new destinations, restores quotas for land and air travel
summary: Singapore expands its Vaccinated Travel Lanes (VTLs) to new destinations, including Indonesia and the Philippines, and restores quotas for land and air travel. Effective February 21, only work permit holders and short-term visitors eligible to travel via VTLs will require a Vaccinated Travel Pass. Long-term pass holders will no longer need a VTP or Entry Approval to enter Singapore. Quotas for air VTLs will be fully restored, and land VTLs with Malaysia will be restored from February 22. The move aims to alleviate labour shortages and facilitate business travel, with the goal of achieving quarantine-free travel for all vaccinated travellers.

site_title: Chip Eng Seng pares H2 loss to S$31.6m as revenue rises
summary: Chip Eng Seng, a property player, reported a net loss of S$31.5 million in FY2021, a significant improvement from a loss of S$81.1 million in FY2020. Revenue rose 28.2% to S$493 million in the second half, driven by higher contributions from construction, hospitality, and education divisions. Despite this, the company's cost of sales increased 22.2% and gross profit nearly doubled to S$60.8 million. The company has proposed a S$0.02 per share dividend and will continue to exercise caution in its property development business.

site_title: Ericsson shares crash after CEO says firm may have paid ISIS terror group
summary: Ericsson shares plummet 14.5% after CEO Borje Ekholm reveals the company may have made payments to ISIS to gain access to transport routes in Iraq, amid ongoing corruption probe. The admission comes after a US$1 billion settlement in 2019 and a breach of agreement with the US Department of Justice. Ekholm stated that Ericsson has spent considerable resources investigating the matter, but no final recipient of the payments has been determined.

site_title: Making disability inclusion part of every firm's DNA
summary: Singapore firms Bolloré Logistics Singapore, Raffles Hotel Singapore, and Deutsche Bank are reaping the benefits of disability inclusion, with 27 employees with disabilities at Bolloré and disability-inclusive hiring efforts recognized by SG Enable's Enabling Mark. The Enabling Mark assesses organizations' practices and outcomes in disability inclusion across six categories. Companies like Bolloré and Raffles Hotel are implementing inclusive hiring practices, such as customizing job roles and providing accommodations, to support employees with disabilities. Deutsche Bank, which started hiring people with disabilities in 1997, believes diversity and inclusion are essential for attracting top talent and promoting sustainable employment.

site_title: Neste to start Singapore sustainable aviation fuel plant by Q1 2023
summary: Finland's Neste plans to start producing sustainable aviation fuel (SAF) in Singapore by Q1 2023, after the COVID-19 pandemic delayed its expansion project. The company aims to ramp up output to 1 million tonnes annually and has secured a mandate from Singapore Airlines to use blended SAF. Neste's executive vice president, Thorsten Lange, stated that discussions with Japan on sustainable jet fuel have been "very promising" and that the company is exploring options such as algae and power-to-liquids to widen its feedstock pool.

images.alt_text: Neste oil refinery in Finland. The company produces renewable fuels, mainly from waste and residues such as used cooking oil, animal fat from food industry waste, fish fat from fish processing waste and residues from vegetable oil processing.

site_title: Digital Chinese currency makes muted Games debut
summary: China's digital yuan, e-CNY, made a muted debut at the Beijing Winter Games, with only 3 forms of payment available: e-CNY, yuan currency, and Visa. Despite being promoted by the Chinese government, foreign visitors were largely unaware of its use, with many opting for cash or Visa. Chinese participants, however, were able to use e-CNY for purchases, with 2 million yuan in daily payments reported. The digital currency was mainly used by domestic users with software wallets, while foreign users relied on hardware wallets.

site_title: Singapore's move to streamline Covid-19 rules signals confidence in living with virus: observers
summary: Singapore has announced plans to streamline Covid-19 rules, scrapping safe-distancing rules in mask-on settings and simplifying border measures. The multi-ministry taskforce will reset restrictions into 5 key parameters, allowing for easier adjustments and relaxation of measures. Mandatory routine testing will be introduced for fewer sectors, and border measures will be simplified with easier re-entry for long-term pass holders. Observers see this as a step towards "living with Covid-19" as an endemic disease, with the measures expected to boost Singapore's reputation as a business hub and facilitate economic growth.

site_title: Special-purpose vehicle with Teo family group offers S$3.50 per share cash offer for Shinvest Holding
summary: A special-purpose vehicle affiliated with the Teo family group has made a voluntary conditional cash offer of S$3.50 per share to acquire all shares of Shinvest Holding. The offeror, which holds approximately 29% of Shinvest's issued shares, is led by managing director Teo Teck Leong and his nephews. The offer price represents a 12.9% premium over Shinvest's last traded price, and the offeror aims to increase its stake to over 50% to gain statutory control of the company.

site_title: Shimao seeks repayment extension on US$947m in trusts
summary: Shimao Group Holdings, a major Chinese property developer, is seeking to extend repayment on approximately $947 million of high-yield trust products over three years. The company has about 1.3 billion yuan (S$275.6 million) due this month and 4.7 billion yuan maturing between April and August. Shimao proposes repaying 25% in 2022, 35% in 2023, and the rest in 2024. This move comes as China's property industry faces a string of defaults and high borrowing costs for junk-rated dollar bonds.

site_title: Prime US Reit posts 0.9% rise in H2 DPU to US$0.0345
summary: Prime US Reit reported a 0.9% rise in second-half distribution per unit (DPU) to US$0.0345, driven by a 17% year-over-year increase in gross revenue from new acquisitions. The Reit's DPU for the full FY2021 fell 2.3% to US$0.0678. Leasing volume more than doubled to 282,199 square feet, with a positive rental reversion of 14.1%. The Reit's portfolio occupancy stood at 90.3% and its gearing was at 37.9%.

site_title: Europe: Stocks steady at open
summary: European stock markets steadied at the open on Wednesday, tracking developments in the Ukraine crisis. London's FTSE 100 index dipped 0.1%, while the eurozone's DAX and Paris CAC 40 indices gained 0.1% and 0.2%, respectively.

site_title: Singapore simplifies Covid-19 border measures; new VTLs with Hong Kong, Philippines, among others
summary: Singapore is simplifying its Covid-19 border measures, introducing changes effective February 21, including a shorter 7-day travel history period and standardized 7-day stay-home notice for arrivals. New Vaccinated Travel Lanes (VTLs) will be introduced with Hong Kong, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, and the UAE, starting February 25. The changes aim to focus on ensuring vaccinated travelers are fully vaccinated and boosted, rather than controlling imported cases. The goal is to eventually move to quarantine-free travel for all vaccinated travelers.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore resets safe-distancing rules, eliminating mask-on settings, as authorities seek to simplify Covid-19 restrictions. The country also streamlined border measures, restored VTL (Land) quotas, and introduced a "kill switch" for customers to freeze accounts in scams. Additionally, OCBC rolled out the feature, Sylvan Group invested US$140.5 million in local healthcare and pharmaceutical companies, and Funding Societies raised US$294 million in a Series C+ equity round. Full-time employment rates and pay for fresh grads improved compared to pre-Covid levels, and condo and HDB rents continued to rise in January.

site_title: BioNTech to ship mRNA vaccine factory kits to Africa
summary: BioNTech is shipping mRNA vaccine factory kits to Africa to ease disparities in global Covid-19 vaccine access. The company has partnered with Pfizer to develop the Comirnaty vaccine and plans to start vaccine production in mid-2022 at a facility in the African Union. The first container module is expected to arrive in the second half of 2022, with production expected to start about 12 months later. The factory, dubbed Biontainer, will require local infrastructure and quality control testing laboratories, with BioNTech staff initially running the facility before local partners take over.

site_title: VTL (Land) quota restored, measures for entry via Causeway streamlined
summary: Singapore will restore its Vaccinated Travel Lane (Land) quota, increasing it from 50% to 100%, effective February 22. The country will also streamline its border measures, allowing travellers to enter via the Causeway with only pre-departure and on-arrival tests. This move comes as the risk of imported infections affecting local cases is deemed low.

site_title: Shopify beats estimates for holiday-quarter revenue
summary: Shopify reported stronger-than-expected revenue for the holiday quarter, reaching US$1.38 billion, exceeding analyst estimates of US$1.33 billion. This represents a 40% year-over-year increase in revenue and a 31% rise in gross merchandise volume to US$54.1 billion. The company's strong performance is attributed to a boom in online shopping, driving demand for its e-commerce tools and services.

images.alt_text: Revenue was US$1.38 billion for the fourth quarter ended Dec 31, compared with US$977.7 million a year earlier.

site_title: Singapore stocks climb on Wednesday as Asia markets rebound; STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.5% on Wednesday, driven by a broader Asian market rebound as investors' fears over a possible Ukraine conflict subsided. The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 3,439.30. Gains were fueled by overnight news that Russia was withdrawing troops from the Ukraine border. Safe havens like the US dollar and gold declined, indicating reduced appetite for safety. Shares of Thai Beverage, ComfortDelGro, and Venture Corp were top gainers, while Mapletree Commercial Trust was the only loser.

site_title: Singapore must do all it can to maintain status as global events hub
summary: Singapore's international events calendar is reviving, boosting the economy after the pandemic. The biennial Singapore Airshow, Formula One grand prix, and various trade shows are returning, including the Singapore International Water Week and World Cities Summit. This is expected to positively impact sectors such as tourism, hospitality, and services. The events are seen as a step towards maintaining Singapore's status as a global events hub.

site_title: SGX approves Roxy-Pacific's application to delist
summary: The Singapore Exchange Securities Trading (SGX-ST) has approved Roxy-Pacific Holdings' delisting application, allowing the residential property managing company to be delisted due to its free float falling below the 10% threshold. The offeror, TKL & Family, now holds over 90% of shares, having offered S$0.485 per share in cash to privatize the company. The delisting application was approved by the SGX-ST, considering the offeror's entitlement to a compulsory acquisition under the Companies Act.

site_title: Singapore resets safe-distancing rules; safe-management measures distilled into 5 parameters
summary: Singapore has reset its safe-distancing rules, replacing them with five key parameters starting from February 25. The five parameters include group sizes, mask-wearing, workplace requirements, safe distancing, and capacity limits. This change aims to simplify Covid-19 restrictions, making it easier for people to follow and remember the rules. The move comes after the rules became "unwieldy" over time, according to Finance Minister Lawrence Wong.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares closed higher on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 3.59 points to 1603.2. Volume was 3.38 billion lots worth RM2.86 billion, with 464 stocks gaining and losing the same amount.

site_title: Heineken to hike prices as inflation rises
summary: Heineken is raising beer prices due to rising inflation and supply chain bottlenecks, with the company citing soaring raw material and energy costs and "crazy" shipping rates as reasons. The company posted a net profit of $3.8 billion last year, with revenue rising 11.8% to $26.6 billion. Heineken aims to offset these costs with price hikes, which may dent demand for beer in households already strained by rising costs. The company delayed updating its 2023 guidance due to uncertainty about economic growth and inflation.

site_title: UK inflation overshoot adds pressure for big BOE rate hike
summary: UK inflation unexpectedly accelerated to 5.5% in January, a new 30-year high, surpassing forecasts and fueling bets on a larger-than-expected Bank of England interest-rate hike.
