site_title: Beware central bankers on the monetarist war path
summary: The world economy is experiencing a potential recession due to central banks' interest rate hikes, which could worsen the crisis. The current state is reminiscent of the post-World War I period in Europe, where high inflation and shortages occurred, and the economy took a long time to recover. With parallels to the 2020 pandemic years, governments' response to the crisis involved unconventional measures, such as printing money, to preserve lives and livelihoods. However, central banks are now preparing to tighten, driven by monetarists blaming pandemic measures for undue money creation, which may lead to substantial problems.

site_title: Singapore shares close flat on Tuesday amid mixed regional markets
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) ended unchanged on Tuesday, closing at 3,421.38, amid mixed regional markets. Regional indices in Japan, Hong Kong, and South Korea fell between 0.8% and 1%. Despite initial decline, the STI rose as Russia returned troops to bases, influencing caution over Russia-Ukraine tensions. Institutional investors continued to pour into the STI, with near-term technical support at 3,400 and resistance at 3,470. Wilmar International shares were the top performer, while DBS shares fell 1.8%.

site_title: Japan is searching for the secrets to healthy old age
summary: Japan aims to close the gap between life expectancy and healthy life expectancy, where the global average is nearly 10 years. The country's average life expectancy is 81.6 for men and 87.7 for women, but their healthy lives are on average nine years shorter for men and 12 years shorter for women. To address this, the Japanese government has made extending healthy life expectancy a central policy goal, with initiatives ranging from practical measures like step-counting apps to quixotic efforts like diabetes-themed poetry competitions. Experts emphasize the importance of broader social and environmental factors, such as jobs, social networks, and community engagement, in promoting healthy living.

site_title: Novak Djokovic has made it clear: He will not get a Covid vaccine
summary: Novak Djokovic stated he will not receive a COVID-19 vaccine, prioritizing personal freedom of choice over titles and competitions. This stance has sparked a global debate over vaccine mandates, with Djokovic previously being deported from Australia due to his vaccine status. Djokovic claims to have received a medical exemption, but immigration officials stated allowing him to compete would incite civil unrest. The tennis star pushed back against this characterization, denying involvement with anti-vaccine supporters.

site_title: MPs have a duty to be responsible when they speak in Parliament, says Indranee at the start of debate on COP report
summary: Singapore's Leader of the House Indranee Rajah emphasized the importance of MPs speaking responsibly in Parliament, citing the recent report on untruth spoken by former Workers' Party MP Raeesah Khan. The report recommended a fine for Khan and possible criminal charges for Leader of the Opposition Pritam Singh and WP chief Faisal Manap. Rajah stated that MPs must be truthful and substantiate their claims, and that the integrity of Parliament and public trust are at stake. The House will debate two motions related to the report, with Rajah seeking to safeguard democracy and ensure the confidence of Singaporeans in their elected representatives.

site_title: Glencore to pay out US$4b to investors after record profit
summary: Glencore, the world's largest commodity trader, reported its highest-ever profit of $21.3 billion, driven by record profits in its trading unit and core earnings. The company will pay out $3.4 billion in dividends and announce a $550 million share buyback. Glencore expects to resolve corruption probes this year, totaling $1.5 billion, and is positioning itself for a potential commodity supercycle. The company's debt has fallen to $6 billion, below its target range, under new CEO Gary Nagle. This is the first full-year earnings report from a major miner, signaling a strong earnings season for the sector.

site_title: Sylvan Group puts US$140.5m in 4 local healthcare and pharmaceutical companies
summary: The Sylvan Group has invested US$140.5 million in 4 Singapore healthcare and pharmaceutical companies through its maiden fund, Sylvan Growth Asia Growth Fund I. Co-founded by Chung Kyung-sun, the fund has raised approximately US$200 million from family and friends, with a target of US$400 million. The investment is backed by members of the Hyundai and Rockefeller families, UOB, and Hanwha Life Insurance.

site_title: LTA awards 2 contracts worth S$596m for Sengkang-Punggol LRT
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has awarded two contracts worth S$596 million for the Sengkang-Punggol Light Rail Transit (SPLRT) project. A S$439 million contract has been awarded to a consortium of Mitsubishi Corporation and others to procure 17 new 2-car trains, while a S$157 million contract has been awarded to Sato Kogyo to design and construct the expansion of the SPLRT depot, increasing its stabling capacity and maintenance facilities. The depot expansion is expected to complete by 2027, replacing existing 1-car trains with new 2-car trains.

site_title: More import sources, local output, stockpiling to manage Singapore food prices
summary: Singapore's government and supermarket operators are diversifying sources, localizing production, and stockpiling to manage food prices. The country has over 10 source countries for top vegetable and seafood imports, including China, Vietnam, and the US. Retailers like FairPrice Group offer discounts on staples and prices for hot coffee and tea have been held until the end of the year. The government also works with the Consumers Association of Singapore to promote consumer awareness and inform purchasing decisions, with the Sing dollar's appreciation against key import currencies expected to temper cost pressures.

site_title: APAC firms must bridge disconnect between ESG awareness and preparedness
summary: APAC firms face a disconnect between ESG awareness and preparedness, with 70% of companies lacking sufficient expertise to cope with increasing scrutiny of environmental, social, and governance (ESG) matters and sustainability. Despite growing understanding of ESG's importance, companies remain under-resourced and under-prepared, with 41% feeling pressure to improve their approach over the next 12 months. ESG and sustainability developments are also the most likely issues to harm companies, with 34% being investigated or expecting to be under probe in the next 12 months.

site_title: MOH working to bring in more non-mRNA Covid-19 vaccines, studying use of Novavax for under-18s
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Health (MOH) is exploring non-mRNA Covid-19 vaccine options, including Novavax, for those medically ineligible for mRNA vaccines. As of Feb 9, 1,000 individuals had completed their primary vaccine course with non-mRNA vaccines, which will expire by Feb 14. To maintain fully-vaccinated status, booster shots are required within 270 days. The Novavax vaccine has been recommended as a booster dose for those under 18, with recent data showing 80% efficacy against Covid-19 in adolescents aged 12-17.

site_title: Major institutions provided over US$1.5t to coal sector in 2019-2021: NGO group
summary: Major financial institutions have provided over $1.5 trillion in loans and underwriting to the coal sector from 2019 to 2021, despite net-zero pledges. The 28 non-governmental organizations found that banks from six countries - China, the US, Japan, India, Britain, and Canada - were responsible for 86% of global coal financing. Japanese banks Mizuho Financial and Mitsubishi UFJ Financial were among the largest lenders, while Chinese banks led the underwriting. The coal sector is a significant contributor to greenhouse gas emissions, with nearly half of global emissions attributed to it.

site_title: Cleaning services company LS 2 Holdings to raise S$5.6m in Catalist listing
summary: LS 2 Holdings, a Singapore-based environmental services provider, is launching an initial public offering (IPO) on the Catalist listing of the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to raise S$5.6 million. The company will sell 27.75 million shares at S$0.20 each, with estimated net proceeds of S$4.4 million. LS 2 plans to use the funds to expand its services, engage in strategic acquisitions, and invest in equipment and technology. The company has a network of subcontractors and aims to diversify its offerings, including horticultural services and infrastructure-level cleaning services.

site_title: BOJ keeps lid on 10-year yield while other tenors renew multi-year highs
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) maintained its lid on 10-year Japanese government bond yields, keeping them at 0.210%, as part of its yield curve control policy. This move came after the 10-year yield reached a six-year high of 0.230% earlier in the week. Meanwhile, yields on other tenors rose to fresh multi-year highs amid concerns over global inflation and monetary policy tightening, particularly in the US. The BOJ's actions are seen as efforts to maintain market stability amidst uncertainty surrounding the situation in Ukraine and other global economic factors.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close lower on fears over Ukraine, US rate hike
summary: Tokyo stocks closed lower on Tuesday, February 15, 2022, due to concerns over a potential Russian invasion of Ukraine and US monetary tightening. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.79% and the Topix index lost 0.83%. Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida spoke with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky, expressing grave concern. Japan's GDP data showed a 1.3% quarter-on-quarter growth, slightly lower than expected.

site_title: China's iron ore crackdown sparks rout as BHP sees price support
summary: China's iron ore prices plummeted 13% in Singapore following a crackdown by Beijing to curb prices, which have risen 60% since mid-November. Regulators warned iron ore companies against speculation and hoarding, while the official China Daily newspaper criticized "guerrilla war" by speculators. Despite this, BHP CEO Mike Henry believes the iron ore price will be determined by supply and demand, citing robust demand prospects and supply-side constraints, which may provide support to pricing.

site_title: Frasers Hospitality expands to Cambodia with launch of 3 properties
summary: Frasers Hospitality has entered the Cambodian market with the launch of three new properties: Capri by Fraser in Phnom Penh (2022), a second Capri by Fraser in the city centre (2024), and Fraser Residence Sen Sok (2026). The properties cater to transient business travellers and mid-level executives, with the first two targeting the city centre and the third on the north-west fringes. The move aims to capitalize on the expected boost from regional events and the return to travel, signaling long-term growth in the country and South-east Asia.

site_title: New Anti-Scam Command, stronger public education to combat rising scams: Desmond Tan
summary: Singapore strengthens enforcement and public education to combat rising scams, with the formation of an Anti-Scam Command and expansion of the Anti-Scam Centre. Minister of State for Home Affairs Desmond Tan emphasized the need for a whole-of-society effort, citing the difficulty in investigating and prosecuting overseas scams. The government will also increase public outreach and education, partnering with agencies and stakeholders to reach vulnerable groups, including seniors, students, and migrant workers.

site_title: Airbus, CAG and CAAS to study potential for hydrogen hub in Singapore
summary: Airbus, the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore (CAAS), and Changi Airport Group (CAG) have signed an agreement to study the potential for a hydrogen hub at Changi Airport by 2035. The 2-year feasibility study aims to identify the necessary infrastructure and ecosystem for the deployment of zero-emission aircraft based on hydrogen fuel. Airbus believes the technology is mature and ready for adoption, with the goal of preparing for the arrival of hydrogen fuel at the airport by 2035. The collaboration comes as Singapore plans to develop a sustainable air hub blueprint by early 2023.

site_title: Electronics marketplace Reebelo secures US$20m to fund global expansion
summary: Reebelo, a Singapore-based refurbished electronics marketplace, has secured US$20 million in a Series A funding round led by venture capital firms Cathay Innovation and June Fund. The funding round also included investors such as FJ Labs, Kream, and Lazada's co-founder Maximilian Bittner. Founded in 2019, Reebelo aims to expand globally by selling pre-owned electronic devices at affordable prices. The funding will support the company's growth plans.

images.alt_text: Rebeelo's co-founders: chief executive officer Philip Franta (left) and chief product officer Fabien Rastouil (right)

site_title: PropertyGuru expects to list in New York by Q1, says CEO
summary: PropertyGuru, a real estate marketplace, expects to list on the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) by Q1 2022, despite waning investor interest in SPACs. The company's CEO, Hari Krishnan, stated that the listing will position the company for post-pandemic growth, driven by a strong market position, rising property prices, and solid agent and consumer confidence. PropertyGuru recorded a 17.9% revenue growth in the first half of 2021, and its rival 99 Group is in talks to be acquired by Carousell ahead of a potential public listing.

site_title: What follows one of the worst Januarys in history?
summary: The S&P 500 is on track for one of its worst January performances since 1929, falling nearly 9% at its lows for the month. Historically, six of the 10 weak January episodes coincided with a US recession, and in 9 of the 10 years, the Fed tightened monetary policy. However, with no recession expected in 2022, the Fed's sharp pivot since the third quarter of 2021 has contributed to market repricing. Despite this, 1977 and 1978 periods, where the market rebounded in February to December and closed above the end-January level, offer a contrast to the current environment, with investors potentially benefiting from 13-15% earnings growth in 2022.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end at 2 1/2-week low on Ukraine crisis
summary: South Korean stocks closed at a 2 1/2-week low on February 15, 2022, due to concerns over a potential Russian invasion of Ukraine and cautious interest rate hikes by the US Federal Reserve. The Kospi index fell 1.03% to 2,676.54, its lowest level since January 28. The Korean won weakened on safe-haven asset demand, while the benchmark bond yield declined.

site_title: PBOC pumps in more liquidity to shore up economic growth
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), has injected 100 billion yuan into the banking system via policy loans for a second straight month to support its slowing economy. The benchmark stock index rose 0.9%, outperforming regional equities. The move aims to keep liquidity conditions ample and market rates low to support credit demand, with economists predicting further policy actions, including rate cuts and reserve requirement ratio reductions. Despite the easing stance, the PBOC's decision to hold interest rates steady may limit its room for further easing later this year.

site_title: Thai baht reverses losses to claim title as emerging Asia haven
summary: Thailand's baht has reversed losses to become the top-performing currency in emerging Asia, driven by optimism over its tourism sector and a quarantine-free visa program. The currency has climbed 3% versus the greenback this year, surpassing regional peers. Thailand's central bank is reassured by the baht's strength, which is expected to continue, with forecasts predicting a rise to 32.1 by year-end. The government expects 200,000 to 300,000 travelers to take advantage of the visa program, a significant boost to the country's tourism industry.

site_title: Companies urged to sign up for SMS registry, restrain use of SMS
summary: Singapore's Minister for Communications and Information Josephine Teo urged companies to sign up for the pilot SMS Sender ID protection registry to prevent scams, following recent incidents where scammers impersonated OCBC using SMS to trick customers into providing login credentials. The registry requires companies to register their alphanumeric sender IDs, which will prevent spoofed SMSes from being delivered. Teo also advised companies to use more restraint when transmitting sensitive information via SMS, as the system is not designed for secure communications.

site_title: Construction firms to lose some relief measures amid green shoots for sector
summary: Singapore's government will not extend relief measures for construction firms that cannot perform their contracts, but is reviewing measures for co-sharing of cost increases attributed to foreign work permit holder salaries. The measures, initially set to expire in Q1 2022, were meant to be temporary, and firms must partner each other for long-term sustainability. Construction output is nearing pre-Covid levels, with about 2,200 firms closing in 2021, comparable to average annual closures between 2018 and 2020.

site_title: Chinese developer Grandjoy gets 10b yuan facility to fund M&A
summary: State-owned Chinese developer Grandjoy Holdings Group has secured a 10 billion yuan (S$2.1 billion) facility from China Merchants Bank to fund acquisitions in the country's real estate sector. This comes as Beijing steps up efforts to stabilize and control the crisis-hit sector, which accounts for a quarter of its economy. The facility will support Grandjoy's acquisitions through loans, funds, and other financing products, aiming to support a stable housing market and promote virtuous cycle development.

site_title: Volocopter aims to have electric air taxis in Singapore in 2024
summary: Volocopter plans to launch electric air taxi services in Singapore by 2024, with a fleet of 10-20 air taxis operating around Marina Bay and Sentosa. The company is also exploring opportunities in Indonesia and Malaysia, and has set up maintenance operations in Singapore. Volocopter expects to increase its staff to 500 by 2030 to support its Asian expansion. The company has raised €322 million in funding and is seeking regulatory approval to operate in the US, with plans to provide parcel delivery services using drones in China.

site_title: Brokers' take: Phillip Securities upgrades UG Healthcare to 'buy'; RHB raises TP
summary: Phillip Securities upgraded UG Healthcare to 'buy' from 'accumulate' with a target price of S$0.32, while RHB raised its target price to S$0.29. The upgrade comes after UG Healthcare posted a net profit of S$21.2 million in H1 FY2022, despite lower ASP and production volumes. Analysts believe glove prices will decline at a slower pace and UG Healthcare's valuations are turning more attractive due to its pricing power and resilient margins.

site_title: Big Bitcoin miners aren't immune to the need for cash
summary: Two major Bitcoin miners, Marathon Digital Holdings and Hut 8 Mining, have filed with the SEC to sell company stock for cash amid a 38% drop in Bitcoin prices. The move aims to stay flexible and potentially raise funds for operations. Marathon can sell up to $750 million in shares, while Hut 8 can sell up to $65 million. This decision comes as cash concerns weigh on the industry, with some miners choosing to sell Bitcoin holdings to invest in equipment or stay afloat.

site_title: Banks, customers to share scam losses; framework to seek views: Wong
summary: Singapore's Deputy Finance Minister Lawrence Wong proposes a framework to share scam losses between banks and customers, with institutions bearing an appropriate share of losses. The framework aims to balance compensation for customers with the need to deter vigilance. Banks are adopting new technologies to bolster digital security, including artificial intelligence and machine learning to detect suspicious transactions. The authorities are also exploring measures to enable customers to freeze their accounts and expand the use of biometric technology for authentication.

site_title: Hong Kong has 'no plans whatsoever' for full lockdown, Carrie Lam says
summary: Hong Kong's Chief Executive Carrie Lam said the city has no plans for a full lockdown to combat the Omicron outbreak, despite its capacity being overwhelmed. Lam announced the city will continue with district-based lockdowns to launch targeted Covid testing blitzes. Hong Kong is searching for more hotels to use as isolation facilities and hopes to procure around 10,000 rooms. The city is grappling with its worst daily Covid caseloads and is challenging its strict Covid Zero approach due to low vaccination rates among the elderly.

site_title: Didi to cut up to 20% of jobs before Hong Kong listing: sources
summary: Chinese ride-hailing giant Didi Global plans to reduce its overall headcount by up to 20% ahead of its Hong Kong listing, affecting most of its core businesses. Ridehailing staff reductions may reach 15%, while drivers will not be affected. The company aims to reduce expenses and address concerns over data exposure. Didi has already seen a 70% drop in shares since its US$4.4 billion IPO and faces penalties from a cybersecurity probe. The Hong Kong listing is part of efforts to allay regulatory concerns and expand its presence outside China.

site_title: Indonesian fashion brand aggregator Grow Commerce bags US$7m from AC Ventures, East Ventures
summary: Indonesian fashion brand aggregator Grow Commerce secured US$7 million in seed funding from AC Ventures, East Ventures, and Irongrey. The funding will be used to acquire more brands, expanding its portfolio to 6 brands generating US$20 million in annual revenue. Founded in 2013, Grow transforms underperforming brands, such as Sorabel, into profitable lifestyle brands. The company aims to further expand its presence across online marketplaces and physical stores.

site_title: China greenlights Audi-FAW's US$3.3b electric vehicle venture
summary: China has approved Audi and its Chinese partner FAW Group's US$3.3 billion electric vehicle joint venture plant in Changchun city, northeastern province of Jilin. The plant will start production in December 2024 with a capacity of 150,000 cars per year and will produce three electric models, including Audi's e-tron SUV. The venture will invest 20.9 billion yuan (S$4.4 billion) and construction is planned to start in April 2022. This approval marks an important step in Audi's electrification strategy in China.

site_title: 'Life-changing' or scam? Axie Infinity helps Philippines' poor earn
summary: Axie Infinity, a blockchain-based game, has helped the Philippines' poor earn cryptocurrency, with players like Dominic Lumabi, who supports his family during the pandemic. The game exploded in popularity in developing nations as Covid-19 destroyed jobs. Sky Mavis, the game's creators, claim it's a revolutionary step towards the future of the internet, providing a life-changing income for players. However, the authenticity of the game's income-generating capabilities remains uncertain, raising questions about its legitimacy as a "life-changing" opportunity or a potential scam.

site_title: Accountants drop Trump, say records can't be relied upon
summary: Donald Trump's longtime accountants, Mazars, have dropped him as a client, citing a decade's worth of financial statements as unreliable. The decision was made after New York state attorney general Letitia James's office found "significant evidence" of misleading business practices, including fraudulent asset valuations. Mazars stated that its advice to Trump to no longer rely on the financial statements was appropriate, but it cannot provide new work product due to the investigation. This move could complicate Trump's potential second White House run.

site_title: Musk donated over US$5.7b in Tesla shares to charity in November
summary: Elon Musk donated 5 million shares of Tesla to a charity between November 19 and 29, valued at $5.7 billion, according to a US Securities and Exchange Commission filing. This donation came after Musk sold $16.4 billion worth of shares, including 10% of his Tesla stake, to pay taxes and potentially avoid capital gains tax. Musk's philanthropic efforts have been discussed, with his foundation having over $200 million in assets and him previously tweeting about donating $6 billion to the World Food Programme to solve world hunger.

site_title: UBS comes on board as new DLC issuer on SGX, to list 10 new DLCs
summary: UBS has become the second bank in Singapore to issue daily leverage certificates (DLCs) on the Singapore Exchange (SGX), listing 10 new DLCs offering up to 7 times daily leverage on 5 top-traded indices. Starting February 15, these DLCs will allow qualified investors to gain exposure to Tencent, Alibaba, Meituan, BYD, and the Hang Seng Index with less capital. The move comes as the market environment remains volatile, with UBS citing a "good time" to launch the products.

site_title: Singapore to unveil sustainable air hub blueprint in early 2023: Iswaran
summary: Singapore's aviation authority is developing a blueprint to guide its efforts in creating a sustainable air hub, with a focus on airports, airlines, and air traffic management. The blueprint, expected to be ready by early 2023, aims to outline medium-term targets for 2030 and long-term goals for 2050. A 20-member international advisory panel, including industry leaders and experts, will support the development of the blueprint. The plan is crucial as global aviation is expected to increase emissions once air travel resumes its pre-pandemic trajectory, with Singapore aiming to contribute to the decarbonization of aviation.

site_title: New private home sales up 3.5% in January as primary market shows resilience amid few launches
summary: Singapore's private home sales rose 3.5% in January to 673 units, the highest since 2014, despite fewer launches. This steady performance is attributed to the resilience of the primary market, with popular projects like Belgravia Ace and Normanton Park driving sales. The introduction of new cooling measures has not severely impacted demand, with buyers primarily focusing on upgrading or right-sizing. Experts expect a slow start to the year, but anticipate resales data to show a rebound after the Chinese New Year period, with new sales potentially reaching 9,000-10,000 units in 2022.

site_title: Brokers' take: Possible Garena Free Fire ban in India a Sea 'buying opportunity', say analysts
summary: Analysts at CGS-CIMB and Citi believe Sea's Garena-produced game Free Fire's removal from India's app stores due to security concerns over its "Chinese origin" presents a "buying opportunity" for the company, despite potential challenges in near-term visibility. Sea's e-commerce and gaming segments are expected to continue growing, with Shopee poised for further take rate growth and SeaBank's growth potential underappreciated. The removal of Free Fire from India is expected to have a minimal impact on Sea's revenue but could lead to a "knee-jerk reaction" in the stock price.

site_title: AMD closes record chip industry deal with estimated US$50b purchase of Xilinx
summary: AMD has finalized the US$50 billion purchase of Xilinx, a record chip industry deal, following all necessary regulatory approvals. The acquisition gives AMD an edge in the data centre market and expands its presence in key markets such as 5G communications, automotive, and aerospace. AMD CEO Lisa Su expects the deal to generate US$300 million in cost savings, solidifying the company's position in the data centre chip market and intensifying its battle with Intel.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower as energy stocks, miners drag
summary: Australian shares fell 0.5% to 7,206.90, their lowest close since Feb 11, due to energy firms and miners being impacted by low oil prices and weak iron ore prices. Despite this, technology stocks helped limit losses. General sentiment remains weak and uncertain, according to CEO Mathan Somasundaram.

site_title: Lim Kok Thay among suitors for Genting's unfinished Global Dream cruise ship
summary: Billionaire Lim Kok Thay is among several investors interested in purchasing the unfinished Global Dream mega luxury liner, which was under construction at MV Werften in Germany. The ship, set to be the world's biggest vessel by passenger capacity, was 72% complete when MV Werften filed for provisional insolvency in January. A deal could come together, but is unlikely before next month due to the complex case. Lim, Genting Hong Kong's CEO, has expressed interest in purchasing the ship, but the insolvency administrator hopes to find a better solution.

site_title: Brokers' take: Analysts raise targets on DBS after strong results showing
summary: DBS Group Holdings reported its fourth quarter and full year results, with net profit of S$1.4 billion and S$6.8 billion respectively. Several brokerages, including RHB, Maybank Securities, Jefferies, and CGS-CIMB, have raised their price targets on the bank, citing sustained business momentum, improved net interest margins, and lower provisions. Analysts expect DBS to benefit from rising interest rates and economic re-opening, with ROE projected to exceed 13% by FY2023. The bank's shares closed at S$36.53 on Tuesday, down 1.8% or S$0.67.

site_title: iFast to continue working on scale, quality of platforms across markets for B2B and B2C segments: CEO
summary: iFast Corporation, a fintech company, aims to expand its business in both B2B and B2C segments over the next four years. CEO Lim Chung Chun emphasized the need for scalability, capital efficiency, and recurring revenue to drive growth. The company will focus on adding capabilities to its offerings, improving user stickiness, and investing in adjacent services like wealth management. iFast recently acquired a majority stake in a UK bank, which is expected to achieve profitability in 2024. The company expects robust growth in revenue and profitability between 2021 and 2025, with Hong Kong's ePension division driving growth.

site_title: Australian nurses strike over Covid-spurred staff shortages, pay conditions
summary: Thousands of nurses in New South Wales, Australia walked off the job for the first time in nearly a decade to begin a 24-hour strike over staff shortages and pay conditions. The strike, which will include staff from over 150 hospitals, follows failed talks with the government. Nurses sought a pay rise of over 2.5% and better nurse-to-patient ratios, with the strike described as "unfortunate" and "disappointing" by the state's health minister. The strike comes amid a decline in new Covid-19 cases and hospital admissions.

site_title: Hollywood actor jailed for US$650m movie ponzi scheme
summary: US actor Zachary Horwitz, 35, was jailed for 20 years for a $650 million Hollywood Ponzi scheme. He created fake contracts to trick investors into handing over money, claiming to buy foreign film distribution rights for Netflix and HBO. Horwitz spent the funds on luxury items and used new investors' money to repay old ones, losing over $230 million. He admitted security fraud in October and was ordered to repay the victims. Horwitz, who acted in small-time horror films, portrayed himself as a Hollywood success story to deceive investors.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Tuesday's open; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.1% at the open on Tuesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3,423.94 points. Gainers outnumbered losers 71 to 35, driven by Thai Beverage, Singtel, and Genting Singapore, which posted earnings statements or announcements on Monday. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.5% on Wall Street, while European shares hit their 20-day low due to concerns over Russia and Ukraine.

site_title: Intel's Mobileye, partners to launch self-driving shuttles in US in 2024
summary: Intel's Mobileye unit, in partnership with Benteler EV Systems and Beep, plans to launch self-driving electric shuttle vehicles in the US in 2024. The shuttles, with 12-14 seats, will operate in "geo-fenced areas" with speed limits of 35mph or less. The companies aim to deploy 200-15,000 vehicles globally, with regulatory approvals pending. Mobileye plans to prove its self-driving system is safer than human drivers, and the shuttles will help address urban issues like emissions and congestion. This marks a step towards scaling up automated driving systems beyond taxis and delivery vehicles.

site_title: Indonesian fintech Akulaku bags US$100m from Siam Commercial Bank
summary: Indonesian fintech company Akulaku secured a US$100 million strategic investment from Thailand's Siam Commercial Bank, following its previously undisclosed US$125 million fundraise. The deal gives Akulaku a boost to its already record levels of fintech funding in South-east Asia. Founded in 2016, Akulaku operates a "buy now, pay later" and consumer financing platform in Indonesia, disbursing over US$2.2 billion of credit in 2021 to over 6 million users.

site_title: 'Don't be Google': The rise of privacy focused startups
summary: A growing number of pro-privacy startups are emerging to challenge Google Analytics, a product used by over half of the world's websites. These startups aim to provide a more transparent and user-friendly alternative, leveraging GDPR regulations to control personal data. Despite Google's dominance, the smaller players see an opportunity to inject fairness and choice into the market, with some reporting significant growth in subscriptions. The startups' goal is to create a more private and equitable internet, with prices that reflect the value of their services rather than relying on free data.

site_title: Australia: Shares track Wall Street lower amid Ukraine crisis
summary: Australia's shares fell 0.6% on Tuesday, tracking a downbeat Wall Street session amid heightened Ukraine-Russia tensions. The S&P/ASX 200 index closed at 7,203.9 points. Gains in BHP Group, which declared a record interim dividend, provided a floor to the benchmark. Energy stocks were the top losers, while gold stocks rose nearly 2% due to safe-haven demand. The mining index lifted 1.8% to its highest level in nearly four weeks.

site_title: Asia-Pacific coal prices to moderate as Indonesia's export ban lifts: Fitch
summary: Asia-Pacific coal prices are expected to moderate in 2022 as Indonesia lifts its coal export ban, according to Fitch. The ban, which lasted from January 2022, led to a rebound in thermal coal prices but will be short-lived. Indonesia's 4,200kcal index has moderated from its all-time high of above $100/tonne in October 2021, currently trading above $60/tonne. The lifting of the ban highlights regulatory uncertainty for the sector, but domestic supply is expected to rise gradually in 2022 due to increased production in China, India, and Japan.

site_title: Cryptocurrencies akin to Ponzi schemes, says RBI deputy
summary: RBI deputy governor T Rabi Sankar has stated that cryptocurrencies are akin to Ponzi schemes and may be worse, calling for a ban to avoid financial and macroeconomic instability. He argued that cryptocurrencies cannot be regulated due to their lack of intrinsic value and underlying cash flows. Sankar cited the high volume of illicit transactions involving cryptocurrencies, totaling US$14 billion last year, and noted that banning private cryptocurrencies would not hinder the development of blockchain technology.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, Far East Hospitality Trust, Lendlease Reit, ThaiBev
summary: Singtel reported a 23.8% rise in net profit to S$734 million for its third quarter ended Dec 31, 2021. Far East Hospitality Trust increased its distribution per stapled security by 10.9% to S$0.0153 for H2 FY2021, while its gross revenue rose 6.9% to S$41.7 million.

site_title: ProfilePrint secures Series A round; investors include Louis Dreyfus Co and Olam
summary: ProfilePrint, a startup that uses artificial intelligence to grade food ingredients, has secured a Series A round of funding from investors including Louis Dreyfus Co, Olam, and Greenwillow Capital. The funding aims to enhance operational efficiency and remove subjectivity in the supply chain. ProfilePrint's platform uses a buyer's taste model to determine the grading of coffee beans, reducing a tedious and time-consuming process. The startup has seen significant growth, securing 4 times more clients in the past year and deploying its solutions globally despite the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares down at beginning of trade
summary: Hong Kong stocks began trading on a down note, extending losses for a third consecutive day, amid concerns over a possible Russian invasion of Ukraine. The Hang Seng Index dropped 0.40% to 24,458.50, while the Shanghai Composite Index and Shenzhen Composite Index also declined marginally. The losses were attributed to investor anxiety over the geopolitical tensions.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 6.29 points, or 0.12%, to 1,590.13 on Tuesday, driven by a gain of 118 stocks over 60 losers. Volume was 35.71 million lots worth RM14.48 million.

site_title: Temasek adds stakes in Robinhood, other consumer-focused companies
summary: Temasek Holdings, a Singapore state investor, added stakes in consumer-focused companies such as Grab Holdings, Robinhood Markets, and Rent the Runway, while selling shares in Uber Technologies, Coinbase Global, and Tencent Music Entertainment Group. The fund also added positions in Toast and Draft Kings, with a focus on sustainability and green initiatives.

site_title: Reserve Bank of Australia has goals in sight, just waiting on wages
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) is closer to meeting its economic goals, but is being cautious on interest rate hikes due to lagging wage growth. The RBA's February meeting minutes revealed the Board wants to see sustained inflation and wage growth before adjusting interest rates. The central bank is prepared to be patient, monitoring inflation factors and waiting for wage growth to respond before making a decision. This approach reflects the RBA's focus on balancing inflation control with economic growth.

site_title: Gold near 3-month high as Ukraine crisis lifts safe-haven appeal
summary: Gold prices reached a 3-month high on Tuesday as investors sought safe-haven assets amid heightened tensions between Russia and the West over Ukraine. Spot gold rose 0.1% to $1,871.52 per ounce, while US gold futures edged 0.2% higher. The move followed a decline in world shares and oil prices, which jumped to 7-year highs. The easing of US Treasury yields also supported bullion, as investors sought a hedge against geopolitical conflicts.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open slightly higher after GDP data
summary: Tokyo stocks opened slightly higher on Tuesday, following positive GDP data, as investors navigated fears of a potential Russia-Ukraine invasion and US monetary tightening. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.10% to 27,107.34, while the Topix index increased 0.02% to 1,930.97.

site_title: DBS digital bourse logs S$1.1b in FY2021 trading value
summary: DBS Digital Exchange recorded S$1.1 billion in trading volume for FY2021, with a significant increase in the fourth quarter. The exchange expanded its operating hours in August last year, contributing to the growth. As of Dec 31, 2021, digital assets under custody were over S$800 million. DBS plans to expand its offerings to retail investors by the end of the year, with a focus on adapting the platform for suitability and protection against fraud. The exchange aims to list more digital payment tokens and security token offerings for trading, contributing to the growth of the digital assets market in Singapore.

site_title: Intudo leads US$4m investment in Indonesian shipping platform Andalin
summary: Indonesian digital freight forwarder Andalin has secured a US$4 million investment led by Intudo Ventures, with participation from other strategic investors. The funding will help Andalin double down on its Indonesia market presence, expand its coverage in the East Indonesia region, and launch a trading service platform. The company aims to capitalize on the growing Indonesian logistics market, valued at US$81.3 billion in 2020 and expected to reach US$138.04 billion by 2026. Andalin plans to expand its trade financing and cargo insurance offerings, offering clients a 15-20% reduction in cross-border shipping costs.

site_title: Far East Hospitality Trust H2 DPS climbs 10.9% as serviced residences performed above fixed rent
summary: Far East Hospitality Trust (FEHT) reported a 10.9% increase in second-half distributable per stapled security (DPS) to S$0.0153, driven by its serviced residences segment performing above fixed rent. The group's gross revenue rose 6.9% to S$41.7 million, while net property income increased 16.1% to S$39 million. Despite hotel segment declines, FEHT's manager attributes the strong performance to a shift towards higher-rated leisure travelers and corporate businesses. The trust's DPS for the full year rose 9.1% to S$0.0263.

site_title: Intel nears US$6b deal to buy Tower Semiconductor: source
summary: Intel is close to buying Israeli firm Tower Semiconductor for approximately US$6 billion, a deal that could be announced as soon as this week. The purchase would deepen Intel's presence in contract chip manufacturing, a space dominated by Taiwan-based TSMC, and help the US company reduce its reliance on Asian manufacturing hubs. Tower Semiconductor specializes in analog chips used in various industries, including automotive, mobile, and medical sectors. The deal comes as Intel invests up to US$100 billion to build the world's largest chip-making complex in Ohio.

site_title: Resale condo prices rise for 18th straight month, volumes down 23.8%: SRX, 99.co
summary: Resale condo prices in Singapore rose for the 18th consecutive month in January 2022, with a 0.4% monthly increase and 9.2% year-on-year growth. Volumes fell 23.8% to 1,118 units resold, the fifth consecutive month of decline. Cooling measures introduced in mid-December may have contributed to the decrease in demand. Despite this, resale prices continued to rise, with the outside central region seeing the highest increase at 0.5%. Experts attribute the rise in prices to sellers having stronger bargaining power due to a better financial position and limited new supply.

site_title: Malaysia Airlines' parent to lease 25 737 MAX jets from Air Lease
summary: Malaysia Airlines' parent, Malaysia Aviation Group (MAG), has leased 25 Boeing 737 MAX jets from Air Lease, with deliveries set to take place between early 2023 and 2026. The deal is tied to restructured terms of MAG's existing order book with Boeing. This marks a significant return for the airline, which had previously ordered 25 737 MAX jets that were grounded worldwide after two crashes in 2018 and 2019. MAG also operates 6 Airbus A350-900 planes on long-term leases with Air Lease.

site_title: 3M expects to sell fewer Covid-19 masks this year
summary: US manufacturer 3M expects to sell fewer Covid-19 masks this year due to a sharp decline in demand, echoing warnings from other companies like Pfizer and CVS. The decline in Covid-related respirator demand is forecast to weigh on overall sales growth and dampen earnings. 3M's warning comes after the company saw sales of medical masks surge during the pandemic, and follows similar predictions from other companies in the industry.

site_title: Chasen reports 23% rise in Q3 profit on higher revenue
summary: Chasen Holdings, a logistics group, reported a 23% increase in Q3 net profit after tax to S$583,000, driven by higher revenue from all business segments. Revenue rose 25% to S$43.4 million, while gross profit margin declined 3 percentage points to 15.6% due to manpower and power shortages in China. The company expects growth in its specialist relocation, third-party logistics, and technical segments, with a new project in China and opportunities in Singapore.

site_title: One killed, many injured in commuter train collision near Munich
summary: A commuter train collision near Munich, Germany, resulted in one fatality and over 10 injuries. The crash occurred at 4:40 pm local time when two trains slammed into each other head-on near the S-Bahn station of Ebenhausen-Schaeftlarn. Rescue workers and police were at the scene, with a train driver reportedly trapped in the wreckage. The stretch of track has been closed, and rail replacement bus services are running. The cause of the crash is still under investigation.

site_title: Lendlease Reit to acquire remaining interest in Jem mall at S$2.08b agreed property value
summary: Lendlease Global Commercial Reit (LReit) has agreed to acquire the remaining interest in Jem mall in Singapore for S$2.079 billion, a 0.3% discount to its appraised value. The deal will increase LReit's total portfolio net lettable area by 70% to around 2.2 million square feet and lift its 2021 financial year net property income to S$147.8 million, resulting in a net property income yield of 4.2%. The acquisition is expected to provide 10.5% distribution per unit (DPU) accretion and is expected to be completed by May 15 this year.

site_title: Singtel Q3 profit rises 23.8% on gains from Australia tower asset disposal
summary: Singtel reported a 23.8% rise in net profit to S$734 million for its third quarter ended Dec 31, 2021, driven by a net exceptional gain from the disposal of its 70% stake in Australia Tower Network. Revenue declined 7.7% to S$3.91 billion, mainly due to lower NBN migration revenue and equipment sales. The company's enterprise segment saw a 3.1% fall in operating revenue, while its ICT revenue remained stable. Post-tax contributions from regional associates increased 13% to S$332 million, boosted by a profit turnaround at Airtel.

site_title: US, UK leaders agree 'window for diplomacy' remains over Ukraine
summary: US and UK leaders agree a "crucial window for diplomacy" remains over the Ukraine crisis, with British Prime Minister Boris Johnson and US President Joe Biden stressing the need for Russia to step back from threats towards Ukraine. They emphasized Western allies must remain united, with potential sanctions against Russia if aggression escalates. The leaders also urged European countries to reduce dependence on Russian gas, a move that would strike at Russia's strategic interests.

site_title: Resident employed households' median monthly work income surpasses pre-Covid levels
summary: The median monthly work income for resident employed households in Singapore surpassed pre-Covid-19 levels in 2021, with a 3.6% nominal increase to S$9,520. This translates to a 1.5% real-term rise and a 4.9% nominal increase in household income per member. Household income inequality fell in 2021, with a Gini coefficient of 0.444, the second lowest since 2000, after accounting for government transfers and taxes.

images.alt_text: From 2016 to 2021, the median monthly household income for resident employed households increased by 4.2 per cent cumulatively, which translates to an annual 0.8 per cent increase in real terms.

site_title: Japan's economy rebounds on solid consumption, Omicron clouds outlook
summary: Japan's economy rebounded 5.4% in Q4 2021, driven by a 2.7% rise in private consumption, exceeding market forecasts. However, rising raw material costs and Omicron variant infections cloud the outlook, with some analysts predicting a contraction in the current quarter due to supply chain disruptions and rising Covid-19 cases. The government's decision to end state of emergency curbs in October last year also contributed to the rebound, but the recent spike in Omicron cases has dampened consumption and production.

site_title: Oil hits 7-year highs as market fears Russian attack on Ukraine imminent
summary: Oil prices surged over 2% on Monday, reaching a 7-year high, amid fears of an imminent Russian attack on Ukraine. Brent crude rose to $96.48 per barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude rose to $95.46 per barrel. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy called for a "day of unity" on Feb 16, which some Western media have cited as a possible start of a Russian invasion. The US State Department said it saw no signs of de-escalation of Russian forces on the Ukraine border, and the US is relocating its embassy operations from Kyiv to Lviv.

site_title: Automakers resume production after Canada bridge protest ends
summary: Automakers have resumed production after a week-long disruption caused by trucker-led protests in Canada that blocked the Ambassador Bridge, a key border crossing with the US. The bridge, which connects Windsor, Canada to Detroit, was cleared of protesters on Sunday, allowing General Motors, Stellantis, and Toyota to resume operations. While some issues remain, General Motors and Stellantis reported no issues, while Toyota said operations are improving daily. Honda reported normal operations on the US side of the border.

site_title: Digital services, autonomous tech and sustainability 3 key opportunities as aviation recovers: Tan See Leng
summary: Second Minister for Trade and Industry Tan See Leng emphasized the importance of technology, innovation, and workforce transformation in the aerospace sector's recovery from the Covid-19 pandemic. He highlighted digital services, autonomous technologies, and sustainability as key opportunities, including leveraging data for optimization, enhancing pilot decision-making, and exploring alternative energy systems. The Singapore government will provide support for workforce transformation, and the country remains Asia's leading aerospace hub, contributing to 10% of global MRO output.

site_title: Europe: Shares sink as Russia-Ukraine jitters rattle market
summary: European shares plummeted 1.8% to their lowest level in 20 days, with travel and banking sectors leading the decline due to Russia-Ukraine tensions. Investors sought safe-havens like gold and government bonds amid warnings of a possible Russian invasion. Some European banks and airlines fell 4-6% as investors dumped riskier assets. The Stoxx 600 has fallen 5.5% this year, while the S&P 500 is down 7.5%.

site_title: Buffett's Berkshire bought Activision Blizzard before deal
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway acquired nearly 14.7 million Activision Blizzard shares before Microsoft's $68.7 billion deal to buy the company. This move suggests Berkshire remains resistant to buying stocks, despite being a net seller in 2021. Berkshire also added to its Chevron position and reduced its Bristol-Myers Squibb and Abbvie holdings. The company's cash holdings reached a record $149.2 billion as of September 2021. Berkshire is expected to disclose more about its investments on February 26.

images.alt_text: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Inc loaded up on shares in video game maker Activision Blizzard Inc ahead of Microsoft Corp's US$68.7 billion deal to buy the company, according to a regulatory filing.

site_title: Federal Reserve's credibility 'on the line' amid US inflation spike: official
summary: Federal Reserve President James Bullard says the central bank needs to accelerate interest rate increases to combat inflation, which jumped 7.5% in January, its largest increase since 1982. Bullard urges the Fed to "front load" its actions, raising the benchmark borrowing rate to 1% by July, but warns that policymakers must do so in a way that doesn't disrupt financial markets. The New York Fed's survey shows consumer inflation expectations have dropped for the first time since October 2020, but still remain above the Fed's 2% target.

images.alt_text: The Federal Reserve needs to accelerate the pace of interest rate increases to fight inflation, but can do so in a way that doesn't roil financial markets, St. Louis Fed President James Bullard said on Monday.

site_title: US: Wall Street peters out on Ukraine tensions, Federal Reserve fears
summary: US stocks declined on Monday as traders worried about a potential Russian invasion of Ukraine and the Federal Reserve's possible interest rate hike in March to combat inflation. The Dow Jones ended with slight losses, despite the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records. The Fed's comments fueled concerns, while the US and its allies vowed to impose tough sanctions on Russia.

site_title: A 'trip' to Hong Kong for Chinese New Year
summary: Hong Leong Foundation, the charity arm of Hong Leong Group Singapore, organized a virtual day-trip to Hong Kong for 130 elderly people aged 60-100 to celebrate Chinese New Year. The event, which took place on February 8, was broadcast live via Zoom and included an interactive tour with a local guide. The trip was part of the foundation's annual charity event, which included cash contributions of S$508,650 to 3,391 beneficiaries. This is the 10th year of the charity event, with a total of S$1.35 million donated in 2021.

site_title: In relief for retailers, Vietnam won't close factories amid Covid-19 surge
summary: Vietnam has decided not to close factories amid a surge in Covid-19 infections, reversing a policy that had hobbled global supply chains for Western retailers last year. The country has successfully vaccinated millions of factory workers, and the Omicron variant is proving less severe. Vietnam's factory workers, who earn on average $330 per month, are hoping to make up for earnings lost last year and expect smooth operations to continue, supporting the global supply chain and helping free up supply chain bottlenecks.

site_title: Stakes 'never been higher' in fight against global warming: UN official
summary: The UN's climate science chief, Hoesung Lee, stated that the stakes in the fight against global warming are higher than ever, as nearly 200 nations meet to finalize a report on climate impacts. The report, set to be released on February 28, warns of species extinction, ecosystem collapse, and deadly heat, with impacts already measurably worse due to rising temperatures. The report highlights the urgent need for adaptation and warns of extreme events and slow-onset disasters, emphasizing the need for vulnerable populations to prepare for devastating consequences.

site_title: Death beats marriage over quiet weekend at US box office
summary: Death on the Nile, directed by Kenneth Branagh, opened at No. 1 at the US box office with $12.8 million from 3,912 locations, while Marry Me, a Jennifer Lopez rom-com, took in $8 million from 3,642 locations. The film, based on Agatha Christie's novel, underperformed compared to its predecessor Murder on the Orient Express, which grossed $102 million domestically. The sequel's production budget was estimated at $90 million, and its quiet rollout and production issues may have contributed to its disappointing opening.

site_title: Newly-introduced omnibus Bill consolidates MAS's key supervisory powers
summary: Singapore has introduced an omnibus Bill that consolidates the Monetary Authority of Singapore's (MAS) key supervisory powers, primarily focusing on regulating virtual asset service providers (VASPs) for money laundering and terrorism financing risks. The bill aligns with the Financial Action Task Force's (FATF) enhanced standards and introduces general powers over VASPs, including licensing requirements and inspections. The bill also expands MAS's powers to impose requirements on technology risk management and provides statutory protection from liability for mediators and employees of approved dispute-resolution schemes.

site_title: A stock investor's playbook for new era of rising rates
summary: Major fund managers' survey in December predicted a central bank policy shift as the biggest risk for 2022, which ultimately occurred. Investors should focus on quality stocks with lower debt and stronger balance sheets, according to experts. This includes value stocks and companies with predictable earnings. The era of looking for returns in one market or sector may be over, and investors should consider alpha-based stock selection. Emerging markets and sectors like energy and financials are seen as potential safe havens, but companies must demonstrate resilient earnings in the face of rising interest rates.

site_title: Russian foreign minister urges diplomacy amid Ukraine crisis
summary: Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov urged President Vladimir Putin to continue diplomatic efforts to extract security guarantees from the West amid the Ukraine crisis. Despite the US offering concrete proposals, responses from the EU and Nato were deemed unsatisfactory. Lavrov signaled a reduced likelihood of imminent Russian military action, saying there are still chances for an agreement. He warned that Russia will not allow endless negotiations and will continue to seek a concrete reaction from each country.

site_title: BOJ intervenes to cap Japanese yields just as havens find favour
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) intervened to cap Japanese bond yields at 0.25% by offering to buy unlimited 10-year bonds at the same rate, despite benchmark yields slipping below 0.25% in the secondary market. The move was seen as a demonstration of the BOJ's commitment to its yield curve control policy, and was met with no take-up from investors. The BOJ aims to keep 10-year yields within a 0.25% range on either side of zero, with the potential to ramp up its operations if yields get closer to 0.25%.

site_title: US: Wall St slips at open on rate fears; Ukraine tensions ease slightly
summary: US stocks opened lower on Monday due to concerns over higher interest rates, falling 0.13% to 34,694.50 on the Dow Jones Industrial Average. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, 0.14% and 0.16% respectively. However, tensions over a possible Russian invasion of Ukraine eased slightly after comments from a Russian official.

site_title: What's turbocharging Carro and Carsome's funding fever?
summary: Carro and Carsome, Southeast Asia's used car platforms, have raised hundreds of millions in venture funding, valuing them at $1.7 billion and $1.2 billion, respectively. This influx of capital, led by Temasek-backed investors, is seen as a bullish sign for the industry, with potential for growth in Indonesia's vast used car market. However, analysts caution that the capital-intensive nature of operations and inventory risk may hinder profitability. Carro's CEO notes that the company aims to digitize the customer purchase journey, while competitors like Moladin also attract capital, highlighting the competitive landscape.

site_title: Serving community is part of the bank's DNA
summary: Standard Chartered Bank Singapore has partnered with various organizations to support Project 100=50, a monthly pop-up supermarket offering discounted groceries to underprivileged families and seniors. Since 2017, the bank has provided over 30 sessions, involving around 50 staff employees each time, to help beneficiaries save on daily necessities and maximize their savings. The initiative aims to empower beneficiaries to choose what they need, and the bank plans to expand to more locations and continue its partnership to benefit more low-income families.

site_title: Consider raising the income cap to allow more to buy HDB BTO flats
summary: Singapore's income ceiling for buying HDB BTO flats, currently S$14,000, may be raised to allow more citizens to purchase affordable housing. The ceiling has been raised three times in the last decade, with some speculating a possible increase to S$16,000 in 2023. Raising the ceiling could encourage couples to have children and start businesses, contributing to the national good. However, timing is crucial, as high subscription rates for recent BTO exercises may make it difficult to implement changes. Adjusting the income ceiling at fixed intervals based on household income could provide a more stable solution.

site_title: Reliance Jio to invest US$200 million in mobile startup Glance
summary: Reliance Jio is investing $200 million in mobile startup Glance, valuing the company at $1.7 billion. Glance, backed by Google and Peter Thiel's Mithril Capital, offers curated content and a short video platform, Roposo. The investment will help Glance expand globally and integrate its services into Jio's operating system. The deal is subject to regulatory approvals and conditions.

site_title: Do rising rents make Singapore homes ripe for investment?
summary: Rising rents in Singapore's housing market may not necessarily make buying homes for rental income a viable investment strategy. Despite bullish leasing demand, yields have fallen from 2.49% to 1.87% over the past decade, largely due to capital values appreciating while rents softened. Experts predict a slight yield expansion in 2022, but caution that investors may shift focus to capital appreciation over rental income. The new cooling measures may deter acquisitions of subsequent residential properties to earn rental income, but could also prompt some owners to lease their units instead.

site_title: Fernandes' big gamble to recast AirAsia Group
summary: AirAsia Group, Malaysia's largest low-cost carrier, has suffered a net loss of RM5.1 billion in 2020, a significant deterioration from RM316 million in 2019. The airline's financial woes are not unique, as the global airlines sector has been hit by the pandemic, with losses forecasted to top US$200 billion. The group's shares are under pressure after being classified as a Practice Note 17 (PN17) distressed firm by Bursa Malaysia, which could lead to delisting if not resolved. Despite efforts to restructure debt and diversify into digital travel and lifestyle businesses, the road to restoring financial health is uncertain, and Tony Fernandes' recovery efforts may be put on hold.

site_title: Changing hands
summary: Creative Technology warns it may miss its H2 revenue target, citing an operating loss similar to the first half. Meanwhile, London's Heathrow airport is considering higher fees for its £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detains an employee of Trafigura in a graft case worth 285 trillion rupiah. OCBC's incoming CEO, Tan Teck Long, is a former DBS veteran, and Helen Wong is retiring as OCBC CEO, with Long named as her successor. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and the People's Bank of China (PBOC) plan to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance, while Singapore stocks have seen a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: iFast Q4 net profit rises 5.5%; higher final dividend proposed
summary: iFast Corporation reported a 5.5% year-on-year increase in net profit for its Q4 2021, rising to S$7.2 million, driven by a 13.9% growth in revenue to S$54.6 million. The company also proposed a 40% increase in its final dividend to S$0.014 per share, bringing the total dividend for FY2021 to S$0.048. Assets under administration reached a record S$19 billion, with net inflows of S$3.8 billion for the full year, and the company expects robust growth in revenue and profitability between 2021 and 2025.

site_title: Appraising or remunerating employees based on sick leave goes against guidelines: MOM
summary: Manpower Minister Tan See Leng stated that appraising or remunerating employees based on sick leave goes against the Tripartite Guidelines on Fair Employment Practices (TGFEP). This practice can be detrimental to workers and should not be seen as fair. The government will work with companies to restructure attendance-related incentive schemes into productivity and welfare schemes, and clarify the understanding of the TGFEP. The goal is to protect the well-being of workers and ensure they receive fair treatment.

site_title: Himalayan yogi ran India's top bourse as puppet master, regulator says
summary: A former head of India's largest stock exchange, National Stock Exchange (NSE), Chitra Ramkrishna, shared confidential information with a yogi and sought his advice on crucial decisions, a probe by the market regulator found. Ramkrishna, who quit NSE in 2016, allegedly shared financial projections, business plans, and board agendas with the yogi, a "spiritual force" she had sought guidance from for 20 years. SEBI imposed penalties, including fines of over $90 million on NSE and Ramkrishna, and barred the exchange from raising money on securities markets for six months.

site_title: China's approval of Pfizer pill opens door to ending 'Covid Zero' strategy
summary: China has approved Pfizer's Covid-19 pill, Paxlovid, for use, marking the first foreign pharmaceutical product cleared for Covid-19 treatment. The move may signal a shift towards a more flexible approach to Covid-19 containment, as China seeks to mitigate the disadvantage of its lower-efficacy vaccines. The approval comes as China struggles to eliminate the virus, with experts warning of the potential for widespread infections if restrictions are lifted. The Pfizer pill has been shown to reduce hospitalization and death risk by almost 90%.

site_title: Cash incentives, subsidies for MediShield Life among suggestions by MP to improve preventive health efforts
summary: Singapore MP Leon Perera suggests providing cash incentives or subsidies for MediShield Life premiums to encourage regular exercise and health screenings. He also proposes adopting a long-term, outcome-focused approach to preventative healthcare, rewarding individuals for good health choices and incentivizing healthcare providers to focus on preventative care. The government is considering implementing a national programme to improve preventive health, but faces challenges in nudging people to take up health screenings.

site_title: Airlines pull services back further from Ukraine
summary: European airlines, including KLM and Norwegian Air Shuttle, have further reduced services to Ukraine amid rising tensions between Russia and Ukraine. Insurers have pulled coverage, forcing airlines to move leased planes to the European Union. Shares of Wizz Air Holdings dropped 11% after the move. The US has warned of a potential Russian invasion, with 130,000 troops amassed at the border. Commercial flights remain prohibited over eastern Ukraine and Crimea. Despite this, some flights to Kyiv are still operating normally, and airlines are preparing for possible changes in routes.

site_title: Gold trades near 4-month high as Ukraine tension lifts havens
summary: Gold prices rose to a four-month high due to escalating tensions in Ukraine, despite expectations of aggressive interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve to combat inflation. The US National Security Advisor warned of a "distinct possibility" of major military action in Ukraine, boosting investor demand for gold. Despite this, the dollar strengthened, causing gold to edge slightly lower. Analysts expect the gold price to climb further if the situation in Ukraine escalates, potentially deterring the Fed from raising interest rates in March.

site_title: US dollar hits 2-week high on tensions over Ukraine
summary: The US dollar rose to a 2-week high on Monday amid fears of a potential Russian invasion of Ukraine, with the dollar index increasing 0.4% to 96.351. The euro fell 0.4% to its lowest level since February 3, while the yen strengthened 0.3% against the dollar. Investors are seeking safe-haven assets, with the euro-dollar implied volatility reaching 7.45%, the highest since November 2020. The US Federal Reserve's January meeting minutes are set to be released on Wednesday, but analysts expect central bank action to be limited until the Ukraine crisis subsides.

site_title: Netlink Trust 9-month profit after tax down 5.2%, despite higher revenue
summary: NetLink NBN Trust reported a 5.2% decrease in profit after tax for the 9-month period ended Dec 31, 2021, despite a 1.9% increase in revenue to S$281.6 million. The decrease in earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization (EBitda) was primarily due to a remeasurement loss of S$12.4 million related to finance lease receivables. The trust's net assets stood at S$2.7 billion, with a cash balance of S$113 million.

site_title: Silverlake Axis reports 72 per cent rise in Q2 profit amid higher revenue
summary: Silverlake Axis reported a 72% increase in Q2 profit to RM59.6 million, driven by a 29% rise in revenue to RM206.5 million. Project-related revenue segments grew 110% and accounted for 75% of total revenue in the first half. The company closed over RM300 million in new contracts in the first 6 months of FY22. Group Managing Director Andrew Tan expressed cautious optimism for the company's medium-term prospects, citing a robust pipeline of opportunities.

site_title: Food factory at Tuas Link for sale with S$52m indicative price
summary: A 7-storey food factory at 30 Tuas Link 2 has been offered for sale via expression of interest (EOI) with a S$52 million indicative price. The industrial building, with a 30-year leasehold tenure, sits on a 107,713 sq ft land parcel zoned Business 2 (B2) and approved for the manufacturing of creamer and beverages. The property is strategically located near the Tuas Link MRT station and the Tuas Checkpoint, providing ready access to Malaysia. Strong interest is expected from companies in the fast-growing F&B manufacturing sector.

site_title: Keppel unit faces civil claim of 1.72t rupiah over ownership of Jakarta land
summary: A civil action has been filed by Raden Saleh Abdul Malik against PT Kepland Investama, a subsidiary of Keppel Land, over ownership rights to 17,000 sq m of land plots in Jakarta. PT Kepland acquired ownership rights in 2000, but Malik claims he is the legal owner and seeks 1.72 trillion rupiah (S$160 million) in compensation and foreclosure of the disputed land plots.

site_title: ThaiBev Q1 revenue up 7.4 per cent as Covid-19 situation improves
summary: ThaiBev reported a 7.4% increase in Q1 revenue to 77.1 billion Thai baht (S$3.2 billion) due to the improving Covid-19 situation in Thailand, driving sales growth across all business segments. Earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortisation (Ebitda) rose 1.6% year-on-year to 14.7 billion Thai baht. The company attributed the growth to the easing of restrictions and increased consumer spending.

site_title: Sea's Free Fire among apps India bans on China security fear
summary: India has banned 54 Chinese-origin apps, including Sea Ltd's Free Fire, citing security concerns amid tensions between the two nations. The ban affects apps from tech firms like Tencent, Alibaba, and NetEase, and is the latest move in a long-standing dispute. Sea's stock plummeted 19% in New York, and analysts predict the ban could impact the company's gaming franchise, although the impact may be limited due to the small share of Indian gaming revenue.

site_title: iPhone maker Foxconn to make chips in India with Vedanta
summary: Foxconn, the world's largest contract electronics manufacturer, has partnered with Indian conglomerate Vedanta to produce semiconductors in India. The Taiwan-based company will invest $118.7 million in a joint venture, with Vedanta holding 60% of the shares. The partnership aims to support India's semiconductor manufacturing ecosystem, aligning with Prime Minister Narendra Modi's vision. This move diversifies Foxconn's business and responds to the global chip shortage, which has affected producers of goods from cars to electronics.

site_title: Oil steady, near 7-year high on Ukraine-Russia tensions
summary: Oil prices remain steady near a 7-year high due to concerns over a possible Russian invasion of Ukraine, which could disrupt exports and trigger US and European sanctions. Brent crude hit $96.16 a barrel, the highest since October 2014, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose to $93.11 a barrel, hovering near a session-high of $94.94. Analysts predict volatility and potential price increases, with some forecasting prices could reach $115 or higher this summer.

site_title: Global chip sales hit record in 2021, will grow 8.8% in 2022: SIA
summary: Global chip sales reached a record $555.9 billion in 2021, a 26.2% increase from the previous year, according to the Semiconductor Industry Association (SIA). The SIA forecasts 8.8% growth in 2022 as chip makers expand production capacity to meet demand. The digitalization trend, driven by the pandemic, is expected to continue driving demand higher, with sales for auto-grade chips increasing 34% in 2021. China remains the largest individual market for semiconductors, with sales totaling $192.5 billion in 2021.

site_title: Court grants SPH permission to convene Cuscaden scheme meeting
summary: The Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) has been granted permission by the court to convene the Cuscaden scheme meeting, a move to take the company private. The court also allowed SPH to withdraw its application to convene the Keppel scheme meeting. This development comes after SPH terminated its implementation agreement with Keppel, citing unmet scheme conditions. SPH will continue to prepare for a shareholder vote on the Cuscaden scheme, while also defending its position against Keppel's arbitration claim.

site_title: HSBC to double some junior banker bonuses in race for talent
summary: HSBC plans to double bonuses for some junior investment bankers and traders in an effort to compete with rivals on compensation, amid concerns that the bank is losing staff to Wall Street firms. The move comes after HSBC cut the bonus pool for its global banking and markets division by 15% last year. More senior employees are set for 10% bonus hikes. The bank aims to keep pay competitive and address concerns about early burnout among junior staff.

site_title: Civmec reports 50.1% rise in H1 net profit; declares dividend
summary: Construction and engineering group Civmec reported a 50.1% increase in net profit to A$22.6 million in the first half of 2021-2022, driven by higher revenue. Sales revenue rose 27.4% year-on-year to A$389.4 million. The company declared an interim dividend of A$0.01 and sees significant growth opportunities in its maintenance and capital works division. Civmec's net asset value per share increased to A$0.6179, and its order book stands at over A$1.15 billion.

site_title: Airbus upbeat on freighter sales, plays down supply chain fears
summary: Airbus expressed optimism about sales of its A350 freighter, citing provisional customers and a deal with Singapore Airlines to buy 7 freighters. Despite Boeing's launch of a competing 777X freighter, Airbus chief commercial officer Christian Scherer declined to provide a timeline for orders. Airbus also downplayed concerns about supply chain disruptions, including those related to Russian titanium, and firmed up orders from 2 airlines for A220 and A320neo jets.

site_title: Singapore amends hijacking and aviation security laws amid high terrorism threat
summary: Singapore has amended its hijacking and aviation security laws to align with international treaties crafted in response to the 9/11 attacks. The new law, which was passed by Parliament, criminalizes the use of aircraft as weapons, nuclear and biochemical attacks, and cyber threats to air navigation facilities. Individuals found guilty can face life imprisonment, while companies can be fined up to S$1 million. The amendments pave the way for Singapore to accede to the Convention on the Suppression of Unlawful Acts Relating to International Civil Aviation and the Protocol Supplementary to the Convention.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's young super-rich snapped up the island's priciest homes, while the country will continue to develop local and global talent to fill jobs. Volatility in the LNG market may keep electricity and power generation prices high in Singapore. The life insurance sector posted a 23% rise in new sales for 2021, and lofty material prices will remain a challenge for the construction industry. Businessman Ng Yu Zhi faces 93 charges linked to a US$1.1 billion nickel trading scam. Singapore shares fell on Monday, tracking regional declines.

site_title: iFast Q4 net profit rises 5.5%; higher final dividend proposed
summary: iFast Corporation reported a 5.5% year-on-year increase in net profit for its fourth quarter, rising to S$7.2 million, driven by a 13.9% revenue growth to S$54.6 million. The company proposed a 40% increase in final dividend to S$0.014 per share. Assets under administration reached S$19 billion, a 31.5% growth, and net inflows of client assets were nearly S$800 million in the fourth quarter. The group expects robust growth in revenue and profitability between 2021 and 2025, with Hong Kong's ePension division expected to be the biggest driver.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 4.95 points or 0.31% to 1,583.84 on Monday, driven by a volume of 3.175 billion lots worth RM2.49 billion. Losers outnumbered gainers 598 to 386.

site_title: Germany to end most Covid curbs in March: draft government plan
summary: Germany will end most COVID-19 curbs in March, according to a draft government plan, as new infection rates ease. Contact restrictions will ease, allowing more private gatherings, while shops will be open to all without vaccination or testing checks. This marks the end of two years of government restrictions to combat the pandemic.

site_title: How Crypto.com is betting big on sports partnerships to reach a billion users
summary: Crypto.com, a Singapore-based cryptocurrency company, is betting big on sports partnerships to reach 1 billion users. The company, founded in 2016, ran a Super Bowl commercial and secured a $700 million deal to rename the Staples Center in Los Angeles as the Crypto.com Arena. Its aggressive marketing push has raised eyebrows, with some warning that the frothy crypto market may be a bubble. Crypto.com's CEO, Kris Marszalek, aims to become a top-20 global brand and has already secured partnerships with major sports organizations, including the Philadelphia 76ers and Formula 1 Racing.

site_title: Ivan Reitman, director of 'Ghostbusters' is dead at 75
summary: Ivan Reitman, director of iconic comedies 'Ghostbusters' and 'National Lampoon's Animal House', died at 75 on February 12, 2022, at his home in Montecito, California. A producer and director of numerous box-office hits, Reitman was known for his contributions to the careers of actors like Bill Murray and Arnold Schwarzenegger. He produced and directed major comedies, including 'Ghostbusters' (1984), 'Animal House' (1978), and 'Kindergarten Cop' (1990). His children, Jason, Catherine, and Caroline, confirmed his death in a statement, describing him as a husband, father, and grandfather who brought laughter and happiness to countless others through his work.

site_title: S Korea to start giving 4th doses of Covid vaccine by month-end
summary: South Korea will start administering fourth doses of Covid-19 vaccines by the end of this month, primarily targeting high-risk groups such as nursing home residents and those with declined immunization. The move aims to combat a surge in Omicron infections, with daily cases reaching records.
