site_title: UEFA on verge of 40% leap in European club TV revenues
summary: UEFA is on the verge of a 40% increase in European club TV revenues, with global deals worth 15 billion euros for 3 seasons to 2027, or 5 billion euros a season. This rise is linked to the expansion of the Champions League and aims to discourage plans for a breakaway super league. The total TV revenue for the current season is expected to be 3.6 billion euros, up from 3.2 billion euros in the 2018-19 season. The increase strengthens UEFA's efforts to maintain control over European club football.

site_title: France to scrap Covid test requirement for vaccinated travellers
summary: France will scrap the requirement for a negative Covid-19 test for all vaccinated travellers arriving in the country, effective Saturday. Proof of vaccination will be sufficient to enter France, replacing the current test requirement. Unvaccinated travellers will still need to show a negative test, while those from "green list" countries may not need to undergo testing or quarantine. The move follows the predominance of the Omicron variant and higher vaccination rates.

site_title: Billionaire Soros buys stake in EV startup Rivian
summary: Billionaire investor George Soros has acquired nearly 20 million shares of electric truck startup Rivian Automotive, worth around $2 billion. This investment makes Soros Fund Management a prominent backer of the company, which is expected to provide Amazon with over 100,000 electric trucks. Rivian's shares have fallen 43% this year due to supply chain constraints and production challenges, with the stock price down 67% from its peak of $179.46 in November 2021.

site_title: China stocks in US start Year of the Tiger on right foot
summary: US-listed Chinese stocks, including those on the Nasdaq Golden Dragon China Index, recorded their largest back-to-back weekly gains in about 5 months, with a 2.5% increase since Feb 11. The rally was driven by state-backed funds' purchases of local shares as the domestic market reopened after the Year of the Tiger celebrations. However, tensions between the US and China may continue to escalate, and analysts are cautious about the longevity of the gains, citing concerns over China's zero-tolerance Covid policy and regulatory agenda.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: First Sponsor Group reported S$121 million in net profit for the full year 2021, up 17.7% from the previous year, driven by strong property sales revenue growth of 189% to S$589 million. The company also announced a second interim cash dividend of 2.35 Singapore cents, totaling 3.45 cents for the year.

site_title: UK police send PM Johnson questionnaire in 'partygate' probe
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson has received a legal questionnaire from police investigating claims of lockdown-breaking parties in his Downing Street office. The "partygate" scandal has placed Johnson in political jeopardy, with several MPs calling for his resignation. Johnson faces a fine unless he can give credible reasons for attending events during coronavirus restrictions. He has already apologized and vowed to fight on in office, but opposition leader Keir Starmer has called for his resignation, saying the police involvement is a "mark of shame".

site_title: Malaysia's Capital A could list aviation arm when conditions are right: Tony Fernandes
summary: Capital A, the parent company of AirAsia, has established an independent board for its aviation business, with plans to eventually list the arm when conditions are right. AirAsia will expand its Indonesian fleet from 7 planes to 30 by the end of the year, with a focus on domestic flights. CEO Tony Fernandes said the airline will continue to grow despite competition, and AirAsia is also exploring routes out of key Indonesian destinations.

site_title: 9,771 new local Covid-19 cases; 1,205 patients in hospitals
summary: Singapore reported 9,771 new local Covid-19 cases, with 1,205 patients in hospitals, including 21 in the ICU. This marks the seventh consecutive day with hospitalization numbers above 1,000. The Ministry of Health also reported 128 people requiring oxygen support and three deaths. The weekly Covid-19 infection growth rate decreased to 1.74. With 449,570 cases and 885 deaths, 93% of Singapore's eligible population has completed the full vaccination regimen, and 62% have received the vaccine booster shot.

site_title: New Eli Lilly antibody cleared by US for use against Omicron
summary: US regulators have cleared Eli Lilly's monoclonal antibody bebtelovimab for patients at high risk of severe Covid-19, particularly those infected with mild-to-moderate Covid and unable to access other treatment options. The FDA granted emergency authorization for use in patients 12 and older, after a similar therapy proved ineffective against the Omicron variant. The treatment is available in the US, with 600,000 doses to be distributed free of charge, and may be purchased in larger quantities through the end of July.

site_title: Europe: Shares end lower, but mark first positive week this year
summary: European shares ended lower on Friday, but marked their first weekly gain this year, closing 0.6% lower and rising 1.6% for the week. Tech stocks fell 2.2%, driven by elevated debt yields, while travel and leisure stocks rose 7.4% on optimism over easing mask mandates. Bond yields retreated after sharp gains on Thursday, and ECB President Christine Lagarde said raising interest rates would not combat record-high inflation. European growth forecasts were also revised downward, citing rising energy prices and labor shortages.

site_title: Stellantis recalling nearly 20,000 plug-in minivans for fire risks
summary: Stellantis is recalling 19,808 plug-in hybrid minivans due to 12 reported fires in parked vehicles. The affected 2017-2018 Chrysler Pacifica Hybrid vehicles will not be recharged, and owners can continue to use the internal combustion engine. No related injuries or accidents have been reported. The cause of the fires is being confirmed, and owners are advised to park the vehicles away from structures and other vehicles. The recall covers 16,741 US, 2,317 Canadian, and 750 international vehicles.

site_title: US investors expect more volatility as Ukraine concerns spook markets
summary: US investors anticipate increased market volatility amid escalating tensions between Russia and Ukraine. The benchmark S&P 500 index fell nearly 1.9% and the Nasdaq was off 2.8% on Friday, while the Cboe Volatility Index surged to its highest level since January. Despite market jitters, some investors believe a more serious conflict may not significantly impact US asset prices in the long term, with the Fed potentially staying aggressive due to surging oil prices.

site_title: Snoop Dogg spokesperson calls sexual assault allegations 'meritless'
summary: Snoop Dogg is facing a civil lawsuit alleging sexual assault and battery by an unidentified woman who claims he forced her to perform oral sex and masturbated in front of her at a 2013 concert. The musician's spokesperson calls the allegations "meritless" and a "shakedown" scheme. The lawsuit, filed just days before Snoop Dogg's Super Bowl halftime show performance, seeks unspecified damages. This is not the first time Snoop Dogg has faced similar allegations, with another woman making similar claims in December 2021.

site_title: Oil soars 3% to 7-year highs on Ukraine jitters, tight supplies
summary: Oil prices surged 3% to 7-year highs, reaching $94.44 a barrel, amid escalating fears of a Russian invasion of Ukraine, which has massed troops near the country. Tight global crude supplies and growing concerns over demand recovery from the pandemic also contributed to the price increase. The International Energy Agency raised its 2022 demand forecast, expecting global demand to expand by 3.2 million barrels per day, while Saudi Arabia and the UAE could help calm volatile markets by pumping more crude.

site_title: US: Wall Street ends down sharply on fears of Ukraine conflict
summary: US stocks ended sharply lower on Friday, February 11, 2022, as investors fretted about deepening tensions between Russia and Ukraine. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 1.43% and the S&P 500 lost 1.90%, with nine of 11 major sector indexes declining. Tech and consumer discretionary sectors were hit hard, while energy surged 2.8% due to oil price hikes. Investors worry about inflation, interest rates, and potential global conflict, with some predicting a half-point rate hike in March.

site_title: Sports Hub ready to stage much larger events, but only if it makes economic sense: CEO
summary: Singapore's Sports Hub is poised to host larger events, but only if it makes economic sense. According to CEO Lionel Yeo, the venue has generated 'healthy interest' from global sports and entertainment promoters. The National Stadium, which normally seats 55,000, was only 20% full for a recent football match due to COVID-19 safe management measures. Yeo's comments come as the country looks to expand its sports and entertainment offerings.

site_title: Liverpool 'working on a plan' to return and play in Asia soon
summary: Liverpool FC is working on a plan to return to Asia for a pre-season tour, despite the COVID-19 pandemic hindering their previous attempts. The English Premier League club's CEO, Billy Hogan, emphasizes the importance of broadcast, commercial, and matchday revenue in securing their success. Former manager Kenny Dalglish notes the immense support from Liverpool's fans in Asia and the need to balance football and business sides to achieve success. The club is also investing in their home stadium, Anfield, with a new development set to increase capacity to around 61,000.

site_title: Hong Kong virus cases top 1,000 again as flight ban extended
summary: Hong Kong reported a record 1,325 COVID-19 cases on February 11, with 1,500 preliminary positive cases, and two more deaths, straining healthcare resources and pushing the government's "Covid Zero" strategy. The city extended flight bans to March 4 and added Nepal to the list. Health officials warned that daily numbers haven't yet peaked, citing significant community transmission chains. The government is urging social distancing measures, while considering mainland China's support for the city's virus measures.

site_title: A new front in ECB's psychological war over tighter money
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) President Joachim Nagel has signaled a potential shift towards tighter monetary policy, forecasting average Germany inflation of "well over 4%" this year. This could lead to hawkish decisions on asset purchases and interest rates at the ECB's next policy-setting meeting on March 10. Nagel's proposal to end net asset purchases and raise interest rates from negative levels before the end of the year has been met with skepticism by some ECB members, but he is seeking to prevail upon President Christine Lagarde to marshal a majority behind this tighter policy.

site_title: Battling in grocery war, HappyFresh sees the light in 'dark stores'
summary: HappyFresh, an Indonesian grocery delivery startup, is expanding its presence with "dark stores" - retail outlets designed exclusively for online delivery. The company plans to open over 100 dark stores across the region, complementing its asset-light grocery picking model. HappyFresh aims to gain more control over customer experience, supply chain, and branding with the dark stores, similar to competitors foodpanda and Grab. Despite being a cash-intensive business, HappyFresh has seen rapid growth and lower customer acquisition costs, and is focused on long-term sustainability.

site_title: US vows stepped-up Indo-Pacific effort in push back against China
summary: The US has pledged to strengthen its diplomatic and security presence in the Indo-Pacific region, pushing back against China's bid to create a regional sphere of influence. The Biden administration has outlined a 12-page strategy to focus on every corner of the region, from South Asia to the Pacific Islands, to counter China's growing economic, diplomatic, military, and technological might. The goal is to maintain the US's long-term position and commitment to the region, amid China's efforts to become the world's most influential power.

site_title: Finding purpose among mountains
summary: Jennifer Zhu Scott, executive chairperson of The Commons Project Foundation, finds purpose and inspiration through hiking in the mountains, particularly in the Tibetan Plateau and Hong Kong. In the past two years, she has hiked over 20 trails, discovering lessons that apply to her work, such as the importance of perspective and human connection. These hikes inspire her to approach societal issues with fresh perspectives and motivate her to restore human connection beyond borders.

site_title: Indonesia to urge G-20 to establish global health fund
summary: Indonesia, as the G-20 president this year, plans to urge the group to establish a global health fund that can provide emergency funds and resources during a health crisis. The current system leaves countries "basically on their own" during emergencies. Indonesia's Health Minister Budi Gunadi Sadikin suggests creating a global health institution similar to the World Bank and IMF, and proposes alternative organizations like the Global Fund and Gavi to manage the fund. This initiative comes as the World Health Organization and aid groups face challenges in meeting their vaccination and testing goals for poorer countries.

site_title: COP report objective, attempts to politicise matter regrettable: Speaker Tan Chuan-Jin
summary: Speaker of Parliament Tan Chuan-Jin has expressed regret over attempts to politicize the findings of a parliamentary committee that recommended fines and investigations for Workers' Party MPs over their lies in Parliament. The committee found Raeesah Khan, Pritam Singh, and Faisal Manap guilty of potential crimes, including perjury and contempt of Parliament. Tan emphasized that the committee's recommendations are based on objective evidence and that the Public Prosecutor will have the final say in determining any charges. He stressed that a strong democratic system requires elected officials to respect institutions and uphold laws.

site_title: Ford reconsiders India after halting production, this time for EVs
summary: Ford Motor is reconsidering its decision to stop producing cars in India after halting production in September due to a lack of profitability. The company is now exploring the possibility of using an Indian plant as an export base for electric vehicles (EVs) and possibly selling EVs in the domestic market. Ford has historically exported vehicles to North America and Europe, both of which are growing EV markets. The company plans to invest $30 billion in EVs and batteries through 2030, and its comments come after its proposal to seek incentives under the government's $3.5 billion scheme for clean-fuel vehicles was approved.

site_title: UK's economic sorrows come in battalions
summary: The UK economy is facing a triple whammy of high inflation, sharp rises in energy costs, and a weakening economy. The Bank of England forecasts a 2% fall in real post-tax labour incomes this year and a further 0.5% in 2023, making it the weakest growth in over 70 years. The government's efforts to alleviate rising energy costs, including a £200 discount on electricity bills, are deemed ill-targeted and may not be enough to cushion the impact. The situation is further complicated by the labour market running hot, with excess demand and rising wages, which could exacerbate inflationary risks.

site_title: Russian rouble drops most in 2 years as US warns of Ukraine invasion
summary: The Russian ruble plummeted 2.8% against the US dollar, its largest daily drop in nearly 2 years, amid US warnings of a potential invasion of Ukraine. The US has urged all citizens to leave Russia within 48 hours. The ruble's decline outweighed a rate increase by the Russian central bank and high oil prices, with geopolitical tensions taking precedence. Russian stocks and bonds also fell, and Ukrainian bonds tumbled. Moscow has denied plans to invade Ukraine, but the market remains concerned about the prospect of an invasion.

images.alt_text: The rouble fell the most in nearly 2 years on Friday (Feb 11) after the United States said Russia has amassed enough troops near Ukraine to launch a major invasion, urging all US citizens to leave the country within 48 hours.

site_title: Property investors to look towards luxury offices, smart buildings, mixed-use developments: Hines
summary: Property investment firm Hines identifies luxury offices, smart buildings, and mixed-use developments as key trends for 2022. The company's newly appointed co-CEO, Laura Hines-Pierce, notes a growing demand for high-end office spaces and mixed-use developments, driven by the need for hybrid work arrangements and diversification of income streams. Hines also aims to incorporate technology, such as artificial intelligence and machine learning, into its developments to reduce carbon footprints.

site_title: New York's unvaccinated city workers face firing on deadline day
summary: About 4,000 unvaccinated New York City employees, including police officers, teachers, and firefighters, face termination on Feb 11 due to failing to comply with the city's vaccination mandate. Approximately 95% of the 370,000 city workers have received at least one dose. Mayor Eric Adams views the employees' termination as a choice to leave their jobs by not following the rules, labeling it as "quitting."

site_title: Samtrade FX placed under judicial management, US$167m in assets seized
summary: The Singapore authorities have placed six entities related to online trading platform Samtrade FX under judicial management following a probe into potential offences under local securities laws. The companies, which include Samtrade FX and its parent company, have been unable to pay debts and have been seized by the police for approximately US$167 million in assets. The directors have deemed it in the interest of stakeholders to place the companies under judicial management. The case is scheduled to be heard again in court on June 27, and a pre-trial conference was held on February 10.

site_title: China property developers shares up on reports they may have more access to funds
summary: China's property developers saw shares rise on reports that authorities may grant easier access to presale proceeds, easing the sector's cash crunch. Regulatory curbs on borrowing have driven the sector into a liquidity crisis, particularly after Evergrande's debt issues. The sector's slump has accounted for a quarter of China's economy. Authorities' latest move aims to support the industry.

site_title: First Sponsor Group posts 18% increase in full-year net profit to S$121m
summary: First Sponsor Group reported a 17.7% increase in full-year net profit to S$121 million, up from S$103 million in the previous year. Revenue rose 189% to S$589 million, driven by strong property sales. The company declared a second interim cash dividend of 2.35 Singapore cents for FY2021, totaling 3.45 cents. This marks the company's 18% increase in full-year net profit.

site_title: China's central bank to keep liquidity ample, step up finance support for key sectors
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), announced it will maintain ample liquidity and step up financing support for key sectors and weak links of the economy. The bank aims to improve the money supply mechanism, guide financial institutions to expand loan lending, and maintain reasonable liquidity without resorting to excessive stimulus. The move aims to support slowing economic growth, which has been clouded by concerns about property developers and the spread of the Omicron variant.

site_title: The Straits Trading Company acquires two freehold office buildings in Melbourne
summary: The Straits Trading Company has acquired two freehold office buildings in Melbourne, Australia, for approximately A$150 million (S$143.9 million). The properties, located in Docklands, are 1010 La Trobe Street and 192 Harbour Esplanade, with 1010 La Trobe being a 9-storey, Grade-A office building and 192 Harbour Esplanade being a 5-storey Grade-A office building. The acquisition is part of the company's business expansion plans and is expected to support post-Covid recovery of Melbourne commercial real estate.

site_title: MLT unitholders vote in favour of plans to acquire assets in China, Vietnam
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) unitholders have voted in favour of acquiring 13 logistics assets in China and 3 properties in Vietnam, as well as issuing 106 million new units to Mulberry, a subsidiary of MLT's sponsor Mapletree Investments (MIPL), at S$1.88 per unit. The acquisition and issuance plans were approved by 99.7% of unitholders, with 92.9% voting in favour of waiving their rights to receive a mandatory offer from MLT's sponsor. The vote follows a meeting held on Jan 13.

site_title: Tales from the Beijing Olympics bubble
summary: The 2022 Winter Olympics in Beijing, China, were held within a "closed loop" system designed to prevent the spread of COVID-19. The system includes a network of hotels and venues, accessible only by special buses, and is heavily restricted to minimize interactions with the outside world. Athletes and journalists must undergo rigorous testing and quarantine, and are subject to strict health protocols, including wearing masks and maintaining social distancing. The system has been successful in keeping cases low, but has also raised concerns about the human cost of the "zero-Covid" policy, with many athletes and staff reporting isolation and confinement. The Olympics have become a symbol of China's efforts to showcase its control over the pandemic, and its ability to balance economic growth with public health measures.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher after sell-off on inflation worries
summary: US stocks opened higher on Friday, Feb 11, after a sharp sell-off the previous session due to soaring inflation numbers and concerns over quicker interest rate hikes from the Federal Reserve. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 26.30 points, the S&P 500 gained 2.19 points, and the Nasdaq Composite increased 27.98 points, all at the opening bell.

images.alt_text: Wall Street's main indexes opened slightly higher on Friday (Feb 11) after a sharp selloff in the previous session when soaring inflation numbers raised fears about quicker interest rate hikes from the Federal Reserve.

site_title: White House tells chip industry to brace for Russian supply disruptions
summary: The White House has warned the US chip industry to diversify its supply chain due to potential Russian retaliation against threatened export curbs. Over 90% of US semiconductor-grade neon supplies come from Ukraine, and 35% of US palladium is sourced from Russia. The administration has been in touch with chip industry members, urging them to find alternative sources. The Biden administration has threatened to impose export controls against Russia if it invades Ukraine, and some chipmakers have been reviewing their supply chains to prepare for potential disruptions.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares close higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index closed higher on Friday, rising 8.79 points to 1,578.89. The index saw 3.191 billion lots worth RM2.416 billion, with 509 gainers outpacing 446 losers.

site_title: Europe: Tech leads stock sell-off on bets of aggressive Fed rate hikes
summary: European shares fell 0.5% on Friday, tracking a global sell-off after US inflation data fueled bets on aggressive Federal Reserve rate hikes. Tech stocks led the decline, falling 1.2%, while sectors like mining and healthcare helped to stem losses. Carmaker Volvo Cars slipped 4.7% after posting earnings below expectations, and State-controlled French power company EDF fell 3.0% after cutting its nuclear output estimate.

site_title: What's at stake in Ukraine is the direction of human history
summary: The Ukraine crisis poses a threat to humanity's greatest political achievement: the decline of war. The direction of history is uncertain, with some believing that change is impossible and that humans are forever condemned to repeat past tragedies. However, another school of thought argues that humans can change their behavior and create a more peaceful world. The decline of war is evident in statistics, such as a decrease in direct wars between superpowers and a shift from material wealth to knowledge-based economies. The "new peace" has been reflected in governments' budgets, with a focus on education, healthcare, and welfare over military spending. But the rise of cyber weapons, AI-driven economies, and newly militaristic cultures could lead to a new era of war, making peace fragile and reversible.

site_title: Opec+ faces 'chronic' struggle to meet output target: IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) warned that Opec+ faces a "chronic" struggle to meet its output target, citing a persistent gap between production and its target levels. Despite agreeing to increase output last year, some members, such as Angola and Nigeria, have been unable to scale up production, while others, like Saudi Arabia and the UAE, are unwilling to do so. The IEA forecasts a 3.2 million barrel increase in world oil demand in 2022, which could lead to rising supply tensions and volatility in oil prices.

site_title: Pines club members' appeal against Peter Kwee and Exklusiv Resorts dismissed
summary: The High Court's appellate division has dismissed an appeal by 139 Pines club members against Exklusiv Resorts, Peter Kwee's company, over the relocation of the clubhouse. The court upheld the original ruling, dismissing claims for deceit, negligence, and breach of contract. The members, who initially won a class-action suit, were awarded a nominal sum of $1,500 each, and were ordered to pay $78,000 in legal costs. The decision was unanimous, with three claims against Exklusiv Resorts and four claims against Kwee being dismissed.

site_title: Feasting in style
summary: Chef David Yip credits his late grandmother for his love of fine porcelain tableware, which was a staple for family gatherings and entertaining. Yip's grandmother used Canton porcelain, also known as Guangcai, with hand-painted designs, often for special occasions. This appreciation for fine china has influenced Yip's approach to dining and entertaining.

site_title: M&A dealmakers optimistic for 2022 despite pain of record-high prices: Bain
summary: M&A dealmakers are optimistic about continued deal momentum in 2022 despite record-high prices and intense competition. According to Bain & Co's fourth annual M&A report, 89% of executives surveyed anticipate their deal activity to remain the same or increase this year. Record valuations and strategic deals achieved $3.8 trillion in value in 2021, up 47% from the previous year. Despite rising prices, Bain believes fundamentals for dealmaking will remain attractive in 2022 and beyond, driven by ESG, talent retention, and revenue synergies.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: M&A dealmakers are optimistic for 2022 despite record-high prices and intense competition. Korean fast food chain Mom's Touch has closed all its Singapore outlets. The appellate division dismissed the appeal by Pines club members seeking higher damages against Peter Kwee's company. More companies tapped Enterprise Singapore support for productivity, and six entities related to Samtrade FX were placed under judicial management. EDB, SAP, and Qualtrics committed $14.1 million to establish an experience management centre in Singapore. Local stocks ended the week flat due to US January inflation figures.

site_title: What would happen if financial markets crashed?
summary: The US financial system is experiencing familiar signs of a potential market crash, with wild trading days, sudden price swings, and a queasy feeling among investors. Despite being in a better shape than 2008, the system still faces risks, including high asset prices, rising interest rates, and hidden leverage in shadow banks and investment funds. The mix of sky-high valuations and rising interest rates could result in large losses, and the system's ability to absorb them is uncertain. The financial system's transformation by regulation and technological innovation has created a high-frequency, market-based system with new players, but also introduces dangers such as the potential for a "fire" that could damage the economy.

images.alt_text: It is tempting to think that the January sell-off was exactly what was needed, purging the stock market of its speculative excesses. But America's new-look financial system is still loaded with risks.

site_title: US says Russia putting more troops near Ukraine, invasion at any time
summary: US Secretary of State Antony Blinken warned that Russia is massing troops near Ukraine, with an invasion possible at any time, including during the Winter Olympics. Satellite images show new Russian military deployments in western Russia, Belarus, and Crimea. President Joe Biden said the US would not send troops to rescue US citizens in the event of a Russian assault. Russia denies plans to invade, but says it may take unspecified "military-technical" action unless certain demands are met. Diplomatic efforts have yielded no progress, with Western countries threatening economic sanctions if Russia invades.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end with losses
summary: Hong Kong stocks ended the week on a negative note, with the Hang Seng Index dipping 0.07% to 24,906.66, following a forecast-beating jump in US inflation and comments from a Federal Reserve official fueling interest rate fears. Global markets were also impacted by the US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Germany eyes easing Covid curbs, says infections peaking
summary: Germany's coronavirus infections are peaking, Chancellor Olaf Scholz said, signaling the country can soon ease curbs. The nation has reported its first week-on-week drop in new infections in over a year, with 240,172 new cases on Friday. Scholz plans to meet with state leaders next week to discuss reopening measures, and Germany's 16 states have begun to ease restrictions. The move comes as the government's plan to make COVID-19 vaccinations mandatory for the public is facing opposition, with Bavaria lifting a health worker vaccination requirement.

site_title: BMW sees up to US$9.1 billion boost from China stake purchase
summary: BMW is set to receive a potential $9.1 billion boost from taking over its Chinese car-making joint venture with Brilliance China Automotive Holdings. The company will now hold a 75% stake, up from 50%, following Chinese authorities' approval. This move is expected to lead to a positive one-time effect of $7-8 billion on BMW's earnings. The acquisition is seen as a significant milestone for the automotive industry, as it marks one of the first times a Western automaker has benefited from China's relaxed foreign ownership rules.

site_title: Australia thwarts Chinese plot to fund election candidates
summary: Australian authorities foiled a plot by Chinese spies to fund candidates for the country's center-left Labor opposition party ahead of the federal election. The alleged scheme, arranged by a businessman with strong Chinese connections, aimed to secure influence in public office in exchange for funding. The Australian Security Intelligence Organisation (ASIO) detected and stopped the plot, but details remain unknown. Labor leader Anthony Albanese has stated he is confident none of his candidates were compromised, while the Chinese Embassy in Canberra declined to comment on the matter.

site_title: Hong Kong food supply at risk again as more drivers get Covid
summary: Hong Kong's food supply is at risk again as more truck drivers testing positive for Covid-19 at the mainland China border have sparked concerns of a potential shortage. Nine drivers have tested positive since February 4, including two on Thursday, which have disinfected visited locations and informed Hong Kong authorities. The logistics industry fears China may tighten virus control measures, affecting the supply chain and border checkpoints, particularly with Hong Kong reporting record daily case numbers.

site_title: Thomson Medical half-year profit up 54.1% to S$12.5m
summary: Thomson Medical Group reported a 54.1% increase in net profit to S$12.5 million for the six months ended Dec 31, 2021, driven by an increase in patient load, higher average bill size, and project-related services. Revenue rose 25% to S$145 million, with Singapore revenue growing 30% to S$109 million and Malaysia revenue rising 11% to S$36.5 million. The company is cautiously optimistic about its prospects, with the new wing in Malaysia expected to contribute to revenue in the second half of the year.

site_title: 1MDB to hold back US$8b suit against Najib till another case ends
summary: The US$8 billion civil suit against former Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak and others will not proceed until a related criminal case against him is disposed. Najib's lawyers reached an agreement with the court to allow the 1MDB-Tanore trial to finish first. The trial, where Najib is the sole accused, must be completed before the civil case can start. This decision follows 1MDB filing 22 civil suits in May last year to recover assets linked to the fund, including US$23 billion.

site_title: UK economy sees best annual growth since World War II in 2021
summary: The UK economy experienced its fastest annual growth since World War II in 2021, expanding 7.5% after suffering a milder impact from the Omicron variant in December. The expansion outpaced other advanced economies, with the Bank of England expected to continue raising interest rates to curb inflation. Despite a 0.2% fall in December, the economy is forecast to outperform other G7 nations this year, with the Chancellor attributing the resilience to government support and timely decision-making.

site_title: Brokers' take: CGS-CIMB maintains 'add' on Q&M Dental with lower target price of S$0.785
summary: CGS-CIMB has maintained its "add" call on Q&M Dental Group, with a lower target price of S$0.785 due to a "normalisation" of revenue and margins from Covid-19 testing. The brokerage expects the group's dental core business to drive long-term growth, with estimated double-digit growth in dental core revenues. Analysts also highlighted Q&M's improving environmental, social, and governance (ESG) standing and attractive dividend yield.

site_title: More productivity support but fewer Covid-related loans in 2021: ESG
summary: Enterprise Singapore (ESG) facilitated S$8.6 billion in loans to 12,600 companies in 2021, a decrease from S$18 billion to 21,000 companies in the previous year, primarily due to fewer Covid-related loan programs. Despite this, ESG saw an increase in productivity support, with companies tapping into its support for capability upgrading. Minister for Trade and Industry Gan Kim Yong emphasized the need for businesses to seize opportunities locally and abroad, with ESG's internationalisation drive intensifying to make up for lost time over the past two years.

site_title: SpaceX chief Elon Musk 'highly confident' his Starship will reach orbit this year
summary: Elon Musk expressed confidence that SpaceX's Starship will reach Earth orbit this year, despite technical and regulatory hurdles. The Starship, designed for lunar and Mars missions, has faced issues with its "Raptor 2" engines, but Musk believes they are close to solving the problems. A successful orbital test flight would be an ambitious feat, even for an uncrewed mission. However, an environmental assessment of the Boca Chica test facility in Texas may delay production, and a worst-case scenario could see a 6-8 month setback at the Kennedy Space Center in Florida.

site_title: US$6b wipeout an omen for food delivery stocks
summary: European food delivery firms, including Delivery Hero, Just Eat Takeaway.com, and Deliveroo, have seen their shares plummet by nearly a third in a record rout, with investors reevaluating the sector's profitability amid rising costs and competition. Analysts attribute the decline to the unpredictable business model, regulatory hurdles, and increasing competition from startups. Despite this, companies remain committed to expanding their businesses, driven by network effects, and are investing in new initiatives to stay ahead.

images.alt_text: While there's a broader shift afoot, food delivery companies are plunging disproportionately to their tech peers.

site_title: Coinbase removes cryptocurrency links after 'rug pull' warnings
summary: Coinbase has removed links to at least three cryptocurrency tokens, DeFi100, Mercenary, and SQUID, after warnings of potential "rug pulls" where investors lose their money. The links were removed after Reuters brought them to Coinbase's attention, and the exchange plans to improve safeguards. The tokens were informational pages created automatically from data website CoinMarketCap, which did not have a partnership with Coinbase. The moves come after Twitter users alleged that DeFi100 had performed a "rug pull" and investors had lost money.

site_title: Local stocks end week flat as US January inflation figures spook traders
summary: Singapore shares ended the week flat, despite a 4-day rally, due to high US January inflation figures. The Straits Times Index rose 0.03% to 3,428.95, with daily turnover reaching 1.2 billion securities worth S$1.4 billion. Markets across the region mostly ended the day with losses, except for the Nikkei and KLCI. Mizuho Bank's head of economics and strategy said the US inflation figures subject the Federal Reserve to "great expectations" and pressure to deliver on a more aggressive interest rate hike.

site_title: Indian inflation expectations ease first time in 8 months
summary: Indian inflation expectations dropped 70 basis points to 9.7% in January, the first decline in 8 months, according to a Reserve Bank of India survey of 5,985 urban households. Expectations for 3-month and 1-year price increases also decreased. The RBI attributed the drop to a slack in demand and moderating supply chain pressures, despite global crude oil near a 7-year high. Governor Shaktikanta Das predicted inflation would reach 4.5% next fiscal year, down from 5.3% this year.

site_title: StarHub earnings climb 27.5% on stronger broadband, enterprise revenue
summary: StarHub's earnings rose 27.5% to S$81 million in the second half of 2021, driven by stronger broadband and enterprise revenue. The telco saw 8.4% growth in broadband revenue to S$98.9 million and 6.4% growth in enterprise revenue to S$372.6 million. Despite a decline in postpaid subscriptions, the company's postpaid ARPU rose to S$30. StarHub has guided for a dividend of S$0.05 per share for FY2022 and FY2023, based on expectations that its Dare+ growth roadmap will be met. The company expects to return to its 2021 Ebitda levels in 2023 and grow its after-tax profit by S$80 million per annum.

site_title: China to focus on Gobi desert for new solar, wind power bases
summary: China plans to focus on the Gobi desert for new solar and wind power bases to meet its climate targets and become carbon neutral by 2060. The country aims to reach 1,200 gigawatts of renewable energy by 2030, with a focus on desert regions. New policies and mechanisms will be implemented to support the growth of green energy, including a "green product certification" system and improved incentives for consumers. Despite this, coal consumption is expected to rise until at least 2025.

site_title: New Zealand Covid-19 protest grows after police draw back
summary: Protesters in New Zealand's capital city, Wellington, gathered outside parliament on Friday, with around 1,500 people camping on the lawns, following a day of violent clashes between police and anti-vaccine demonstrators. Police scaled back efforts to clear the protesters, citing the presence of children, and described their approach as "measured". The protesters, who began camping four days earlier, remain committed to ending vaccine mandates, which are mandatory for certain sectors and require proof of vaccination to enter public venues.

site_title: Malaysia's VS Industry hires PwC Consulting to review labour practices
summary: Malaysia's VS Industry hires PwC Consulting to review its labor practices for migrant workers, following scrutiny over allegations of abuse. The review will be based on 11 indicators of forced labor set by the International Labour Organization. The move aims to identify and close gaps in labor practices under a government worker recalibration program. This comes after a rival firm, ATA IMS, was charged with labor law violations in December, and Dyson terminated contracts with ATA following an independent audit and whistleblower accusations.

site_title: Fast food chain Mom's Touch shuts all outlets operated by No Signboard in Singapore
summary: Korean fast food chain Mom's Touch has shut all its Singapore outlets operated by No Signboard Holdings' subsidiary Hawker QSR, effective February 10, due to liabilities. No Signboard had previously made a statutory declaration of its inability to continue business and intends to pursue creditors' voluntary liquidation. The company faced challenges in the local food and beverage industry, with arrears of over S$176,000 to landlords and a share price of S$0.031. The closure affects three Mom's Touch outlets in Singapore.

site_title: Biden urges Americans to leave Ukraine as fears of Russian invasion mount
summary: US President Joe Biden urged Americans to leave Ukraine immediately as Russia's live-fire drills and troop buildup near the border deepened fears of an invasion. The US estimates around 130,000 Russian soldiers are near the border, prompting Biden to warn that "things could go crazy quickly." Biden reiterated that the US would not send troops to Ukraine, even to rescue Americans, and that Russia should not underestimate Western unity and determination. NATO leaders have also condemned Russia's actions, with German Chancellor Olaf Scholz warning that Russia should not underestimate Western resolve.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end week lower as Fed rate-hike bets weigh
summary: South Korean shares ended the week lower due to concerns about aggressive interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve, triggered by rising US inflation. The Kospi index fell 0.87% to 2,747.71, with Samsung Electronics and LG Chem among the biggest losers. Foreigners bought 377.2 billion won worth of shares, while the Korean won weakened 0.17% against the dollar. This is the 7th week of decline for the Kospi this year.

site_title: Ransomware: To pay or not to pay
summary: Ransomware attacks have become a global concern, with over half of attacks targeting critical infrastructure such as banking, utilities, and retail services. Despite the risks, over 80% of companies pay the ransom, with the average payment reaching a record $570,000 in 2021. However, paying up does not guarantee data recovery, and only 65% of companies get their data back intact. Companies are advised to implement robust cybersecurity measures, including user education and robust backup strategies, to mitigate the risk of ransomware attacks. Boards are often left with a difficult decision, weighing the cost of paying the ransom against the potential consequences of not paying.

site_title: Australia: Shares mark worst day in 2 weeks as tech stocks weigh
summary: Australian shares fell 1% to 7,217.3 on Friday, marking their worst day in two weeks, due to tech stocks sliding 3.8% and US inflation data fuelling interest rate hike bets. The S&P/ASX 200 index still gained 1.4% for the week. Reserve Bank of Australia Governor Philip Lowe said interest rates could rise later this year, but there are risks in moving too early.

site_title: Federal Reserve to move interest rates up 'steadily': Barkin
summary: Richmond Federal Reserve Bank President Tom Barkin expects the US Federal Reserve to move interest rates up "steadily" towards neutral, aiming to bring rates back to pre-pandemic levels "relatively soon." Barkin emphasized that policymaker decisions will depend on economic data.

site_title: Asia: Markets drop on Fed rate fears as US inflation rages
summary: Asian markets dropped on Friday amid concerns the Federal Reserve will raise interest rates aggressively to combat US inflation, which surged 7.5% in the previous month, its fastest in 40 years. The US Fed's stance has fueled uncertainty, with Fed official James Bullard suggesting interest rates should be lifted by July. The sell-off on Wall Street was mirrored in Asia, with stocks sinking before recovering.

site_title: Asia-Pacific real estate investments back to pre-pandemic levels in 2021: JLL
summary: Asia-Pacific real estate investments reached pre-pandemic levels in 2021, with US$177 billion in direct investments, according to JLL. This represents a 26% year-over-year increase, driven by surge in activity in Australia and China, and sustained resilience in Japan. Australia was the region's biggest draw, with US$35 billion in investment volumes, while logistics investments grew 50% year-over-year to US$48 billion. JLL predicts increased interest in larger deals and platform acquisitions in 2022, driven by robust rental growth and investors seeking to reposition portfolios.

site_title: Malaysia's foreign inflows to see greater differentiation for 2022: UOB
summary: Malaysia's foreign inflows are expected to show greater differentiation in 2022, according to UOB, despite increased investment in the country's capital markets in January. The bank attributes this to regional central banks' cautious approach to interest rates, increased global financial volatility, and domestic challenges such as high public debt and policy uncertainty. In January, foreign portfolio inflows totaled RM3.8 billion, with foreign debt inflows reaching RM4.6 billion, mostly into Malaysian government securities.

site_title: Hong Kong home sellers cut asking prices as Covid curbs tighten
summary: Hong Kong home sellers are cutting asking prices by up to 10% due to the city's strict Covid-19 measures, with property prices likely to drop 3-5% in the near term. Sellers are open to negotiating discounts as gatherings in private homes are restricted to 2 families. The city's housing market, already impacted by population outflow, interest rate increases, and restrictions on capital outflows, faces further challenges. Experts predict prices may fall as much as 10% in 2022, citing a 2-decade surge that saw prices near all-time highs last year.

site_title: EDB, SAP, Qualtrics commit S$14.1m to establish experience management centre in Singapore
summary: SAP, Qualtrics, and the Singapore Economic Development Board (EDB) are committing S$14.1 million to establish an experience management (XM) centre of excellence in Singapore. The centre will create up to 30 new roles, focusing on XM innovation in Asia, and aims to develop the XM discipline, build professional capabilities, and foster a community of XM professionals. The centre will benefit over 180,000 small and medium-sized enterprises, enabling them to use experience as a key competitive differentiator and unlock innovation to drive customer value and retention.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares fall at Friday's open
summary: Hong Kong stocks opened with a 0.35% loss on Friday morning, following a sell-off on Wall Street due to a forecast-beating US inflation reading and fears of a sharp interest rate hike. The Hang Seng Index fell to 24,837.20, while the Shanghai and Shenzhen Composite Indices also declined.

site_title: Malaysia economy rebounds while inflation, growth risks eyed
summary: Malaysia's economy rebounded to 3.6% GDP growth in the December quarter, exceeding expectations, driven by easing pandemic restrictions and vaccine booster shots. The country's full-year GDP growth reached 3.1%, within the forecast range of 3-4%. Despite risks from inflation, global growth, and supply chain issues, the economy is expected to accelerate in 2022, with growth projected at 5.5%. The central bank remains vigilant of inflation and will adjust monetary policy accordingly, while flagging potential rate hikes in the third quarter.

site_title: iX Biopharma swings into the black in H1 with S$3.7m profit on licensing agreement
summary: iX Biopharma, a Catalist-listed company, has reported a net profit of S$3.7 million for the first half of its fiscal year ended Dec 31, 2021, compared to a net loss of S$2.8 million the previous year. The turnaround in profitability was driven by the out-licensing of its lead drug Wafermine to Seelos Therapeutics in November 2021. Revenue increased to S$13.2 million, and gross profit reached S$12.1 million. The company expects to generate additional development and sales milestone payments of up to US$239 million and sales royalties.

site_title: South Korea petrochemical plant blast kills 4, but no impact on output
summary: An explosion at South Korea's Yeochun NCC petrochemical plant in Yeosu has killed four people and injured four. The incident occurred during a leak test and has not affected the plant's production. The plant's capacity is 2.29 million tonnes per year, accounting for about 1.1% of global capacity. The South Korean law punishing management for incidents involving worker death may impact production if stricter rules are imposed, but for now, there is no significant disruption. The incident is being investigated by the labour ministry.

site_title: UG Healthcare's H1FY22 net profit slides 61% on lower selling price, production volumes
summary: UG Healthcare Corp's net profit for H1 FY22 fell 61% year-on-year to S$21.2 million due to lower average selling price and softer production volumes. Revenue decreased 26% to S$117.3 million, while gross profit dropped 55.1% to S$44.6 million. The company attributed the decline to the pandemic's impact on manufacturing facilities and workforce capacity. Despite this, UG Healthcare remains confident in achieving better financial performance compared to pre-Covid times, driven by heightened hygiene awareness.

site_title: Tokyo: Markets closed on Friday for holidays
summary: Japan's financial markets closed on Friday for a public holiday, resuming trading on Monday, Feb 14. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks continued their 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. In other news, Popiah king Sam Goi made a mandatory offer for the rest of PSC at S$0.40 a share, and eSIM platform Airalo raised US$220 million in new funding, lifting its valuation past US$1 billion.

site_title: Reserve Bank of Australia sees risks in hiking rates too early
summary: Reserve Bank of Australia Governor Philip Lowe expressed concerns about raising interest rates too early, citing the potential to secure a lower unemployment rate than initially thought. Despite a recent surge in coronavirus cases, Lowe believes the economy will recover strongly and is willing to take on the risk of higher inflation to achieve this goal.

site_title: Apple aims to thwart secret AirTag tracking with tweaks
summary: Apple has updated its AirTag tracking devices to prevent misuse, such as secretly tracking people. The company has implemented new features, including an "unknown accessory detected" alert for new iPhone models and a software update that displays a warning advising against tracking people without consent. Apple will also share the identities of AirTag owners with police when warranted. The move comes after reports of AirTags being used for malicious purposes, including car theft and stalking. Apple condemns the misuse of its products and emphasizes that AirTag was designed to help people locate lost items, not track people.

site_title: Tesla plans to locate China design centre in Beijing: city government
summary: Tesla plans to establish a China design center in Beijing, according to a city government document. The company had previously announced plans to open such a center in 2020 to produce "Chinese-style" vehicles. The location was initially reported to be either Shanghai, where its factory is located, or Beijing. This move is part of Tesla's efforts to increase local production and design capabilities in the country.

site_title: South Korea's US$200b wealth fund is betting on the metaverse and AI startups
summary: South Korea's $200 billion sovereign wealth fund, Korea Investment (KIC), plans to boost investments in Silicon Valley startups, focusing on the metaverse and artificial intelligence. Under the new CEO, Seoungho Jin, KIC aims to increase alternative assets to 25% of its portfolio by 2025 and assets under management to $300 billion. Jin is also exploring investments in hotels, tech shares, and financial stocks, and plans to add staff to evaluate opportunities in emerging markets, including Indian bonds.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 5.09 points lower at 0.32% to 1,565.01 as of 9:07am on Friday. Losers outnumbered gainers 242 to 77, with a total volume of 168.39 million lots worth RM79.32 million.

site_title: Australia drops landmark criminal cartel case against Citi, Deutsche Bank
summary: Australia dropped a landmark criminal cartel case against Citigroup, Deutsche Bank, and several former executives over a $2.5 billion share issue, ending a nearly 4-year investigation. The case was withdrawn after the prosecutor narrowed the scope of the lawsuit, including dropping charges against the client, Australia and New Zealand Banking Group (ANZ). The decision marks a stunning retreat from a lawsuit that could have seen former executives behind bars, and the ACCC chair said the move represents a lesson in considering the impact on individuals involved.

site_title: Telework in metaverse precursors already a reality
summary: Telework in the metaverse is already a reality for some, with virtual reality headgear allowing individuals to access remote workspaces from various locations. Forerunners of the metaverse vision are being adopted by a handful of people beyond gamers and techno-hipsters. This trend is expected to shape the internet's future, with the metaverse potentially offering new opportunities for remote work and collaboration. As the metaverse continues to develop, it may become a norm for remote work, blurring the lines between physical and virtual workspaces.

site_title: First Reit H2 DPU drops 29.2% to S$0.0131 after rights units issuance
summary: First Reit's distribution per unit (DPU) dropped 29.2% to S$0.0131 in the second half of 2021, despite a 41.5% increase in distributable income to S$21.2 million. This was due to the issuance of 791.1 million rights units, which diluted the DPU. The Reit's top line and net property and other income grew 54.6% and 56.8% respectively in the second half, driven by accounting treatment for rental income. The Reit's assets are 100% master-leased, and it continues to operate under precautionary measures due to the pandemic.

site_title: China guarantees support for Hong Kong amid Covid surge
summary: China guarantees full support for Hong Kong as it battles a surge in COVID-19 cases, with the territory's hospital capacity nearing maximum. The central government is "highly concerned" about residents' safety and the economy, and will hold a meeting with officials to develop policies to support Hong Kong's fight against the disease. China has previously assisted Hong Kong with mass testing schemes, and has pledged to ensure the supply of essential goods, including vegetables, amid a run on the commodity. The city's strict restrictions have turned it into one of the world's most isolated cities.

site_title: SGX rejects Hong Lai Huat's proposed warrants issuance
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has rejected Hong Lai Huat's proposed issuance of 80 million warrants to investment bank Soochow CSSD Capital Markets (Asia) due to a lack of commercial rationale. The warrants, exercisable at prices ranging from $0.30 to $0.45, would have raised approximately $29.3 million for general working capital purposes. The SGX cited high exercise prices and a lack of clear fund-raising intentions as reasons for the rejection, following HLH's announcement in November 2021.

site_title: International bookings to South-east Asia rising as borders open: Skyscanner
summary: International bookings to Southeast Asian countries increased sharply in January as borders reopened, according to Skyscanner data. The region's airlines are optimistic about the recovery, with countries like Thailand, the Philippines, and Vietnam seeing a 19-300% rise in return economy-class bookings from the US, Britain, and Germany. Australia's border reopening on February 21 led to a 200% rise in bookings on the first day, and Qantas Airways plans to restart several international routes in the coming weeks. This positive trend is seen as a sign of the region's hard-hit airlines recovering from the pandemic.

images.alt_text: International bookings for flights to South-east Asian countries that are relaxing tight pandemic-related border controls rose sharply in January, data from online travel company Skyscanner shows, in a positive sign for the region's hard-hit airlines.

site_title: CAG unit green-lights re-auction of concession for Rio de Janeiro airport
summary: Changi Airport Group's subsidiary Changi Airports International has approved a re-auction of the concession for Tom Jobim International Airport in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. The re-auction application, submitted by the airport's manager, is subject to regulatory approval and will result in a new operator being defined in an auction structured by the federal government. The current concession, set to expire in 2039, will continue to operate until the process is completed, with the airport's manager remaining responsible for operations and upholding standards. The decision aims to address the challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic and Brazil's economic recession.

images.alt_text: Above: People walking in the Tom Jobim International airport in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. CAI is the majority shareholder of the Brazilian airport's operator, which submitted the re-auction application on Feb 10 to the regulator National Civil Aviation Agency of Brazil (ANAC).

site_title: Gold slips as chances of hefty Fed rate hike rise after CPI data
summary: Gold prices fell 0.1% to $1,825.29 per ounce due to a stronger-than-expected US inflation reading and hawkish comments from Federal Reserve official James Bullard, increasing the odds of a 50 basis point interest rate hike. US consumer prices rose solidly in January, leading to the largest annual inflation increase in 40 years, and benchmark 10-year Treasury yields rose to near 2% as rate futures showed a 62% chance of a 50 basis point hike in March.

site_title: Tesla undertaking fourth car recall in 2 weeks
summary: Tesla is recalling over 578,600 US electric cars due to a "Boombox" feature that can interfere with audible warnings for pedestrians, increasing the risk of a collision. The feature, launched in 2020, allows custom sounds to be emitted from an outdoor speaker when the car is parked or moving. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) plans to update the software remotely rather than requiring owners to visit service centers. This is the fourth recall by Tesla in two weeks, amid increasing scrutiny from American regulators over safety concerns.

site_title: Europe: Shares edge lower as rising yields, weak results rattle tech
summary: European shares ended 0.2% lower, driven by rising bond yields and weak results from tech companies, including France's Atos. The tech sector sank 1.1%, despite positive earnings from Linde and Siemens. The Stoxx 600 index was also pressured by US inflation data, which created space for a more hawkish Federal Reserve.

site_title: Altara Ventures closes inaugural fund for early-stage startups at US$130m
summary: ALTARA Ventures, a Singapore-based venture firm, has closed its debut fund at US$130 million. Led by 5 general partners, the firm has made 7 investments, including in Philippine digibank Tonik, Indian fintech Stashfin, and Malaysian insurtech PolicyStreet. Altara will focus on deploying capital into Series A and B investments in fintech, consumer tech, and edtech, which it considers the fastest-growing market opportunity segments. The firm expects 2022 to offer more market opportunities for entrepreneurs to capture, with plans to close 3 new investments in Q1.

site_title: mDR to be restrained by court from dealing with property related to loan dispute
summary: The court has restrained mDR Limited from dealing with a property linked to its loan dispute with MKY Capital, pending final determination on an originating summons. The property, used to secure a S$24 million loan, was appointed as a receiver after MKY defaulted on interest payments. The court order prohibits mDR and its receivers from selling, disposing of, or otherwise dealing with the property. This move comes after mDR terminated its chief operating officer following investigations into suspected misconduct and unauthorized use of marketing incentive rebates.

site_title: Deliveroo partners with Waitrose for 10-minute hummus delivery
summary: Deliveroo has partnered with Waitrose to offer 10-minute grocery delivery in southern London's Bermondsey neighborhood. The trial service, initially launched in 20 minutes, aims to cut delivery time in half. The partnership will be available from 8 am to midnight, offering over 1,000 Waitrose lines on the Deliveroo app. This move is part of Deliveroo's expansion into the on-demand grocery delivery market, which has seen significant investment and startup growth.

site_title: Expedia swings to profit even after Omicron setbacks
summary: Expedia Group reported a fourth-quarter profit of $276 million, beating analysts' estimates, despite the Omicron Covid-19 variant disrupting travel. Revenue more than doubled to $2.28 billion, driven by a resilient holiday travel season. Expedia's US net room nights booked declined 18% from 2019, but infection rates receding suggest a travel recovery. CEO Peter Kern expects continued growth, citing work-from-anywhere policies and short-term rental reservations. The stock gained 5% in extended trading, pushing shares to a record high.

site_title: US lawmakers introduce bipartisan bill to address social media addiction
summary: US Senators Amy Klobuchar and Cynthia Lummis introduced a bipartisan bill to address social media addiction. The bill aims to study potential interventions to address social media addiction issues and create rules for platforms to address problems such as spreading misinformation. The National Science Foundation and National Academy of Sciences will conduct the study, and the Federal Trade Commission will hold platforms accountable if they do not comply. This comes after a Facebook whistleblower revealed that Instagram was harmful to teenagers, and other platforms have faced allegations of spreading misinformation.

site_title: Australia: Shares sink on tech sell-off after US inflation data; miners shine
summary: Australian shares fell 0.5% to 7,249.5 on Friday, snapping a three-day winning streak, amid a sell-off in technology stocks following a hot US inflation reading. The benchmark rose 0.3% on Thursday and is on course for a 1.7% gain this week. Heavyweight miners, such as BHP Group and Rio Tinto, limited losses with a 0.9% climb, driven by a firm iron ore price. Reserve Bank of Australia Governor Philip Lowe reiterated his reluctance to raise interest rates, citing concerns over employment goals.

site_title: Singapore stocks fall at Friday's open; STI down 0.3%
summary: Singapore stocks fell 0.3% at the opening of trading on Friday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3,417.76. The decline followed US stocks' sharp drop overnight due to inflation concerns and potential monetary policy tightening. Losers outnumbered gainers 105 to 43, with actively traded counters including QT Vascular, Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust, and Jiutian Chemical experiencing declines.

site_title: Australia lists koalas as endangered in 2 eastern states
summary: Australia has listed koalas as endangered in two eastern states due to prolonged drought, bushfires, and habitat loss. The Environment Minister stated that the decision aims to ensure a healthy future for the koala. The listing highlights the challenges the species is facing, with scientists warning that the koala could become extinct unless immediate action is taken to protect habitats. The move is part of a broader effort to address the decline of the iconic Australian mammal.

site_title: Daiwa House Logistics Trust portfolio valuation up 14.1% from purchase consideration
summary: Daiwa House Logistics Trust's portfolio valuation rose 14.1% to S$949.7 million as of end-December 2021, up from its initial purchase consideration. The trust's net asset value per unit increased to S$0.92, and aggregate leverage decreased to 37.7%. Total borrowings stood at 35.6 million yen, with a weighted average debt tenure of 3.4 years. The trust's gross revenue and distributable income also beat forecasts, and the manager expects demand for logistics space in Japan to remain "robust" despite some market fluctuations.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Daiwa House Logistics Trust, MNACT, MCT, First Reit, F&N
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Stocks to watch include Daiwa House Logistics Trust, Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust, First Reit, Fraser & Neave, and Wing Tai, with notable developments including a business update from Daiwa House Logistics Trust, a merger proposal from Mapletree North Asia Commercial Trust, and a distribution per unit decrease from First Reit. Other companies reported earnings and revenue changes, with Wing Tai and Oxley posting lower profits and Fraser & Neave experiencing a revenue decline. The Singapore Exchange rejected Hong Lai Huat Group's proposed issuance of non-listed warrants.

site_title: Skoda pulls a fast one with the Octavia RS
summary: Skoda has launched the redesigned Octavia RS in Singapore, priced at S$199,900, including a Certificate Of Entitlement. The new model aims to counter rising COE premiums with its powerful engine. This is Skoda's attempt to kick-start 2022 with a strong lineup, showcasing the brand's efforts to stay competitive in the local market.

site_title: Prince Charles tests positive for Covid-19 for second time
summary: Prince Charles has tested positive for Covid-19 for the second time, isolating himself after meeting the Queen at Windsor two days prior. The 73-year-old monarch, 95, is not currently displaying symptoms. Buckingham Palace has not confirmed whether the Queen tested positive. Charles had recently unveiled a statue in Winchester and had met several people, including finance minister Rishi Sunak, before his second positive test. He has been fully vaccinated against Covid-19 and is following isolation protocols.

site_title: US woman held hostage saved after failing to share Wordle score
summary: An 80-year-old US woman, Denyse Holt, was rescued from being held hostage in her Chicago home after a 32-year-old man broke in on February 5. Holt was forced to take a bath with the suspect, James H Davis III, who had cuts and blood on him after breaking a window. Her daughter's failure to receive her daily Wordle score alerted authorities, leading to a 1-hour standoff and eventual rescue using a stun gun. Davis faces charges of home invasion and aggravated kidnapping, and police suspect he suffers from a mental illness.

site_title: Indonesia to buy US, French warplanes as Paris boosts Asia alliances
summary: Indonesia has ordered 42 Rafale fighter jets from France, with a potential deal for two Scorpene submarines also in the works. The US has approved a sale of 36 F-15s to Indonesia, valued at $14 billion. The agreements come as Indonesia replaces its ageing fleet and amid growing tensions in the Asia-Pacific. French President Emmanuel Macron welcomed the deal, saying it would strengthen partnerships, while Indonesia's Defence Minister Prabowo Subianto confirmed the Rafale contract worth $8.1 billion. The deals mark a boost to Indonesia's military capabilities and come as France rethinks its alliances in the region.

site_title: China suspends Lithuanian beef imports as Taiwan row grows
summary: China has suspended imports of beef from Lithuania amid a growing trade dispute over the Baltic nation's relations with Taiwan, which Beijing claims as Chinese territory. The suspension, announced by China's General Administration of Customs, comes after Britain joined the US and Australia in backing an EU trade case against China over alleged trade curbs on Lithuania. Lithuania had not exported beef to China since early December 2021, and its exports to China fell 91% in December compared to 2020. China's move is seen as retaliation against Lithuania's decision to allow Taiwan to open a de facto embassy in its capital.

site_title: EU chief unveils 150b euro investment plan for Africa
summary: EU Chief Ursula von der Leyen unveiled a 150 billion euro investment plan for Africa as part of the European Union's Global Gateway, aiming to mobilize up to 300 billion euros by 2027. The plan targets renewable energy, disaster risk reduction, internet access, and education, and is seen as a response to China's Belt and Road initiative. Von der Leyen stated that Europe is Africa's biggest and most reliable partner, and the funds will be raised and spent with transparency, sustainability, and good governance in mind.

site_title: The power of chat
summary: Retailers in Singapore and Malaysia turned to chatbots during pandemic-driven lockdowns to manage online orders. Chat apps have become a key technology in social commerce, offering a personalized shopping experience. Businesses are incorporating AI-driven chatbots into their messenger apps, with a diverse customer base including banks, insurance companies, and retail conglomerates. This shift reflects the growing importance of chat in replicating the physical shopping experience and improving customer engagement.

site_title: US, Asia allies meet to deepen bulwark against China
summary: US, Australian, Japanese, and Indian diplomats met in Melbourne to strengthen the Quad alliance, countering China's growing influence in the Asia-Pacific region. The US sees China's expansion as a long-term challenge to the traditional order, while Australia's Foreign Minister emphasized the importance of liberal democracies cooperating to ensure nations can make their own strategic decisions. The talks aim to deepen cooperation and promote stability in the region.

site_title: Oil prices fall on fears of aggressive Federal Reserve rate hike
summary: Oil prices fell on Thursday, with Brent crude futures dropping 27 cents to $91.26 a barrel, despite forecasts of rising energy demand. The decline came amid fears that the US Federal Reserve will hike interest rates more aggressively to combat inflation, leading to a stronger dollar and increased costs for oil producers. US stock markets also fell, and OPEC's report showed the organization may not meet its pledged oil output rise in January, adding to price uncertainty.

site_title: Bank of England's Bailey sees no need for EU time limit on euro clearing access
summary: Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey stated that the European Union should not have set a time limit on how long Britain's clearing houses can serve customers in the bloc, as it could disrupt markets. The EU extended temporary equivalence for Britain's derivatives clearing houses by three years to June 2025. Bailey argued that maintaining open markets and regulatory standards is crucial for financial stability, making a time limit unnecessary. The EU's decision aims to prevent an abrupt end to cross-Channel activity, which would have disrupted euro-denominated transactions.

site_title: Riksbank's calm over inflation hurts Swedish krona
summary: The Swedish krona fell against the US dollar and euro due to the Riksbank's dovish stance on inflation, keeping monetary policy plans unchanged. The US dollar rose 0.9% against the krona, a 1-week high, while the euro also increased 0.9% against the krona, a 10-day high. Investors await US inflation data for clues on the Federal Reserve's policy tightening trajectory, with a 70.5% chance of a 25 basis point rate hike at its March meeting.

site_title: Biden could well rise from the dead
summary: US President Joe Biden faces significant political challenges, with a recent Reuters/Ipsos poll showing 56% disapproval and 41% approval of his performance. However, his approval ratings seem to correlate with the increase in coronavirus cases and inflation. Despite this, the US economy has shown resilience, with the strongest first year of job gains since the federal government began collecting economic data. The economy is expected to continue recovering, and the Biden administration may use this momentum to reboot public confidence in his handling of the economy. A strong economic performance could also help Biden shift to the political centre and improve his approval rating before the mid-term elections in November.

site_title: Singapore commercial real estate investment volume bounces back in 2021: report
summary: Singapore's commercial real estate investment volume rebounded in 2021, reaching US$9 billion, a triple-digit increase from 2020. Overseas capital drove the market recovery, with Singapore investors spending a record US$16 billion on the rest of Asia-Pacific. The market saw significant growth across various sectors, including offices, retail, hotels, and new economy assets. The industrial sector continued to attract capital, with investment more than tripling over the past 5 years. Singapore's commercial property market is expected to remain a top target for global investors.

site_title: US: Stocks end lower on worries over inflation, Fed policy
summary: US stocks ended lower on Thursday, snapping a two-day winning streak, due to concerns over inflation and the Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hikes. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 1.5%, the S&P 500 dropped 1.8%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index declined 2.1%. The inflation report showed a 7.5% increase in the US consumer price index, prompting investors to bet on a bigger interest rate increase in March. The comments from St. Louis Fed President James Bullard also fueled concerns, leading to a shift in market bets and a lift in the yield on the 10-year US Treasury note.

site_title: GenScript opens new S$15m Singapore manufacturing facility, to create 100 jobs
summary: GenScript Biotech has opened a new S$15 million manufacturing facility in Singapore, creating nearly 100 jobs in research and development, production, and supply chain fields. The facility is part of the company's expansion in the region.

site_title: SocGen seals rebound with record year
summary: Societe Generale SA reported a record annual profit, marking its first profitable year in decades. The French lender's main businesses exceeded analyst estimates in the fourth quarter, driven by a resurgent equities trading unit and record earnings from financing and advisory. Revenue jumped 13% in the final months of last year, with net income almost quadrupling.

site_title: Brexit talks are stuck with little hope of progress before May
summary: Brexit talks between the European Union and UK have stalled with no progress on post-Brexit trading relationship in Northern Ireland. Despite a more constructive tone, diplomats see little chance of substantial progress until the May election. The UK and EU have not moved on the substance of their differences, despite increased discussion.

site_title: Novavax says Covid vaccine more than 80% effective among teens
summary: Novavax announced its Covid-19 vaccine is 82% effective among adolescents aged 12-17, based on a phase three clinical trial. The two-dose vaccine, using synthetic proteins to mimic the virus's spikes, was found safe and effective among over 2,200 teens. The company plans to submit for regulatory approval in this age group. This news comes as an alternative to existing vaccine options, and the results are encouraging for the ongoing need for Covid-19 vaccines.

images.alt_text: Novavax said on Thursday its Covid vaccine was 82 per cent effective among adolescents during the period when the Delta variant was dominant, and the US biotech now plans to submit for regulatory approval in this age group.

site_title: The hybrid MG that wants you to take charge
summary: The MG HS PHEV is a plug-in hybrid electric vehicle that combines smooth electric drive with long-distance petrol power. It offers a seamless driving experience, with the ability to drive up to 52km on electric power and then switch to the 1.5-litre turbo engine for longer trips. The vehicle has a range of 137.7km on a full battery, with fuel efficiency of 1.1 litres per 100km. With its affordable price tag of S$109,888, the MG HS PHEV is a viable option for those looking to reduce their carbon footprint without committing to a full electric vehicle.

site_title: When time tells a story
summary: Van Cleef & Arpels is hosting an exhibition, "A Journey Through The Poetry of Time", at Marina Bay Sands in Singapore from Feb 12 to 20, featuring 200 luxury timepieces and high jewelry. The exhibition showcases the brand's beautiful craftsmanship and the stories behind each piece, with a focus on the "Encounters on the Lovers' Bridge" theme. The collection includes iconic Pont des Amoureux timepieces celebrating love, as well as other pieces inspired by nature, music, and dance. The exhibition is free but strictly by appointment only, with a limited capacity of 3,000 guests.

site_title: Logistics new contender in top digitally mature sectors on the back of e-commerce
summary: The Manufacturing Transformation Insights Report identified the top 5 most digitally mature sectors in manufacturing, including semiconductor electronics, pharmaceuticals, energy and chemicals, logistics, and medical technology firms. These sectors have achieved digital maturity due to their leaders' vision, according to the report.

site_title: Hong Kong Covid-19 infections surge; Carrie Lam 'deeply sorry' for long queues for testing and isolation
summary: Hong Kong reported 986 new coronavirus infections on February 10, a 10-fold increase since February 1. The city is struggling to contain the outbreak, with medical experts warning that daily cases could reach 28,000 by March and 1,000 deaths by June. Leader Carrie Lam apologized for long queues for testing and isolation, citing the unvaccinated elderly as a concern. The city's "dynamic zero" policy is being tested, and Lam said the government is working to enhance capacity, but vaccination rates have finally surged, particularly among the elderly.

site_title: Panel recommends further probe into Singh, fine for Raeesah
