site_title: Upcoming GST hike seen as key to improving fiscal sustainability
summary: Singapore's Budget 2022 is expected to focus on fiscal sustainability, with at least three tax forms under consideration, including a Goods and Services Tax (GST) hike. A 2-percentage point GST increase could bring in S$3.2 billion in additional revenue annually, and its implementation may take place this year or in mid-2023, depending on economic conditions. The government has committed a S$6 billion Assurance Package to delay the impact of the increase by at least 5 years for most households.

site_title: Major global companies largely fail net-zero pledges
summary: A corporate climate responsibility report found that 25 major global companies have failed their net-zero climate pledge tests, with only 3 companies (Maersk, Vodafone, and Deutsche Telekom) meeting the 90% decarbonization target. The report revealed that companies' net-zero targets are often vague, and only 13 of the 25 companies have explicit emission reduction commitments, averaging a 40% reduction. Many companies are criticized for excluding downstream or upstream emissions, reducing the effectiveness of their targets.

site_title: Spooked by rate-hike fears, S-Reit sell-off could offer opportunity to dive in
summary: S-Reit sell-off in 2022, driven by US Federal Reserve interest rate hike fears, may be overdone. Despite 5.5% year-to-date decline, the iEdge S-Reit Index still outperforms the benchmark Straits Times Index (7.8%). Rising interest rates may negatively impact dividend-driven investments like Reits, but some managers are well-positioned with fixed-rate exposures and diversified debt maturity profiles. Analysts expect attractive yield spreads and forecasted 6.1% yield for FY2022, outweighing market concerns.

site_title: Covid-19 had 'no material impact' on FLCT's portfolio despite challenges to retail segment
summary: Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust (FLCT) reported a Q1 2022 distributable income of S$0.2 million lower due to rental waivers and doubtful receivables. However, this had no material impact on the REIT's portfolio. The retail segment, representing 1.7% of income, was more challenged. Despite this, FLCT's logistics and industrial portfolio occupancy rate stood at 100%, and its weighted average lease expiry was 4.6 years. The REIT announced the divestment of Cross Street Exchange, expected to raise occupancy rates and lower leverage.

site_title: Rate hikes are coming too slowly in Asia for some bond funds
summary: Asian bond funds are lukewarm on the region's debt due to slow rate hikes, with Fidelity and abrdn avoiding Asian local debt and favoring bonds in Latin America and Europe instead. Most Asian local bonds have fallen this year, while countries like Brazil, Chile, and Turkey have seen gains. Central banks in Latin America and Europe are ahead of the curve in tightening monetary policy, creating scope for a rally in the region's debt. Experts expect rate cuts in Brazil and Russia, which could lure funds into the region's bonds.

site_title: EU in talks with other gas suppliers amid concern over Russian delivery
summary: The European Union is in talks with the US and other suppliers to boost gas deliveries to Europe amid concerns over Russian supply due to escalating tensions with Ukraine. EU Commission President Ursula von der Leyen stated that Russia's energy giant Gazprom is uninterested in increasing gas supplies despite record-high prices and huge demand. The EU is building a partnership for energy security with the US, and talks are also ongoing with Qatar and Azerbaijan. Gas prices could remain high due to a potential halt in Russian supply, and the EU has rolled out measures to shield consumers from higher bills.

images.alt_text: Gazprom has cut its daily volume of gas transit via Ukraine to Europe to about 53 million cubic metres (mcm) so far in January 2022. The volume was an average 124.6 mcm in 2021.

site_title: Toshiba plans to split into 2 instead of 3, hike shareholder return targets
summary: Toshiba has revised its restructuring plan, aiming to split into 2 companies instead of 3, focusing on its device business and power chip unit. The company also plans to increase shareholder returns to 300 billion yen (S$3.5 billion) over the next 2 years. The revised plan, which was initially met with resistance from foreign hedge funds, aims to save costs and facilitate alliances with strategic partners. The plan will be put to a shareholder vote in March, with an approval threshold set at just over 50%.

site_title: Ezion enters into contract for charter, disposal of vessel
summary: Ezion, a liftboat operator, has entered into a 24-month bareboat charter and obligation to purchase agreement to dispose of vessel Teras Conquest 1 to April Pearl, a subsidiary of JUB Pacific, for a minimum consideration of US$11.35 million. The estimated gain from disposal is US$3.77 million to US$3.84 million. The consideration will be used to reduce outstanding liabilities and discharge the mortgage over the vessel. Trading of Ezion shares had been suspended since early 2019.

site_title: Dating app owner Bumble buys France's Fruitz in first acquisition
summary: Bumble Inc, a dating app company, has acquired France's Fruitz in its first acquisition, aiming to strengthen its presence in Europe. Fruitz, launched in 2017, is a popular freemium dating app among Gen Z users. The deal marks Bumble's entry into the European market, where it will compete with Match Group, the owner of Tinder. The acquisition sets the stage for Bumble to challenge Match Group's dominance in the European dating app market.

site_title: Jackass Forever catapults to box office summit as Moonfall craters
summary: Jackass Forever, a comedy film, topped the North American box office with $23 million from 3,604 locations, defeating Spider-Man: No Way Home. The film's success is surprising, as a pure comedy has not claimed the top spot in a while. Critics praised the film's 90% Rotten Tomatoes score and B+ CinemaScore from audience members. In contrast, disaster epic Moonfall, starring Halle Berry, fell short with $10.1 million in ticket sales, despite a $140 million production budget.

site_title: Euro dips after US jobs data aids dollar rebound
summary: The euro dropped 0.2% to US$1.1425 on Monday, following a surge last week driven by the European Central Bank's hawkish turn, as traders shifted to the US dollar, betting on faster Federal Reserve rate hikes. The euro's decline was attributed to market expectations of a rate hike in July, with ECB policymaker Martins Kazaks pushing back against the timing. Meanwhile, the US dollar gained support from better-than-expected jobs data and rising Treasury yields, which have led markets to price in a one-in-three chance of a 50-basis-point Fed rate hike in March.

site_title: PriceRunner sues Google for 2.1b euros, prepares for long fight
summary: Swedish price comparison firm PriceRunner is suing Alphabet-owned Google for approximately 2.1 billion euros, alleging the search giant manipulated search results to give itself an unfair advantage over smaller European rivals. This lawsuit follows Google's loss in a 2017 fine of 2.42 billion euros for similar practices. PriceRunner, set to be acquired by Klarna, claims it has secured external financing and is prepared to fight the lawsuit for many years, with the goal of ensuring real choice in shopping services for European consumers.

site_title: China's Jan services activity expands at slowest rate in 5 months: Caixin PMI
summary: China's services sector activity expanded at the slowest pace in 5 months in January, according to a private survey, with the Caixin/Markit services Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) dropping to 51.4. The decline was attributed to Covid-19 outbreaks and foreign demand, leading to a fall in employment. Policymakers are expected to roll out more support measures to stabilize the economy, which has been growing at its weakest rate in 1.5 years.

site_title: Crypto firms launch coalition to promote market integrity
summary: A coalition of major cryptocurrency firms, including Circle, Anchorage Digital, and Huobi Global, has launched the Crypto Market Integrity Coalition to promote market integrity and prevent manipulation. The coalition urges companies to sign a "market integrity" pledge, which acknowledges the potential for fraud and the need to protect investors. The move comes as regulators remain concerned about the safety of the industry, with the Securities and Exchange Commission citing market manipulation as a primary reason for rejecting several applications for spot bitcoin exchange-traded funds.

site_title: Australia retail sales soar to record high 8.2% in Q4 2021
summary: Australia's retail sales surged to a record 8.2% in Q4 2021, driven by relaxed virus restrictions and holiday shopping. This rebound outpaced economists' expectations and boosted confidence in the economy's recovery. The sales surge was led by clothing, cafes, and restaurants, while food retailing declined. The result is expected to influence the Reserve Bank of Australia's decision to raise interest rates in the second half of the year, as a surge in household spending is seen as a key factor.

site_title: Tesla's Bitcoin holdings worth nearly US$2b: filing
summary: Tesla reported its bitcoin holdings' fair market value as of Dec 31 at US$1.99 billion, down from US$1.50 billion due to a drop in bitcoin's value. The company recorded impairment losses of US$101 million and gained US$128 million on bitcoin sales. Tesla briefly accepted bitcoin as payment but stopped due to environmental concerns.

site_title: Singapore's role in regional sustainable financing
summary: Singapore is set to tap into the growing demand for sustainable and green finance in the region, with the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) rolling out schemes to promote this emerging form of financing. The authority aims to simplify the ESG disclosure process and partner with the financial industry to set up a common disclosure portal. MAS will also launch a data orchestrator to aggregate ESG data from different sectoral platforms and trusted data sources. With an estimated $200 billion in green investment needed in ASEAN by 2030, Singapore is positioning itself as a key player in the region's sustainable financing landscape.

site_title: Paris announces launch of multi-billion euro tech fund in Europe
summary: France announces a multi-billion euro tech fund to boost European tech investment and reduce dependence on foreign giants. The fund will provide at least €1 billion to finance tech champions and support 10-20 funds. The goal is to have 10 tech companies worth over €100 billion by 2030. This move aims to address the lack of financing for European start-ups, which often turn to larger US funds.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 7.89 points, or 0.52%, to 1,530.65 on Monday, with a trading volume of 3.08 billion lots worth RM2.30 billion. Gainers outnumbered losers 539 to 383.

site_title: Hong Kong residents raid supermarket shelves as Covid surge disrupts supplies
summary: Hong Kong residents stockpiled essential items like vegetables, noodles, and tissues as a record 614 Covid-19 cases were reported, disrupting food supplies. The city imports 90% of its food from mainland China, exacerbating concerns. Several cross-border truck drivers tested positive, forcing them to isolate, but supplies "remained stable." Supermarkets were seen with bare shelves, and vendors warned of a 30% drop in vegetable supply. Residents scrambled to buy essentials ahead of potential shortages.

site_title: US on the road to 1950s-style unemployment, but it may only be a pit stop
summary: The US unemployment rate is predicted to fall below 3% this year, a level last seen in the 1950s, which historically preceded a recession. This pattern poses a challenge to the Federal Reserve as it seeks to slow inflation without harming the economy, which is experiencing strong gains for workers. Experts, including St. Louis Fed President James Bullard, are concerned about the potential consequences of a falling unemployment rate, warning of a possible pit stop before a more severe economic downturn.

site_title: Hot stock: SGX shares rise 5.3% amid heavy trading on married deals
summary: SGX shares surged 5.3% on Monday amid heavy trading, with 12 married deals taking place throughout the day. The counter reached its highest price since October 2021, closing at S$9.86. Analyst Thilan Wickramasinghe upgraded SGX to "buy" from "hold", citing potential for Chinese and South-east Asian homecoming listings and increased demand for derivatives to manage risk. Despite a 8.8% decline in net profit, Wickramasinghe expects an inflection in the bourse's performance due to Singapore's value-oriented investment destination and regional reopening.

site_title: Tyson Foods raises meat prices to outrun higher supply costs
summary: Tyson Foods, the largest US meat company, has raised meat prices to counter higher supply costs. The company aims to boost productivity, targeting $1 billion in savings by 2024, to offset tight labor markets and smaller livestock herds. Tyson reported adjusted earnings per share of $2.87, up from $1.94 last year, and increased sales to $12.9 billion. Beef prices jumped 32%, while chicken and pork prices rose 20% and 13%, respectively. The company's efforts to boost productivity and use automated technology will help offset labor and supply chain pressures.

site_title: LTA awards S$363m civil contract for Cross Island Line Phase 1
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) has awarded a S$363 million civil contract to Singapore Engineering and Construction and Sinohydro Corporation (Singapore Branch) for the design and construction of Pasir Ris East station and tunnels under the Cross Island Line (CRL) Phase 1. Construction is expected to start in 2022, with passenger service set to begin in 2030. The 29-kilometer phase will feature 12 stations, serving over 100,000 households and is expected to be completed by 2029. Measures will be taken to minimize the impact on residents and motorists during construction.

site_title: Oil falls on positive signals from US-Iran talks
summary: Oil prices fell on Monday, with Brent crude down 31 cents to $92.96 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude down 78 cents to $91.53 a barrel. The decline was driven by positive signals from US-Iran nuclear talks, which could lead to a removal of US sanctions on Iranian oil sales. The US administration restored sanctions waivers to Iran to allow international nuclear cooperation projects, seen as a positive signal by the markets that both sides are determined to reach a deal. This could lead to an increase in Iranian oil exports, driving down oil prices.

site_title: Local stocks kick off week in the black, STI advances 1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 1% to 3,366.48 on its first trading day of the week, following positive Wall Street gains on Friday. Local investor sentiment was boosted by positive jobs data figures for January. The top gainers included Jardine Matheson Holdings, UOB, DBS, and iFast Corporation. Meanwhile, AEM Holdings and Nanofilm Technologies were the biggest losers. Markets across the region were mixed, with the Hang Seng Index up 0.03% and China's SSE Composite Index up 2%.

site_title: Italy expects EU carbon price of 80 euros per tonne this year
summary: Italy expects the European Union's carbon price to average around 80 euros per tonne this year, resulting in an estimated 3.36 billion euros in additional revenue to curb energy bills and offer relief to households and businesses. This would be a significant increase from the 69 euros per tonne in the fourth quarter of 2021. The government aims to use these funds to cut system-cost levies and help families and firms affected by rising energy costs.

site_title: MAS orders DBS to set aside S$930m more in regulatory capital over serious service failure
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has ordered DBS to set aside an additional S$930 million in regulatory capital due to the bank's serious digital disruption in November last year. The disruption, which lasted for two days, left many customers unable to access online banking services. MAS has also directed DBS to appoint an independent expert to conduct a comprehensive review of the incident and implement measures to prevent future disruptions. The additional capital requirement is the highest ever imposed on DBS, with a multiplier of 1.5 times applied to its risk-weighted assets for operational risk.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shanghai stocks rally on return from long break
summary: Chinese stocks rallied on their first day back from a week-long Chinese New Year break, with the Shanghai Composite Index adding 2.03% to 3,429.58. Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index also rose 6.26 points to 24,579.55. The global rally influenced the gains, with investors playing catch-up after the break.

site_title: Six global trends in business and society
summary: Business and society are grappling with six major trends, including climate change, socio-economic risks, and growing inequality. The 2022 Edelman Trust Barometer reveals people believe business should address societal problems, but perceive it as not doing enough. Climate change is the top priority, with extreme weather and climate action failure posing significant threats. Inequality between and within countries worsens, with the top 1% producing twice as many emissions as the bottom 50%. Consumers and employees increasingly hold businesses accountable, driving demand for ESG reporting and climate action.

site_title: The next big thing
summary: Fidelity International portfolio manager Jon Guinness discusses the future of technology, citing accelerated adoption of e-commerce, gaming, and enterprise software as major secular themes. Guinness highlights the growing importance of IT for businesses, enabling sustainability gains, and notes that technology scores relatively well in terms of greenhouse gas emissions. He emphasizes the need for companies to address digital ethics issues, such as cybersecurity, data governance, and ethical AI. Guinness also expects the Metaverse to become a significant market, with hardware and semiconductor makers benefiting first, followed by software and services providers. On valuations, Guinness looks for underappreciated growth among companies with proven end markets and robust fundamentals.

site_title: Keppel Corp names inaugural chief digital officer and chief sustainability officer
summary: Keppel Corp appoints Manjot Singh Mann as chief digital officer and Ho Tong Yen as chief sustainability officer, effective March 1. Mann, former CEO of M1, will lead the group's digital strategy, while Yen, current director of group corporate communications, will oversee sustainability efforts. Both appointments align with Keppel's Vision 2030, driving the company's transformation and long-term strategy.

site_title: GlobalWafers aims for March decision on greenfield expansion
summary: GlobalWafers aims to decide on a new greenfield site by the end of March as part of its $3.6 billion expansion plan. The company, which failed to acquire German chip supplier Siltronic, plans to redirect funds from the now-ended takeover and invest $2 billion in the new site. The move aims to boost production and address Europe's semiconductor shortage, which has highlighted the continent's dependence on Asian suppliers. GlobalWafers expects total capital expenditure to reach $100 billion between 2022 and 2024.

site_title: Bitcoin posts longest rally since September
summary: Bitcoin rose for a 5th consecutive day, the longest winning streak since September, gaining as much as 3.2% to US$43,017, as investors re-embraced risk assets. This rally comes after the cryptocurrency lost nearly half its value in "crypto winter." Analyst Nathan Batchelor suggests a short squeeze in the market, with Bitcoin potentially targeting the US$45,000 level if it breaks above US$43,000. The strengthening relationship between Bitcoin and the Nasdaq 100 index has emerged in recent months, with a correlation of 0.43.

site_title: Rate hikes are coming too slowly in Asia for some bond funds
summary: Asian bond funds are lukewarm on local debt due to slow rate hikes in the region. Fidelity and abrdn are avoiding Asian local bonds, favoring Latin American and European debt instead. Central banks in Latin America have already started tightening monetary policy, while Asia's central banks are expected to follow in the third quarter. Countries like Brazil, Chile, and Turkey have recorded significant gains, while Indonesia and Malaysia have kept rates on hold. The prospect of rate cuts in Brazil and Russia is attracting investors, with some funds seeing attractive value in their bonds.

site_title: CSE Global wins S$131.2 million in new orders in Q4 21
summary: CSE Global secured S$131.2 million in new orders in Q4 2021, a 33% increase from the same period last year, bringing its order book to S$229.4 million. The majority of new orders, S$85.5 million, were landed in the energy sector, driven by higher time and material jobs and new power and electrification projects.

site_title: Hotel Grand Central to sell office building in Australia for A$80.8 million
summary: Hotel Grand Central has agreed to sell its office building in Melbourne for A$80.8 million, with the sale expected to be completed in the coming months. The property, 300 Flinders Street, was purchased in 2013 for A$51.45 million and leased to Victoria University, which pays a rent of A$5.36 million annually. The sale will allow Hotel Grand Central to realize its investment before the lease expires in October 2022, with the proceeds to be placed into interest-bearing bank term deposits.

site_title: Indonesia's GDP speeds up on easing Covid-19 curbs, brisk exports
summary: Indonesia's economy accelerated to 5.02% growth in the final quarter of 2021, driven by easing Covid-19 curbs and strong commodity prices. Household consumption and investment growth also picked up, while export growth reached a record high. However, rising Covid-19 cases, global monetary tightening, and potential policy tightening cloud the outlook for this year. Analysts predict a slower recovery, with GDP growth expected to range between 4.8% and 5% in 2022.

site_title: Covid-19 had 'no material impact' on Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust's portfolio despite challenges to retail segment
summary: Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust (FLCT) reported a S$0.2 million decline in distributable income for Q1 2022 due to rental waivers and doubtful receivables from the Covid-19 pandemic, but this had no material impact on its portfolio. The retail segment was more challenged, but the logistics and industrial portfolio remained at 100% occupancy. FLCT's manager expects structural changes to drive demand for logistics and suburban office spaces. The trust has a well-spread lease expiry profile and recently divested Cross Street Exchange, expected to raise occupancy and lower leverage.

site_title: Thailand to seek travel bubbles with China, Malaysia
summary: Thailand is set to discuss travel bubble arrangements with China and Malaysia, aiming to boost its tourism sector. The agreements would determine the number of people allowed in the exchange, including protocols for visas, travel, and insurance. Thailand's tourism sector suffered significantly due to the COVID-19 pandemic, with nearly 40 million foreign visitors in 2019, but only 0.5% of that number last year. The talks come as Thailand reinstated its "Test & Go" travel scheme for vaccinated arrivals, while China requires lengthy quarantine for most arrivals.

site_title: Marching forward with China's state digital economy
summary: China's National Development and Reform Commission has set a target to increase the country's digital economy's gross domestic product (GDP) contribution to 10% by 2025, up from 7.8% in 2020. This comes despite recent regulatory crackdowns on private providers of digital finance, ride-hailing services, and other sectors. The state-led digital development plan prioritizes the sector, following a trend where the state advances while the private sector retreats. This move may be seen as a surprise, given the regulatory tightening of the private sector.

site_title: Would Biden's foreign policy wins have long-term political effects?
summary: US President Joe Biden has navigated a foreign policy crisis in Ukraine, resisting pressure to deploy troops and threatening economic sanctions against Russia. Despite criticism for not consulting with allies before withdrawing from Afghanistan, Biden's measured response has consolidated the Western alliance and strengthened the US position in Europe. The crisis has also provided Biden with political momentum at home, as he focuses on domestic issues such as the pandemic and economy. Ultimately, Biden's long-term political effects will depend on the state of the US economy, rather than foreign policy achievements.

site_title: The Covid policy that really mattered wasn't a policy
summary: The US COVID-19 response failed to effectively deploy vaccines, masks, and testing, despite being a leader in vaccine development. A recent study found that if the US had a higher level of trust in government and its citizens, it could have prevented 13% of global infections and 40% of global cases. The study's authors suggest that moving countries to the 75th percentile in trust in government and fellow citizens could have significantly reduced the spread of the virus. The key to effective pandemic policy lies in building trust and solidarity, rather than relying solely on policy measures.

site_title: Chinese firms pay women's soccer team millions after cup victory
summary: Chinese companies are rewarding the nation's women's soccer team with cash payouts totaling US$3.6 million after their championship victory in the AFC Asian Women's Cup. Alipay and China Mengniu Dairy are among the companies giving the players and coaches cash prizes, while the Chinese Football Association may also award the team 10 million yuan. The victory marks a contrast to the treatment of the men's team after a recent loss, and is seen as a boost to the government's efforts to develop soccer in China, with President Xi Jinping making it a priority.

site_title: UK housing boom starts to fade as cost-of-living squeeze tightens: Halifax
summary: The UK housing market is experiencing a slowdown, with house prices rising by 0.3% in January, the slowest monthly pace since June last year. The post-lockdown boom is fading due to a growing cost-of-living squeeze and limited supply of houses for sale. Affordability remains historically low, with house price rises outpacing earnings growth. Experts expect the rate of house price growth to slow further over the next year, with interest rate hikes and higher tax payments further exacerbating the issue.

site_title: NTUC forms company-training committees with 811 firms, hopes to scale initiative in 2022
summary: NTUC has formed 811 company-training committees since the initiative's launch in 2019, exceeding its initial target of 1,000 companies in 3 years. The labour movement aims to scale up the program in 2022, with about 200 committees established in the past year, largely due to the Covid-19 pandemic. NTUC secretary-general Ng Chee Meng attributed the growth to increased engagement with companies, with about 25 officers involved in the process.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore is likely to raise its carbon tax to S$10-15 per tonne, but watchers suggest a steeper hike may be needed to drive change. The city-state also holds the top spot globally for CEO roles held by women, according to a Deloitte report. The LTA has awarded a S$363m civil contract for the Cross Island Line Phase 1. Teo Lay Lim has been appointed as the new CEO of SPH Media Group. BHP unveiled the world's first LNG-powered ore carrier, aiming for a 30% emissions cut. Local stocks ended the first trading day of the week on a positive note.

images.alt_text: Most observers now agree that the current rate is too low, and Sustainability and the Environment Minister Grace Fu has also indicated that a "stronger price signal" will be needed, with the new rate expected to be revealed at Budget 2022.

site_title: Meta adds 'personal boundary' tool after virtual world harassment
summary: Meta has rolled out a "personal boundary" tool in its virtual reality Horizon network to address harassment reports. The feature, which adds a ring of space around users' digital proxies, prevents others from invading their avatar's personal space. The tool comes after complaints of verbal and sexual harassment, and is turned on by default. Users can still interact with others in non-intrusive ways, such as bumping fists or giving high-fives. Meta aims to improve its metaverse vision, but critics warn that issues like harassment and misinformation may be reproduced in immersive worlds.

site_title: Dealing with Pyongyang: Moon's approach may offer a better way forward
summary: South Korean President Moon Jae-in's approach to dealing with North Korea may be a more effective way forward, as demonstrated by Pyongyang's recent missile tests. Unlike previous responses from the US, Moon's efforts to engage Kim Jong-un have shown promise, with the two leaders meeting three times in 2018 to pledge an end to the Korean War. Moon's persistence, despite setbacks, may offer a better path forward, as Pyongyang's primary goal is an end to American military bases in South Korea. The US should reconsider its approach and work towards a symbolic declaration of peace on the Korean peninsula.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei slides as industrials fall on weak earnings, Fed worries simmer
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average fell 0.70% to 27,248.87, with industrials declining 0.99% and growth stocks dropping 0.88%. Disappointing earnings from Olympus and Taiyo Yuden contributed to the losses, while financial shares rose with higher bond yields following a strong US employment report. Energy shares also gained due to rising crude oil prices, with Nissan Chemical being the Nikkei's biggest winner. Market participants expect calm market moves until the Federal Reserve's meeting in March.

site_title: Genting Hong Kong cruise ships with unpaid bills seized
summary: Two Crystal Cruises ships, Crystal Symphony and Crystal Serenity, operated by Genting Hong Kong, were seized in the Bahamas after a fuel supplier sought US$4.6 million in unpaid bills. The ships, anchored in Freeport, were arrested late Friday after a Florida judge issued an arrest warrant. The vessels ended their voyages last month, and crew members have been paid all wages. Genting Hong Kong, which filed for provisional liquidation in January, is facing financial struggles, including a record loss of US$1.7 billion.

site_title: British homebuilder Taylor Wimpey names insider Daly as CEO
summary: Taylor Wimpey, Britain's third-largest homebuilder, named company insider Jennie Daly as its next CEO, replacing long-time CEO Pete Redfern. Daly, who has been with the company since 2014, was chosen after a thorough recruitment process and consultation with shareholders. The move follows concerns from activist investor Elliott Management, which had called for an external candidate. Daly's appointment marks a rare instance of a woman leading a FTSE 100 company. She will take up the role after the company's annual general meeting on April 26.

site_title: Brokers' take: Maybank upgrades SGX to 'buy' despite lower target price
summary: Maybank Securities has upgraded its call on Singapore Exchange (SGX) to "buy" from "hold" due to expected inflection in the bourse's performance as Singapore becomes a value-oriented investment destination. The analyst attributed the lower target price to weaker-than-expected treasury earnings and lower peer multiples. Despite this, the analyst sees potential for Chinese and South-east Asian homecoming listings and a stronger-than-expected reception for local SPAC listings to support market velocity and fees.

site_title: Toshiba says to sell air-conditioner business, in prelude to restructuring
summary: Toshiba Corp plans to sell its 60% stake in air conditioning unit Toshiba Carrier to US joint venture partner Carrier Global Corp for $870 million, ahead of a restructuring plan. The deal is expected to pave the way for a two-way split of the conglomerate into device and energy businesses, saving costs compared to a three-way break-up. The plan, to be announced on Monday, will likely face resistance from foreign shareholders. Toshiba's management will brief investors on the new plan, which will replace a previously planned three-way split.

site_title: Australia opens border to international visitors after 2 years
summary: Australia has reopened its border to international visitors after 2 years of strict controls, allowing double-vaccinated visa holders to enter from February 21. The decision comes as COVID-19 cases and hospitalizations trend down in most parts of the country. States will still set their own quarantine rules, and Western Australia remains closed. The move marks the final step in a gradual relaxation of international border restrictions, following initial steps in November.

site_title: BHP unveils world's first LNG-powered ore carrier, sees 30% emissions cut
summary: BHP unveiled the world's first LNG-powered ore carrier, Mt Tourmaline Newcastlemax, in Singapore. The 299-meter vessel, built by Eastern Pacific Shipping, will reduce emissions by about 30% per journey, meeting BHP's goal of net-zero emissions by 2050. The LNG-powered bulk carrier will be used to transport iron ore from Western Australia to China, with plans to also burn alternative fuels such as bio-LNG and ammonia in the future. This move is part of BHP's efforts to curb supply chain emissions and transition to cleaner fuels.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as US jobs data ramps up rate-hike bets
summary: Asian markets fluctuated on Monday, following a forecast-busting US jobs report that reinforced optimism about the US economy's recovery but also raised interest rate hike expectations. The Labor Department revised up non-farm payrolls, revealing a wage growth surge, and traders are anticipating tighter policies, potentially leading to four or seven interest rate hikes this year. This could end the era of ultra-cheap cash, weighing on stocks, and drive oil prices higher as demand is expected to continue improving.

site_title: Intraco to acquire 51% of digital asset platform MHC Singapore
summary: Intraco I06 has agreed to acquire a 51% stake in MHC Singapore for approximately S$47.2 million. The acquisition comes after the companies signed a binding heads of agreement in December 2021. MHC Singapore, led by Australian entrepreneurs Mark Carnegie and Sergei Sergienko, will take over the businesses and assets of MHC Digital Group, an Australian digital asset platform.

site_title: Singapore posts highest percentage of women CEOs globally: Deloitte
summary: Singapore has taken the top spot globally for the percentage of CEO roles held by women, with 13.1% of sampled companies having female CEOs. However, the number of women CFOs has dropped to 33.7% from 35.3% in 2018. Female board representation rose to 17.6% in 2021, with the technology and media industries having the most women on boards. South-east Asian companies have collectively improved in women board representation, but the perception of women in top leadership positions varies across geographies.

site_title: Australia: Shares weighed down by banking, healthcare stocks
summary: Australian shares declined 0.1% to 7,110.80, weighed down by losses in the banking and healthcare sectors. The benchmark index recouped losses after a 1% decline earlier in the day. Banking stocks, particularly Australia and New Zealand Banking Group, fell 0.4% and 5.4% respectively due to margin pressures. Meanwhile, energy and mining firms gained, and travel stocks rose as Australia prepares to reopen its borders to vaccinated tourists.

site_title: Private equity and SPACs: a match made in heaven?
summary: Private equity firms are increasingly investing in Special Purpose Acquisition Companies (SPACs), with 10% of global SPACs raised in the past year backed by PE firms. This partnership appears beneficial for both parties, offering PE firms a path to liquidity and SPACs an alternative to traditional IPOs. However, concerns arise about competition between PE firms and SPACs, as well as regulatory changes in Singapore and Hong Kong aiming to attract SPAC listings. Existing SPACs are expected to announce deals valued over $800 billion in the next two years, posing a significant challenge for the PE world.

site_title: Landlord to oppose Kitchen Culture unit's judicial management application
summary: Kitchen Culture's subsidiary, KHL Marketing Asia-Pacific (KHLM), has filed a judicial management application in the High Court, but its landlord, Kim Hup Lee & Co, will oppose the application. KHLM owes Kim Hup Lee S$1.8 million in rental arrears, and a winding-up application was filed against KHLM on Dec 16, 2021. The court has set a deadline for creditors to file their opposition by Feb 17. Both judicial management and winding-up applications will be heard together on Mar 16.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks fall as US rate hike bets, local Covid cases rise
summary: South Korean stocks fell 0.19% on Monday as investors bet on a US Federal Reserve interest rate hike, while rising local Covid-19 cases dampened sentiment. The Kospi index dropped 5.2 points to 2,745.06, with technology giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix falling 1.35% and 1.2% respectively. The won weakened, and foreigners sold 5.2 billion won worth of shares, as the US economy created more jobs than expected in January.

site_title: Electric vehicles: Look to history for lessons
summary: The article highlights the history of electric vehicles (EVs), noting that they were first commercially used as taxis in 1897, predating the first internal combustion engine by 50 years. Despite early advantages, EVs failed to gain traction due to range limitations and high costs. The article argues that the current EV market is experiencing a bubble, with valuations tripling despite zero growth in global car sales. The sector's reliance on government regulation and a lack of progress in battery technology are cited as reasons for the disconnect between valuations and reality.

site_title: Carbon tax likely to be raised to S$10-15, but rate needs to be higher to drive change: watchers
summary: Singapore is likely to raise its carbon tax to S$10-15 per tonne, starting from 2024, but experts say the rate needs to be higher to drive significant change. The current rate is too low, with many countries charging between S$1-30 per tonne, and Sweden's rate being the most expensive at 1,200 krona (S$177). To achieve the Paris Agreement target of limiting global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius, some experts recommend a rate of US$50-100 per tCO2e. However, a sharp increase could be counter-productive in the short term, and the government may need to balance global, regional, and local concerns when setting the price.

site_title: Taiwan's GlobalWafers says funds for failed Siltronic take over to go into capacity expansion
summary: Taiwan's GlobalWafers has decided to allocate funds for a failed $6.7 billion takeover of German chip supplier Siltronic into capacity expansion. The company expects to invest T$100 billion between 2022 and 2024, including substantial greenfield investments in Asia, Europe, and the US. The expansion plan includes new production lines, with ramp-up expected in the second half of next year. The failed acquisition comes amid a global semiconductor shortage and Europe's reliance on Asian suppliers.

site_title: Major global companies largely fail net zero climate pledges: report
summary: A report by the Corporate Climate Responsibility Monitor found that 25 major global companies have mostly failed their net-zero climate pledge tests, with only 3 companies (Maersk, Vodafone, and Deutsche Telekom) clearly committing to deep decarbonization. The report found that companies' headline climate pledges often lack real substance, with 13 companies committing to only 40% emission reductions and others having no specific targets. The report highlights the need for greater scrutiny and regulation of companies' climate pledges to ensure transparency and integrity.

site_title: Fave veteran Ng Aik-Phong joins ShopBack as managing director
summary: ShopBack appoints Ng Aik-Phong as managing director, bringing over a decade of experience in e-commerce and fintech. Ng previously led Fave's payments and BNPL offerings in Singapore, Malaysia, and Indonesia. He will oversee the rollout of ShopBack In-Store and ShopBack Pay in Australia, Thailand, and Taiwan, focusing on merchant adoption and strategic partnerships. This move marks a significant milestone for ShopBack as it deepens its presence in the fintech realm.

site_title: Gold gains as inflation worries outweigh higher yields
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to $1,810.38 per ounce, driven by inflation worries outweighing higher US Treasury yields. The Labor Department's jobs report showed a 467,000 jobs increase, potentially supporting interest rate hikes. Gold is seen as an inflation hedge, but rate hikes increase its opportunity cost. Silver, platinum, and palladium also rose, while the dollar index remained flat. The US inflation data, due out Thursday, is expected to show a 0.5% rise, the largest since 1982, further fueling gold's appeal.

site_title: Vietnam starts reopening schools after year-long pandemic closure
summary: Vietnam has started reopening schools after a year-long pandemic closure, with over 17 million students returning to classes. The country aims to vaccinate children as young as five against Covid-19, with plans to administer a booster shot to all adults by March. Most schools are expected to reopen by mid-February, with precautions in place to prevent the spread of the virus. Vietnam has reported 2.34 million Covid-19 infections and over 38,300 deaths, with the government focusing on containing the virus after managing it for most of 2020.

site_title: Credit Suisse faces money laundering charges in trial of Bulgarian cocaine traffickers
summary: Credit Suisse faces Swiss court charges of allowing alleged Bulgarian cocaine traffickers to launder millions of euros through the bank between 2004 and 2008. The bank's former relationship manager is accused of facilitating money laundering, and Credit Suisse disputes the claims, stating it took necessary steps to prevent the alleged money laundering. Prosecutors seek 42.4 million Swiss francs in compensation, which the bank plans to defend vigorously in court. The case has drawn attention to Switzerland's stance on banking and money laundering, with some questioning whether the bank was sufficiently vigilant at the time.

site_title: Indonesian weight-loss app Sirka snags US$2.6m from AC Ventures, Wavemaker
summary: Indonesian weight-loss app Sirka has secured US$2.6 million in seed funding from AC Ventures, Wavemaker Group, and other investors, including Sequoia Capital and angel investors. Launched in June, Sirka offers personalized weight-loss programs and preventive care for obesity-related diseases at a monthly subscription rate of US$15. The app has helped over 1,000 members shed weight and plans to use the funds to enhance its platform and research partnerships with medical professionals.

site_title: TikTok rival's first-year slump has analysts eyeing recovery
summary: Kuaishou Technology, a TikTok rival, is expected to recover from its first-year slump after posting hefty losses due to its large user base and strong profit outlook in coming quarters. Despite losing about a quarter of its market value, analysts see it as a "contrarian play" in the China Internet space, citing a more benign competitive environment and a shift in growth strategy. Analysts predict a turnaround and a target price of HK$140, driven by its 400 million daily active users by 2024 and its role as an official broadcaster of the Beijing Olympic Winter Games.

site_title: Oil turns higher on fears of tight supply, shrugging off US-Iran talks
summary: Oil prices rose on Monday, reversing earlier losses, as investors maintained expectations of a tight global supply despite signs of progress in US-Iran nuclear talks. Brent crude rose 60 cents to $93.87 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude climbed 25 cents to $92.56 a barrel, near its 7-year high. Analysts predict Brent could reach $100 a barrel due to strong global demand and Opec+ struggling to meet production targets.

images.alt_text: Oil prices rose on Monday, reversing earlier losses, as investors kept bullish sentiment on expectations that global supply would remain tight as demand picks up and shrugged off signs of progress in the US-Iran nuclear talks.

site_title: Former Accenture Singapore chair Teo Lay Lim to helm SPH Media Group as new CEO
summary: SPH Media Trust appointed Teo Lay Lim, 58, as the new CEO of SPH Media Group, effective March 1. She previously held leadership positions at Accenture, including Singapore chairman, and brings experience in customer relationship management, analytics, and sustainability services. Teo will succeed interim CEO Patrick Daniel, who led the media business since its restructuring in May 2021. SMT chairman Khaw Boon Wan welcomed Teo's experience and passion for building and transforming people and organizations.

site_title: Alibaba SEC filing may signal SoftBank plans to sell, Citi says
summary: SoftBank Group may sell some of its Alibaba shares, according to Citigroup analysts, as the tech giant's SEC filing suggests a potential sale. Alibaba registered 1 billion unregistered ADSs, which could allow existing shareholders to sell their shares. This move comes as SoftBank faces pressure due to the decline in the value of its portfolio companies, including Didi Global and One 97 Communications. SoftBank's shares rose as much as 5.4% in Tokyo, while Alibaba's Hong Kong shares dropped 4.6%.

site_title: South Korea fines Mercedes 20.2b won over emission rules breach
summary: South Korea's antitrust regulator fined Mercedes-Benz 20.2 billion won (S$22.7 million) for false advertising related to gas emissions of its diesel passenger vehicles. The Korea Fair Trade Commission found Mercedes tampered with pollution mitigation devices by installing illegal software, affecting 15 models. The German carmaker falsely advertised its vehicles met Euro 6 emission standards between 2013 and 2016. This is the latest fine imposed by the KFTC on a major automaker, following similar incidents involving Audi-Volkswagen Korea, Nissan Motor, Stellantis Korea, and Porsche.

site_title: Thailand's central bank awaits tourism revival, to hold rates for another year: poll
summary: Thailand's central bank is expected to maintain record-low interest rates for at least a year to support the tourism-dependent economy, which has yet to recover from the coronavirus pandemic. Despite inflation breaching the bank's target range, economists predict it will fall back within the range, allowing the central bank to maintain an accommodative stance. Interest rates are expected to rise to 0.75% in the second quarter of 2023 and 1.0% in December 2023. The Bank of Thailand's decision aims to revive growth and prevent capital outflows from less developed economies.

images.alt_text: Although inflation breached the Bank of Thailand's (BOT) target range of 1-3 per cent in January, it was expected to fall back within that range in the coming months.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower on US monetary policy concerns
summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on Monday due to concerns over a tightening of US monetary policy, with the Nikkei 225 index falling 0.57% and the Topix index down 0.36%. This move follows a global trend, as the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq edge to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty and split Fed views.

site_title: Growing digital skills gap: Businesses need to take action now
summary: Singapore is facing a growing digital skills gap, with 64% of respondents feeling unprepared for workplace digital skills and 71% lacking resources to learn. The country's digital transformation has created a need for businesses to invest in digital skills training and upskilling. According to Salesforce's Global Digital Skills Index, only 30% of respondents in Singapore are proficient in collaboration technologies. Businesses are taking action, incorporating digital skills training into their programs and partnering with public sector organizations to provide training opportunities to the wider community. Immediate and sustained investment in digital skills is crucial for economic recovery and long-term growth.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Monday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened 5.36 points higher, or 0.35%, at 1,528.12, with 225 gainers and 106 losers. The country's shares rose as investors brushed off new Trump threats, extending the stocks rally.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks begin with small gains
summary: Hong Kong stocks began the day with small gains, extending a strong rally from the end of last week. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.15% to 24,609.43, while the Shanghai Composite Index climbed 1.38% to 3,407.76. Mainland Chinese markets also rebounded after the Chinese New Year break. The gains followed a healthy lead from Wall Street, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reached fresh records despite ongoing tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Australian retail sales surge record 8.2% in Q4
summary: Australian retail sales surged a record 8.2% in the December quarter, driven by pent-up spending after coronavirus lockdowns ended. Adjusted for inflation, retail sales reached A$93.2 billion, exceeding forecasts of 8.1%. Key sectors saw significant growth, including clothing and personal accessories (43.1%), cafes and restaurants (18.8%), department stores (25%), and household goods (9%). The strong sales figures indicate a major boost to economic growth, marking the largest increase on record.

site_title: Budget speech on Feb 18, 3.30pm: Latest news on dedicated micro-site at The Business Times
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Lawrence Wong will deliver his maiden Budget speech on February 18 at 3:30pm, live on TV, radio, and online channels. A dedicated micro-site (bt.sg/budget22) provides the latest coverage and updates. The official Budget statement will be available on www.singaporebudget.gov.sg. Two virtual Budget Conversations will be held to gather public feedback, and post-Budget dialogues will be organized by the People's Association and grassroots organizations.

site_title: Football: Senegal declares national holiday to celebrate Cup of Nations win
summary: Senegal declared a national holiday to celebrate the country's first-ever African Cup of Nations win. President Macky Sall cancelled a trip to Comoros to welcome the national football team, led by Sadio Mane, back to Dakar after their 4-2 victory over Egypt in the final penalty shootout. The team will be decorated by Sall on Tuesday at the presidential palace. This marks Senegal's first Cup of Nations title after previous final defeats in 2002 and 2019.

site_title: Australia: Banks weigh on shares as ANZ outlook disappoints
summary: Australia's shares fell 0.4% on Monday as the S&P/ASX 200 index closed, with banks ANZ and Westpac slumping 5% and 1.3% respectively due to competition and interest rate concerns. Other "Big Four" lenders also dropped between 0.9% and 1.6%. In contrast, Graincorp rose 12.9% and James Hardie jumped 5% after positive earnings forecasts. Energy and technology stocks gained 1% each, while healthcare stocks retreated 1.1%.

site_title: Spain's loophole clampdown hits 29-billion-euro investment vehicle industry
summary: Spain's government has shut down a tax loophole in the 29-billion-euro investment vehicle industry, known as sicavs, which wealthy Spaniards use to wrap their investments. Over 800 out of 2,276 registered sicavs have announced their intention to close due to tightened tax regulations. The new rules require participants to have at least 2,500 euros invested, increasing the tax rate to 25% if the condition is not met. Wealthy investors, including those from Banco Santander and UBS, are rushing to pull their money from the affected products.

site_title: Singapore bets on niche SPAC listings to capture tech boom
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) is betting on niche SPAC listings to capitalize on the tech boom in the region. The bourse plans to list up to a dozen special-purpose acquisition companies (SPACs) within 12-18 months, with a focus on fintech, tech, and consumer sectors. Despite regulatory scrutiny and poor returns in the US, SGX's revised rules and support from state firms are encouraging startups to seek funding through SPACs. The exchange faces a challenge in attracting risk-averse investors, but large international institutions are turning to Singapore for blockbuster equity listings.

site_title: Big China-backed London development on brink of collapse
summary: A £1.7 billion regeneration project in east London, backed by Chinese developers, is on the brink of collapse due to lack of tenants and construction halt. The project, awarded to Beijing-based Advanced Business Parks in 2013, has been stalled for over 2 years. The Greater London Authority has set a March deadline for final termination, giving Dauphin Holdings Group, the guarantor, until then to confirm completion. The project's future remains uncertain, with no clarification given by Dauphin Holdings Group.

site_title: UK and South Korea to sign deal to strengthen supply chains
summary: Britain and South Korea will sign an agreement to strengthen supply chains for key products like semiconductors, amid global disruptions caused by the Covid-19 pandemic. The deal aims to improve supply chain resilience and is a precursor to formal trade negotiations expected to begin later this year. The UK and South Korea have a trade worth £13.3 billion and are seeking to join a trans-Pacific trade pact. The agreement is seen as part of Britain's efforts to build stronger ties with faster-growing economies in Asia and the Pacific, particularly after leaving the EU.

site_title: Singapore shares rise at Monday's open; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks opened higher on Monday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) rising 0.2% or 7.83 points to 3,339.24. Gainers outnumbered losers 91 to 35, following Wall Street gains. Banking stocks were mixed, with DBS and OCBC up 0.3% each, while UOB fell 0.4% after a mobile app disruption. The gains followed strong January jobs data in the US, which raised expectations for monetary policy tightening.

site_title: BT Explains: The metaverse and its 7 layers
summary: The metaverse, a concept that combines social media, online gaming, and virtual and augmented reality, has gained significant traction in the past year. According to Beamable's CEO Jon Radoff, the metaverse can be broken down into 7 layers: experience, discovery, creator economy, spatial computing, decentralisation, human interface, and infrastructure. The metaverse aims to be a decentralized, open, and distributed platform where users can interact and work in a digitally-driven environment, with applications in areas such as gaming, NFTs, and e-sports.

site_title: ANZ margin shrinks amid home lending competition, mulls more buyback
summary: ANZ Banking Group reported a 8 basis point decline in its group net interest margin, amid increasing competition in the Australian mortgage lending market. The bank aims to return surplus capital to shareholders, considering expanding its A$1.5 billion buyback program. ANZ also made progress in improving its home loan application systems, with application times now comparable to major lenders. The bank expects costs to remain flat, despite plans to lower fees for Australian retail and commercial customers, resulting in an annual operating income reduction of A$140 million.

site_title: Russian attack on Ukraine possible 'any day' but diplomacy still an option: White House
summary: US National Security Adviser Jake Sullivan warned that Russia could order an attack on Ukraine "any day" or "a couple of weeks" from now, citing 70% of Russia's combat power near the border. Diplomatic efforts continue, with US President Joe Biden speaking to French President Emmanuel Macron ahead of Macron's visit to Moscow. The US and its allies have threatened extensive economic sanctions against Russia if it invades, which could hit President Putin and Russian elites hard.

site_title: Growing ESG regulation: What should businesses be prepared for?
summary: Businesses must prepare for increased ESG regulation globally and domestically, driven by growing expectations and extraterritorial reach of international laws. The US Securities and Exchange Commission's Climate and ESG Task Force and the European Commission's proposed legislation on environmental and human rights due diligence are expected to shape regulatory developments. Companies must review existing compliance programs, map exposures, and leverage technology to track and authenticate ESG practices. Soft and hard approaches to regulation will continue, but mandatory guidelines are likely to emerge, particularly in Singapore.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The tanker and dry bulk market experienced a subdued week due to Lunar New Year holidays, with most regions seeing minimal activity. The Capesize market traded sideways, with rates improving by $1,384 to $10,302, mainly driven by increased bunker fuel prices. The Atlantic witnessed minimal demand, while the Panamax market declined further. The Ultramax/Supramax market showed mixed activity, with positive sentiment returning towards the end of the week. Handysize rates showed glimmers of recovery, particularly in East Coast South America. The VLCC market remained quiet, and Suezmax, Aframax, and Clean markets saw slight declines in rates.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, SGX, SPH Reit, Lendlease Reit, Hiap Hoe, Jiutian Chemical, Sinjia Land
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Singapore stocks to watch saw various developments on February 7, 2022. UOB's mobile app disruption resulted in a 1% share price gain. Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported an 8.8% decline in net profit. Hiap Hoe clarified there's no certainty about Orchard Towers' collective sale. Jiutian Chemical expects a significant increase in consolidated net profit for FY2021. Sinjia Land may revise its S$2 billion price tag for its reverse takeover.

site_title: This is the only Goldman banker standing trial for 1MDB
summary: Roger Ng, a former Goldman Sachs banker, is set to go on trial in the US for his role in the 1MDB scandal, the first Goldman Sachs employee to face charges. Ng, 49, has pleaded not guilty to charges of laundering billions of dollars embezzled from the Malaysian fund and violating US anti-bribery laws. His defense team claims he was a deputy to star Goldman banker Tim Leissner and warned compliance about Malaysian financier Jho Low, while prosecutors argue Ng played a critical role in the bribe-paying and money-laundering scheme. Ng faces up to 30 years in prison.

site_title: Jiutian Chemical to report 'significant increase' in profit for FY2021
summary: Jiutian Chemical Group is expected to report a "significant increase" in consolidated net profit after tax for FY2021 due to higher average selling price and sales volume of its main products. The company attributes this growth to strong demand for dimethylformamide and methylamine since the start of FY2021, as China's post-Covid-19 economic recovery gained momentum. This marks a notable improvement from the previous year, when the company reported record-high earnings but did not declare a dividend due to unprofitability.

site_title: Social campaign helps caregivers of youths to care for own mental health
summary: A social campaign "Prepare to Care" aims to improve mental preparation and normalise help-seeking behaviors among caregivers of youths. Launched by 4 students from Nanyang Technological University, the campaign collaborates with the Institute of Mental Health and Caregivers Alliance Limited to encourage caregivers to prioritize their mental health. The campaign's virtual expert panel on Feb 19 will discuss topics such as improving communication and removing guilt, with the goal of reducing caregiver burnout and promoting resilience.

site_title: Australian PM signals reopening borders to tourists 'not far away'
summary: Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison has signaled that the country's borders to international tourists may reopen "not far away," amid the Omicron variant's spread. Despite hospitalizations and deaths stabilizing, Morrison faces pressure from a federal election and his handling of the outbreak. Parliament will debate the issue this week, with Home Affairs Minister Karen Andrews stating the government is "very close" to deciding. Australia requires all international travelers to be vaccinated or provide medical vaccination exemption.

site_title: China stocks set to have muted reopening after HK's surge
summary: China's stock market is expected to have a muted reopening after Hong Kong-listed names surged during the Chinese New Year break. The CSI 300 Index may struggle to keep up with offshore market gains unless policymakers take steps to restore investor confidence. Mainland traders face challenges including weak local manufacturing data and an expanding hawkish foreign central bank camp. The People's Bank of China's liquidity management will also be closely watched.

site_title: China sees low inflation based on Western monetary moves
summary: China's National Development and Reform Commission expects modest inflation in 2022 due to weakening global commodity prices. The consumer price index is forecast to rise 0.9% this year, lower than previous years, and the producer price index is expected to cool down to 8.1% from 2021. China's monetary policy is expected to remain prudent, avoiding unnecessary stimulus, and the country expects monetary tightness in western countries to weaken price inflation on imports.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: Make money even through a bumpy 2022 (Ep 112)
summary: Correspondent Howie Lim discusses investment strategies with DBS senior investment strategist Daryl Ho, focusing on the 2022 investment outlook. Key takeaways include: prioritizing time in the market, building resilient portfolios, and leveraging a transitional global economy. Ho emphasizes the importance of deploying cash and adopting a diversified approach to weather uncertainty. The conversation concludes that a robust portfolio can navigate market volatility, and listeners are advised to consult a financial adviser for independent advice.

site_title: Elizabeth II marks Platinum Jubilee with 'Queen Camilla' announcement
summary: Queen Elizabeth II marked her Platinum Jubilee by announcing her "sincere wish" that Camilla, the wife of Prince Charles, should be known as Queen Consort when Charles becomes king. The 95-year-old monarch expressed her desire for Camilla to have the full title of a monarch's wife, following a long history of the royal family's efforts to normalize Camilla's role. The Queen's statement comes as the main Platinum Jubilee celebrations are set for June, with world leaders and Londoners reacting to the announcement.

images.alt_text: Queen Elizabeth II on Sunday became the first British monarch to reign for seven decades, announcing her "sincere wish" that Camilla, the wife of her heir Prince Charles, should ultimately be known as Queen Consort.

site_title: US dollar rises from 2-week low after jobs numbers surprise
summary: The US dollar rose 0.1% to 95.446 after jobs data showed the US created more jobs than expected, increasing the chances of a larger Federal Reserve interest rate hike at the March policy meeting. This move reversed the dollar's 2-week low of 95.136. The dollar's increase also countered a resurgent euro. The better-than-expected jobs data suggests the Fed may consider a larger rate hike, potentially impacting global financial markets.

site_title: Ottawa mayor declares state of emergency to deal with trucking blockade
summary: Ottawa Mayor Jim Watson declared a state of emergency due to a 10-day trucking blockade that has paralyzed the city. The blockade, which began as a protest against a Canadian vaccine requirement, has turned into a broader protest against COVID-19 health restrictions and the government of Prime Minister Justin Trudeau. Watson criticized the protesters, saying they outnumbered police and posed a serious threat to safety and security. The police have issued 450 tickets and opened 97 investigations into possible criminal offenses, with efforts underway to investigate email-based threats to public officials.

site_title: BT podcast: Real opportunities for profit and growth in sustainable healthcare investing
summary: HSBC's co-heads of Sustainable Healthcare Equity, Nathalie Flury and Michael Schröter, discuss the opportunities for profit and growth in sustainable healthcare investing on the BT podcast. They highlight emerging diagnostic themes, the evolving telehealth sector, and what makes health economic sense. The conversation also touches on the pros and cons of sustainable healthcare investing and the importance of due diligence for investors. The panel concludes that a robust sustainable healthcare portfolio can be a valuable addition to investors' portfolios.

site_title: Marcos Jr leads Philippines presidential race in raucous election campaign season
summary: Ferdinand Marcos Jr. leads the Philippine presidential race, with a landslide victory predicted as he seeks to revive the family brand. The son of former dictator Ferdinand Marcos, Marcos Jr. has formed a strong alliance with Vice-President Leni Robredo, and his massive social media campaign is seen as whitewashing the clan's history. The election, to be held on May 9, will determine the country's next president and vice-president, with Marcos Jr. aiming to unify the country and give its people a better future.

images.alt_text: Supporters cheering for Robredo whose volunteer-driven campaign has struck a chord with progressives, but her mild-mannered personality is hurting her appeal in the deeply macho country.

site_title: A survival guide for early 2022's sharp market swings
summary: A market expert emphasizes that 2022's sharp swings are a necessary price for high long-term returns, as volatility and stocks go hand-in-hand. Despite January's 9.1% plunge, the expert believes a great year for world stocks is still possible, citing a lack of bear market signs and a positive correlation between bond yields and stocks. To navigate volatility, the expert recommends a four-step plan: stay calm, put market movement in context, and only deviate from your investment plan if a huge negative is probable and others don't see it.

site_title: Are current laws effective?
summary: Singaporean law professor Lan Luh Luh says current ESG laws are ineffective in mitigating climate change, as they only serve to raise awareness and impose costs, but do not mandate environmentally friendly behavior. She believes that laws and regulations, such as carbon taxes and climate change disclosures, do not restrict the amount of carbon companies can produce, and companies may choose to pay more taxes if it benefits their profits. Immediate actions are necessary to address the deteriorating climate crisis, but current measures may not be strong enough to evoke significant change in corporate behavior.

site_title: Inclusive growth for all
summary: Singapore's Budget 2022 should focus on three key priorities: enhancing global competitiveness, tackling wealth inequality, and ensuring environmental sustainability. The budget should also address immediate pain points such as the talent crunch, rising inflation, and cash flow concerns. Experts expect measures to promote social mobility, encourage productive longevity, and support businesses in driving sustainability within their operations. Key areas of focus include carbon taxes, green finance initiatives, and education and training programs to equip workers with the required skills to access job opportunities. The budget should also provide targeted financial support and special incentive packages to support businesses in their transformation efforts.

site_title: Swiss call for 'calm and creativity' to fix EU ties
summary: Swiss President Ignazio Cassis has called for "calm and creativity" to resolve strained relations with the European Union. Switzerland's relations with the EU have been tense since ending talks on a broad cooperation agreement in May 2021. Cassis emphasized the need to focus on content, not just technical and institutional questions, and to consider cooperation in areas like health, research, and culture. He also warned that unstable relations would harm both Switzerland and the EU, which is its main economic partner.

site_title: TPG stays light to drive growth
summary: TPG Singapore, the country's fourth telco, maintains its competitiveness by focusing on smaller infrastructure. Despite a high mobile penetration rate of 149.9%, the telco's light infrastructure base is seen as a key factor. Competition in Singapore's telecoms market has become intense, with price wars between mobile network operators and virtual network operators. As a result, TPG's strategy to stay light is expected to drive growth and maintain its position in the market.

site_title: Johnson's future still in limbo; UK economy heads for another recession
summary: The UK economy is expected to enter another recession due to the Covid-19 crisis and government mismanagement, wastage, and imprudent borrowing. Energy bills are soaring, inflation is forecast to rise above 7%, and taxes are increasing. Prime Minister Boris Johnson has appointed new staff, including former Brexit minister Steve Barclay, to try to reassure Conservative backbenchers and cut state intervention and spending. However, 16 Tory MPs have already called for Johnson's resignation, and speculation suggests another 40 MPs may follow, potentially triggering a no-confidence motion and leadership election.

site_title: After pandemic setback, RedDoorz CEO aims for IPO in 2024
summary: RedDoorz, a Singapore-based hospitality company, has overcome the COVID-19 pandemic by adopting a new business model that focuses on ancillary services, such as renting unused space and charging for Wi-Fi use. CEO Amit Saberwal aims to list the company in 2024, driven by tech and a growth strategy that targets domestic travelers. The company has seen revenue grow 8 times since 2019, with occupancy rates now at 70% of pre-pandemic levels. Saberwal believes the hospitality sector in South-east Asia is poised for growth, driven by domestic business travel and the return of tourism.

site_title: NFTs get the thumbs-down from some artists
summary: Artists are criticizing non-fungible tokens (NFTs) for perpetuating the commodification of art and fueling speculation, with some labeling the trend as elitist. The environmental costs of minting NFTs are also a concern. Many artists argue that NFTs prioritize financial gain over artistic value, and that the market is dominated by a few big players. Some, like musician Rene Ann Wong, call the NFT world an "elite boys' club" due to the barriers to entry and the emphasis on financialization.

site_title: Apollo co-chief operating officer Anthony Civale to retire
summary: Apollo Global Management's co-chief operating officer Anthony Civale, 47, plans to retire in July, transitioning to an advisory role after 20 years with the firm. Civale, who has held various roles including senior positions in private equity and credit, will focus on family, health, and philanthropy. His departure comes after a tumultuous period for the firm, including the departure of co-founder Leon Black and the appointment of new CEO Marc Rowan. Civale's exit is seen as a stabilizing factor for the company, allowing it to move forward under new leadership.

site_title: Kheng Leong bags Gilstead Road site for S$70m
summary: Two freehold redevelopment sites in Gilstead Road, Singapore, have been sold for S$70 million and S$17 million, respectively. The first site, owned by Kheng Leong Company, is zoned for residential use and can be redeveloped into a condo project with up to 56 units. Meanwhile, an entity owned by Melvin Poh has bought an old house in Gilstead Road for S$17 million, with plans to redevelop it into two bungalows. Additionally, a freehold bungalow along Meyer Road is being sold for S$32.68 million.

site_title: Green issues top of mind as industry leaders eye Budget
summary: Industry leaders in Singapore are urging the government to include more support for environmental, social, and governance (ESG) issues in the upcoming national Budget 2022. They recommended grants, incentives, and tax breaks for sectors such as the built environment, small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), and the aviation industry to promote sustainability and low-carbon development. The industry leaders also emphasized the need for enhanced training and digitalization for workers and firms, as well as support for supply-chain resilience and cash flow issues.

site_title: Sinjia Land's S$2b RTO may be revised with new valuation
summary: Sinjia Land's proposed reverse takeover (RTO) of sorghum producer Binex Singapore may be revised with a new valuation after the Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) questioned the deal's terms. The RTO, initially valued at S$2 billion, may be revised based on an independent valuation report by EY Corporate Advisors, which is expected to take 12 weeks to complete. Sinjia Land's board considered the deal in the best interest of shareholders, citing a significant discount to its fair value, and may consider divesting its backpacker hostel operations after the RTO.

site_title: Peloton said to draw takeover interest after share plunge
summary: Peloton Interactive is evaluating takeover interest from potential suitors, including Amazon and Nike, following a decline in its shares. The company is working with an adviser to explore options, which may not lead to a transaction. This move comes after Peloton's shares plummeted, making it a target for potential acquirers.

site_title: Hours-long UOB mobile app disruption fixed; breach ruled out, probe under way
summary: UOB's TMRW mobile app experienced a disruption for hours, with users unable to log in or make transfers, but the bank has ruled out a cyberattack or breach. Internet banking and ATM services remained available. The bank is reviewing the root cause of the issue and assured customers that its banking system remains secure. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is following up with UOB on the incident.

site_title: They rushed to buy in pandemic; Here's what they regret
summary: Homebuyers who entered the market during the pandemic are expressing regret over their purchases due to the frenzied sellers' market and astronomical prices. A survey by the WAV Group and Zillow found that about three-quarters of recent buyers regret their choices, citing factors such as not having enough time, not having considered living somewhere else, and overpaying. Market forecasts predict that conditions won't change significantly this spring, with home prices expected to rise another 16% in 2022. Successful buyers advise making snap decisions and recalibrating expectations to avoid disappointment.

images.alt_text: About 1 in 3 regret buying a house needing more work than anticipated, 31 per cent wish the home they bought was bigger and 21 per cent thought they overpaid, according to a US survey.

site_title: S&P500 prospects in 2022
summary: The S&P 500 (SPX) experienced a 7.5% decline in January 2022, breaking its 200-day moving average and ascending channel, but fell short of a correction territory criterion. The main attributed factor was the hawkish US Federal Reserve, which shifted its stance to stop bond-buying and hike interest rates. This led to a rise in US Treasury yields, creating an inverted yield curve, which is a reliable indicator of a recession. The decline in the Nasdaq 100 index was attributed to the difference in components between the two indexes, with the NDX being heavily weighted towards technological sectors.

site_title: Halimah, Xi reaffirm Singapore-China ties
summary: Singapore President Halimah Yacob and Chinese President Xi Jinping reaffirmed their country's ties during a meeting in Beijing, agreeing to upgrade bilateral relations and cooperate in areas like the digital economy and green economy. They also welcomed the signing of a memorandum of understanding for giant panda research and a student hostel in Chongqing, marking the 30th anniversary of bilateral relations. The leaders emphasized the importance of people-to-people ties and "win-win cooperation".

site_title: US regulators should block costly fintech loans, advocates say
summary: US regulators should block banks partnering with fintechs to charge high-interest rates, advocates say. A coalition of groups, including the National Community Reinvestment Coalition and Consumer Reports, warned that "rent-a-bank schemes" have flourished, with some loans having annual percentage rates as high as 225%. The groups claim the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp (FDIC) has not taken sufficient action to curb these practices, despite the OCC's Trump-era "true lender" rule being overturned.

site_title: Powell named US Fed chair pro-tempore pending US Senate confirmation
summary: The US Federal Reserve named Jerome Powell chair pro-tempore, effective February 5, pending his confirmation by the US Senate to a second term as chair. The confirmation process, scheduled for February 15, is expected to have broad bipartisan support. Powell's duties will continue uninterrupted while the confirmation process unfolds.

site_title: UK to make tech firms take faster action against criminal content
summary: The UK government has announced plans to expand a law requiring tech firms to actively combat criminal content on their platforms. The updated list of prohibited content now includes sexual images posted without consent, hate crimes, and promotion of suicide. Firms will face fines of up to 10% of their global turnover if they fail to comply. The Online Safety Bill, set to be voted on this year, will be enforced by Ofcom and gives regulators the power to block offending websites and fine operators.

site_title: Wormhole rescue shows crypto world can move fast and fix things, but winter is coming
summary: A hacker exploited a software bug in the Wormhole cryptocurrency bridge, draining $320 million. However, the project's developers, Jump Trading Group, quickly replaced the stolen tokens, demonstrating the crypto world's ability to move fast and fix issues.
