This incident highlights the enormous amounts of cash sloshing around the crypto world and the potential for rapid profits. The decline in trading volume and revenue for companies like Coinbase and Robinhood is also a concern, with investors shaken by the hawkish Federal Reserve's plans to withdraw stimulus. A "crypto winter" is feared, with Bitcoin losing a fifth of its value this year.

site_title: ECB official sees first interest rate hike in fourth quarter of 2022
summary: ECB official Klaas Knot predicts the European Central Bank's first interest rate hike in the fourth quarter of 2022, with a possible 25 basis point increase. This move would mark a shift from the bank's current negative interest rate policy. Knot also expects a second rate hike in 2023, following the completion of the asset purchasing programme, which is set to be wound down to €20 billion per month by the fourth quarter. The ECB's decision could signal a tightening of monetary policy to combat inflation.

site_title: S-Reits with Singapore office assets sanguine on rental outlook
summary: Office rental prices in Singapore improved by 0.9% in Q4 2021, with a 1.9% year-on-year increase. Office vacancy rates also showed a slight improvement at 12.8%. S-Reits with significant exposure to local office assets, such as CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust and Mapletree Commercial Trust, are optimistic about the rental outlook.

site_title: Coups, Covid and climate test African leaders at summit
summary: African leaders gather for an AU summit to address the Covid-19 pandemic, climate change, and a surge in military coups across the continent. The summit, attended by Nigeria, Senegal, and Kenya, comes amid concerns about peace and security. The bloc will also discuss its relationship with Israel, with some countries pushing for Israel's status to be revoked. Climate change is expected to be a major focus, with devastating effects on food supplies and migration. The war in Ethiopia and unrest in Sudan will also be on the agenda.

site_title: Covid entrepreneurs can lead a new wave of creative destruction
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in entrepreneurship, with a record 5.4 million new business applications filed in the US last year. This trend, known as "creative destruction," is driven by the shift to remote work, increased access to capital, and a change in mentality towards entrepreneurship. Experts believe this could mark a "welcome and disruptive end to a lost decade of US entrepreneurship," with new businesses potentially leading to productivity growth and a more entrepreneurial and equitable future.

site_title: Airbus, Quebec agree to invest US$1.2b in A220 jet programme
summary: Airbus and the government of Quebec have agreed on a US$1.2 billion investment to support the A220 jet programme. Airbus will invest US$900 million, while Quebec will contribute US$300 million. The deal allows Quebec to retain its 25% stake in the programme for four additional years, with the buyout date now set for 2030, up from 2026. The investment aims to stabilize the loss-making programme, which has faced challenges since its development.

site_title: Mexico agrees to talks with US after solar cell tariffs extended
summary: Mexico agrees to negotiate terms of its export of solar energy equipment to the US after US President Joe Biden extended Trump-era tariffs by 4 years. The US Trade Representative must enter talks with Mexico and Canada to ensure the tariffs don't undermine their effectiveness. Mexico will lead negotiations to maintain competitiveness and certainty for trade and investment in North America, but may take measures under the USMCA and WTO if necessary.

site_title: Genting HK decides fate of German shipyard
summary: The MV Werften shipyard in Germany's Baltic coast, owned by Genting HK, has filed for bankruptcy, putting 2,000 jobs at risk. The unfinished cruise ship, Global Dream, is 75% complete but requires 600 million euros to finish. With no buyer, the ship's fate is uncertain, and local authorities fear a huge economic hit. The shipyard, which was once a major employer, may have to be converted to offshore wind or hydrogen production sites, a proposal opposed by unions. Genting HK, the parent company, has abandoned the project due to pandemic disruption and financial guarantees.

site_title: Thai tourism rebound will lag other hot spots, hotel tycoon says
summary: Thai tourism is expected to lag behind other hot spots due to the country's conservative border reopening policies, according to American-born Thai businessman Bill Heinecke. Thailand resumed quarantine-free tourism for vaccinated travelers, but Heinecke criticized the requirements as "cumbersome." He suggests that countries like Europe and the Maldives, with more liberal reopening policies, will see a stronger tourism rebound. Tourism numbers in Thailand are expected to be "tough and challenging" until the government changes its position.

site_title: The epic rise and fall of Elizabeth Holmes
summary: Elizabeth Holmes, the founder of Theranos, a blood-testing company, was convicted of four counts of fraud. Holmes' rise to fame in Silicon Valley was fueled by her self-improvement plan and a promise of revolutionary technology that turned out to be fictional. She fooled investors, employees, and media with her claims of a working device that could analyze health without touching the finger. Holmes' conviction marks the end of an era in Silicon Valley, where the line between talk and achievement was often blurred.

site_title: 7,639 new local Covid-19 cases in Singapore; 1,074 patients hospitalised
summary: Singapore reported 7,639 new local Covid-19 cases on Feb 6, bringing the total to 7,639, down from 10,208 the previous day. The number of hospitalised cases rose to 1,074, up 6 from Saturday. 1,518 new cases were detected through PCR tests, and 6,121 through antigen rapid tests. Three more people died of Covid-19, bringing the total to 871 deaths. The weekly infection growth rate was at 1.49.

site_title: STI hits 30-month high as net institutional buying of heavyweights soars
summary: Singapore's STI index reached a 30-month high, closing at 3,331.41 on February 5, with a 6.7% gain for the first 5 weeks of 2022. Net institutional buying of heavyweights surged, with the bank sector averaging 9.5% gains in January, driven by expectations of US interest rate hikes. Energy stocks also performed well, with Sembcorp Industries generating a 14% return. The sector with the highest net institutional selling was Reits and technology stocks, while conglomerates like Jardine Matheson Holdings and Singtel saw significant buying.

site_title: Keppel commences S$500 million share buyback programme
summary: Keppel Corporation has commenced a S$500 million share buyback program, with 977,600 shares repurchased at an average price of S$5.68 per share over the past two sessions. The program aims to accelerate growth engines through strategic mergers and acquisitions, as part of its Vision 2030 initiative. The shares will be held as treasury shares for employee share plans and potential future M&A activities.

site_title: Bank of America CEO's pay rises more than 30% for 2021
summary: Bank of America Corp CEO Brian Moynihan's total compensation for 2021 increased by over 30% to $32 million, according to a regulatory filing. This represents a $7.5 million rise from the previous year, when Moynihan received $24.5 million due to the pandemic. The increase is attributed to the bank's record-breaking profits and stock price rise of 47% in 2021. Moynihan's compensation includes a base salary of $1.5 million and an equity incentive award worth $30.5 million.

site_title: US SEC to push private equity firms for more robust fee disclosures
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) plans to propose new rules requiring private equity firms to provide more detailed fee disclosures to investors, aiming to increase transparency and bargaining power. The proposed rules would force firms to disclose specific expenses they pass on to clients and address the frequency of information provision. SEC Chair Gary Gensler has criticized the industry's fees as opaque and too high, sparking a potential fight from private equity lobbyists who argue that fees are agreed upon by sophisticated parties.

site_title: Keppel's remaking of itself a work in progress
summary: Keppel Corp, a Singapore-listed conglomerate, is undergoing a transformation from a diverse group of unrelated parts to an integrated provider of sustainable urbanization solutions. The company has reorganized into four business divisions: energy and environment, urban development, connectivity, and asset management. Keppel's FY2021 earnings rose to S$1 billion, with the energy and environment segment reporting a loss, while the urban development segment contributed the majority of earnings. The company has proposed a final dividend of S$0.21 per share and announced a S$500 million share buyback program. Analysts predict further upside, with some targeting a price of S$7.20 per share.

site_title: Sinjia Land's S$2b RTO price tag may be revised with new valuation report
summary: Sinjia Land, a Catalist-listed backpacker hostel operator, may revise its S$2 billion price tag for its proposed reverse takeover (RTO) of sorghum producer Binex Singapore, according to the company's board. The RTO deal, announced in January, would see Sinjia Land issue new shares at S$0.35 apiece to Binex's owners. The board has appointed EY Corporate Advisors as an independent valuer to conduct a new valuation report, which may replace a preliminary report estimating Binex's valuation between US$2.5 billion and US$3.1 billion.

site_title: Omicron-specific booster may not be needed, US monkey study finds
summary: US monkey study finds that an Omicron-specific booster may not be needed, as it showed no significant differences in protection compared to the current Moderna Covid-19 booster. The study tested the immune response of vaccinated monkeys to both the conventional Moderna booster and an Omicron-specific booster, and found comparable increases in neutralizing antibody responses against all variants of concern, including Omicron. This suggests that the original vaccine can be effective against Omicron variants without the need for a targeted booster.

site_title: New local Covid-19 cases in Singapore triple to 13,046; 6 more deaths reported
summary: Singapore reported 13,046 locally transmitted Covid-19 cases as of Feb 4, tripling from the previous day's 4,087 cases. The new cases include 10,312 mild cases identified by antigen rapid tests. Six more deaths were reported, bringing the total to 1,548. The surge in cases highlights the ongoing pandemic situation in the country.

site_title: P&G, household-products shares see haven appeal dimmed by lofty valuations
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) and other household-goods companies face a dimmed appeal due to lofty valuations, despite a strong performance in the S&P 500 Household Products Index. The index has outperformed the broader market, but shares are trading at the priciest level since 2000 based on projected earnings. Analysts, including David Bahnsen, favor the companies for their stable consumer demand and dividend history, but caution against increasing their weighting due to valuation concerns.

site_title: J&J tried to get federal judge to block publication of story on baby powder lawsuits
summary: Johnson & Johnson attempted to block the publication of a Reuters story about the company's efforts to shift liability for Baby Powder lawsuits into bankruptcy. The company claimed confidential documents were protected from public disclosure, but Reuters denied possessing the documents. The US judge, Michael Kaplan, denied J&J's request, calling it a "prior restraint of speech on a matter of public interest." J&J has withdrawn its request but maintains it will continue discussions with Reuters.

site_title: US restores sanctions waiver to Iran with nuclear talks in final phase
summary: The US has restored sanctions waivers to Iran, allowing international cooperation projects on non-proliferation work to proceed, as indirect talks between the US and Iran enter the final phase. The waivers were previously rescinded by former President Donald Trump in 2019 and 2020. The move is aimed at facilitating discussions to return to the 2015 Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action (JCPOA) and has been welcomed by analysts as a "modest sign" of movement in the negotiations.

site_title: Hertz names Goldman ex-finance chief Stephen Scherr as CEO
summary: Hertz Global Holdings has named Stephen Scherr, former Goldman Sachs finance chief, as its new CEO, succeeding interim CEO Mark Fields. Scherr, who spent 3 decades at Goldman, will assume the role at the end of February. Fields will remain on Hertz's board. The appointment comes as Hertz seeks to navigate the digital and electric-vehicle era.

site_title: Post-Fed, US Treasury 5-year futures' net shorts hit lowest since Sep
summary: US Treasury 5-year note futures' net shorts dropped to 120,524 contracts, the lowest since mid-September, following the Federal Reserve's policy meeting. The US 2-year note futures' net longs increased to 47,474 contracts, while net shorts on US 10-year note futures rose to 274,875 contracts. The US 5/30 Treasury yield curve flattened to 42 basis points, and the US 2/10 yield curve narrowed to 60 basis points, the tightest since late November 2020. Speculators shifted their bets to the long end after a hawkish Fed, with leveraged funds buying across the curve.

site_title: Amazon is exploring offer for Peloton: source
summary: Amazon is exploring a potential offer for Peloton Interactive, the exercise bike maker, amid struggles to maintain pandemic-fueled growth. The news comes after activist investor Blackwells Capital urged the company's board to consider a sale. Peloton's shares surged 30% in extended trading following the report. Amazon is speaking with advisers about whether and how to proceed with the offer.

site_title: Facebook parent Meta rethinks election ads ban ahead of 2022 midterms
summary: Meta, the parent company of Facebook, is rethinking its policy of banning new political ads in the final days before an election, ahead of the 2022 US midterm elections. The company has been evaluating its 2020 policy, which was implemented to prevent last-minute manipulation of the election, and considering changes to how it defines a "new" ad. The decision comes as the 2022 midterms are expected to be highly contested, with Republicans aiming to regain control of Congress.

site_title: EU, US agree to resume trade in mussels, clams and oysters
summary: The European Union and the US have agreed to resume trade in mussels, clams, and oysters from the end of February, after a halt more than a decade ago due to food safety differences. The agreement initially applies to the Netherlands, Spain, Massachusetts, and Washington states, with other US states and EU countries able to apply for export clearance through a streamlined process. This marks a positive step in US-EU trade relations, with both sides praising the agreement as a major win for the seafood industry.

site_title: Airbus may make engines for hydrogen fuelled planes, CEO tells paper
summary: Airbus CEO Guillaume Faury has revealed plans to develop its own engines for hydrogen fuelled planes, potentially equipping the aircraft with electric motors produced in-house. The planemaker aims to develop the world's first zero-emission hydrogen fuelled commercial aircraft by 2035. This move could represent a "change of strategy" for Airbus, according to Faury.

images.alt_text: Airbus may make its own engines for its hydrogen fuelled planes, chief executive officer Guillaume Faury told a German newspaper in an interview published on Saturday (Feb 5).

site_title: India's Chettinad mansions a testament to past glory
summary: In southern India, nearly 11,000 Chettinad mansions, once the residences of wealthy bankers and traders, now lie abandoned due to a century of decline. Built during British colonial rule, these palatial homes featured intricate designs and materials sourced from Europe. Despite efforts to preserve them, many remain dilapidated, with owners unable to afford upkeep or caught in property disputes. However, some have been restored as heritage resorts, attracting tourists who seek to experience the region's faded grandeur.

site_title: Apple aims to debut a new low-cost 5G iPhone and iPad in early March
summary: Apple is set to unveil a new low-cost 5G iPhone and an updated iPad in early March, with the exact date likely to be on or near March 8. The new iPhone will feature 5G capabilities, an improved camera, and a faster processor, while the iPad will have a faster processor and 5G. The company is also planning to release iOS 15.4, a new Mac with Apple-designed chips, and multiple product launches throughout 2022, including new iMacs, Mac Pros, and AirPods.

site_title: Biogen says US FTC, SEC probing Alzheimer's disease drug
summary: The US Federal Trade Commission (FTC) and the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) are probing Biogen for its approval and marketing of Alzheimer's disease treatment Aduhelm. Biogen disclosed this in its annual report, stating it received a civil investigative demand from the FTC. The FTC oversees industry competition and consumer protection, while the SEC regulates securities markets and protects investors. The investigation's outcome is not yet known.

site_title: BNM head aims to give Malaysians more digital options in finance
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia (BNM), is exploring the adoption of central bank digital currencies (CBDCs) to capitalize on new technologies and speed up the growth of financial technology. BNM governor Nor Shamsiah Mohd Yunus aims to provide more digital options in finance, with a focus on expanding coverage for low-income working adults and serving the insurance and takaful sectors. The bank will ensure that new systems face similar scrutiny and safeguards to manage risks, and plans to further develop domestic bond and currency markets.

site_title: Big tech's week featured alphabet and Amazon rallies, Meta crash
summary: Big tech stocks experienced significant weekly moves, with Alphabet and Amazon rallying and Meta crashing. Alphabet rose 7.5% for the week, its best performance since October, adding $122.5 billion to its market valuation. Amazon rose 9.5% for the week, its biggest gain since July 2020, with a record $191 billion added in market value. In contrast, Meta fell 21% for the week, its biggest drop on record, after a weak revenue forecast and stagnating user growth.

site_title: Group of crypto DAOs considers taking over crypto exchange Sushi in latest DeFi twist
summary: A group of decentralized autonomous organizations (DAOs) is proposing to take over the governance of Sushi, a beleaguered cryptocurrency exchange. The proposal, led by Ondo Finance, aims to bring renewed leadership and balance between community buy-in and quick decision-making. If successful, the group plans to raise $15 million in donations and compensate contributors. Sushi is revamping its leadership and structure amid infighting among developers, who have been accused of extravagant spending and self-enrichment. The takeover attempt comes after another DAO coalition, Frog Nation, abandoned its involvement with Sushi following a contentious vote.

site_title: US CDC backs full approval of Moderna's COVID-19 vaccine
summary: The US CDC has backed the full approval of Moderna's COVID-19 vaccine for individuals 18 and older, following the FDA's approval in December 2020. The vaccine, now branded as Spikevax, is the second fully approved vaccine in the US. CDC Director Rochelle Walensky's signature marks the final step in the approval process, allowing the vaccine to be sold and distributed nationwide. Approximately 75 million people in the US have been fully vaccinated with Moderna's shot, following the Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine's full approval for those 16 and older in August.

site_title: US House backs sweeping China competition bill as Olympics start
summary: The US House of Representatives narrowly passed a $300 billion bill to boost American competitiveness with China, despite Republican opposition, with a vote of 222-210. The "America COMPETES Act of 2022" authorizes funding for research and development, semiconductor manufacturing, and supply-chain problems. The bill sets up negotiations with the Senate on a compromise version, which must pass both chambers before it can be sent to President Joe Biden for signature. The bill aims to offset China's market-distorting trade practices and includes changes to US trade rules.

images.alt_text: The US House of Representatives on Friday (Feb 4) narrowly passed a multibillion-dollar bill aimed at increasing American competitiveness with China and boosting US semiconductor manufacturing, despite Republican opposition.

site_title: MOH probe death of 103-year-old woman erroneously given fourth Covid-19 vaccine shot
summary: A 103-year-old woman in Singapore died after being erroneously given a fourth Covid-19 vaccine shot by a mobile vaccination team. She was admitted to hospital with pneumonia and stroke, and the coroner has not determined if the vaccination contributed to her death. The Ministry of Health (MOH) is investigating the incident, which is the first case of mistaken identity leading to erroneous vaccination by a mobile team. MOH has reminded mobile vaccination teams to perform independent identity verification and authentication before administering vaccinations, and both the nursing home and mobile vaccination provider have reviewed their processes to prevent recurrence.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slide as automakers fear tougher emission standards
summary: European stocks fell 1.4% on Friday, with automobile stocks hitting a one-month low due to tougher emissions tests planned by the European Union. The EU's move would require automakers to sell more battery-operated vehicles to meet emissions targets. The European Central Bank hinted at possible rate hikes, further pressuring markets. Technology stocks lost 14% this year due to inflation concerns and soaring energy prices. Bank stocks were the best performers, up 2.4%, while German and Dutch bond yields turned positive for the first time since 2018.

site_title: IMF taps ex-Bundesbank chief Weidmann to lead oversight panel after scandal
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has appointed an independent outside panel led by former Bundesbank President Jens Weidmann to strengthen institutional safeguards after accusations against its chief, Kristalina Georgieva. The panel will review the fund's framework for addressing complaints about management and the board, following an October review that found insufficient evidence of improper action by Georgieva. The panel aims to finalize its report and recommendations by the end of March, building on previous work to improve dissent and accountability within the IMF.

site_title: Oil hits 7-year highs as rally extends to a 7th week
summary: Oil prices surged to 7-year highs, reaching $93.70 per barrel, driven by ongoing supply disruptions and frigid US weather. Brent crude rose 2.4% and US West Texas Intermediate crude rose 2.3% in their longest rally since October. Strong global demand and bullish market views expect prices to surpass $100 per barrel. However, some analysts see risks to the rally, including Omicron setbacks, economic growth concerns, and financial market corrections.

site_title: Apple wins a new trial in US$1.1b Caltech patent case
summary: A US appeals court has vacated a $1.1 billion verdict in favor of California Institute of Technology (Caltech) over Apple and Broadcom in a patent case over Wi-Fi technology. The court ruled that a two-tier damage award of $270.2 million against Broadcom and $837.8 million against Apple is "legally unsupportable". A new trial will be held to determine damages and infringement on a third patent. Caltech's patents were upheld, but the court also found that Broadcom and Apple infringed on two patents.

site_title: Brokers' take: UOBKH maintains 'buy' on ThaiBev, cuts TP due to lower beer segment valuation
summary: UOB Kay Hian has maintained its "buy" call on Thai Beverage Public Co (ThaiBev) with a target price (TP) of S$0.85, citing the company's attractive price and stable core business in spirits. The TP was lowered due to a lower valuation for its beer segment. Analysts also see potential value unlocking for the group through a potential initial public offering (IPO) of its beer business in the second half of 2022.

site_title: What the 'Active Grandparent Hypothesis' can tell us about ageing well
summary: A new theory, the "Active Grandparent Hypothesis," suggests that our need for physical activity may be linked to our ancestral need for grandparents to care for grandchildren, helping them survive. This theory proposes that physical activity, which helped hunter-gatherers survive long enough to become grandparents, is beneficial for our health today. Research supports that exercise improves heart health, reduces disease risks, and boosts overall well-being, potentially due to our evolutionary roots. This idea offers a fresh perspective on the benefits of physical activity, linking it to our ancestral survival and longevity.

site_title: Japan's US$1 trillion crypto market may ease onerous listing rules
summary: Japan's cryptocurrency market, valued at nearly $1 trillion, may see eased listing rules. The Japan Virtual and Crypto assets Exchange Association (JVCEA) is considering allowing exchanges to list more than a dozen coins at once without a lengthy screening process. This change could benefit newcomers like Coinbase, which lists fewer tokens in Japan than in the US. The proposal would also make it easier for popular coins to be listed without a long review process, and could help the industry grow despite Japan's waning presence in global crypto markets.

site_title: Interest rates may have to rise sharply to fight inflation
summary: The Federal Reserve may need to sharply raise interest rates to combat inflation, but a permanent return to high rates is unlikely due to the world's aging population. The era of low rates, which has characterized rich economies for over a decade, is expected to continue. Interest rate rises would lead to a financial squeeze, rather than a return to the 1970s, when rates were higher. The shift in monetary policy would be a significant change, battering stock markets and affecting firms and homeowners accustomed to cheap financing.

images.alt_text: The Fed says it plans to get interest rates back to about 2 per cent by 2024, not far off most estimates of their neutral level, which in theory neither stimulates the economy nor holds it back. But as the Fed has dragged its feet, the risk has grown that it will have to go further.

site_title: After fraught run-up, Beijing stages spectacular Olympics opening
summary: The 2022 Beijing Winter Olympics opening ceremony took place on February 4, 2022, after a fraught run-up due to the Covid-19 pandemic and criticism over human rights in China. The ceremony featured a performance with glowing green stalks, fireworks, and a 3D cube with images from previous Winter Games. The official start of the Games was a relief to organisers, who navigated complexity during a pandemic while adhering to China's zero-Covid policy, in an effort to quiet criticism over China's human rights record.

site_title: US: Stocks mostly up after strong January jobs data
summary: US stocks finished mostly higher on Friday after a strong January jobs report, with the US adding 467,000 jobs and significantly raising job figures for November and December. However, the report raised concerns about aggressive monetary policy tightening and a rise in 10-year US Treasury note yields. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.1%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes gained 0.5% and 1.6%, respectively. Individual companies saw mixed results, with Amazon surging 13.5% and Snap soaring nearly 60%, while Ford slumped nearly 10%.

site_title: Sandwiched between a rock and a hard place?
summary: The policy gap between the US Federal Reserve and China's People's Bank of China is likely to widen, potentially increasing the risks of negative spillovers for Asia and the rest of the world. The Fed is poised to commence lift-off in March, while the PBOC has continued to deliver easier monetary policy. China's leaders are unlikely to accept GDP growth below 5% this year, and another reserve requirement ratio reduction may be imminent. This divergence could lead to uneven distribution of risks, particularly for emerging markets, and may leave them "sandwiched between a rock and a hard place."

site_title: Gold firms as inflation risks counter higher US yields, dollar
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $1,805.95 per ounce, driven by inflation concerns despite higher US Treasury yields and a firmer dollar. The unexpected jump in US job growth in January fueled fears of inflation, while interest rate hikes would raise the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion. Silver, platinum, and palladium also moved, with silver up 0.2%, while platinum and palladium declined.

site_title: Saudi royals end feud over 'plaything' Beverly Hills estate
summary: Saudi royals Prince Faisal Bin Abdullah Bin Abdulaziz Al Saud and his ex-wife Fahdah Husain Abdulrahman Al-Athel have settled a 3-year-old lawsuit in Delaware Chancery Court over their 18-bedroom Beverly Hills compound. The terms of the settlement are confidential, but a judge deemed it "fair, reasonable and adequate" for the warring royals. The couple, who divorced in 2016, bought the $16.8 million estate in 2011 and are currently listing it for sale at $20 million.

site_title: Visions and divisions in legal leadership
summary: Lawyer Eric Grossman, Morgan Stanley's chief legal officer, has called for a return to the office, citing the importance of in-person interactions for learning and mentoring young lawyers. He argues that remote work hinders bonding and relationship-building, crucial for the development of future leaders. Grossman believes that current legal leaders have a responsibility to the next generation of lawyers, requiring in-person training and mentoring. The pushback from the legal community highlights the challenges of adapting to the "next normal" in a hyper-competitive industry.

site_title: US added more jobs than expected in January, defying Omicron
summary: US employers added 467,000 jobs in January, exceeding forecasts, despite a surge in Covid-19 infections. The unemployment rate rose to 4% and average hourly earnings jumped 0.7%. The strong labor market data supports the Federal Reserve's intention to raise interest rates in March to combat high inflation. Average hourly earnings rose 5.7% from last year, fueling concerns about inflation persistence. The data contrasts with expectations of a weak or negative payrolls print due to virus-related disruptions.

site_title: Born cycling! Mountain biking for a clear mind
summary: Andreas D Joergensen, managing director of Organon's South, East, and South-east Asia region, attributes his physical and mental fitness to his passion for mountain biking and running. Born in Denmark, Joergensen began cycling at 10 and took up mountain biking seriously at 13. He finds mountain biking challenging and mentally rewarding, and credits it with boosting his confidence. As a leader, Joergensen emphasizes the importance of a supportive community, citing the encouragement and camaraderie he finds in the mountain biking community as a model for his own workplace culture.

site_title: SingPost to make second partial award in arbitration related to Famous Holdings
summary: SingPost will make a further payment in an arbitration case related to a share-purchase agreement with Famous Holdings, following a partial award issued by the Singapore International Arbitration Centre. The dispute centers on the transfer of Tan Ho Sung's 37.5% shares in FHPL to SingPost. The tribunal had previously ruled in SingPost's favor on material accounting issues, but the parties are still disagreeing on the final valuation. The second partial award is expected to have a minimal impact on SingPost's finances, with the exact amount undisclosed.

site_title: A market crash will depend on which bit of the equation investors got wrong
summary: A market crash is likely to occur if investors' assumptions about a high-profit, low-inflation environment prove incorrect. Historically, extreme market valuations have been rare, but investors often overestimate the permanence of such conditions. The key factor determining the severity of the crash is which assumption investors have gotten wrong: the discount rate or corporate profits. Rising interest rates, which are now being anticipated by the Federal Reserve, could impact corporate margins and contribute to a sharper crash, while a high-profit assumption could lead to a longer, drawn-out bear market.

site_title: Tesla plans to build cathode building at Texas Gigafactory
summary: Tesla has applied for a permit to build a 1.6 million square foot cathode building at its Texas Gigafactory in Austin, Texas. The facility, part of the company's battery cell production plant, is expected to produce cathodes, the single most expensive component of a battery. The new building would extend Tesla's existing vehicle factory, which began manufacturing vehicles earlier this year. The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality previously approved Tesla's vehicle manufacturing site, and the company still needs air quality permits for polluting manufacturing sites.

site_title: SPH Reit appoints PrimePartners Corporate Finance as adviser for possible Cuscaden Peak chain offer
summary: SPH Reit has appointed PrimePartners Corporate Finance as its independent financial adviser for a possible chain offer by consortium Cuscaden Peak. The offer, if made, would involve a minimum chain offer price of S$0.964 per unit in cash. The IFA will report on distributions to unitholders during the offer period. A circular containing the IFA's advice and independent directors' recommendations will be sent to unitholders within 14 days if the offer is made. The move follows Cuscaden Peak's surprise bid to privatize SPH Reit, which may result in a chain offer for all remaining units.

site_title: US: Dow subdued at open as surprise jobs growth fans inflation
summary: The Dow Jones Industrial Average opened flat on Friday, down 15.4 points, as data showed a surprise jump in US growth in January, fueling concerns about inflation. This countered the boost from Amazon's results. The S&P 500 rose 5.4 points, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 79.7 points, both at the open.

images.alt_text: The Dow opened flat on Friday (Feb 4), as data showing an unexpected jump in US growth in January fanned fears around inflation, countering a boost from Amazon's results at the end of a volatile week.

site_title: War over CEO's US$200m pay flares at Sculptor as Och's board member quits
summary: Sculptor Capital Management Inc's CEO Jimmy Levin is facing a board dispute over a $200 million annual pay package. Director J Morgan Rutman, a former board member of Dan Och's firm, quit citing governance failures and claiming he was frozen out of the compensation process. Rutman said Levin's award was "staggering" and would cause shareholder dilution. Sculptor has denied Rutman's claims, stating his letter contains inaccuracies and baseless assertions. Levin's pay package is part of a larger effort to turn around the company, which has seen withdrawals decrease and its stock price rise in recent years.

site_title: Realism about foreign policy realism
summary: US President Joe Biden faces a diplomatic challenge in finding a way to avoid war in Ukraine without abandoning the country or its values, which sustain the US's soft power. Realism in foreign policy, which prioritizes survival and power, is necessary but insufficient, as it neglects the importance of soft power, values, and cosmopolitanism. A smart realist would consider different types of power, including coercion, payment, and attraction, and balance them to achieve desired outcomes. Biden must navigate this complex landscape, weighing security against freedom, identity, and rights, to find a solution that upholds US values and avoids war.

images.alt_text: Youths climb on destroyed Russian military machinery, displayed near St Mykhailivsky Cathedral in downtown Kyiv, Ukraine, Oct 8 2024, amid the Russian invasion.

site_title: Asian commercial property will continue to roar in the Year of the Tiger
summary: Asian commercial property is poised for a strong year in 2022, driven by governments shifting to live with Covid-19 and investors seeking value-added opportunities. CBRE's Asia Pacific Investor Intentions Survey 2022 found 60% of investors plan to purchase more real estate, with total investment turnover forecast to increase 5-10% to $150 billion, a historical high. Key sectors include logistics and offices, with Tokyo, Shanghai, and Singapore favored for cross-border investments.

site_title: Satisfaction with taxi, private-hire car services holds steady in 2021: PTC survey
summary: Commuters in Singapore reported steady satisfaction with taxi and private-hire car services in 2021, with taxi satisfaction averaging 8.5/10 and private-hire car satisfaction averaging 8.3/10. The number of commuters satisfied with these services increased slightly. Respondents cited pricing, safety, and ease of use as key factors in their choice between taxis and private-hire cars. The survey, conducted online due to the Covid-19 pandemic, polled 3,332 commuters and found that safety was the top concern for both taxi and private-hire car services.

site_title: Blockchain Association says it's concerned over lack of clarity, mixed messaging
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has announced a ban on advertising cryptocurrency services, sparking concerns among blockchain association members. The lack of clarity on the guidelines has raised questions about the impact on the industry, including education seminars, merchandise, and NFTs. Industry members worry that the ban will make it more difficult for crypto and blockchain firms to set up shop in Singapore. The MAS has yet to provide clear guidance on the rules.

images.alt_text: A Bitcoin machine at Sim Lim Square being removed on Jan 18. MAS had, on Jan 17, said providers of digital payment token services should not market or advertise in public areas.

site_title: Kia Sonet - Poetry in motion
summary: The Kia Sonet, a budget SUV, offers value and practicality, making it a desirable option for those seeking a cost-effective vehicle. With a roomy boot and easy-to-use features, the Sonet is a decent machine that can seat five comfortably. Although it lacks premium features, it boasts a range of conveniences, including keyless operation, a parking camera, and auto headlamps. The Sonet's affordability is enhanced by its inductive phone charging pad and seamless integration with Apple CarPlay and Android Auto. With a starting price of S$108,999, the Kia Sonet is a surprisingly well-equipped and practical choice for those on a budget.

site_title: Sale of animal-linked NFTs raises conservation funds for South African reserve
summary: WildEarth, a wildlife streaming service, is selling NFTs linked to 25 prominent animals, including a four-year-old leopard named Tlalamba, to raise funds for conservation on the Djuma Game Reserve in South Africa. The NFTs, unique digital signatures, are part of a new project that aims to support conservation efforts on the reserve.

site_title: Billionaire Bhatia to helm IndiGo after surprise swing to profit
summary: Billionaire Rahul Bhatia has taken on the newly-created role of managing director at IndiGo, the Asia's biggest budget airline by market value, after a surprise quarterly profit was posted. This move signals a truce with fellow co-founder Rakesh Gangwal, who had accused Bhatia of corporate governance lapses. Bhatia will focus on expanding the airline in India and overseas, and build the carrier for the long term. The airline swung to a profit of 1.3 billion rupees in the 3 months ended Dec 31, with revenue increasing to 92.95 billion rupees.

site_title: After Australian Open heroics, more glory beckons for Nadal and Barty
summary: Rafael Nadal and Ashleigh Barty emerged as the first Grand Slam champions of 2022, winning the Australian Open titles in a fortnight marked by high-quality tennis and numerous nail-biting finishes. Nadal, overcoming a 5-month injury layoff, defeated Daniil Medvedev in a 5-set marathon final to reach 21 Grand Slams. Barty dominated the women's competition, dropping just 30 games and not losing a set en route to her third Grand Slam title. Both players now set their sights on the French Open, with Nadal seeking to extend his record on clay courts and Barty aiming to make a statement return in Paris.

site_title: Argentina's imaginary miracle
summary: Argentina's economic recovery appears to be a "miracle" but data suggests otherwise. The country's economy contracted by 10% in 2020, the second-largest slump in the region, and has yet to return to pre-pandemic levels. Despite this, President Alberto Fernandez's policies have led to high growth, improved finances, and a rebound in employment and investment. However, critics argue that this growth is largely a rebound from a massive output dip, rather than sustainable growth. The true state of Argentina's economy remains unclear, with the country's economic recovery appearing to be a complex issue.

site_title: Thailand's Jan main CPI jumps 3.23% y-o-y, beats forecast
summary: Thailand's headline consumer price index (CPI) jumped 3.23% in January from a year earlier, beating forecast of 2.40%. This is the second consecutive month of price increases, following a 2.17% rise in December. The core CPI index also rose 0.52% from a year earlier, exceeding the forecast of 0.37%.

site_title: Bank of Japan's Kuroda vows to keep ultra-easy policy to support growth
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda reiterated the need for ultra-easy monetary policy to support growth, citing subdued inflation in Japan due to soft wage growth and a lingering deflationary mindset. Kuroda stated that nominal wages must rise in tandem with prices for inflation to reach the 2% target. This stance maintains the Bank of Japan's loose monetary policy, which is expected to continue supporting economic growth despite global economic trends.

site_title: Russia, China agree to 30-year gas deal via new pipeline
summary: Russia has agreed to a 30-year gas deal with China, with Gazprom to supply 10 billion cubic meters of gas per year via a new pipeline from Russia's Far East to northeast China. The deal, settled in euros, will increase Russian pipeline sales to China and bolster the energy alliance between the two countries. First flows are expected in two to three years, and the deal will add to Russia's existing pipeline sales to China, which currently stands at 16.5 billion cubic meters per year.

site_title: Hacker attack hits airport services provider Swissport
summary: Swissport, an airport ground services and air cargo operator, was hit by a ransomware attack on Thursday, disrupting some operations at Zurich Airport. The attack affected a limited part of Swissport's IT infrastructure, with several servers knocked out, but critical systems and applications were not impacted. The attack was detected promptly, and measures were taken to contain and mitigate the impact. Swissport is now restoring affected systems and will work to prevent further spread. The exact impact on flights is not yet known, with 22 flights delayed by up to 20 minutes on Thursday.

site_title: Evergrande to push ahead with sale of Hong Kong land after receiver appointment
summary: China Evergrande Group will proceed with the sale of a Hong Kong land plot despite the appointment of a receiver by a creditor, US asset manager Oaktree Capital Management. The receiver's move is unlikely to impact Evergrande's restructuring process, and the asset is expected to be sold in the near term. Oaktree aims to recover its investment and any residual proceeds through the sale. This move comes after Evergrande defaulted on a secured loan, with the group facing over $300 billion in debt and multiple defaults on loans.

site_title: Aston Martin F1 team signs long-term deal with Saudi’s Aramco
summary: Aston Martin F1 has signed a long-term deal with Saudi's Aramco, aiming to aid its ambition of winning races and championships. The partnership will help Aston Martin meet Formula One's target for sustainable fuels by 2025 and develop efficient hybrid engines. The team will be renamed Aston Martin Aramco Cognizant Formula One Team, with Aramco contributing to fuel-efficient engine technologies for road cars and the automotive industry. The deal strengthens Saudi Arabia's profile in motorsport, with Aramco already a major Formula One sponsor.

site_title: Carlsberg warns that higher beer prices could hit sales
summary: Carlsberg plans to raise beer prices by 10-12% to offset rising raw material costs, potentially impacting sales this year. Despite better-than-forecast fourth-quarter sales, the company expects organic operating profit to grow only 0-7% in 2022, down from 12.5% last year. CEO Cees 't Hart notes that the significantly higher input costs and continued Covid-19 impact will pose challenges, and price hikes may negatively affect beer consumption.

site_title: Hong Kong to send tens of millions of Covid tests to residents
summary: Hong Kong is sending tens of millions of Covid-19 home testing kits to its 7.4 million residents amid a surge in cases threatening the city's healthcare system. Chief Executive Carrie Lam announced plans to convert a quarantine centre into an isolation facility and tighten social distancing curbs, with the goal of increasing inoculation rates, especially among the elderly. The city has reported 131 new cases, with nearly half having no known origin, and officials expect a significant increase in infections following the Lunar New Year holiday.

site_title: Indonesian social commerce platform Grupin raises US$3m, led by Sequoia India's Surge
summary: Indonesian social commerce platform Grupin has raised US$3 million in funding led by Sequoia India's Surge. Skystar Capital and East Ventures also participated. Grupin offers a community-based shopping experience with discounts on bulk consumer products, aiming to capitalize on Indonesia's growing e-commerce market, expected to reach US$60 billion by 2025. The platform plans to expand its team and sourcing reach, following its successful use of "gotong royong" cultural behaviors in engaging customers.

site_title: SGX posts 8.8 per cent decline in net profit due to weaker treasury income, higher operating expenses
summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported an 8.8% decline in net profit to S$218.7 million for the first half of 2022 due to weaker treasury income and higher operating expenses. The company's adjusted net profit fell 2.7% to S$221.8 million. Operating expenses rose 8.2% to S$215.6 million, driven by staff expenses, technology expenses, and professional fees. Despite a decline in equities segment revenue, SGX remained optimistic about its outlook, citing growth in its FICC segment and ETF market. The company declared an interim quarterly dividend of S$0.08 per share.

site_title: No certainty that Orchard Towers' potential S$1.6b collective sale will proceed: Hiap Hoe
summary: Singapore property developer Hiap Hoe has reiterated that there's no certainty its Orchard Towers collective sale will proceed or be completed. The proposed reserve price of S$1.6 billion needs 80% unit owner consent, which will be voted on at an upcoming general meeting on Feb 18. Hiap Hoe's board will provide further updates on the sale at an appropriate time, advising shareholders to exercise caution.

site_title: Exxon eyes more long-term gas supply deals with India
summary: ExxonMobil is considering signing more long-term gas supply deals with India, citing rising spot prices as an opportunity to secure contracts. The company currently has a 1.5 million-tonne annual liquefied natural gas supply contract with Petronet LNG. India aims to increase gas's share in its energy mix to 15% by 2030, and Exxon's CEO believes long-term contracts can help de-risk the country's energy demand from price volatility. This move comes as global energy costs surge, with LNG prices reaching all-time highs.

site_title: With rings breaking from block of ice, Games ceremony begins
summary: The 2022 Beijing Winter Olympics opening ceremony began on February 4, 2022, with a performance by dancers and fireworks, followed by the raising of the Chinese flag and the performance of the national anthem. The ceremony featured imagery from previous Winter Games carved into a block of ice, which was then broken by ice hockey players to reveal the Olympic rings. The event marked a culmination of preparations amidst the Covid-19 pandemic and criticism over human rights in China. Russian President Vladimir Putin attended the ceremony, and the games aim to showcase China's confidence and pride amidst global tensions.

site_title: BOE's Bailey urges pay restraint as UK reels from cost squeeze
summary: Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey urged UK workers to hold off on asking for higher pay raises, citing concerns that rising wages could fuel inflation. Bailey said "restraint" is needed in pay bargaining to prevent a wage-price spiral. The comments come as households face a decades-long squeeze on incomes, with energy bills set to jump by nearly £700 in April. Bailey's pay amounts to over £575,000, sparking accusations of insensitivity. The BOE is raising interest rates to combat inflation, which is expected to reach 7.25% this year.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks close sharply higher
summary: Hong Kong shares surged 3.24% on Friday, driven by a strong performance across world markets, with tech and financial firms among the best performers. The Hang Seng Index rose to 24,573.29 points, following a 3-day break. Mainland Chinese markets were closed for a holiday. The rally comes as investors returned from a break and amid global optimism, with US and European markets also reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Oil majors are close to erasing all losses since pandemic began
summary: European oil majors, including Shell, BP, and TotalEnergies, are erasing pandemic losses as tensions between Russia and the West drive Brent crude above US$92 a barrel. Energy stocks have outperformed all other sectors in Europe, with the Stoxx Europe 600 energy sub-index reaching its seventh week of gains. Strategists attribute the sector's success to a tight market, geopolitical tensions, and rising bond yields, making energy stocks an attractive diversifier. However, some analysts, like Joachim Klement, expect gains to be capped in March due to concerns about a slowdown in China and seasonal demand decline.

site_title: Employees should prepare to work longer hours to cover colleagues as Omicron cases spike: Tripartite advisory
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Manpower, National Trades Union Congress, and Singapore National Employers Federation have issued an advisory advising employers to prepare for potentially high levels of workforce absences due to the Omicron variant. Employees may be asked to work longer hours to cover for absent colleagues. Essential services, such as transport and healthcare, will be exempt from overtime limits, but some work activities, like crane operations and woodworking, will not be eligible. Employers are encouraged to develop business continuity plans, including regular testing and redeployment of critical staff.

site_title: Mahathir allowed home but still receiving hospital treatment
summary: Former Malaysian Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad, 96, is undergoing treatment at the National Heart Institute but has been allowed to return home for the day. He has been advised not to receive visitors and continues to undergo certain procedures in the evenings. Mahathir has a history of heart problems and was re-admitted to hospital after an elective medical procedure on January 8. His family has requested people not to be too worried about his health, with his daughter stating that Mahathir has recovered, "not fully."

site_title: Seoul: Stocks gain for third session on upbeat US equity futures
summary: South Korean shares rose for a third consecutive session, logging their best weekly gain in almost a year, driven by upbeat US equity futures following Amazon's profit beat. The Kospi index gained 1.57% to 2,750.26, with technology giants Samsung Electronics and SK Hynix also rising. The Korean won strengthened, attracting offshore investor demand, and foreigners bought 190.4 billion won worth of shares.

site_title: Europe: Stocks rebound ahead of US jobs data
summary: European stock markets rebounded, with London's FTSE 100 index up 0.8% and the eurozone's DAX and CAC 40 indices gaining 0.3% and 0.6%, respectively. The rebound follows a decline on Thursday due to concerns over interest rate hikes and Meta's share price drop. Analysts attribute the recovery to Amazon's strong earnings and offsetting concerns about the US tech sector.

site_title: Ex-GMs of Uber and Deliveroo, foodpanda executive back food ordering app Gobble
summary: Gobble, a social food ordering app, has raised $1.3 million in a seed round led by venture firms Beenext and Flash Ventures, along with prominent industry figures. The startup, co-founded by Ashwin Purushottam and Domenico Tan, aims to launch its app across universities, focusing on group ordering and food-gifting. The funds will be used to expand the tech and product team and improve its value proposition for restaurant partners. Gobble's founders, including former Uber and Deliveroo executives, see an opportunity to address a unique market need in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: Putin tells Xi of new deal that could sell more Russian gas to China
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin informed Chinese President Xi Jinping of a new deal to supply China with 10 billion cubic meters of gas per year from Russia's Far East, surpassing previous agreements. This move aims to strengthen Russia's energy ties with China, a major hydrocarbon consumer. The new contract is seen as a step forward in the gas industry, building on Russia's existing Power of Siberia pipeline and liquefied natural gas (LNG) shipments to China.

site_title: Malaysia's new Covid cases exceed 7,000 again on Omicron wave
summary: Malaysia reported 7,234 new COVID-19 cases on February 4, the highest level in over three months, driven by the Omicron variant. The nation is focusing on the severity of infections rather than the number, with nearly 52% of adults having received booster shots. Malaysia has extended its vaccination drive to children as young as 11 years old, with 15% of the total cohort registered to receive shots. Despite the surge, the government remains hopeful that almost half of the children will be vaccinated by the end of February.

site_title: Activision Blizzard earnings miss estimates after Microsoft deal
summary: Activision Blizzard reported a 18% decline in adjusted revenue to $2.5 billion in the fourth quarter, missing analyst estimates. The company cited lower-than-expected performance in its Activision division, which produces Call of Duty. The decline comes amid controversy surrounding allegations of sexism and harassment, which led to executive-level shake-ups and employee discontent. Microsoft's $69 billion acquisition of Activision Blizzard may provide a boost to the company's long-term prospects, with plans to incorporate the company's games into its Game Pass subscription service.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks end higher
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Friday, recovering from selloffs prompted by the European Central Bank's hawkish stance. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.73% to 27,439.99, while the Topix index increased 0.55% to 1,930.56. The gains followed a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and a record close in the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq.

site_title: Singapore stocks track regional peers to close higher; STI up 0.5%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.47% on Friday, outperforming regional peers, to close at 3,331.41. The Straits Times Index (STI) gained 2.62% for the week, while Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rose 3.24% and South Korea's Kospi Index increased 1.57%. However, Bursa Malaysia KLCI declined 0.19%. Sembcorp Industries led gains, while Wilmar International fell 0.68%. The benchmark index has now surpassed its 30-month record high made on Thursday.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly rise as Hong Kong reopens, eyes on US jobs
summary: Asian markets mostly rose on Friday as Hong Kong reopened, overcoming a sharp drop on Wall Street. The European Central Bank's surprise shift towards lifting interest rates this year added fuel to fears about the removal of pandemic-era stimulus. Investors await US jobs data later in the day, which could influence Federal Reserve policy decisions, particularly if a strong reading sparks talk of a 50 basis-point rate hike in March.

site_title: Philippine banks want more laws as cybercrime losses mount
summary: The Bankers Association of the Philippines signed a memorandum with the Department of Justice to boost cooperation against cybercrime, amid losses of 1 billion pesos (S$26.3 million) due to illicit activities during the pandemic. The group is pushing for updated cybercrime laws, including a bill against "mule accounts," and will organize more cybersecurity information campaigns. This comes as phishing and other sophisticated cybercrimes have become more prevalent in the country.

images.alt_text: The Philippines' biggest bankers' group boosted cooperation with the government and sought new laws against cybercrime, as losses due to these illicit activities hit 1 billion pesos (S$26.3 million) during the pandemic.

site_title: Lendlease Reit raises H1 DPU to S$0.024, revenue dips 5.8%
summary: Lendlease Global Commercial Reit (LReit) reported a 2.6% increase in its first-half distribution per unit (DPU) to S$0.024, driven by its acquisition of an additional stake in Jem. However, its gross revenue fell 5.8% to S$39.2 million due to lower rental reversion at the 313@somerset mall and a drop in revenue from Italy's Sky Complex office buildings. Net property income (NPI) edged down 2.5% to S$29.6 million, while the portfolio occupancy rate reached an all-time high of 99.9%.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is developing a framework for equitable sharing of losses from scams, while Singapore retail sales surged 11.1% in 2021, reversing the previous year's decline. The rise in Omicron cases is expected to lead to longer working hours for employees, and ERA Singapore has launched a new business unit for capital markets and investment sales. The 10-year average return for the March issue of Singapore Savings Bonds (SSBs) reached 1.79%, its highest rate since 2019, with Singapore stocks closing higher at 0.5% due to regional gains.

site_title: Brokers' take: CGS-CIMB raises Sembcorp target price to S$2.96 after adjusting valuation methodology
summary: CGS-CIMB has raised its target price for Sembcorp Industries to S$2.96, a 22.8% potential upside, after adjusting its valuation methodology to the sum of parts. The research team maintains its "add" call on the counter. This follows a 3% rise in the company's shares after the announcement.

site_title: Indonesia's gig economy fails to deliver on the social aspect of ESG
summary: Indonesia's gig economy, dominated by Grab and Gojek, has failed to meet the social aspect of ESG benchmarks, with scores falling below the halfway mark. The study found that pay and work conditions fell short of decent work standards, with workers averaging over 70 hours of work per week and many earning less than the minimum wage after costs. Only Grab and Gojek's services had policies to protect workers from risks, and none provided fair representation or management. The report calls for reforms, including the recognition of gig workers as employees and changes to labor laws.

site_title: Australia: Shares set for biggest weekly gain since late-December
summary: Australian shares are set for their biggest weekly gain since late-December, driven by the Reserve Bank of Australia's decision to push back on market wagers for an early rate hike and firmer commodity prices. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.2% to 7,092, with technology stocks recovering 1.7% and financials gaining 0.2%. Shares of Westpac Banking Corp beat estimates for first-quarter profit, while energy stocks and REA Group also rose.

site_title: Thailand's Gulf Energy to seal crypto JV with Binance in Q2
summary: Thailand's Gulf Energy Development plans to finalize a joint venture with Binance, the world's largest cryptocurrency exchange, in the second quarter of this year. The venture, which will require regulatory approval, aims to capitalize on the growing demand for cryptocurrency trading in the country. Gulf Energy's CEO, Yupapin Wangviwat, expects the venture to take about 6 months to obtain a license for trading and other features to follow. This move comes as Thailand's authorities introduce regulation for cryptocurrency trading, following a criminal complaint filed against Binance last year.

site_title: Japan's 5-year government bond yield rises to 0% on hawkish policy bets
summary: Japan's 5-year government bond yield rose to 0% for the first time in 6 years due to hawkish policy bets amid stubbornly hot inflation and other central banks' tightening. The 10-year yield also climbed to 0.195%, its highest since 2016. Speculation suggests the Bank of Japan may need to tighten policy, potentially shifting its yield curve control target from 10-year to 5-year notes, which could lead to a rate hike.

site_title: GameStop picks NFT market partner in challenge to OpenSea
summary: GameStop partners with Sydney-based Immutable to launch an NFT trading hub on the Ethereum blockchain by the end of the year. The partnership will provide a fund of US$100 million to support creators and pay up to US$150 million in IMX tokens. This move counters GameStop's existing NFT market presence on OpenSea, which charges a 2.5% transaction fee. The collaboration aims to increase exposure and liquidity for assets on Immutable's platform, focused on gaming, and its token IMX has seen a significant gain in value.

site_title: UK car sales jump 25% in January on electric-vehicle demand
summary: UK car sales jumped 25% in January, driven by strong demand for electric vehicles. New-car registrations rose to a 7-month high, with one in five buyers opting for a battery-powered car. Shipments of fully electric vehicles more than doubled, while plug-in hybrids rose 45%. The surge compares to the prior-year period, when sales were affected by Covid-19 lockdowns. The Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders expects sales to rebound this year as the semiconductor shortage eases.

site_title: Australia: Shares end higher to mark best week since late-December
summary: Australian shares ended the week higher, marking their best week since late December, with the S&P/ASX 200 rising 0.6% to 7,120.1 points. Technology stocks rebounded, gaining 1.1% after plummeting in the previous session, while energy stocks closed 1.1% higher, driven by rising oil prices. Despite Meta's $200 billion loss in value, sector leaders like Block and Xero rose between 0.9% and 2.5%. The Australian central bank expects core inflation to peak at 3.25% in the June quarter, but plans to maintain an accommodative policy stance.

site_title: Maersk container ship towed free after running aground off German island
summary: A Maersk container ship, the Mumbai Maersk, was successfully towed free after running aground off the German island of Wangerooge in the North Sea. The ship, carrying 30 people and over 18,000 containers, had become stranded on Wednesday evening. Despite a failed first attempt to tow it into deeper water, a second effort by multiple tug boats and vessels succeeded in freeing the vessel. The ship is now en route to its destination in Bremerhaven, Germany, with no injuries reported and no fuel leak sighted.

site_title: British PM Johnson is 'taking charge' after lockdown party row, minister says
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson is taking charge of his Downing Street team after a row over lockdown parties, according to Business and Energy Secretary Greg Hands. Four of Johnson's closest aides resigned, and finance minister Rishi Sunak distanced himself from a false claim about Labour's handling of a sex offender case. Johnson pledged to change his leadership style after a report condemned "serious failures of leadership" following gatherings at his office and residence. The moves aim to shore up Johnson's premiership amid growing anger over the lockdown parties and his chaotic leadership style.

site_title: Philippines' Jan annual inflation at 3.0%, index rebased to 2018
summary: The Philippines' annual inflation in January was 3.0%, slightly below the 3.1% expectation, according to the statistics agency. The inflation figure used 2018 as the base year, replacing 2012. This change resulted in new weightings for the consumer price index (CPI) basket.

site_title: Japan has no plans to review sales tax rates: finance minister
summary: Japan's finance minister, Shunichi Suzuki, stated that the country has no plans to review its national sales tax rates, currently at 10%. The current rate is crucial for funding social security for Japan's ageing population. Suzuki emphasized the need for spending and revenue reform to restore market trust in Japan's fiscal position, which he described as severe.

site_title: Brokers' take: SAC Capital initiates 'hold' on Livingstone Health with S$0.168 target price
summary: SAC Capital has initiated a "hold" call on Livingstone Health Holdings (LHH) with a target price of S$0.168, citing expected recovery of the medical industry and improved employment. Analyst Peggy Mak expects reopening of borders and increased spending on healthcare services, driven by a growing population and improved employment. However, regional competition and a shrinking population pose long-term headwinds, and the brokerage notes that LHH faces challenges in retaining doctors and increasing profits. Shares rose 4.8% on the news.

site_title: Maybank Securities downgrades Thailand's tourism sector to 'negative'
summary: Maybank Securities downgraded Thailand's tourism sector to "negative" from "neutral" due to market expectations of an expected recovery in international tourist arrivals in FY2022 being already priced in. Analyst Yuwanee Prommaporn expects softer hotel occupancy rates in Q1 2022 due to the spread of Omicron and higher food raw material costs. The brokerage downgraded ratings for Central Plaza Hotel and Minor International, but retains a "buy" call for Airports of Thailand due to its sound fundamentals.

site_title: ERA launches new business unit for capital markets, investment sales
summary: ERA Realty launched a new business unit, Capital Markets & Investment Sales (CMIS), to cater to high-net-worth individuals, family offices, developers, and institutional investors. The unit, headed by Managing Director Steven Tan, focuses on big-ticket assets such as commercial and industrial buildings, retail spaces, and en bloc sales. ERA expects a rise in major investment sales and leasing of business-related properties amid the Covid-19 pandemic and cooling measures. The unit aims to expand into the sales and leasing of commercial and industrial buildings, capitalizing on growing demand in the sector.

site_title: Japan's economy likely rebounded in Q4 on solid consumption: poll
summary: Japan's economy likely rebounded in Q4 with a 5.8% annualized growth rate, driven by a 2.2% rise in private consumption, according to a Reuters poll of 18 economists. The increase reversed the 3.6% contraction in the third quarter. Wholesale prices rose 8.2% in January, slowing for the second straight month, while household spending rose 0.3% in December, marking the first rise in five months. The rebound is attributed to a drop in Covid-19 cases, but the economy may slide back into contraction due to the Omicron variant.

site_title: Toshiba to more than double power chip output with new plant
summary: Toshiba plans to build a new 300-millimetre wafer fabrication plant in Ishikawa Prefecture, Japan, to more than double its power semiconductor production capacity by March 2025. The $1.2 billion facility will take 2 phases to complete and will increase Toshiba's power semiconductor capacity 2.5 times larger than in fiscal 2021. The move aims to address growing demand for power-regulating chips driven by vehicle electrification and industrial automation. Toshiba is targeting 100% renewable energy for the facility and has reassured investors that demand will continue to grow, despite pandemic-fueled electronics frenzy.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks open with strong gains
summary: Hong Kong shares surged 2.48% on Friday, February 4, 2022, with the Hang Seng Index reaching 24,392.86 points. The rally follows a strong advance across world markets this week. Mainland Chinese markets are closed for a holiday, allowing Hong Kong to capitalize on the gains.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open flat on Friday despite Wall Street selloff
summary: Tokyo stocks opened flat on Friday, despite a sharp selloff on Wall Street. The Nikkei 225 index edged up 0.01% and the Topix index rose 0.09%. Investors digested the market's reaction to US President Trump's new threats, which traders brushed off as a potential catalyst for a stocks rally.

site_title: Saudi wealth fund boosts gaming bets with Capcom, Nexon stakes
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) has increased its stakes in Japan-listed gaming firms Capcom and Nexon, with combined holdings valued at over $1 billion. The PIF now holds more than 5% of Capcom and 5.02% of Nexon, following a series of investments in the gaming industry, which also includes stakes in Electronic Arts and Take Two Interactive Software.

site_title: Reserve Bank of Australia sees faster inflation, stresses patience
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) revised its inflation outlook, predicting faster inflation and potentially meeting policy goals sooner than expected. However, it emphasized patience until a sustained wage growth pick-up is evident. The bank maintained its loose policy stance to support a lasting recovery in wages and living standards.

images.alt_text: Australia's central bank on Friday sharply revised up its outlook for inflation while projecting unemployment at 50-year lows, yet was still content to keep policy super loose as it seeks a lasting recovery in wages and living standards.

site_title: Gold set for weekly gain on weaker dollar, inflation woes
summary: Gold prices rose on Friday, setting for a weekly gain, as a weaker dollar and concerns over inflation and Ukraine tensions lifted demand for the metal. Spot gold reached US$1,806.86 per ounce, with US gold futures gaining 0.2% to US$1,807.50. A weaker dollar index, its biggest weekly drop since March 2020, also boosted demand for gold. The Federal Reserve's focus on inflation and interest rate hikes may lead to a hawkish monetary policy pivot, further supporting gold prices.

site_title: Singapore Savings Bonds' 10-year average return hits new high of 1.79% for March issue
summary: Singapore Savings Bonds' 10-year average return hits a new high of 1.79% for the March issue, surpassing its previous record of 1.95% set in 2019. The interest rate increase comes amid expectations of a US Federal Reserve interest rate hike to tame rising inflation. The Bank of England also raised its interest rate for the second consecutive time to tackle decades-high inflation. The maximum amount offered for the SSBs' March issue is S$150 million, with interest payment dates every 6 months until maturity.

site_title: Singapore retail sales up 11.1% in 2021 after year-end rise in December
summary: Singapore's retail sales surged 11.1% year-over-year in 2021, reversing a 3-year losing streak, driven by a year-end shopping spree and broad-based demand. Excluding motor vehicles, sales grew 10.5% for the year, with online sales accounting for 14.6%. Food and beverage services sales also rose 3.9% for the full year, with a 7.4% increase in December. The rebound is seen as a sign of private consumption bouncing back, but experts predict a slower growth rate in 2022 unless visitor arrivals increase.

images.alt_text: Singapore retail sales expanded by 6.7 per cent year on year in December, picking up from the 2.2 per cent rise in the month before.

site_title: MAS to draw up framework for 'equitable' sharing of scam losses
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is developing a framework for sharing losses from scams between consumers and financial institutions. The framework aims to enhance the security of digital banking and promote transparency. Under the framework, financial institutions will be responsible for protecting customers, while consumers will need to take precautions such as not sharing personal credentials. The proportion of losses each party bears will depend on their responsibilities. The framework is expected to be published for public consultation within the next 3 months.

images.alt_text: Under the framework, all parties have responsibilities to be vigilant and to takeprecautions against scams.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened flat on Friday, down 1.25 points or 0.08% to 1,524.48. The index saw 113.9 million lots traded worth RM62.5 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 163 to 112.

site_title: South Korea January inflation at 3.6%, near a decade-high
summary: South Korea's consumer inflation for January reached 3.6%, near a decade-high, driven by surging fuel and food prices. Core inflation, excluding food and fuel costs, jumped 2.6%, the fastest since December 2015. Transportation costs also rose 7.2% year-on-year, fueling concerns of price pressures and potential interest rate hikes by the Bank of Korea in 2022.

site_title: Nike cries foul over virtual shoes, suing retailer that sells sneaker NFTs
summary: Nike sued online reseller StockX in New York federal court for selling unauthorized images of Nike shoes as non-fungible tokens (NFTs), claiming trademark infringement and confusing consumers. StockX sold over 500 Nike-branded NFTs, with buyers told they could redeem the tokens for physical shoes. Nike seeks unspecified damages and a court order blocking sales. The lawsuit follows a surge in NFT popularity and similar lawsuits over digital assets, including a recent suit by Miramax over Quentin Tarantino's NFTs.

site_title: IMF chief says 'too early to say' if world facing sustained inflation
summary: IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva stated it's "too early" to determine if the world is experiencing sustained inflation, but warned that inadequate economic resilience to future shocks could lead to significant problems. Global policymakers need to adjust fiscal and monetary policies to account for varying country-specific conditions. The COVID-19 pandemic remains the biggest risk to the global economy, and increasing vaccination rates in low-income countries is crucial to meet a 70% vaccination target by mid-2022.

site_title: US lawmakers push to rename Taiwan's de facto embassy in Washington
summary: US lawmakers have proposed matching bills in the Senate and House of Representatives to rename Taiwan's de facto embassy in Washington as the "Taiwan Representative Office", a move likely to strain US-China relations. The proposed change, sponsored by bipartisan lawmakers, aims to boost engagement with Taiwan, which China claims as its own territory. The US does not have official ties with Taiwan but is its largest international backer. The move could create a rift in US-China relations and potentially encourage other countries to take similar steps to engage with Taiwan.

site_title: Four aides quit as UK's Johnson seeks to reset beleaguered premiership
summary: Four senior aides to UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson resigned on Thursday amid a growing crisis over scandals, including parties held at Downing Street during coronavirus lockdowns. The resignations follow a report by senior civil servant Sue Gray condemning "serious failures of leadership." Johnson's personal ratings have plummeted, and his party has fallen behind Labour in opinion polls. The shake-up comes as the UK faces a cost of living squeeze and the police investigate 12 lockdown gatherings. Johnson has been criticized for accusing Labour leader Keir Starmer of failing to prosecute a sex offender, and his finance minister has called for an apology.

site_title: Stocks to watch: First Ship Lease Trust
summary: First Ship Lease Trust (FSL Trust) reported a net profit of US$88,000 for the fourth quarter ended Dec 31, 2021, reversing a net loss of US$2.2 million in the same period last year. The trust's FY2021 saw a net loss of US$1.5 million, compared to a net profit of US$6.2 million in FY2020.

site_title: Germany to get 'sovereign' cloud
summary: Germany is set to launch a "sovereign" cloud platform, where all data processing and services will be handled domestically. The platform, developed by SAP, will provide secure cloud services that meet the German government's data protection rules, allowing public institutions to store sensitive information locally. The infrastructure will be operated by a German firm and governed by German law, separating it from Microsoft's global data center infrastructure. This move aims to reduce reliance on US-based companies and enhance data security, following similar efforts by other countries to build their own sovereign clouds.

site_title: Ford Q4 profits hit by supply chain woes
summary: Ford reported weaker-than-expected fourth-quarter profits due to supply chain problems caused by the Omicron variant of Covid-19 and higher commodity costs. The company's profit margins were also affected by elevated expenses tied to fuel and shipping. Despite this, Ford managed to boost North America's profits by steering production to its most profitable vehicles. The company's profit came in at $12.3 billion, with revenues rising 5% to $37.7 billion. Ford projects 2022 operating earnings of $11.5-12.5 billion, an increase of 15-25% over the 2021 level.

site_title: Lisa Cook, expert on racism's economic scars, now Biden's Federal Reserve pick
summary: US President Joe Biden has nominated Lisa Cook, a researcher on racism's economic scars, to the Federal Reserve Board of Governors, making her the first Black woman to serve on the seven-member body.
