Cook, a professor of economics and international relations at Michigan State University, has dedicated her research to understanding the economic impacts of discrimination. If confirmed, she would be part of a majority of women on the board for the first time in the central bank's history.

site_title: US oil busts through US$90/barrel for first time since 2014
summary: US oil prices surged to over $90 a barrel for the first time since 2014, driven by supply concerns amid frigid weather and tensions between Russia and the West over Ukraine. Global benchmark Brent crude reached $91.11 a barrel, while West Texas Intermediate crude closed at $90.27 a barrel. Analysts attribute the rally to fears of production disruptions in Texas and tightness in global crude markets, with Goldman Sachs predicting Brent to top $100 a barrel in the third quarter.

site_title: Pinterest beats revenue target on advertising strength, shares surge
summary: Pinterest Inc. exceeded revenue estimates in its fourth quarter, with $847 million in revenue, a 20% increase from the previous year. However, the company's monthly active users declined 6% to 431 million, the lowest since June 2020. Pinterest's shares surged 20% after the earnings report, driven by strong advertising performance. The company faces competition from other social media platforms and will need to scale its video-first features and influencer marketing efforts to sustain revenue growth.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise at Friday's open; STI up 0.1%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.1% at the open on Friday, Feb 4, 2022, with the Straits Times Index (STI) reaching 3,320.29. The rally followed a drop in US shares on Thursday, with 61.9 million securities worth S$90.6 million changing hands. This marks the fifth consecutive day of gains ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: US: Nasdaq ends 3.7% lower as stocks drop on weak earnings
summary: US stocks declined on Thursday, with the Nasdaq plummeting 3.7% to 13,878.82, following weak earnings from Meta and other companies. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 1.5% and the S&P 500 fell 2.4%. Central banks' readiness to tighten monetary policies and disappointing results from companies like Spotify and Honeywell International also contributed to the market's downturn. Analysts warn that rallies are "fragile" as investors await further interest rate hikes, potentially headwinds for the market this year.

site_title: Facebook usage dips for first time. Will Instagram follow?
summary: Facebook experienced a decline in usage for the first time, with fewer users checking the platform daily per quarter than the year before. Meta's Instagram is also facing a slowdown, with growth in monthly users projected to fall to 5.8% this year and 3.1% by 2025. The decline is attributed to increased competition from TikTok and rising internet costs in India. Meta's CEO Mark Zuckerberg is concerned, as a decline in Instagram users could halt his ambitions for virtual reality and metaverse technologies.

site_title: Xi to meet Putin as tensions rise with West
summary: China's President Xi Jinping will meet with Russian President Vladimir Putin on Friday, marking his first face-to-face meeting with a world leader in nearly two years. The meeting comes as tensions with the West grow, with Putin confirming his attendance at the Winter Olympics opening ceremony. The two leaders will discuss security and other issues in a joint statement, and Xi has invited over 20 leaders to the games, including those from non-democratic regimes, to showcase China's soft power.

site_title: Amazon hikes Prime membership fees in US, profit soars on Rivian stake
summary: Amazon raised its US Prime membership fees, increasing the monthly fee to $14.99 from $12.99 and annual fees to $139 from $119. The move is aimed at offsetting higher shipping costs and wages despite beating profit expectations for the holiday quarter, with earnings reaching $14.3 billion. Amazon's electric car maker Rivian stake contributed $11.8 billion to the profit. The company also reported a 40% rise in revenue for its cloud unit Amazon Web Services and a 32% increase in ad revenue.

site_title: Iraq struggles to make use of Saddam's crumbling palaces
summary: Iraq struggles to restore and utilize over 100 palaces and villas built by former dictator Saddam Hussein, many of which lie in ruins due to looting and damage during the 2003 US-led invasion. Only a handful have been renovated as military bases, public administrations, or museums, with the majority remaining empty due to high renovation costs and bureaucratic hurdles. The Iraqi government aims to turn some of these palaces into tourist complexes or heritage centers, but progress is slow, with corruption and red tape hindering efforts.

images.alt_text: One of former Iraqi dictator Saddam Hussein's palaces in the Babylon Tourist Resort in central Iraq. While a handful of the residences have been repurposed, most lie empty due to prohibitive renovation costs.

site_title: 'Enough is enough': Biden urges end to US gun violence
summary: US President Joe Biden urged lawmakers to collaborate on ending gun violence, calling it "enough is enough" as recent police shootings in New York highlighted growing fear of violent disorder in American cities. Biden proposed a comprehensive strategy to combat gun crime, including cracking down on rogue gun dealers and launching a national initiative to tackle untraceable "ghost guns." The move comes amid a surge in major crimes in US cities, with homicides increasing by 44% in 22 cities compared to 2019, according to a January study.

site_title: Bank of England agrees second consecutive rate hike as inflation soars
summary: The Bank of England has agreed to its second consecutive interest rate hike to combat decades-high inflation, raising borrowing costs by a quarter point to 0.5%. The central bank expects Britain's annual inflation rate to peak at 7.25% in April, surpassing the 5.4% rate in December. The move aims to keep inflation close to 2% while also considering the tight labor market and persistent domestic cost pressures.

site_title: Europe: Shares dealt double whammy by hawkish ECB, tech slump
summary: European stocks plummeted 1.8% as the European Central Bank signaled a potential rate hike this year, citing higher inflation. Tech stocks suffered the most, falling 3.5% amid a spike in bond yields. The ECB's hawkish stance, led by Christine Lagarde, contradicts past comments, putting pressure on global technology stocks.

site_title: British energy bills to jump 54% in blow to consumers amid tax hikes, rising inflation
summary: British households face a 54% increase in energy bills starting April, with the energy regulator Ofgem raising the price cap to £1,971 per year. This surge follows record global gas prices and coincides with tax hikes and forecasted 6% inflation. The government will unveil a new multi-billion-pound support package for hard-hit households.

site_title: Crypto platform Wormhole says 'funds are safe' after US$320m hack
summary: A US$320 million hack has occurred on crypto platform Wormhole, resulting in the theft of over 120,000 units of ether. The platform has stated that "all funds are safe" and that a fix has been deployed to the vulnerability. The attack is the fourth-largest crypto heist on record and highlights the risks associated with decentralized finance (DeFi) sites. Wormhole is offering a US$10 million bounty to the attacker to return the funds.

site_title: Canada's housing market in a 'speculative fever,' regulator says
summary: Canada's housing market is experiencing a "speculative fever" fueled by rising home prices, readily-available mortgages, and a buying frenzy. Regulator Peter Routledge predicts a slowdown in prices as interest rates rise, potentially leading to a 10-20% decline in certain markets. Despite fears of a housing bubble, the government's stress test and Canada's history of weathering similar declines suggest the country can absorb volatility.

site_title: US dollar takes a break from the week's slide
summary: The US dollar experienced a brief respite from its week-long slide, as investors became risk-averse due to a slump in tech and social media stocks and anticipation of central bank meetings in Britain and Europe. The Australian and New Zealand dollars fell slightly, while sterling slipped and the euro weakened. The yen dropped marginally, and the dollar index steadied at 96.043. Market expectations have risen for potential policy changes from the Bank of England and European Central Bank, potentially boosting the euro.

site_title: US claims evidence of Moscow plan for 'false flag' Ukrainian attack
summary: The US Pentagon claims evidence of a Moscow plan to stage a "false flag" Ukrainian attack, with the goal of justifying an invasion. The alleged plan involves filming a fake attack on Russian territory or Russian-speaking people, which could be used to produce propaganda videos and provide a pretext for an invasion. The US has seen similar activities by Russia in the past and believes it is a high-level plot, but no concrete evidence was provided. British Foreign Secretary Liz Truss has condemned the claim as "clear and shocking evidence of Russia's unprovoked aggression."

site_title: Vietnam's factories desperate for workers to return to the big cities
summary: Vietnam's factories are struggling to return to full capacity due to ongoing labor shortages, with over 300,000 new workers needed in Ho Chi Minh City alone. The country's garment and electronics industries, which supply major global brands, are particularly affected. Businesses are offering incentives such as subsidized accommodation and transport to entice workers to return, but salary increases are unlikely. The shortage is attributed to the mass exodus of workers from cities to villages during lockdowns last year, and many are hesitant to return due to uncertainty and the need to start from scratch.

site_title: Japanese dining scene heats up
summary: Taiga Dining, a 11-seater sushi restaurant in Regent Singapore, has opened with a unique design theme inspired by Kochi prefecture in Japan. Helmed by chef Taiga Kanekuni, the restaurant features a dark, club-like space with a hinoki counter and incorporates Kochi's indigenous produce into its menu. The restaurant's signature dishes include a fatty tuna marinated in soy sauce wrapped in arugula and a trio of uni hand roll. Menu prices start at S$280++ for lunch and S$380++ for dinner, offering a modern perspective on traditional sushi.

site_title: Sydney Airport shareholders back A$23.6b cash deal in one of Australia's biggest buyouts
summary: Sydney Airport shareholders approved a A$23.6 billion cash takeover by infrastructure investors, with 96% of votes cast in favor. However, 20.7% of shareholders, representing 4% of the stake, voted against the deal due to a lack of a scrip component. The purchase is a long-term bet on the travel sector, driven by record-low interest rates. The deal was contingent on UniSuper, the company's largest investor, folding its 15% stake into the unlisted vehicle rather than accepting cash.

site_title: 50 years after Nixon, can US-China ties be renewed post-pandemic?
summary: US-China relations are at a critical point 50 years after Richard Nixon's historic visit, with bilateral ties at their lowest ebb since the 1970s. Despite President Biden's efforts to dial down hostility, tensions remain high due to issues like human rights abuses in Xinjiang, cyber attacks, and competition for influence in the South China Sea. New legislation, such as the Hong Kong Human Rights and Democracy Act, has further strained relations. However, there may be opportunities for cooperation on issues like climate change and economics, potentially paving the way for a renewed strategic partnership.

site_title: Flower power at Marguerite
summary: Chef Michael Wilson brings new life to the Flower Dome with his fine-dining restaurant, Marguerite, offering a unique dining experience amidst the botanical gardens. The menu features a mix of ordinary and innovative dishes, with standouts including watermelon ravioli, smoky eel with sweet vinegar jelly, and salmon with fish broth and Hungarian wax peppers. While the meal is enjoyable and well-executed, it falls short of being truly exceptional, with some dishes feeling safe and unchallenging. Overall, Marguerite is a pleasant addition to the Flower Dome, but Wilson's full potential remains to be seen.

site_title: Premature to tighten monetary policy now, says BOJ official
summary: Bank of Japan Deputy Governor Masazumi Wakatabe stated that it's premature to tighten monetary policy as the economy has not fully recovered from the pandemic's impact. He expects consumer inflation to reach around 1% in the coming months, potentially accelerating due to companies passing on higher costs to households. However, Wakatabe emphasized that the BOJ must maintain its massive stimulus program until inflation expectations reach its 2% target, which he believes will take time.

site_title: How to reduce Putin's leverage over Europe
summary: The European Union can reduce its vulnerability to Russia's gas supply disruptions by creating a strategic gas reserve. The reserve, estimated to cost around €10 billion (S$15.2 billion), would provide a buffer to acquire more gas from other producers, reducing Europe's reliance on Russian supplies. This would bolster Europe's energy security and strengthen its geopolitical standing. An operational Nord Stream 2 pipeline may not significantly impact Europe's energy security, as it would mainly allow Russia to reduce transit fees. Creating a European Strategic Gas Reserve would also benefit Ukraine by providing a more stable gas supply.

site_title: Westpac hires Fannie Mae's Zanin as chief risk officer, cuts jobs
summary: Westpac Banking has hired Ryan Zanin, former chief risk officer at Fannie Mae, as its new chief risk officer. Zanin will start in May, as part of a broader risk transformation effort at the Australian bank. The move comes amid ongoing compliance issues, including a record fine of A$1.3 billion in 2020. The bank also reduced its headcount by over 1,100 people in the first quarter, citing a cost-cutting plan.

site_title: Shell boosts buybacks as profit soars on high oil, gas prices
summary: Shell announced a $8.5 billion share buyback program after reporting a 16,400% increase in adjusted net income to $6.39 billion in the fourth quarter, exceeding analyst estimates. The company's return on capital employed rose 8.8% to 2.9% a year ago, driven by high oil and gas prices. Shell plans to keep capital spending at the lower end of its forecast range, instead using excess cash to boost shareholder returns and pay down debt.

site_title: Orchard Towers' potential en bloc sale may come with S$1.6 billion price tag
summary: Orchard Towers' collective sale committee has recommended a reserve price of S$1.6 billion, potentially making it Singapore's most expensive collective sale. The unit owners will vote on the proposed reserve price at an extraordinary general meeting on Feb 18. To proceed, at least 80% of owners must consent, a challenge given the mixed-use development's diverse space types. If successful, the sale could eclipse the S$1.34 billion fetched by Farrer Court in 2007.

images.alt_text: Completed in the early 1970s, Orchard Towers has a plot ratio of 4.9 and a site area of about 6,130 square metres. The mixed-use freehold development spans 2 buildings.

site_title: Carlyle buys iStar's net-lease business for US$3b
summary: Carlyle Group's global credit unit has agreed to acquire iStar's net-lease business for approximately $3 billion. The acquisition will provide Carlyle with a portfolio of triple-net leases, including industrial, office, and entertainment properties in the US. The deal is part of Carlyle's expansion in real estate and aims to grow its net-lease strategy into a $10 billion business. Key personnel from iStar's net-lease team will join Carlyle's real estate credit team, marking a significant expansion of Carlyle's global credit business. The transaction is expected to close in the first quarter of this year.

site_title: Snapchat parent shares soar on first quarterly profit
summary: Snapchat's parent company, Snap, reported its first-ever quarterly profit, with shares soaring 59% on earnings that beat expectations. The company posted a net income of $22.5 million in the final quarter of 2021, ending the year with a loss of $488 million. Revenue increased 42% to $1.3 billion, driven by strong ad revenue growth. Despite supply chain woes and changes to iPhone operating software, Snap's core business allowed it to invest in augmented reality and maintain a strong daily active user base of 319 million.

images.alt_text: Shares in Snap soared on Thursday after the firm behind image-centric, ephemeral messaging app Snapchat reported its first-ever quarter profit.

site_title: Abolishing the motherhood penalty
summary: Singapore is taking steps to address the "motherhood penalty," a pay differential of 13-18% between men and women in their 30s and 40s. The issue of workplace discrimination and caregiving duties at home is being examined. The country aims to promote gender equality and support working mothers.

site_title: No Signboard receives letters of demand from landlords
summary: No Signboard, a restaurant operator, received letters of demand from landlords of 2 outlets for over S$176,000 in arrears. The group believes these claims will have a material adverse impact on its financial position and performance. Landlords have threatened legal action if payment is not made.

site_title: Biden says Islamic State leader Qurayshi killed in US raid in Syria
summary: US President Joe Biden announced that Islamic State leader Abu Ibrahim al-Hashimi al-Qurayshi was killed in a US counter-terrorism operation in northwest Syria on Wednesday night. According to a senior US official, Qurayshi detonated a bomb that killed himself and family members, including women and children, at the start of the operation. The operation was carried out at Biden's direction to protect the American people and make the world a safer place.

site_title: Controversial Beijing Olympics 'will change winter sports': IOC chief
summary: IOC President Thomas Bach stated that the Beijing Winter Olympics will "change the scale of winter sports forever" despite concerns over human rights, Covid-19, and surveillance. The Games, which launched on Feb 4, feature artificially made snow and rely on a "closed loop" bubble to control the coronavirus. China hopes the Olympics will be a soft-power success and inspire 300 million people to engage in winter sports. The Games have been marred by diplomatic boycotts, concerns for tennis player Peng Shuai's safety, and environmental impact, but Bach believes everything is in place for a safe and successful event.

site_title: SICCI urges 'selective' application of GST hike to ease strain on businesses
summary: The Singapore Indian Chamber of Commerce and Industry (SICCI) has urged the government to apply the 2 percentage point Goods and Services Tax (GST) hike "selectively" to ease strain on businesses, particularly small and medium-sized enterprises. The chamber also recommended measures to address labor shortages, such as relaxing entry rules for workers and developing flexible employment schemes. Additionally, SICCI suggested tax holidays for companies building eldercare facilities and a surcharge on income taxes for high-income earners.

site_title: Higher energy prices drive ConocoPhillips' quarterly profit
summary: ConocoPhillips reported a higher-than-estimated quarterly profit driven by sharply higher oil and gas prices. The company's production rose to 1.6 million barrels of oil equivalent per day, up 423,000 boepd from last year. ConocoPhillips also increased its plan for shareholder returns by $1 billion, benefiting from global travel restrictions easing and tight supplies. The company's earnings lifted as crude oil prices reached 7-year highs.

site_title: American Dream 'super mall' drains reserves to pay municipal bonds
summary: The US$5 billion American Dream super mall in New Jersey has drained a reserve fund to pay a $9.3 million municipal bond payment, leaving $820 in the reserve account. The mall's struggles to attract shoppers and tenants, exacerbated by the pandemic, have led to concerns about its ability to make future payments. The developer, Triple Five Group, has hired legal and financial advisers to cope with the mall's $3 billion debt load, and a letter from the bond servicer, Trimont Real Estate Advisors, has threatened to take remedies for non-compliance with project costs and performance obligations.

site_title: Sunak reveals £9b package to offset energy crunch
summary: UK Chancellor Rishi Sunak announced a £9 billion package to offset record energy bill increases for 22 million households, with a £693 price cap rise expected to add £350 to bills. The package includes a £200 upfront electricity discount and a £150 council tax rebate for 80% of homes in England. The measures aim to help households manage the cost-of-living crisis amid a 54% price cap rise on domestic gas and power bills.

site_title: US factory orders fall in December; shipments rise further
summary: US factory orders fell 0.4% in December, slightly more than expected, but manufacturing remains supported by businesses rebuilding inventories. Inventory investment surged 17.3% in the fourth quarter, with sales-to-inventory ratios remaining low. Shipments of manufactured goods rose 0.4% and unfilled orders increased 0.5%. The decline in orders was driven by decreases in computers, electronic products, and transportation equipment, while machinery, primary metals, and electrical equipment saw increases.

site_title: Stronger economic outlook to support continued loans growth for Malaysia banks: UOBKH
summary: Malaysia's banks are expected to maintain strong loan growth momentum in 2022, with UOB Kay Hian analyst Keith Wee predicting a 5% system loans growth rate. This follows a 4.5% growth rate in December 2021, driven by strong growth in household and business segments. Wee also expects net interest margins to expand by 1-2 basis points due to rising interest rates, supporting double-digit earnings growth and 5% average dividend yields over the next two years.

images.alt_text: Jennifer Wu, BlackRock, Director of Sustainable Investing.

site_title: 932 Covid-19 cases in hospital on Thursday, up from 819 the day before
summary: Singapore reported 932 Covid-19 cases in hospital on Feb 3, up from 819 the previous day. Of these, 78 required oxygen support and 16 were in the ICU, with one death. The country also reported 4,087 community cases, with 2,730 identified through antigen rapid tests and 210 imported cases. The weekly infection growth rate stood at 1.23, down from 1.41 the previous day. The total number of Covid-19 cases in Singapore now stands at 366,473, with 860 deaths.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares snap 4-day winning run as Sony, Panasonic drag
summary: Japanese shares snapped a 4-day winning streak on Thursday, falling 1.06% to 27,241.31 due to weaker Nasdaq futures and tech stocks amid worries over Sony's gaming business and Panasonic's quarterly profit. Shares of Sony Group fell 6.08% and Panasonic lost 6.86%. Other technology heavyweights also declined, while NTT gained 1.68% after a report showed its operating profit would rise 3% to about 1.55 trillion yen.

site_title: Shell boosts buybacks as profit soars on high oil, gas prices
summary: Shell reported a profit of $6.39 billion in the fourth quarter, beating analyst estimates, driven by surging energy prices. The company announced an $8.5 billion share buyback program, its first European oil major to do so. This follows Chevron's disappointing results and Exxon Mobil's decision to accelerate buybacks. Shell's share price has seen its biggest annual gain in five years, despite a 50% reduction in cash flow from operations. CEO Ben van Beurden attributed the financial strength to the company's transformation efforts.

site_title: World food prices are climbing closer towards a record high
summary: Global food prices rose 1.1% in January, nearing a record high, due to expensive vegetable oils and dairy. The UN's food index is edging closer to its 2011 peak, driven by unfavourable weather and the energy crisis. This increase may further strain household budgets, particularly for the poorest consumers and nations with limited disposable income. Crop supplies face risks from bad weather and geopolitical tensions, which may lead to cutbacks on farm inputs and increased reliance on crop imports.

site_title: Inflation risks tilted to upside, ECB's Lagarde says
summary: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde acknowledged that euro zone inflation is running hotter than expected, with risks tilted to the upside, but still forecasts it to ease through 2022. Inflation is likely to remain elevated for longer than expected, but decline in the course of this year. The ECB has chosen not to repeat its past comment that a rate hike this year is very unlikely, instead emphasizing the need for gradual determination.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims decline further; productivity rebounds in Q4
summary: US jobless claims declined further, falling 23,000 to 238,000 for the week ended January 29, as Covid-19 infections subsided. This marks the second straight weekly decline, partially unwinding the recent surge in initial claims. Economists expect job growth to reaccelerate, with the unemployment rate forecast to remain at 3.9%. Productivity rebounded at a 6.6% annualized rate in Q4, after falling at a 5.0% rate in the third quarter.

site_title: New Zealand to reopen in phases, all travellers must still self-isolate
summary: New Zealand announced a phased reopening of its border, allowing vaccinated New Zealanders in Australia to return home without isolation from Feb 27, and citizens worldwide from March 3. The move aims to revive the struggling tourism sector. However, the travel and airline industry expressed concerns that more measures were needed. The phased reopening is part of New Zealand's efforts to gradually lift COVID-19 restrictions after nearly two years of closure.

site_title: Clues to next variant are all around us
summary: Scientists in South Africa and Botswana discovered the Omicron variant in November 2021, but it was too late to stop its global spread. To detect the next variant early, researchers monitor patterns in case counts and sequence virus samples from infected people, sharing data globally. However, the analysis process is time-consuming and often too slow, allowing variants to spread before being detected. This highlights the need for a more efficient and coordinated global approach to tracking and sharing coronavirus variant data.

site_title: Zuckerberg's wealth plunges by US$31b after Meta shock
summary: Mark Zuckerberg's wealth dropped by $31 billion after Meta Platforms' fourth-quarter results fell short of analysts' expectations. The company's shares tumbled 24% due to a lack of growth in monthly Facebook users. As a result, Zuckerberg's net worth decreased to $92 billion, pushing him outside the top 10 wealthiest people in the world for the first time since 2015. Meta's historic stock collapse raises concerns about the company's future growth.

images.alt_text: Meta's steep decline leaves Zuckerberg, the company's chief executive officer, with a net worth of about US$92 billion, down from US$120.6 billion.

site_title: US: Wall St drops at open as Facebook outlook sparks tech rout
summary: US stock indexes fell at the open on Thursday, with the Nasdaq plummeting 2% due to Facebook-owner Meta Platforms' negative forecast, threatening a nascent tech sector recovery. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 0.31% and the S&P 500 fell 1.18%. The Nasdaq Composite fell 2.58% to 14,045.834.

site_title: Facebook parent Meta opens 24% lower after weak earnings
summary: Meta's parent company, Facebook, plummeted 25.6% after reporting weaker-than-expected profits due to a loss of one million daily users on its platform. The tech giant's market value dropped by roughly $200 billion, affecting the Nasdaq and threatening a four-day winning streak. The sell-off follows a similar liquidation of Netflix shares last month and contrasts with other tech giants like Apple and Alphabet, which have rallied after their results.

site_title: UOBKH adds Aztech, Thai Beverage to February alpha picks
summary: UOB Kay Hian (UOBKH) has added Aztech Global and Thai Beverage to its February alpha picks, citing strong order books and intact operations for Aztech and potential benefits from Thailand's tourism revival and boost to consumption for ThaiBev. The brokerage has also removed ComfortDelGro and Uni-Asia from its picks due to lack of near-term catalysts. Aztech's share price rose 1.8% after the addition, while ThaiBev's shares closed flat.

site_title: Indonesia uncovers nearly 8.47t rupiah in first month of tax amnesty
summary: Indonesia's second tax amnesty programme, launched in January, has collected nearly $600 million in unreported assets in its first month, according to official data. The six-month programme allows participants to declare unreported assets acquired between 2016-2020, with authorities taxing declared assets at 6-18%. The government hopes to improve compliance, but analysts warn against repeating such programmes too often, citing the need for sustained efforts beyond amnesties.

site_title: BoE agrees to second rate hike in a row as inflation soars
summary: The Bank of England (BoE) raised its main interest rate for the second time in a row, aiming to combat decades-high inflation, which is expected to peak at 7.25% in April. The rate was increased by a quarter point to 0.5%, with policymakers divided on the size of the increase. The move aims to curb domestic cost and price pressures, as the UK's inflation rate is forecast to remain higher than the target of 2%.

site_title: ECB sticks to gradual stimulus exit as bets on hikes build
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) reaffirmed its plan to withdraw pandemic stimulus gradually, despite a record inflation reading and market expectations for a first interest-rate hike in over a decade. The ECB kept rates unchanged, but signaled that it will slow bond-buying and end asset purchases before raising borrowing costs. The decision underscores the divergence with the US and UK's more aggressive monetary policy tightening and suggests that elevated inflation is not yet abating.

site_title: First Ship Lease Trust turns a profit of US$88,000 in Q4, FY2021 DPU up 16.7%
summary: First Ship Lease Trust reported a net profit of US$88,000 in Q4 FY2021, a significant improvement from a net loss of US$2.2 million in the same quarter last year. Revenue fell 27.7% year-over-year to US$4.9 million. The trust's DPU increased 16.7% to 3.5 US cents. The manager attributed the improvement to the majority of vessels operating under fixed-rate period charters and low leverage of its fleet. However, the company remains cautious about the near-term tanker market environment due to the ongoing pandemic.

site_title: Budget to extend support to ailing sectors, will tackle cost of living: Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore's upcoming Budget will provide more support to struggling sectors, while also tackling the cost of living. Finance Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the need for measures that will position the country stronger in the post-pandemic world, addressing economic and geopolitical challenges. Policymakers aim to balance support for ailing industries with the looming uncertainties of the post-pandemic era.

site_title: Omicron sub-variant BA.2 harder to identify, found in 5 African nations: WHO
summary: The World Health Organization has confirmed the presence of the Omicron sub-variant BA.2 in five African countries, including Botswana, Kenya, Malawi, Senegal, and South Africa. The variant is harder to identify due to a "stealth" characteristic, making it challenging to distinguish from other variants. Despite this, data from Denmark suggests no difference in disease severity. The WHO is working closely with laboratories to gain a more precise picture of the spread of BA.2.

site_title: Saudi wealth fund reveals latest video game bet with Nexon stake
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund (PIF) has taken a 5.02% stake in Nexon, a Japanese gaming company behind popular titles like MapleStory and Dungeon&Fighter, for about US$883 million. The investment is a pure bet, with no further details on the expected return or strategic partnership. This move comes after the PIF turned around its investment in Activision Blizzard with a face-saving deal.

site_title: Meta set for US$200b wipeout, among worst in market history
summary: Meta Platforms is set to experience a US$200 billion market value wipeout, one of the largest one-day losses in market history, following its disappointing Q1 forecast that missed estimates. Shares dropped 22% in pre-market trading amid stagnant user growth and increasing competition from TikTok. The tech-heavy Nasdaq 100 Index is also expected to decline, putting pressure on other social media peers and dragging down Nasdaq 100 Index futures.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's government plans to extend support to ailing sectors such as aviation and tourism, and aid individuals to manage the cost of living. The Singaporean government also approved its first oral tablet to treat Covid-19 infection. The Straits Times Index surged 2.04% to a 30-month high, reaching 3,315.99 points, due to an upbeat Wall Street performance. Additionally, Ascott acquired a US student accommodation asset and Singtel partnered with Gulf Energy and AIS to build data centers in Thailand.

site_title: China smartphone demand helps lift forecasts for chipmaker Qualcomm
summary: Qualcomm posted record first-quarter revenue, beating Wall Street forecasts, driven by strong growth in the Android business and demand from Chinese handset makers. The company forecast second-quarter revenue between $10.2 billion and $11 billion, above analysts' estimates. Handset revenues rose 42% year-over-year, with Snapdragon chipsets for Android devices driving growth. Despite a 3% decline in shares after the earnings call, Qualcomm expects strong year-over-year growth rates in the second half of 2022.

site_title: Asia's 4 tigers have matured, but still burning bright
summary: Asia's 4 original tiger economies, South Korea, Taiwan, Singapore, and Hong Kong, continue to hold their own in the global market despite being surpassed by China. Strategists suggest investors consider them carefully when screening for opportunities, citing their unique strengths and lower valuations compared to the US. The economies face challenges from ageing populations, automation, and rising costs, but have carved out niches in manufacturing, finance, and technology. Despite these challenges, investors see potential in sectors like digital technologies, chip production, and sustainable investments, with Singapore emerging as a strong destination for high-net-worth individuals and family offices.

site_title: US job market faces reshuffling as workers quit at near record rates
summary: The US job market is experiencing a significant shift as workers quit their jobs at near-record rates, averaging nearly 4 million monthly departures last year. Despite near-historically high job openings, there aren't enough workers to fill all positions, leading to a mismatch. This trend, dubbed the "Great Resignation," is being characterized by a great reshuffling as workers take advantage of the tight labor market to move to jobs with better pay, flexibility, or new opportunities, rather than a mass exodus.

site_title: IOC members fume over plans for biennial soccer World Cup
summary: International Olympic Committee (IOC) members expressed frustration over FIFA's plan to hold a biennial soccer World Cup, citing a major negative impact on other sports. The proposal, which would generate an extra $4.4 billion in revenues, has been met with opposition from the IOC, international sports federations, and other organizations, including UEFA and CONMEBOL. A biennial World Cup would clash with the Summer Olympics and dent the Games' commercial appeal, potentially overshadowing other competitions.

site_title: Tesla recalls 817,000 US vehicles over seat belt alert
summary: Tesla is recalling 817,000 US vehicles due to a seat belt alert issue, where the audible chime may not activate when the driver hasn't buckled up. The affected vehicles include 2021-2022 Model S and Model X, 2017-2022 Model 3, and 2020-2022 Model Y. An over-the-air software update will address the issue. As of January 31, Tesla reported no crashes or injuries related to the issue.

site_title: The best wineglass for any occasion
summary: A wine enthusiast has been testing 5 high-end wineglasses, including the Zalto Denk'Art Universal, to determine the best for various occasions. The author notes the Zalto Denk'Art Universal remains a top choice among wine lovers, offering a unique and superior experience.

site_title: Singapore PMI dips in the new year, echoing slowdown seen across Asia
summary: Singapore's manufacturing sector experienced a slight dip in January, with the Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) easing to 50.6, down 0.1 point from the previous month. Despite this, the sector has expanded for 19 consecutive months. Uncertainties over supply chain disruptions due to new Covid-19 variants and geopolitical developments have led to slower expansion rates in key indexes. The sector remains cautiously optimistic about growth in the new year, with some areas of concern including declining imports and rising finished goods stock.

site_title: Europe: Stocks diverge before rate calls
summary: European stocks diverged slightly at the open on Thursday, with investors waiting for interest rate announcements from the European Central Bank and Bank of England. London's FTSE 100 rose 0.1%, while the eurozone's DAX and Paris CAC 40 fell 0.3% and 0.2% respectively. Strong earnings from Shell and other companies also influenced the market.

site_title: Maersk container ship runs aground off German island
summary: A Maersk container ship, the Mumbai Maersk, ran aground off the German island of Wangerooge in the North Sea on Wednesday evening. No injuries or fuel leaks were reported, and the ship's crew and cargo details are not available. Two attempts to tow the 400-metre ship into deeper water have failed, with a second attempt scheduled once the tide rises. An investigation into the incident is ongoing, but no cause has been determined yet. The ship was en route from Rotterdam to Bremerhaven when it ran aground.

site_title: Banks face surge in equal-pay claims after landmark BNP ruling
summary: BNP Paribas was ordered by a UK employment tribunal to conduct a pay audit after a London court ruled in favor of Stacey Macken, who was awarded £2 million for being paid less than her male colleague. The tribunal found that the bank's "opaque" pay structures did not address potential pay disparities. The ruling may encourage other women to come forward with equal-pay claims, and the bank plans to retain the current pay structures despite the order. The pay gap in the UK finance industry remains significant, with men earning 25% more than women in 2020.

site_title: Iraq struggles to make use of Saddam's crumbling palaces
summary: Iraq struggles to utilize over 100 opulent palaces and villas built by former dictator Saddam Hussein, many of which are in ruins. The palaces, featuring marble columns and ornate carvings, reflect Saddam's megalomania and grandeur. Despite some being used, others remain abandoned, a symbol of the war-scarred country's challenges in preserving its cultural heritage. Authorities face difficulties in maintaining and restoring the palaces, highlighting the ongoing struggle to revitalize Iraq's historic sites.

site_title: Singapore approves its first oral tablet to treat Covid-19 infection
summary: Singapore's Health Sciences Authority (HSA) has granted interim authorisation for Pfizer's Paxlovid, the first oral tablet approved in the country to treat mild to moderate Covid-19 in high-risk adult patients. Paxlovid, a combination of nirmatrelvir and ritonavir, reduces the risk of hospitalisation and death by 88.9% when given within 3 days of symptoms, and 87.8% when given within 5 days. The treatment will be prescribed and prioritised by the Ministry of Health for those at higher risk of severe Covid-19 illness.

site_title: US IPO slowdown slams door on tech unicorns looking to cash out
summary: US technology start-ups are experiencing a slowdown in initial public offerings (IPOs) due to volatile stock markets. Since the beginning of the year, the S&P 500 index has dropped 6% and the Cboe Volatility Index has risen 75%, leading companies to cancel or postpone IPOs. The average share price of 396 companies that went public in 2021 is down 28% from their flotation price. Experts predict fewer deals will be launched this year, with companies opting for direct listings instead. However, the IPO pipeline remains healthy, and some technology unicorns are still planning to go public in the second half of the year.

site_title: Nippon Steel to seek more merger chances to boost global output
summary: Japan's top steelmaker Nippon Steel plans to explore more merger and acquisition opportunities to increase global output capacity to 100 million tonnes. The company recently acquired two Thai steelmakers, and expects overseas steel markets to recover post-Chinese Lunar New Year and Beijing Winter Olympics, driven by higher raw material prices and economic stimulus. Nippon Steel aims to capitalize on the expected market recovery to boost its global output.

site_title: Genting Hong Kong's Dream Cruises files to wind up
summary: Dream Cruises, a subsidiary of Genting Hong Kong, has filed for a winding-up application with the Bermuda Courts. The move comes after the insolvency of Genting Hong Kong's German shipbuilding subsidiary and follows a suspension of bookings by Dream Cruises. The company is seeking to appoint joint provisional liquidators to develop a restructuring proposal and maintain the value of its core assets. Genting Hong Kong reported a record loss of US$1.7 billion in 2020, and the company's parent company is also facing financial challenges due to the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: Upbeat Wall Street sends STI to 30-month high at 3,315.99 points
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) surged to a 30-month high of 3,315.99 points on February 3, driven by Wall Street's fourth straight day gains. The STI rose 2.04% to close at 3,315.99 points, beating gains in most sectors. Brent crude oil fell below US$90 per barrel, and expectations for interest rate hikes at the Federal Reserve meeting turned less hawkish, contributing to the market's positivity. Gainers beat decliners 256 to 116, with H78's share price surging 5.56% to US$5.70.

site_title: Danske sees rising 2022 profit on cost cuts, higher activity
summary: Danske Bank A/S has forecast a higher 2022 profit than analysts' expectations, with net income ranging from 13 billion kroner to 15 billion kroner. The bank attributed the rise to good economic activity and cost cuts. Despite facing penalties for its role in a major money laundering scandal, Danske aims to return 40-60% of net profit to shareholders, with a dividend payout of 7.5 kroner per share. The bank reported a core Tier 1 capital ratio of 17.7% at year-end, down from 18.3% the previous year.

site_title: BT in exclusive talks with Discovery on sport TV joint-venture
summary: BT Group has entered exclusive talks with Discovery to create a 50:50 joint venture between BT Sport and Eurosport, a pan-European TV network. The deal avoids an outright sale to streaming service DAZN, which also made an offer. The joint venture will retain BT Sport's major sport broadcast rights, including Premier League soccer, and will feature a range of Olympic and other sports events. BT expects adjusted revenue for the year to be down around 2% due to Covid-19 and supply chain issues.

site_title: UAE wealth funds behind US$10b investment push in Israel
summary: UAE wealth funds, including Mubadala Investment and ADQ, have discussed investing up to $10 billion in Israel over the next decade, according to three people familiar with the talks. The funds, which include Abu Dhabi Investment Authority, are looking to expand into Israel to advance investments in local venture capital firms, businesses, and public projects. This would be the largest cash commitment since the UAE and Israel normalized ties in 2020, driven by shared concerns over Iran's nuclear program. The talks are in early stages, with ADQ planning to invest around $2 billion through its Abu Dhabi Growth Fund.

site_title: Flower power at Marguerite
summary: Chef Michael Wilson brings new life to the old Pollen premises with fine-dining Marguerite, a second-floor casual cafe Hortus, and a gelato cafe, all under the Flower Dome. The menu features clever layering of flavors, with standout dishes including smoked eel with horseradish ice cream and caviar, watermelon ravioli, and roast duck with crisp crackling skin. While the meal is enjoyable, the reviewer feels that Wilson should push the envelope more to reach his full potential. The restaurant is open for lunch and dinner from Friday to Sunday and dinner only on Wednesdays and Thursdays.

site_title: Glencore moves into lithium recycling in deal with Britishvolt
summary: Glencore, a metals giant, has agreed to build a lithium-ion battery recycling plant in the UK as part of a deal with Britishvolt. The plant, expected to process 10,000 tons of lithium-ion batteries annually, will support Britishvolt's plans to develop Britain's first large-scale electric vehicle battery plant. The move aims to address supply chain constraints driven by surging electric vehicle sales and rising battery metal prices. The facility is set to come online by mid-2023, ahead of Britishvolt's planned plant opening later in the year.

site_title: Buying art in designer-led spaces
summary: Interior designer Patricia Ho Douven has created a space at her White Jacket studio to showcase works of local artists, dubbed "very much a tribute to Singapore artists". The studio, which doubles as an art gallery, features works by local artists such as Aeropalmics and Lush Tan, and hosts two exhibitions: WJ x NAFA Showcase and A Decade, celebrating the firm's 10th anniversary. The studio also plans to introduce an artist-in-residency program and has partnered with boutique hospitality firm Figment to showcase local artists' works in conservation shophouses.

site_title: DeFi project Wormhole hit with potential US$320m hack
summary: A hack on the DeFi project Wormhole has stolen approximately $320 million in cryptocurrency, with 120,000 wETH tokens stolen. The vulnerability has been patched, and the project's team is working to add Ether to back the stolen tokens. The hack is considered one of the largest thefts from a DeFi protocol, highlighting security concerns in the industry. Wormhole's developers have offered a $10 million bug bounty for exploit details and the return of the funds.

site_title: Raskin signals she won't target energy industry in Fed role
summary: US Federal Reserve nominee Sarah Bloom Raskin signals she won't target specific industries in her role as vice-chairman for supervision, saying bank regulators should focus on big-picture risks and avoid "short-term political agendas". Raskin's past remarks on climate change have drawn Republican opposition, but she aims to address this criticism in her prepared testimony. The Senate is set to question her on her positions on climate change, cryptocurrencies, and bank mergers before she can clear confirmation and take on the role.

site_title: Bank of Japan deputy governor Wakatabe says premature to tighten monetary policy now
summary: Bank of Japan Deputy Governor Masazumi Wakatabe stated it's premature to tighten monetary policy as the economy hasn't fully recovered from the pandemic. He warned that consumer inflation may accelerate to 1% in coming months, but emphasized the need to maintain the massive stimulus program until inflation expectations reach the 2% target. Wakatabe also noted that the BOJ would only consider tightening policy if wages and inflation expectations rise, triggering a second-round effect and pushing inflation above the target.

site_title: Singtel to build data centres in Thailand with Gulf Energy, AIS
summary: Singtel has signed a joint development agreement with Gulf Energy and AIS to build and operate data centers in Thailand. The collaboration aims to capitalize on Thailand's strong growth potential of digital infrastructure. Site selection has commenced, and developments are expected to begin in the coming months. The partnership brings together Singtel's telecommunications expertise, Gulf Energy's energy leadership, and AIS's local data center operations know-how to strengthen and accelerate plans for the data centers.

site_title: Westpac hires Fannie Mae's Zanin as risk officer, cuts jobs
summary: Westpac Banking has appointed Ryan Zanin as its new chief risk officer, replacing David Stephen and Les Vance, as part of a risk transformation effort. Zanin joins from Fannie Mae, bringing extensive risk management experience. The bank has also reduced its headcount by over 1,100 people, with cash earnings reaching A$1.58 billion for the first quarter. Westpac expects a decline in net interest margin through 2022, but shares have climbed 2.2% following the announcement.

site_title: Nintendo cuts Switch outlook again on supply, logistics jam
summary: Nintendo has cut its Switch sales outlook for the second quarter in a row due to a chronic chip shortage, with the company now expecting to sell 23 million units in the fiscal year ending March, down from 24 million. Despite the challenges, Nintendo reported strong operating profit of 252.6 billion yen, driven by software sales and a fast-selling Pokémon entry. Console makers continue to struggle with semiconductors, and Nintendo's president Shuntaro Furukawa reiterated that the company will not change its investment policy, but may consider acquisitions if necessary.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks jump the most in over 2 months on strong data
summary: South Korean shares jumped 1.67% to a 2-month high, driven by data showing the country's factory activity grew at the sharpest pace in 6 months. The benchmark Kospi index rose 44.52 points to 2,707.86. Technology giants SK Hynix and LG Chem led the gains, with SK Hynix rising 2.9% and LG Chem climbing 5.95%. The Korean won weakened, while the benchmark bond yield fell.

site_title: Asia: Stocks mixed as profit-taking, tech woes offset catch-up play
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Thursday as profit-taking and tech woes offset catch-up play. The tech sector, including Meta and Netflix, reported disappointing earnings, fueling worries about the sector. The US market provided a lead, but the positivity was short-lived. Asian markets, except Singapore and Seoul, fell, while US futures turned lower. The Federal Reserve's interest rate hike plans remain uncertain, with officials trying to soothe concerns about a hard approach. The week's weak economic data, including private jobs data, has made interpretation of the US labor market difficult.

site_title: Sony shares slide as gaming concerns re-emerge
summary: Sony shares plummeted 8.8% in early trade after 4 consecutive days of gains, citing concerns over its gaming business amid component shortages and competition from rivals. Despite reporting a third-quarter profit smash and a gaming unit profit rise, Sony's struggles to produce enough PS5 units to meet demand and potential pressure to offer games on Game Pass services weigh on investors. The company aims to double first-party gaming revenues and launch at least 10 live service titles, but analysts warn divisional profitability will come under pressure.

site_title: India's services growth at six-month low in Jan, input costs at decade high
summary: India's services sector expanded at its slowest pace in six months in January, with a growth rate of 51.5, down from 55.5 in December. The slowdown was attributed to restrictions due to a new wave of Covid-19 cases and surging prices. This marks the first time the services sector has contracted below 50 since the pandemic began. The decline in growth is a concern for policymakers, who may need to take steps to boost demand and stimulate economic growth.

site_title: Bank of England poised to act under new inflation strain
summary: The Bank of England is set to raise interest rates to 0.5% from 0.25% to curb surging inflation, marking the first back-to-back borrowing cost increases since 2004. This move signals further unwinding of its pandemic stimulus, including a gradual reversal of its bond-buying plan. The decision aims to demonstrate the central bank's ability to address an inflationary surge, reflecting pressure from economists and policymakers.

site_title: Britons face record energy bill surge, forcing government to act
summary: The UK government is set to announce measures to ease the burden of record energy bill increases, which are expected to surge by 50% to an average of £1,924 per year. The energy regulator Ofgem's decision is expected to cost consumers £18 billion more, prompting Prime Minister Boris Johnson's government to roll out a multi-billion pound package. State-backed loans to energy providers and interest rate hikes by the Bank of England are among the measures expected to be announced.

site_title: Japan's service sector shrinks at fastest pace in five months: PMI
summary: Japan's services sector contracted at its fastest pace in five months in January, according to the au Jibun Bank Japan Services Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI). The sector's activity declined to 47.6, driven by a surge in new coronavirus infections due to the Omicron variant. This contraction was the fastest since August, with staffing levels cut and business optimism at a five-month low. The private sector also saw increased cost burdens, with input price growth remaining elevated. The decline contributed to a broad stagnation in private sector output in January.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.65 points, or 0.24%, to 1,515.92 on Thursday, driven by a higher volume of 90.29 million lots worth RM45.71 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 168 to 81.

site_title: Brokers' take: RHB lowers CAO target price to S$1.09 on profit warning
summary: RHB Securities lowered its target price on China Aviation Oil (Singapore) Corporation (CAO) to S$1.09 following the company's profit warning of a 26% decline in FY2021 profit before tax. Analyst Shekhar Jaiswal also reduced earnings estimates by 3-11% for FY2021 to FY2023. The analyst attributes this to lower earnings from Shanghai Pudong International Airport Aviation Fuel Supply Company and expects oil prices to remain high due to geopolitical tensions. Despite this, Jaiswal maintains a "buy" call on CAO, citing a compelling valuation and gradual profit growth over the next two years.

site_title: Brokers' take: Maybank Securities positive on semicon equipment makers, sees 'robust' outlook for industry
summary: Maybank Securities remains positive on semiconductor equipment makers, citing "attractive" valuations and "robust" fundamentals. Analyst Gene Lih Lai expects strong earnings growth and cash flows, despite a sector sell-off due to rate-hike fears. The brokerage's preferred picks include AEM Holdings, UMS Holdings, Frencken Group, and Aztech Global, with shares trading at 7-12 times estimated FY2022 earnings. Industry estimates affirm the view that fundamentals remain positive, with companies like TSMC and Lam Research increasing capital expenditure budgets. Lai sees room for AEM and UMS to provide positive earnings surprises in Q4 FY2021-2022.

site_title: Australia: Shares end lower after tech rout; Westpac outperforms
summary: Australian shares ended 0.1% lower at 7,078, as technology stocks plummeted 5.9% due to inflationary risks and rising interest rates. Westpac rose 2.3% after beating quarterly profit estimates, while mining stocks rose 1.6% due to strong copper and gold prices. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.4% as Air New Zealand climbed 3.3% after the country floated plans to reopen its borders.

site_title: Sydney Airport shareholders set to approve A$23.6b takeover
summary: Sydney Airport shareholders are set to approve a $23.6 billion takeover by infrastructure investors, backed by 96% of proxy votes. However, 20.4% of shareholders opposed the deal, citing concerns over not being able to remain invested in the company long-term. The deal, which will see UniSuper fold its 15% stake into the unlisted company, is a long-term bet on the travel sector. An independent expert deemed the deal "fair and reasonable" amidst revenue uncertainty due to the pandemic.

site_title: Singapore stocks open higher on Thursday; STI up 1.8%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 1.8% or 59.88 points to 3,309.47 at 9:04 am on Thursday, driven by gains on Wall Street. Local banks DBS, UOB, and OCBC also saw early gains. Meanwhile, Singtel inked a joint development agreement with Gulf Energy and Advanced Info Services to develop data centers in Thailand. The US market closed higher, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average up 0.6% and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes advancing 0.9% and 0.5%, respectively.

site_title: SpaceX rocket successfully launches US spy satellite
summary: US intelligence agency National Reconnaissance Office (NRO) successfully launched its newest spy satellite, NROL-87, into orbit atop a reusable SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket from Vandenberg Air Force base in California. The rocket successfully landed back at the base after releasing the satellite, marking the third time the NRO has used a Falcon 9 rocket. NROL-87 will provide timely intelligence information, supporting the agency's overhead reconnaissance mission.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower as Ukraine crisis worries investors
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Thursday, with the Nikkei 225 index dropping 0.88% or 242.42 points at 27,291.18, amid growing investor worries over the intensifying crisis in Ukraine. The broader Topix index fell 0.47% or 9.19 points at 1,927.37.

site_title: Gold holds above US$1,800 on weaker yields as job data disappoints
summary: Gold prices remained steady above $1,800 per ounce on Thursday, influenced by weaker US Treasury yields following a disappointing private payrolls report. The data showed a decline in US jobs for the first time in a year, casting uncertainty on the pace of monetary policy tightening. With interest rate hikes, the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion increases, affecting investor sentiment. The US and Canada are set to discuss potential military responses to Russia's troop buildup near Ukraine.

site_title: Federal Reserve nominee Cook says tackling inflation is the most important task
summary: US Federal Reserve nominee Lisa Cook stated that tackling high inflation is the central bank's most important task, a sentiment shared by Chair Powell. Cook, an economics professor at Michigan State University, would be the first Black woman to serve on the governing body of the US central bank if confirmed. Her testimony before the Senate Banking Committee comes as the US economy faces inflationary pressures.

site_title: Bob Marley's daughter and grandson open London exhibition on reggae star
summary: Bob Marley's daughter, Cedella, and grandson, Saiyan, have opened an exhibition, "The One Love Experience," at London's Saatchi Gallery, showcasing memorabilia, photographs, and personal items from the reggae star's life. The 10-week exhibition features items such as handwritten lyrics and shoes worn by Marley in the 1970s. The event aims to capture the spirit of Marley's music and legacy, with interactive elements and a personal connection to Marley's life, including a visit to his 1970s home in Chelsea.

site_title: Brazil hikes key interest rate to double digits
summary: Brazil's central bank raised its benchmark interest rate by 1.5 points to 10.75%, the first time in nearly five years, to combat rampant inflation. The eighth consecutive increase aims to slow the pace of rate cuts and control inflation, which reached 10.06% in 2021. The move has put the brakes on economic growth, which contracted in the second and third quarters of last year. The decision comes ahead of Brazil's presidential election in October, where a weak economy is a major concern for far-right President Jair Bolsonaro.

site_title: Ferrari wants to take its real-world wow factor to the metaverse
summary: Ferrari is expanding into the metaverse with a new department focused on digital services, exploring opportunities in virtual reality, gaming, and social media. CEO Benedetto Vigna aims to leverage new technologies like blockchain and non-fungible tokens to bolster the brand. Ferrari has a history in digital entertainment, including partnerships with games like Fortnite and Out Run. The company's metaverse push is part of a broader effort to speed up its shift toward batteries, led by Vigna's industry background.

site_title: US: Wall Street shrugs off weak jobs data to end higher
summary: US stocks ended higher on Wednesday, capping a four-day winning streak despite weak employment data. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.6%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.9% and 0.5%, respectively. Positive earnings reports, including from Alphabet, boosted the tech sector. Recent comments from Federal Reserve officials calmed concerns about interest rate hikes, and analysts see the market as oversold and due for a rally.

site_title: Dutch probe Tata Steel for 'intentional' pollution
summary: Dutch prosecutors have opened a criminal probe into Tata Steel for "intentional and unlawful" pollution at a plant near Amsterdam, posing a potential risk to public health. The investigation follows charges laid by a lawyer representing over 800 plaintiffs, who accuse the steel giant of causing air, soil, and water pollution. The probe also targets Harsco Metals, which operated on Tata Steel's premises. Tata Steel has agreed to cooperate with the investigation, while the public prosecutor's office says it could lead to prosecutions if the probe finds evidence of wrongdoing.

site_title: Fresh inflation record creates headache for ECB
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) faces a debate on raising interest rates due to record eurozone inflation of 5.1% in January, the highest since 1997. The surge in inflation, driven by supply disruptions and high energy prices, contradicts the ECB's previous stance of "very unlikely" rate hikes in 2022. Market expectations of rate hikes before the end of the year increase pressure on the ECB to reconsider its policy.

site_title: Australia: Shares drop as tech stocks weigh; Westpac jumps
summary: Australian shares fell 0.2% to 7,074.7, weighed down by technology stocks, which dropped 5.3% and lost over 20% for the year. Westpac Banking Corp rose 3.6% after beating earnings estimates and cutting costs. Other losers included gaming company Aristocrat Leisure and healthcare and energy stocks, while mining stocks gained 1% due to rising copper and gold prices. New Zealand's benchmark index rose 0.1%.

site_title: South Korea's Jan factory activity grows at fastest pace in six months: PMI
summary: South Korea's factory activity grew at the fastest pace in six months, with the IHS Markit PMI reaching 52.8 in January, above the 50-point mark for 16 consecutive months. Output volumes rose for the first time in four months, driven by increased new orders, while new export orders expanded to 50.4. However, supply chain disruptions from material shortages and the Omicron variant continued to hinder the recovery, with suppliers' delivery times deteriorating for the 27th month in a row.

site_title: Major airlines urge White House to end Covid-19 international air travel testing rules
summary: Major airlines and travel groups have urged the White House to end Covid-19 pre-departure testing requirements for vaccinated international passengers traveling to the US. The groups claim that testing is a leading factor in the decision not to travel internationally. They argue that the requirement is deterring travel and impacting the US economy. The letter, sent to White House coronavirus response coordinator Jeff Zients, suggests that the US should adopt a more flexible approach to international travel. The change is seen as a way to boost travel demand and stimulate the economy.

site_title: Nestle nears deal for protein powder maker Orgain
summary: Nestle has agreed to acquire a majority stake in Orgain, a protein powder maker, with CEO Andrew Abraham retaining significant minority ownership. The deal, valued at around $2 billion, is part of Nestle's health and wellness portfolio expansion. This is Nestle's latest acquisition under CEO Mark Schneider, who has overseen a series of deals to bolster the company's portfolio. Orgain's products include powders, bars, shakes, and almond milk, and the deal is expected to contribute to Nestle's growth. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

site_title: Ascott buys US student accommodation asset via US$150m joint venture
summary: The Ascott Limited, a unit of CapitaLand Investment, is acquiring a US student accommodation asset in Nebraska through a US$150 million joint venture with Riyad Capital. Ascott will manage the venture and hold a 20% stake, while Riyad Capital will hold the remaining stake. This new venture, Student Accommodation Development Venture (Save), aims to develop student accommodation assets in the US. The joint venture will provide Ascott with a presence in the US market and diversify its portfolio.

site_title: Meta shares plunge 20% as Facebook owner sees slowing growth
summary: Meta Platforms Inc shares plummeted 20% as the social media company missed earnings estimates and forecasted slower revenue growth due to increased competition and Apple's privacy changes. The company reported 2.91 billion monthly active users, with no growth compared to the previous quarter. Meta's total revenue rose to $33.67 billion in the fourth quarter, beating analysts' estimates. The company also announced plans to rebrand as "META" and invest in the metaverse.

site_title: Siemens Gamesa's CEO resigns after run of profit warnings
summary: Siemens Gamesa's CEO Andreas Nauen resigned following project delays, cost overruns, and profit warnings. The company reported a loss of 309 million euros in the first quarter of 2022, citing inflation and volatile markets. Nauen's successor, Jochen Eickholt, will focus on restructuring and fixing issues plaguing the company. Rising commodity costs, pandemic-related disruptions, and scaling difficulties with new turbine models have contributed to Siemens Gamesa's challenges. The company's parent, Siemens Energy, has also been impacted by the issues at its renewable subsidiary.

site_title: Warehouse space is the latest thing being hoarded
summary: US warehouse space is in short supply due to pandemic-fueled growth in online shopping, leading companies to adapt with new storage, distribution, and delivery strategies. Logistics firms are signing long-term deals for new space, expanding searches for inland locations, and reimagining existing warehouses. To cope with the shortage, companies are stockpiling space even if they can't fill it, and exploring alternative options like multi-story warehouses and using vacant storefronts. The shortage is affecting smaller businesses, which are struggling to compete with larger companies for available warehouse space.

site_title: The Fed is too late to remove the punchbowl
summary: The US Federal Reserve is too late to reverse its expansionary monetary policy, which has fueled a strong recovery and soaring inflation. Despite the economy's robust growth, including a full return to pre-pandemic consumption and investment levels, and a rapidly rising labor market, inflation remains a concern. The Fed's policy is still aggressively loose, with ongoing asset purchases and a low interest rate, increasing the risk of an inflationary spiral. Policymakers may struggle to contain inflation without inflicting a recession, and the Fed's forecasts are uncertain, with some predictions suggesting a prolonged period of expansion.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Singtel, CapitaLand Investment, F&N, ThaiBev, Chip Eng Seng
summary: Singaporean stocks to watch include Singtel, which signed a joint development agreement with Gulf Energy and AIS to develop data centers in Thailand. CapitaLand Investment's lodging business acquired a US$150 million student accommodation asset in Nebraska. F&N named Hui Choon Kit as its new CEO, while Edmond Neo stepped down to focus on ThaiBev. Chip Eng Seng's subsidiary entered a JV with Ariva Hospitality to provide management services to hotels and serviced residences.

site_title: Biden plans 'several' stops on Asia trip, region to remain focus: US official
summary: US President Joe Biden plans to visit Asia in the spring, focusing on regional allies Japan, Australia, and India, with a summit in Japan's Quad group. The trip, which could occur in May, aims to counter China's growing power and influence. Biden's administration will prioritize engagement through the Quad, the Association of Southeast Asian Nations, and other regional initiatives. The visit will also involve stops in other countries, with an announcement of "concrete offerings" under an Indo-Pacific Economic Framework initiative expected soon.

site_title: NYT aims for 15 million subscribers or more by end of 2027
summary: The New York Times reported it has surpassed its 10 million-subscription target years ahead of schedule, thanks to the acquisition of The Athletic. CEO Meredith Kopit Levien stated the company now aims for 15 million subscribers by 2027, marking a significant growth milestone. The Times has seen a 23% growth in subscriptions and newspaper sales, and 26% in ad revenue, despite the decline in print edition sales and advertising revenues. The company's diversification efforts, including cooking recipes and games platforms, have contributed to its success.

site_title: Spotify shares tumble on weak profit forecast
summary: Spotify reported a quarterly loss of 39 million euros and forecast lower profit margins for the first quarter of 2022. The company's shares fell 12.7% to US$167.50 in after-hours trading. Despite a strong podcasting platform with increased consumer engagement, Spotify cited a decline in gross profit margin to 25% from 26.5%. The company's shares have fallen steeply over the last year, amid the disruption caused by the Covid-19 pandemic.

site_title: UK, Russian leaders agree on need for peaceful outcome to Ukraine: Downing Street
summary: British Prime Minister Boris Johnson and Russian President Vladimir Putin agreed in a phone call to work towards a "peaceful resolution" of the Ukraine crisis, according to Downing Street. Johnson warned Putin that any Russian invasion would be a "tragic miscalculation" and stressed Ukraine's right to join Nato. The leaders also discussed existing dialogue on climate change, Afghanistan, and the Iran nuclear deal. Britain is preparing to offer Nato a "major" deployment of troops and defensive weapons in Europe amid tensions.

site_title: IMF staff cut critical language on coal from Japan statement: document
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) deleted a critical sentence about Japan's continued financing of high-emissions coal projects from a staff mission statement on the Japanese economy. The sentence, which had been part of a January draft, urged Japan to phase out existing commitments to support coal projects abroad. The change was made in a revised report issued on January 28, which focused on Japan's need to scale back pandemic-relief measures as its economy recovers. The move has been criticized by climate finance experts, who see it as a setback for global efforts to combat climate change.

site_title: Singapore tech companies still flocking Down Under
summary: Singaporean tech companies are increasingly investing in Australia, citing the country's strategic location as a springboard for both Asia and Western markets. Enterprise Singapore's support has been instrumental in facilitating this growth, particularly in the Infocomm & Tech and media sectors. Despite pandemic disruptions, Singaporean companies are finding opportunities in Australia, with the ICT and media sector being one of the top sectors leveraging Enterprise Singapore's support for their first foray into the country.

site_title: Getting a taste of Japan until travel borders open up
summary: At least 5 new Japanese restaurants are set to open in Singapore this month, offering a range of options including destination dining, sushi, tempura, and yakiniku. These new eateries will cater to Japanese food enthusiasts until travel borders open up.

site_title: Euro surges after inflation hits new record high
summary: The euro surged for a third consecutive day, rising 0.3% versus the US dollar, after the eurozone inflation hit a new record high of 5.1% in January, exceeding the European Central Bank's 2% target. Investors expect the ECB to raise interest rates sooner than expected, with the US dollar falling 0.25% against a basket of currencies. The euro's increase is seen as a response to the ECB's potential policy tightening, while US Federal Reserve officials cautioned against aggressive rate increases this year.

site_title: New Zealand to stay closed to foreigners until October
summary: New Zealand's Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern announced a five-step plan to reconnect the country to the world, starting with waiving hotel quarantine requirements for Kiwis stranded overseas, followed by relaxation of border restrictions for New Zealanders, skilled migrants, international students, Australians, and vaccinated foreign nationals. International arrivals will self-isolate for 10 days, replacing the current 10-day monitored quarantine. The plan aims to ease restrictions by October, as New Zealand's high vaccination rate and successful pandemic containment make the move possible.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary: Singapore Government Bonds quotation is available, but no specific details are provided in the given articles. Companies like Creative Technology and OCBC have released financial updates, warning of potential revenue decline and operating losses. Indonesia has detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case. Meanwhile, OCBC's new CEO, Tan Teck Long, will take over after Helen Wong's retirement. MAS and PBOC are set to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance.

site_title: How to disseminate science quickly
summary: The scientific community has made progress in disseminating research quickly while maintaining the quality of science. The use of preprints and the acceptance of preprints by major scholarly journals have increased the speed of publishing. However, dissemination could be improved. The article notes that peer review can be a slow process and may hinder the dissemination of new ideas, particularly in fast-changing fields like medicine. Despite this, the scientific community has managed to balance speed and quality, with most research being released quickly while still undergoing closer scrutiny through peer review.

site_title: Oil edges higher after Opec+ keeps to steady supply bump, US stockpiles draw
summary: Oil prices edged up on Wednesday after Opec+ stuck to planned moderate output increases, despite pressure from top consumers to raise output. Brent crude rose 31 cents to $89.47 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude gained 6 cents to $88.26 a barrel. Despite bullish fundamentals, the market has been unable to push higher due to profit taking at resistance levels near $90. US crude stockpiles fell by 1 million barrels last week, while Opec+ remains committed to its 400,000 barrel per day output increase.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: AC Energy Corp, the listed energy unit of the Philippines' Ayala Group, has agreed to acquire 49% of Solar NT, a solar power platform under Thailand-based Super Energy Corp, for $165 million. Post-restructuring, Solar NT will own and operate 9 solar power plants in Vietnam with a total capacity of 837 MW. This deal is part of efforts to grow renewables footprint across South-east Asia, with ACEN aiming to reach 5,000 MW of renewables capacity by 2025.

site_title: Europe: Shares boosted by strong earnings, reports of M&A
summary: European shares rose for a third consecutive session, driven by strong fourth-quarter earnings and potential mergers and acquisitions. The Stoxx 600 index gained 0.5% as French IT consultancy Atos jumped 8% following reports of a potential bid for its cybersecurity arm. Other sectors, including mining and healthcare, also supported the rally ahead of key central bank decisions on interest rates.

site_title: Amid multi models, the one consensus in tackling Covid: Vaccines work
summary: The article emphasizes the importance of vaccines in combating COVID-19, stating that despite various approaches to managing the pandemic, vaccines have proven to be effective. Critics of government responses should consider the fear and uncertainty of the early days of the pandemic, when medical experts advised drastic measures. The article concludes that there is no single "model" for fighting COVID-19, but vaccination remains the key to saving lives, with areas with low vaccination rates experiencing higher infection and death rates.

site_title: The Fed's climate awakening
summary: The US Senate Banking Committee will hold confirmation hearings for three nominees to the Federal Reserve's board of governors: Sarah Bloom Raskin, Lisa Cook, and Philip Jefferson. The Fed is expected to take a more proactive approach to addressing climate-related financial risks, a concern raised by Fed Chair Jerome Powell. The vice-chair for supervision, a position created in the Dodd-Frank financial reform legislation, will focus on existing risks and potential future threats. Raskin, an experienced regulator, is seen as a key appointment to support Powell on these issues.

site_title: S&P downgrades issuer rating of India's Future Retail to 'SD' amid default
summary: S&P Global Ratings downgraded India's Future Retail issuer credit rating to 'SD' due to the retail group's failure to repay principal on its onshore debt. The downgrade comes after Future Retail defaulted on its bank borrowings, which were part of a one-time restructuring plan. The company's inability to monetize its small format stores and insufficient cash flows contributed to the default.
